description:
Each sushi has its own soul. 

The role model of all sushi restaurant.

I got the koo omakase. I think it is great value at around 70 dollars. 

The highlight for me is the spoonful of happiness and the Nigiri platter. Each sushi has its new identity. There's so much beyond soy sauce and Wasabi! Truly eye opening experience!

Fish is top quality and fresh. Rice is extremely nice. There is no sloppiness here, unlike most Japanese restaurant in town. 

Must try. Cannot recommend enough.
author: Vivian Z.

description:
I have had their Omakase several times now and it is worth every dollar. They don't do set menus here (or at least in my experience) so you keep going with courses until you are full. They start off your omakase experience with the spoonful of happiness and it is the best thing ever. It's even paired with sake. During my last visit here I asked for this course twice because it's just that good. 

The chefs are very friendly and interactive. Pricing is decent for omakase. Strongly recommend, the best omakase sushi in the city!
author: Lushi Z.

description:
Very reasonably priced for the amazing quality of the sushi! We loved the "Best" role - it has a great crunch to it. The sashimi was delicious. The spoonful of happiness was amazingly delicious and creative. We also loved the yellowtail Jalapeño poppers. We finished the meal with Tempura Ice cream that I highly recommend. The service was great - they were highly attentive.

This is our new spot for the Inner Sunset! We will definitely be back
author: Erica C.

description:
Koo is a cozy neighborhood sushi spot in a quiet area. I stopped in for dinner with a friend one weekday evening and the restaurant filled up quickly. We split the veggie tempura appetizer, which was perfectly crispy and a great start to the meal. We also split a bottle of crisp and refreshing chilled sake. 

This place is known for their starter called Spoonfuls of Happiness, which the gentlemen next to us ordered and explained. We didn't end up getting it, but I definitely would try it next time. It was something really unique that I'd never seen before. I ordered the sashimi combo, with 3 pieces each maguro, hamachi, salmon, and albacore. The combo also comes with miso soup and a house salad or wakame (seaweed salad). The fish seemed very fresh and each piece was perfectly cut. Hamachi and salmon are my favorite - they're so buttery! It was a lot of food for $29 so I was happy. Service was good and we had no complaints there. If I lived in this area I would frequent this place often. I don't think I'd necessarily seek it out or drive a long way to get there, but if you're area and craving sushi give it try.
author: Katy C.

description:
First time at Koo after my friend has asked me to go a dozen times. I called last minute for a res with ease and chose to sit at the sushi bar for the omakase.

Nigiri and Sashimi Omakase - I went in thinking this would come out to around $70 but it only came out to $56.50! They calculate based off the individual piece of fish they give you. It was very worth given that I had 6 pieces of sashimi in addition to the 10 pieces of nigiri. However, I'm not a fan of their rice nor the way they made the nigiri. All the fishes were decorated with tons of sauce and I felt that overpowered the fish. One thing that stood out in particular was the Hokkaido scallop; it was the sweetest I had ever had! The other courses weren't that memorable nor special though. 

Hamachi Kama - Don't get this! It was one of the worst ones I've had...super tough and dry :( it wasn't cheap either. 

The chef was kind of awkward and didn't really converse with us at all, but at the end he split the last piece of nigiri into two pieces for us (we shared the omakase) and I thought that was super nice! 

The server gave us the wrong check originally that was almost twice as much as what we had ordered, but they corrected it after. I would say this place is cheap if you just want to try omakase, but given the price you won't get the freshest/best fish. Since it's mediocre fish for the price I'm paying, I'd prefer to go to somewhere that costs more or considerably cheaper.
author: Tina P.

description:
Based on my famous foodie friend HungryHungryHeejin's recommendations, we ended up at Koo and it was as good as advertised!

I got the Nigri omakase ($60) while my fiance got the Koo omakase ($75).  I also got a glass of hot green tea ($1) and a bottle of Oze sake ($30).

Customer service was amazing! According to my receipt, we were served by waitress Mao who was super friendly, nice, fast, and very helpful!  She was hustling all day and its really refreshing to see hard working people who seems to be enjoying their jobs!

The sushi was very good!  The quality was very nice, especially for the price!  The sushi/rice ratio was pretty good and the rice had its own unique flavor.

The ginger here is extra good, its got a nice kick to it. However, their wasabi was just ok.  I personally perfer a wasabi that has a bit more of a kick.  Their miso soup was on the bland side but that would really be my only complaint about this place.
author: Jang N.

description:
I've been hearing so much about Koo for the past few years.  And from the yelp ratings this place looks promising! Well, there is also a phrase that says promises don't come easy.   My friends and I made reservations for a Friday and were seating promptly.  This place has air conditioning, so dress comfortably. The waiter came with our drinks pretty quick and we already studied the menu the night before and already know what we were going to order.  We got the omakase,  1 was the nigiri and sashimi omakase, and the other the Koo Omakase.  We did get a few appetizers to start out.  We ordered the Hamachi Carpaccio, the Santa Barbara Uni, Hokkaido Uni and the scallops two way.  

The Hamachi Carpaccioi was ok, it was cut a little too thick, so it didn't have the melt in your mouth taste. The second thing that came out was the Spinach salad.  You had to mix it well with the sesame dressing, which i liked.  

The Spoonful of Happiness came out next.  One spoon had the uni with the egg, the other i think was hamachi.  The Uni and the egg spoon was my least favorite.  The egg was a little over powering.  You couldn't really taste the uni that well.  The other spoon had the hamachi and that was better, because you can taste the freshness.  For each spoon, they recommend you take a sip of your sake first before each bite.  I thought the sake was ok, it was a light sake to me, and was a little smooth, not as smooth as i normally like it to be.  

Next came the Santa Barbara and Hokkaido Uni.  Both of the uni's were fresh, but the Hokkaido one, won by a mile.   It was more fresh, like fresh from the sea fresh.  You can also taste the sweetness more compared to the Santa Barbara one.  I don't know what sauce they added to it, but it made it really good. 

The sashimi came out next and i was disappointed with portion of the slices.  They were really small.  The tuna didn't taste that fresh to me, i liked the scallop and the butterfish one more.  The scallop tasted super sweet, which was good. The butterfish did taste more fresh compared to the tuna. 

The Nigiri was ok,   I felt there were two out of the 7 that didn't taste as fresh.  We told the waiter in the beginning , that one of the omakase needs the wasabi omitted, but he forgot.  He also forgot our scallop two way.  We actually asked about the miso soup after our appetizers but he said it comes last.  Miso soup comes out last?  hmm, ok,  maybe it's a new modern.  He did feel bad that he forgot our scallop and the wasabi dish, so he did give us some mochi ice cream.   

Overall, i understand that some people have the off days, but we were the first customers and there wasn't any customers for a while, so i was a little disappointed with the service.  The food was ok to me, i have to say that i like Saru a lot more.  If i wanted Omakase, i would recommend Wako or Saru, sorry Koo, you ain't cool enough for me.
author: Belinda C.

description:
Got the Koo Omakase and was deliciously surprised by some really great flavors! We had reservations and was the first party seated, but we got forgotten about and didn't end up ordering until three other tables had received food first, so that was a little frustrating.

Spoonful of happiness was absolutely delicious! The spoonful with the quail egg/uni was a little too soft for me - texture wise. The spoonful that contained ankimo was my favorite! Fantastic flavors and great texture! Goma Ae-rather plain but something good to get the meal started. Consisted of asparagus and spinach balled up. Sashimi-very fresh and good variety. Miso soup-steaming hot and full of flavor! Delicious :) Nigiri-some really great flavors! I loved the pieces that had ponzu on them. Also very fresh! Added on the Hamachi Carpaccio - not the best I've had, but love ponzu sauce. Also added the lion king roll-delicious and full of flavor. Rice tasted so soft and fresh! The salmon and the snow crab was a great combo!
author: Laura S.

description:
I came here with a group of Yelp Elite friends claiming Koo as one of the best sushi spots in town. We had reservations for 5 and were immediately seated and served hot tea and water.

We mainly came for the Happy Hour menu which contains a selected number of appetizers, handrolls, and drinks for $5. I went for two handrolls --Salmon and California. Per recommendation, I also got the Spoonfuls of Happiness ($14).

To start off, we shared the Stuffed Jalapenos ($5 for 4 pieces) and Godzilla Tofu ($5 for 8 pieces). I liked that the jalapenos were stuffed with chopped hamachi and nicely roasted, which was a great starter. As for the tofu, it had good flavor on the outside, but not so much on the inside.

Now comes the star of the show at Koo: Spoonfuls of Happiness. It comes in a shot of chilled sake and two spoonfuls --one with uni and quail egg in ponzu sauce, and another with ankimo (monkfish liver) wrapped with white fish. You start with half the shot of sake followed by the lighter spoon with the uni and quail egg. Then back to the sake to finish the second spoon. This entire dish was quite the presentation and experience in itself. The flavor profiles truly balances the flavors and enhances your tastebuds --so creamy and melt in your mouth! Trust me, you can't come here without trying this.

As for the handrolls, they were quite standard. I'm not usually a big handroll fan except for Kazunori in LA, so these were decent. The fish was fresh and rice was warm and soft, but the nori was a bit chewy to bite into. It's a good item choice for happy hour though.

Overall, pretty delicious sushi here. The menu is quite reasonable in pricing and I am much more excited to come back and try their omakase. I also appreciated that the waitresses continued refilling our waters and hot tea even after we finished our meal as we continued chatting for another half an hour or so.
author: Cindy Z.

description:
While Koo has a good happy hour, and one that lasts until 7pm, I wasn't blown away by their handrolls... When they're wrapped ice cream cone style, the fish just falls out of it and it's all clumped together at the top with the rice all at the bottom. 

Other than my issues with hand rolls, their J&L roll was good, with a good fish to rice ratio. And their Spoonful of Happiness is just that - a definite must-order and one of their specialities.

As for service, very good. We paid our bill and staff were still coming around to fill our tea and waters. 

I'll have to come back for their omakase as their prices were very reasonable!
author: Mandi W.

description:
Fresh sashimi but small portions. I'd definitely recommend sharing many plates with a group so you can try everything!

If you like uni, I'd recommend the spoonful of happiness. The Koo Omasake sashimi slices are a lot smaller than that of the Sashimi 12pc Order.
author: Cheri C.

description: Made a reservation here about 3 days before hand. Walked in about 10 minutes early...no issues. I had the Koo omakase. I did like the Spoonful of happiness...but just like quite of few people, I do admit the egg was somewhat over powerful. The sushi was good quality and the size/cut were good. I sat at the sushi bar. However...the bar itself was super SUPER sticky. The service was good. Only one bathroom (ladies..be prepared..not always cleaned up) Staff was friendly.
author: Olive R.

description:
I had a lovely meal at Koo last night. I was in the city  to meet N for dinner. We decided on Koo. It was a close call because parking was a ___, but patience pays off and we found a space just a few blocks away. We ordered:

Hamachi Carpaccio- very good, but I would have preferred it to be sliced a bit thinner.
Shrimp Dumplings- delicate and sweet, a nice warm course.
Toro- this was fantastic. I will return for this.
Dragon Roll- well prepared and fresh
Tekka maki- a classic tuna roll. They make it the way it should be made. 
Hot sake- not as hot as I like.

This was nearly a 5 star visit, in addition to the minor food/drink issues, the party seated next to us was disruptive and became extremely distracting.
I really don't feel is was the fault of Koo, these things sometimes happen, but it did, however, affect our overall experience.

There are so many dishes that we missed, I plan to return soon.
author: Kris M.

description:
We came here because Ebisu was closed that day. The service is super friendly, and the atmosphere felt a bit more relaxed than Ebisu. 

The sushi was pretty fresh, but for the value I still prefer Ebisu
author: Mimi T.

description: Amazing Omakase! I would highly recommend sitting at the sushi bar which absolutely requires a reservation. Go right when they open for the best experience and make sure to buy the sushi chefs beers!
author: Kari L.

description:
The Man on the Moon enters into Koo. He sits by the sushi bar and quietly splits the pair of wooden chopsticks. He tabs them softly on his plate, making a series of individual beats. The man begins humming, linking the beats into a song...

(sing along to the tune of The Pursuit of Happiness)

Ratatat...

Dip a bit, little bit
Roll it up, 'sabi hit,
Feeling lit, tasting right
6pm, Sushi night.
I don't care, hand on the beer
Eating drunk I'm doing my thang
Sensei knife be on the deck
Feelin' himself, living his dream
Mayonnaise on the sushi roll, im screaming out - eff that
Omakase if I want
Paying ahead no turning back.
If I fall if I die
Know I ate it to the fullest
If I fall if I die 
Koo will always be the illest

I'm on the Spoonful of Happiness and I know
Uni in one bite is always gonna be goldd
I'll be fine once I hit ittt
I'll be goo-oood

Tell me what you know about shrimpin' (shrimpin)
Ama-ebi fry the head is crackin' (crackin)
Tell me what you know about them night Tako everynight
Suction cups, chewy stuff, finish that, then the Tai.
Tell me what you know about Tuna (tuna)
Tell me what you know about night Maki -tekka
Do you really care about the types of Maguro
Gonna lay awake in a bed full of Toro

I'm on the pursuit of fattiness and I know
Butterfish is good but the O-Toro is goldd 
I'll be fine once I hit ittt
I'll be goo-oood

I'm on the pursuit of happiness and I know
Koo comes with the fish then Kid Cudi is solddd
I'll be fine once I get itt
I'll be goo-oood
--
author: Ringo M.

description:
I had 2 days in the city in my  very first time visiting California and was looking for a special place to do omakase. It would've been our first experience and we chose Koo based on a recommendation from a friend and all the great yelp reviews. 

Unfortunately out experience at Koo was truly an awful one. I had emailed to RSVP in advance for omakase at the bar. We were confirmed for Saturday at 8pm. We showed up last night at 8pm and were escorted to a table. We asked the waiter why we couldn't get bar seats after being confirmed for omakase at the bar through email and she said you can do omakase at the table, everything would come out at once instead of one by one. We offered to wait until they were done and she condescendingly stated, those are frequent customers and they will be here until closing. 

We ultimately decided NOT to do omakase because we didn't want both of our first omakase experience to be at a table and not in true omakase fashion - everything would've come out at once instead of one at a time. We put our order in for other food there. By 8:30 (30 minutes later), all the people sitting at the bar left. The waiter had clearly not even asked or even bothered to try and accommodate us. She didn't even offer us the seats after they left. 

This was my first time traveling to California, and my first time in San Francisco. Also this would've been my first time doing omakase. The customer service here was terrible and stands out as the single most disappointing thing that happened during my short weekend in California. Thanks Koo, for being awful.
author: Adam N.

description:
Food: 5/5     Price: 4.5/5      Service: 5/5      Ambience: 3.5/5

The Yum: Sit at the bar! Especially during Omakase. Friendly and funny sushi chef/staff! Very fresh fish! 

The Yuck: The ambiance isn't great for date nights. 

I came here with a friend to celebrate my birthday and it was definitely one of my better experiences at a restaurant. We were thinking of sitting at a table for dinner but the waitress advised us to sit at the bar if we wanted omakase. The sushi chef also said the same thing when we sat there and during the whole dinner he happily served us and joked around a lot with us.

The dishes that really popped out to us were the spoonful of happiness, scallops, red snapper, toro, negi toro. All of the fishes were really fresh but these were the dishes that stood out the most. Our meal started with the spoonful of happiness and our palate was wowed. The combination of the ingredients of each spoon complimented one amother so well. Another dish I have to talk about are their scallops. The scallops were extremely fresh and tasted a little sweet and buttery.

Overall great experience and definitely will come back to try out their different seasonal catches. Our sushi chef also treated us a tamago nigiri which was really nice of him. I think we were pretty lucky with the customer service because they were having a slow day so we practically had that one sushi serve us the whole time.
author: Eric L.

description: Koo sushi is a great no fuss local sushi place for those nights that you want great sushi without all of the formalness of a full blown omakase meal. The fish here is great and tasty... now it won't be as good as expensive freshly flown from japan fish that you get at a $150 pp omakase but it is much better than sketchy local neighborhood joints. In addition, it is fairly reasonably priced. The spoon full of happiness is great and the sushi pieces were delicious. I had some of the rolls as well and they were good. The location is convenient for those who are close to the 9th and Irving area but parking is terrible for those who are not close to the area. Therefore, if you aren't close by, I would recommend taking an Uber or taking public transportation. Either way, if you live close to here, this is a perfect date spot :)
author: Jocelyn K.

description:
Second time here and I'm still a fan. Lost sushi bar seats because we were late by 15 minutes. So sad.

Pros:
+ Quality nigiri
+ Friendly service 
+ Deadly sake

Cons:
- None so far

Can't remember what we ordered aside from nigiri and sake, but the dinner was delicious! Our server was also really nice.
author: Fanny W.

description:
Solid 5 stars all around!

Came here to do omakase and try out this spoonful of happiness that everyone talks about. Totally worth it!!

When we first arrived, there was a mixup with the reservations. However, it was quickly resolved and that was already the first sign of great service. 

We had omakase at the bar and it was very enjoyable. Wang (Wayne?) perfectly seared our nigiri pieces and his attention to detail for presentation was well appreciated by us and even the guy next to us! (Turns out, the guy next to us comes twice a week for omakase - what a nice life!).

Every piece for omakase was so delicious. Can't wait to come back!!!
author: Cal C.

description:
Review specifically for their Omakase.

We were served by Wayne at the bar and selected the Omakase. We mentioned how much we were looking to spend and the chef accommodated that for us and would let us know when we were nearing the end (in case we wanted to order more, which we did).

Everything was absolutely delicious! The fish was fresh and the value and quality was there. They definitely 'dress up' their nigiri here instead of letting the freshness/quality of the fish speak for itself - but everything was so delicately and appropriately paired. There's also happy hour here (even the weekend!).

Would highly recommend you to check this place out.
author: Kim N.

description: Good spot all things considered and I liked the hamachi carpaccio here.   Would come back again.
author: Jeffrey H.

description:
This place is koo. Lame joke but this place is really delicious for its given price point. My boyfriend and I ordered a la cartel so we could get a feel for their dishes. 

Koo sushi roll
It's very rare that I find a complex sushi roll that I like. This one is superb. You have snow crab with tempura topped with avocado and spicy tuna. The flavors intertwine very well. It's a very basic roll but it is well put together. The roll is huge too! 

Spoonful of happiness
Two spoonful of happiness in an order of one? Yes please. On one spoon you get a super creamy uni with a quail egg and ponzu sauce. It goes down so smooth. The other spoon is ankimo (monk liver) with ponzu sauce. This is chunkier and more solid but it liquidates in your mouth. Two spoons of happiness indeed!

Hamachi Kama
I'm not too much a fan of this dish but for what it was, it was good. My boyfriend was head over heels for this dish. It was very flaky and tender. The sauce had the right touch of acidity to balance out the sweetness of the fish.

Oysters
This was meh for me also. I am a big fan of oysters but there was a lack of oyster in this. The sauces over powered the over all texture and taste of the oyster and the oyster meat was relatively small.

Uni spoon
Uni(you need) one spoon and you just fall in love. The vibrant orange color. The impact the taste has on me. I didn't think you can fall in love over and over again in a period of seconds, but I was proven wrong. I think Uni is my real true sole mate.

This place is amazing and I cannot wait to come back for Omakase!
author: Ada H.

description: This sushi is on the pricier end but you get what you pay for. Exceptional food. The hamachi carpaccio was delicious. Exquisite flavors. The sashimi was fresh and melts in your mouth. The baked mussels were a little overcooked but was still very tasty especially with that unagi sauce. I need to come back!
author: Caroline N.

description:
Four star mainly for reasonably-priced Omakase with good amount of food.  Service is attentive.  Quality is decent,  but not the best I had.  

They use tuna in a couple of their Omakase dishes (tuna is not my favorite).  The spoonful of happiness was interesting but did not wow me.  I felt the soy sauce in it overpowered the fish.  I really enjoyed the uni and scallop.  It was sweet and creamy.
author: sandy h.

description:
Spoonful of happiness.  At Koo, this is a must!  You get 2 spoons...one of ankimo, one of uni.  The flavor profiles are amazing and absolutely delicious!!!  

As far as everything else, we went ahead and ordered a bunch of nigiri and a few rolls.  Everything was fresh with great sushi rice to fish ratio.  Prices were pretty much in line with the quality you get.  

Sake and beer list is extensive and we definitely took advantage of it.  We were able to make a same day reservation by contacting the restaurant through email.  Got a confirmation in less than an hour!  Woot woot.  Service was attentive.  

Too still remains one of my favorite spots in the city.  5 stars.
author: Jen W.

description:
An amazing omakase isn't just about the food, it's the interactions with the chefs and learning more about the fish that make the overall experience amazing. 

Our omakase experience at Koo was that. Amazing food and great conversations with our chef, Yoshi, as well as the other chefs that night - Wade and Mike. Yoshi also poured out some of his beer to us since he wanted to cheers but we already finished our beers. Yoshi's a homie!

Koo's omakase is an eat-until-you're-not-hungry type. We set our initial budget, but then ended up ordering more. 
 
We started off with the Spoonfuls of Happiness which were amazing. Then we moved onto the 13 pieces of nigiri for the night. Standouts were:

- Saba: the best mackerel I've ever had in my life. Prepared in salt, sugar and kelp, then torched until the fishy smell is gone. Seriously a game changer. 

- Hokkaido scallop: straight from Japan, it was tender and amazing

- Uni: I don't usually like uni, so the fact that I loved this one means it was reallllllly good

- Kamasu/Barracuda

Overall, it was a great variety of fish and a good mix of unique preparations and more traditional nigiri. Total came out to $207 for two people with two beers and sake which is not bad considering we were stuffedddd. Highly recommend making a reservation request online as the sushi bar seating is pretty limited and an omakase is just not the same unless you're at the bar. 

Another great omakase for the books!
author: Laverne N.

description:
Food was 5/5. Price was 4/5. Wayne was 10/5. 

I always sit at the bar to try Wayne's amazing omakase. Everyone at the bar is funny and friendly. The nigiri omakase is always fresh and delicious!
author: Lauren L.

description: Really amazing food! Super fresh but not cheap. Their specials are quite pricey but the quality is really very good. I ordered 6 piece Toro sushi, (Spain, blue fin tuna fate belly). This part of the fish literally melts in your mouth. Sooooo good! I paid $45 for 6pcs. Well worth it but don't go there hangry coz their portions weren't that big. Service was a little slow.
author: Donci B.

description:
Why bother coming here if you aren't going to try the spoonful of happiness?!? 

That uni... That ankimo... That quail egg... That sake shot... I don't know how else to describe this.

We opted for the $70 omakase because, in the end, getting the HEAVENLY MUST spoons with sashimi pieces and sake will all end up being more expensive or at least the same! 

The venue is a cozy and casual spot, where you can easily catch up with friends.  The bar section is also perfect for a small birthday dinner party, which is what we witness as we arrived there that night.  Everyone was very attentive and friendly. The staff was very responsive to your reservation emails and accomodating.  I know how hard it can be to get any ressies at a popular sushi spot in the city!

Fish was super quality and couldn't ask for more in trying out a sushi spot in the city!
author: Kathy D.

description:
The best is when one requests for it and it comes personalized from the chef's heart!

Do get their omakase and make reservations because one can only sit at the limited sushi bar by making reservations.  Once there at the sushi bar, I got to interact with Chef Wayne while he presented the many distinctive nigiri of his choosing!  The talking with the Chef helped with what one was in the mood for.  

Their signature Spoonfuls of Happiness was the highlight as an opener, surely! It was served up with sake as well!  The delicacy of uni, quail egg, ponzu sauce, ankimo with whitefish and amazing truffle oil, was to savor over!

Once we were warmed up with some hot sake shots, Chef Wayne was quite a softie.  He tossed in a few tidbits, based on our conversation with him.  I got to understand the difference in texture on scallop that has been sitting in water compared to fresh scallop that hasn't been in water for the longest time. The texture was more thorough or shall I say meaty instead of soft, it's thinner in comparison and tinted in darker shade of color.

The seared Wagyu and Hokkaido uni nigiri stood out as specialities. 

Most of all, when we asked Chef Wayne to make us something that truly came from him as a form of expression to his craft, he served up what I deemed the Chef's Heart.

My ultimate favorite was just that. The difference between something ordinary and extraordinary, is just that little extra. 

I got the Chef's Heart and that made all the difference!
author: Tiffany D.

description:
My boyfriend and I came here for our Valentine's Day dinner. We had a reservation for 8:15, but had to wait half an hour before we got seated. By this time, it was 8:45 and our late dinner was made even later...

We ordered the agedashi tofu, omakase #2, and green tea tempura ice cream. The tofu was covered and deep fried with mochi, which was delightfully crisp and chewy at the same time. 

The omakase came with two sashimi dishes and 10 pieces of nigiri. We eventually realized how much food this was, because we were beginning to feel full even before we had the main dish! It was amazing that the omakase was only $60 for such high quality fish. The omakase had a great diversity of fish and flavors, for a great price.

Lastly, we ended our meal with tempura ice cream ($4)! It was a single scoop, but just enough for me and my boyfriend to add a sweet treat to our already full bellies. 

Overall, a very good meal in a restaurant with a quiet, romantic ambiance. However, -1 star for the wait on top of our reservation..
author: Christine L.

description: I loved Koo.   Very comfortable setting and amazing food.   Sarah hooked us up with recommendations.    We tried the sockeye salmon(fantastic) , halibut (yes) crab roll ( delightful) quail egg and sake (ok) seared toro (OmFG) and eel (no rice please ) and ice cream.    She understood what we wanted and came through.    Loved it !!!!
author: Saul G.

description: Enjoyed this place with my friends last night. For starters, staff was very welcoming. Seated us instantly. We arrived close to last call but the restaurant was very accommodating. Pricing was great for how amazing and fresh the food was. Such a good choice!
author: Navita S.

description: I had my uber drop me off at Koo thirty minutes before they closed on a Thursday night.  I had planned to get take out.  Someone who worked there informed me that they were closed, even though their hours of business were set to close at 10pm, according to both the internet and their placard in the window.  I could have taken the uber straight home and instead I have to schlep up mount Sutro with an excruciatingly painful plantar fasciitis injury. Forget the crawfish handroll--not good enough to go back for that bs service.  Never going back here.
author: Candice E.

description: I am having such a wonderful experience this evening... We stopped here for appetizers since we are meeting a couple of our friends later on in the night. The food is marvelous. The waiter is attentive. The ambiance is perfect and with great company, I might add. Definitely get the spoonful of happiness and ankimo for starters. We also ordered the hamachi carpaccio, hotate nigiri, and uni roll.
author: Anji W.

description:
Our experience sampling their happy Hour was FANTASTIC!  Attentive service, fair prices, a large menu, and above average quality make this a standout choice for Japanese cuisine near Golden Gate Park!

Devour (strongly recommended dishes in CAPS): 
+ Any/all of the TEMAKI/HANDROLLS ($4 each): Spicy tuna, shrimp tempura, dynamite, hamachi/maguro/or salmon & avocado.
+ All of the $5 appetizers: GOMA AE (spinach) salad, wakame salad, stuffed jalapenos, GODZILLA TOFU, MARINATED ARTICHOKE,
+ BEEF TATAKI ($15)
+ UNAGI nigiri ($6 for pair)
+ Two-way scallop ($13)
+ Spicy & sour green beans ($6)
+ Duck breast salad ($10)
+ Tempura Combo ($10)
+ 12pc Sashimi combo ($27) - nice cuts and clean flavors
+ Cheap alcohol: $4 14oz Asahi draft, $5 large saporo, kirin, house hot sake, or wine
+ DEEP FRIED ICE CREAM ($4) and big mochi covered ice cream pieces ($4 for 2)

The only downside (keeping it from 5 stars) is that they don't state anywhere that their fish is certifiably sustainably harvested.  Given the worldwide crisis of overfishing and crashing fish stocks, it's critical that customers and restaurants make efforts to ensure we are not contributing to this problem.  I hope more sushi restaurants follow the lead of Bamboo Sushi in Portland that is a worldwide leader in sustainable practices.
author: Bryan I.

description:
Wow! We sat at the counter tonight and we had omakase with a spoonful of happiness (which comes with 2 spoons and a shot of sake)! They were delicious! I'm overall so impressed with this spot. Everything was great! Koo has been around for a long time, however the owner changed when the chef opened Sushi An in Japantown. I haven't been to the old Koo, but I'm really glad we tried this place! 

The selection of fish were diverse and good quality. We even had Hokkaido uni, which a lot of places don't offer. I loved every piece of nigiri and the rice was perfect. I would prefer Koo over some of the more expensive and well known places in the city.. (ju-ni, pabu, omakase). I may love this place now more than Daigo! And I loveeee Daigo!!

They have a great selection of sakes and the service was great.
author: Joanna S.

description: Came here since a few other places we wanted to try were busy. So glad we came here. It is not as formal as expected. We sat at the bar because we wanted omakase. They start off with spoonful of happiness, it was great! I would get that again. The rest amazing, we got quite the tour of different fish. It was all delicious and we felt very taken care of. We over heard the person next to us talking about this somewhat rare beer that is served at Koo, Koshihikari Echigo. I had to have it after they talked about it and It was very much worth it. I recommend getting this one. And we left full but not in pain, which was the best thing we could have asked for. It was $100 per person for an amazing meal. Worth it in my book.
author: Alex S.

description: We were here for dinner and was highly recommended by a cooworker who loves this place, mostly for their omakase menu.  We made the reservation for 6pm but we were concerned of the parking situation, so we had to delay it to 6:30pm.  They were very accommodating to the delay. We arrived at 6:30pm and were quickly seated at the sushi bar (we specifically requested the bar table). The ambience of the place was nice with traditional decor. We were served by Chef Mike, a super friendly guy that really took good care of us that evening.  We ordered the Nigiri and Sashimi Omakase, and we added an order of shrimp nigiri and  a spicy tuna roll. The quality of the fishes and it's variety were jaw dropping. Chef Mike served us with a bowl of miso soup first, followed by a plate of mixed sashimi, then 10 Nigiri, piece by piece.  Chef Mike explained each nigiri by the type of fish and it's origin. We enjoyed the dinner and the conversation with Chef Mike, he is definitively a fun guy to talk to, and he made the evening for entertaining.  The hostess and waiters were also very nice and very responsive to request. I like it when they notice my tea cup was close to the level that require refill and they quickly refill it. I like that kinda added attention .  We will definitely come back again.
author: Wil M.

description:
Came in on a Sunday night for a treat yo-self sushi dinner. All the other $$$$ sushi places in the city were packed but luckily they were able to seat me right away here. I got the $65 Omakase (there's 3 options for the omakase between $50-$65) and an ika shiso maki roll. Parking in the area was pretty easy. It was street parking only but luckily there's plenty around (at least on a Sunday night). Service was also very attentive. The guy who served me was new so there was a bit of confusion with my order but it was sorted out. He was also very nice when I asked him for the list of the fish served in my nigiri course since I never heard of one of the fish before so he wrote out the entire thing. A+ for that!

Onto the food!
0) Ika shiso maki roll: Not part of the omakase but I knew I needed a little extra something to feel full and this was perfect. The ika was a bit tough and it could've used more shiso. Otherwise it was a good combo. Nothing amazing but a good extra something to fill me up (3.5/5)

1) Appetizer: Cucumber w/ Kinmedai: I love golden eye snapper so much and this was a great way to eat it. I would've liked a bit more acidity in the cucumber because the kinmedai had a rich char taste that could've used some acid. Also to be nit picky the cucumber slices were not very uniform. Not a huge deal since this was only a $65 omakase but Yelp is basically my food diary so I'm throwing that in. (3.5/5)
2)Sashimi Course: 2 Slices of maguro, 2 pieces of kampachi, 1 piece of hotate (cut into 2 halves): There wasn't much presentation in this dish but the quality speaks for itself. The maguro was delicious and I don't say that easily. It was meaty, clean, and light all at the same time. Kampachi was also decently fresh. It had some flavor and a good meaty bite as well. The hotate was the only disappointing piece. It didn't have as much flavor and wasn't very tender. (4/5)
3) Miso Soup: Nothing particularly noteworthy. Not a great bowl but not bad.
4) Nigiri Course: Included Isaki (Threeline Gruntfish), Kasugotai (Baby Spring Sea Bream), Umimasu (Ocean Trout), Kurodai (Black Sea Bass),  Shima Aji (Striped Jack), Toro (Blue Fin Belly), and Japanese Uni. This was a great selection of fish that transitioned very well from one piece to the next. I had never had the Isaki before and honestly it was a my least favorite but it was a good piece to start with since it was very light and firm. The kasugotai still retains the taste of sea bream but with a more tender bite. I could've used a bit more of the added ingredient but it had a sweet sour kick that was nice. The Shima Aji also had a tasty garlic ponzu? on it that I really liked. Toro was fatty and soft. Honestly better than some otoro which can be a bit much. The uni was absolutely amazing. It's been a while since I've had good Uni but this was superb. It wasn't sweet but it was pillowy and buttery. Everything else wasn't particularly special but it was all delicious. Rice wasn't too strongly flavored but had just enough to pair well with all the neta. It had a good bite to it and the nigiri itself was formed well. (4/5)
4) Spoon of Happiness: Spoon 1 is kampachi wrapped around monkfish w/ ponzu. Spoon 2 is uni w/ tobiko and uzura. They are served w/ a shot of sake for a palette cleanser. I had the kampachi first. Since the kampachi isn't very strong it went well w/ the monkfish that seemed to have a very strong smokey flavor. It almost tasted like bacon. The two together were still a bit salty but the sake helped out. The second spoon was also delicious but honestly I can't say I liked it more than just uni w/ rice & wasabi but honestly you can't go wrong w/ the uni/tobiko/uzura combination.

Overall my experience here was fantastic. It was a bit awkward to dine alone here but at least I got some great food out of it!
author: Vivian C.

description:
Yoshi is da man!! I love the guys at the sushi bar.  Server's are so kind....love them all. 

Hamachi kama
Miso(they add spinach!) So bomb!
Negi toro(2 orders)
Spoon full if happiness(brings tears to my eye's)
Goma (spinach w sesame dressing) 
Couple different sashimi orders
Large hot sake 
I don't use soy sauce they always bring me ponzu sauce w lemons
Ponzu is already citrus flavored...dip that sashimi!
author: Jennifer C.

description:
Koo was delicious! We were able to get a table for 7 by calling at 5pm on a Saturday night before they officially opened. The fish was so fresh, and their rolls were all delicious. The Spoonfuls of Happiness were 100% worth it as you can see in all the reviews. They have a list of the fresh fish they get every day, so you can tell they take the quality of their fish very seriously. 
I want to go back with a smaller group to try their omakase!
author: Margaret K.

description:
Amazing service and high quality sushi. 

When I came Koo was very packed, so you should put a reservation ahead of time. I got an assortment of nigiri and each was delicious! The toro was the standout here.
author: Steve C.

description: Expensive, costs way more than it should.  Some tasty dishes but tiny portions, disappointing. Typical hype.
author: John H.

description:
My favorite sushi spot in the city, Chief Wan is amazing! So ask for him when sitting at the bar! Also get the Gabriel spoon, nothing like good Sake and Uni to get your night started off right! 
Cheers
author: Gabriel R.

description: Honestly can't remember everything we tried here but I can remember everything was very, very good.  The rolls, sashimi, appetizers were all really great and I just was disappointed I hadn't checked out the place before after living so close for over a year!  High quality menu, nice family-owned kinda vibe, and good service.  I will be returning again..
author: Saminda W.

description:
We were intensely craving sushi after the late night Academy of Science, so we decided to give this place a try. I came here thinking we'd get mediocre sushi and leave somewhat satisfied, but DAMN, was I wrong.

Sat at the sushi bar and ordered omakase with the owner himself. He basically gave us everything I said I wanted :D Not so much omakase, but I'M DOWN! Every bite was so delicious. I think this place is highly underrated in quality. AMAZING! I honestly liked this place WAY better than other well known omakase places like Kusakabe and Zushi Puzzle, both of which were MEH to me. 

They also had the kubota manjyu which was surprising since it's one of our favorite sakes :) 

10/10 would come back for another casual omakase night. SUPER inexpensive too for omakase!!!
author: Anna M.

description: Anything but koo (cool). Staff didn't greet us when we arrived. Once we got their attention, they left us waiting for 10 mins with no help. Finally sat us then left us at the table with no service (not even water and menus) for another 10 mins. Got up and left...
author: K J.

description: I like this restaurant but it is a bit hit and miss when it comes to the food. Some of the rolls are awesome and some not so well thought out. Servers and chefs are super sweet though!
author: Lei T.

description: I used to love this place. I would have given it 4 or 5 stars before as a solid neighborhood sushi spot. Unfortunately today we went for an early dinner and initially everything was fine. I did notice the bathroom, especially the floor was not very clean and they just opened so i feel when a place lacks attention to detail that can be problematic but i thought...no worries we have been here many times before. The food was decent in flavor but not overly fresh. My husband noted it was not as fresh as it normally is. But then just when i should be asleep and about 10 mins after my husband I start feeling upset stomach followed by clear symptoms of food poisoning. This is about 6 hours after we ate at Koo. So sad because they are so friendly and it has a relaxing vibe but obviously they are slipping in quality. I hope you can turn things around but sadly we will not be back.
author: Speak F.

description:
Based on 1 visit. Hovering between 3 and 4 stars. We got (for four people):

-2 x Koo Omakase
-2 x Spoonful of happiness
-Godzilla tofu
-3 handrolls (spicy tuna + California)
-2 orders of umi masu nigiri
-Koo tataki

Overall, the fish was fresh and good quality (even the spicy tuna). The flavors of the other dishes and rice were lacking a bit of punch. The total was about $300 after tip. I would definitely come back, but at this price point it falls slightly behind on the priority queue.

It was easy to get a same-day reservation on a Sunday night. They have happy hour Sunday through Thursday until 7 p.m.: you can get a few dollars off of some appetizers, handrolls, and beer.
author: M N.

description:
I treated this as a "YOLO" night and was determined to eat a bunch of things I've never had before.  (while I was there, someone YOLO-ed too hard and lit their menu on fire)

We started with the "Spoonful of Happiness" -- fyi the quail eggs are raw...but it was a super pretty and interesting dish.  I would say the one with the quail egg in it was really mushy and to soft for my liking (honestly, it was probably a mental thing, since I knew there was a raw egg in my mouth).  All in all though, definitely worth a taste -- and honestly I actually liked it. 

Then we got the "Kumamoto Oysters On The Half Shell" -- really tasty.  Loved this dish, but keep in mind its only two -- so it's just a taste (not filling).  

We also tried the "Tuna And Salmon Tartar," which was delicious.  Its tuna and salmon tartar on avocado with shrimp chips -- it can do no wrong.  Loved it.

Then we also got the "Tempura Wakasagi Curry-salt" which was basically super salty fried fish.  I thought it was good, but my friend LOVED it and basically ate the whole thing. 

The "Dynamite" Temaki/hand roll was pretty interesting -- as I'd never had one before.  It was really good, just a little difficult to eat.  

All in all, I got to taste a bunch of new things I've never had before -- and I had a great time!  I would definitely recommend this place and I'll probably return as well.
author: Michelle S.

description: Our whole family enjoys dinner at Koo - kiddos up to grandparents. I'm a fan of the spoonfuls, the black cod, and nigiri... kiddos dive into hamachi kama, and simple rolls. We've been just 3 or a whole group of 10 (with a reservation) and had a great time every time.  Wish Koo was open for LUNCH!
author: Bret W.

description:
Omakase is quite overpriced for the quality. The spoonful of happiness is wonderful, and they deserve credit for it, but outside of that the sushi was very average. For a bill that comes to almost $100 per person after tax and tip, I'd expect high quality pieces. The most significant issue was their rice is cold and normal. No matter how nice and delicate your cuts of fish are, when you hit cold and what feels like older rice (by its temperature and hardness) it becomes too difficult to focus on anything else.

When you take the issues described above and start to look around the restaurant and see crumpled, laminated menus and worn out decor it seems to fit a story that perhaps this place once served great food but no longer is putting in the effort.

I only had their most expensive omakase, perhaps their other food is good.
author: Jared G.

description: Came here given the good yelp reviews. Was a bit disappointed by the quality of the fish. For the price, would have a much better meal at the likes of wako, ijji, Kinjo.
author: Lu C.

description: I made a reservation for Omakase, and when I got there, they didn't give me the Omakase menu until I asked. It's super crowded and so much noise. Too many children screaming( kids can feel the noise but not to know how to tell). I waited 20 minutes for the first dish, another 10 minutes for sashimi, and 30minutes for for sushi. The fish is ok, the sushi rice is horrible. I won't come back because of their poor quality. We spent $235 for this? What a joke? It's completely over priced. This place should lower their price or remodel to a better environment. Thanks.
author: Momo W.

description:
As of 2017, THIS IS MY FAVE JAPANESE RESTAURANT (in SF). 
After a semi-fun and really windy day at Golden Gate Park, we decided to get dinner nearby instead of going back to downtown. After all, I feel that the food in the sunset and richmond area is way better and less pricey. We felt like getting sushi and Koo was recommended on several websites. So, from GG Park, we walked over. 
Full disclosure here, we got here exactly when it opened (5:30 PM?) so our service was quite prompt (5 star service here!). We were the only people for like 5-10 minutes so the waitress gave us all her attention and described a lot of the dishes/fish of the day for us. 
We got TWO spoons of happiness because its so good, you shouldn't share. AT ALL. They're beginners and comes with a shot of sake that you can drink between each spoon to clear the flavor. Best deal-$15 for some amazing uni and fish PLUS a shot of sake that would probably be like $5/shot at any other japanese restaurant. R loved it. And then, after we finished the spoons, our entire order came out. Nicely timed. We got some salmon, toro, hamachi, and a few other fishes. SO GOOD. Although R said next time we come, we should just order 3 of the toro and the salmon. The final bill wasn't as high as other Michelin star restaurants but we loved it all the same (or more!) because I love a worthwhile meal and this was very much a worthwhile meal. The restaurant gets packed, FAST. I'm so glad we came here when it opened and had such a great meal.
author: Michelle R.

description:
After seeing the high ratings on Yelp and reading through the reviews, I had such high expectations. I was not very impressed, or maybe the reviews just hyped it up too much for me. 

We were able to get reservations the day of for 8:30 p.m. since we were driving back to the city. When we arrived, the place was more on the emptier side. Since we came later, a lot of the nigiri we wanted to order was already out. The server was extremely apologetic and was nice enough to go back and forth from our table and the bar to ask what was still available. 

When we got our nigiri, it was all plated on a round plate. I didn't find the nigiri to be anything special, but maybe it was because they had already ran out a lot of fish that night. I felt the pieces of fish were a bit too big and just not...elegant? I'm sorry for the lack of better word. The Spoon Full of Happiness was good though!

Overall, very underwhelming experience and most likely will not be returning.
author: Doris K.

description: Delicious. Loved the spoonful of happiness, the sake collection, and all the rolls. My favorite was the Best Roll.
author: Meaghan H.

description:
I was blown away by the quality of the service and seafood at this restaurant. I'm already counting down the days til my next trip to San Francisco, so I can make a much needed stop here!

First off, if you can make a reservation at the sushi bar, do so. There are only around 7-8 seats in this area. Our entire dining experience was transformed by this seating arrangement, as we got to converse with and learn from our sushi chef, and laugh with the couple next to us. Put your trust in the wonderful and talented chefs in front of you and get the omakase - you won't regret it.

We started off with the spoonfuls of happiness, which yes are as beautiful as the pictures and I could rave on and on about just like everyone else here. Just do it, you won't regret it. Even myself who isn't the biggest fan of uni would order this again and again. The oysters were spectacular, and every nigiri set in front of us was melt in your mouth  delicious. I was so caught up in the presentation and experience of each beautiful piece, that I completely forgot to take pictures!! Getting the omakase introduced us to fish we'd never even heard of, presented in the most elegant way with no additional seasoning necessary. One highlight was a beautiful salmon toro nigiri, with the orange sashimi sliced pieces shaped into a rose and topped with the bright yellow yolk of a quail egg. I'm drooling again just thinking about it! (And again, apologies for forgetting the pictures!!)

We spent about 2 hours at the restaurant, and probably could've stayed longer if we could have fit any more food in our bellies. I have found my new favorite sushi place in San Francisco, until next time Koo!!
author: Lian M.

description: Excellent. Traditional. Real sushi. Take a date here. Celebrate your raise. Enjoy eating a sushi meal
author: Vanessa R.

description:
Had dinner here a week ago and was in heaven with every bite.  The spoonful of happiness was exactly that.. Perfectly named.. Perfect bites.  The Hamachi tar tar was also incredible.  Throughout the meal, each bite of food was amazing.  Not to be missed are the descriptions of the sake, "clean and elegant". 

The location is unassuming tucked into mostly residential and nothing super fancy.  Staff was friendly.
author: Rick B.

description:
+/- THE FOOD
My boyfriend and I stumbled upon this place randomly on a Sunday night and decided to give their omakase a try. Although there were no none in line and visibly many empty tables, we still ended up waiting 15 minutes. Their omakase was an 8-piece nigiri set with miso soup and choice of seaweed salad or house salad. For $65, I felt that the omakase was a little skimpier and didn't really have a lot of different things that were impressive. The 8-piece nigiri set came all at once, another 30 minutes after we had ordered. I was a little disappointed that there was a lot of sushi rice to the amount of fish. The fish was fresh and tasty but it wasn't out of the world. If I were to come back again, I might chose a different omakase set that has more options.
author: Cindy C.

description:
The spoonful of happiness. Go try it yourself. They do make you happy. They always made ME happy!
I moved from SF to OC a few years ago,and every time I visit SF now I have to get my spoonful of happiness. It's so delicious that it is beyond words. You have to try it to believe it.
The other items on the menu are good, but overpriced from my book. I often get the spoonful of happiness as a happy hour item and then go for dinner later.
author: Natalie L.

description:
Koo, I've been looking for you- solid sushi restaurant in Sf.

If you're looking for authentic, delicious, and fresh nigiri and sashimi, this will be your jam! Koo is pretty solid, like I said. 

Came here with a coworker a couple days ago and we started off with pretty every nigiri they had on the menu. Yum! The toro and barracuda were my favorite. Piece after piece we thanked the chef that kept filling our plates and ate to our hearts content. The spoonful of happiness was delish!

I bet the omakase here is awesome! Next time.

On a side note, the other items were ordered were stuffed jalapeno, shrimp dumplings, and Tokyo crunch which were not as good as the fresh fish and wasn't a huge fan of.

I'll be back sometime, probably!
author: Shereen A.

description:
Koo is pricey, yet so delicious that my husband and I went about 4x/year, because that's how great it is.  The servers are attentive and cheerful, the fish is fresh, the rice is cooked perfectly, and the chefs should be proud.  

If you're in a small group, being at the bar is fun.  You can just ask for anything, or request a surprise.  If you're in a large group, they'll accommodate you in the larger part of the restaurant.  Either way, it's a great space with incredible food, and they have gluten-free soy sauce (tamari) if you need it.  

We're already missing this place, even though we just moved out of SF.
author: Valerie T.

description: Came here on a Tuesday night and had a great omakase experience. On a weekday night, there's no wait for tables but a slight wait for the bar. The chefs are laid back and friendly, and the food was of course delicious. The amount of food in the omakase was slightly less than average in my opinion, so plan to spend a little more than the course itself.
author: Amee L.

description: The food is ok~ but ppl there made a loud noise! can't say it is cozy and nice restaurant ~
author: Vivienne H.

description:
So amazing!

I went in for the omekase yesterday and it's one of the best omekases (and one of the best meals, period) I've ever had outside of Japan. Like everyone said, the spoonful of happiness is absolutely amazing. The great thing about this omekase is that the chef really tries to combine different tastes -- for example, a sprinkle of lemon peel, or a dash of green onion -- to create mouth-watering concoctions. Other omekases I've had were just...some raw fish on a bite of rice. The omekase at Koo actually felt personal. And the chef was really great at making things for us that weren't on the menu after asking what types of fish/seafood we liked.

Unfortunately I don't have the memory to tell you what exactly I had, but everything was delectable.
author: Jennifer J.

description:
This used to be our favorite neighborhood sushi place - after moving out of the neighborhood, we would even come back to dine here. Today, I took an out-of-state colleague of mine here to impress her with good quality sushi, but unfortunately this place is not what it used to be. I used to live in Japan for 10 years and have experienced a lot of sushi places (including Sukiyabashi Jiro), and have tried a lot here in the US. I think they are under new management and the staff is certainly new (I remember the old staff used to speak Japanese). The sushi we ordered was still okay, but my problem is with the service and the lack of understanding of what and how they are serving. We were asking for umeshu (plum liqueur) and first, the chef at the counter did not understand what I was asking. When I switched from ordering in Japanese to English, he still gave me the look. Then he told me the server takes the drink orders (he could have just let our server know - the place was not busy at all). Then the server said they don't have such drink. I could not believe, so we opened the menu, and there it was - umeshu or plum liqueur.
While the place was almost empty (this place used to be always full), the counter was full (six seats), and the three chefs serving the guests started to drink beer. This would be no problem in a bar for sure, but quite unusual in a sushi place. Then, when I asked for a pinch of salt for the tempura we ordered, the chef gave me the surprised look again, like I was ordering something that does not match with tempura. In Japan, it's common practice to either serve salt with the tempura, or certainly provide it upon request. 
Then the chef dropped another client's order slip and a pen on my wooden plate (that holds the sushi). It happens, no problem. However, he did not even bother to apologize, then after laughing and picking it up he did not change nor offer me a new plate.
Perhaps he was a bit drunk - after all, they were having a party there with the other chefs.
But the most surprising thing was that when our chef rolled the sushi, he put a plastic food wrap between the sushi and the bamboo rice paddle and then left the plastic wrap on the roll when cutting the roll up. It does not seem to be a big deal, but it is like having a table cloth in a restaurant covered up with a piece of paper so they don't have to change the table cloth after each guest. The bamboo rice paddle can be / should be washed after rolling a messier roll. They certainly use the plastic wrap so that they don't have to bother washing it / cleaning it / wiping it each time. Also, small pieces of the plastic wrap could end up in the roll. Also, I have never seen this in Japan.
I am sorry to be so picky, but sushi making is certainly ALL about the details. And it is ALL about service when you are sitting at the counter, watching the chefs working. And this place is slipping... If this was a $ place, with half the prices, I would overlook such details. While this place is certainly not high end, the prices they charge would command for better focus on details.
Food quality: 3.5/5
Preparation technique: 2/5
Service: 2/5
Value for the price: 3/5
author: G N.

description: This used to be my favorite place for omakase but unfortunately this past weekend will be my last. I made reservations to sit at the bar and when we arrived on time, they said they gave up our bar seats based on a "miscommunication." However, no one called to notify us prior and we drove all the way from the South Bay. We decided to sit at the dining area but it wasn't the same as we had to pick a prix fixe omakase option and the quality of the fish wasn't as fresh as the past couple of times we went. The total bill for two people was $300 and they didn't even comp us for the inconvenience :(
author: P S.

description:
The spoonful of happiness is one of the best dishes I've had anywhere!  The baked scallop roll was very well balanced and a unique take on a usually sloppy dish.  Not too much mayo, real crab, and large scallops instead of bay scallops.  Really tasty!

The nigiri sushi was all very fresh and fantastic quality, but the wasabi was a little overpowering, and the scallop and albacore could have used a little lemon.  If they brought the same flavor balance to the nigiri as they do with the spoonful of happiness, it would be out of this world.

The uni was hands down the best I've have.  Melts in your mouth and great flavor.
author: Doron K.

description: Awesome place to have omakase! Make sure you sit by the bar because that's where you'll get your best omakase experience. Visiting from NY, we have as much sushi places as we want to choose from. This sushi bar, is one hell of an experience! Every piece was fresh and the price? It's CHEAP! Being able to have omakase with the amount of pieces they provide you with is a blessing for that price. The sushi chef, would probably own a Michelin star sushi bar in NY if he was there.. The service was great as well.
author: Dennis K.

description: The Omakase is everything and the sushi chefs and staff are most hospitable and inviting. Will be my new go to for sushi in San Fran.
author: Dee K.

description:
I suggest trying out Koo only if you have some appreciation of izakaya style cuisine. I came here a few years ago and it was naïve and cynical because I was frustrated at all small portions, overpricedness, and general fuss and frills of fine dining--3 stars. Then I came back for happy hour after living in SF for a few years and becoming accustomed to/spoiled by all the good food so I was finally able to pick up on some of the subtleties instead of complaining about paying so much and still being hungry--4 stars. Maybe one day I will be a professional diner and be able to taste things at Koo that normal people can't detect, and I will give 5 stars.

[THE SIGNATURE]

A Spoonful of Happiness (a spoonful of uni, quail egg, tobiko ponzu & a spoonful of ankimo wrapped with whitefish, white truffle-oil ponzu & a shot of chilled sake):This is the highlight of many reviews and after seeing all the pretty photos you feel inclined to order it because it looks so photogenic. I'm not even a fan of sea urchin or monkfish liver or truffle oil (too fancy for me) and $13 is expensive but includes alcohol. So I decided to be adventurous and deviated from my friends' orders. The conversation went like this: 

Friends order appetizers and drinks.
Me: Can I get the Spoonful of Happiness?
Server: Just one order?
Me: Yes, I'll be happy by myself...!

Although my palate is not culinarily cultured to all these exotic ingredients (raw quail egg made me squirm a little), I did enjoy the unique flavors and complex layers. The sake definitely made it tastier; if a spoonful of sugar makes the medicine go down, a shotful of sake makes the spoonfuls go down. It's among the craftiest things I've ever eaten--spoonfuls of happiness indeed. (And, of course, I maximized my $13 by essentially taking multiple 360-degree panoramic shots of my spoons)

[THE HAPPY HOUR]

Godzilla Tofu (crispy tofu with spicy garlic miso): Surprisingly tasty for tofu! The crispy exterior is nicely balanced by a soft silky interior. While I liked the simplicity, I think it could be even better with a ponzu dipping sauce of sorts.

Stuffed Jalapeno (with hamachi, with lime aioli): Before you get scared by the jalapeno pepper, let me tell you this is not spicy at all (nor is most Japanese food). Decent appetizer especially if you like strong, bold flavors.

[THE KITCHEN]

Miso Marinated Black Cod (served with dashi branched baby bok choy and fried tofu): Pricey, but the cod melts in your mouth! 

Flying Kamikaze (spicy tuna and asparagus wrapped with albacore and topped with garlic ponzu and scallions): For once, gimmicky toppings are a nice addition to the sushi roll and not just used to mask funky fish--the sashimi quality is good, and overall it's tasty (this is one of their more popular rolls).

[THE VERDICT]

I browsed around their website and read up on the chef and the restaurant name: Koo is a masculine, informal way of saying eat (I guess it's somewhat the Japanese equivalent of omnomnom except less cutesy). In my opinion it's quite the opposite because it's dainty and the portions are too small to be something that guys would be happy with. 

Koo is a level up from the rest of the Inner Sunset in terms of food and ambiance fanciness, but the price is also leveled up accordingly. Worth a try if you think spoonfuls and happiness and the like will make you happy!
author: Edna C.

description:
Sushi delivery is the best.

There is something so satisfying about eating carefully crafted rolls while being makeup free, donning old sweats, and listening to Van Morrison in the comfort of your own kitchen.

It's just the best.

Koo is my new favorite Japanese/sushi spot as of late. Their rolls are insanely fresh and the quality of the fish is wonderful. 

Koo has been serving authentic sushi in the Inner Sunset since 2004 and you can taste it in their entire menu. Some of their most popular and acclaimed dishes are their Spoonful of Happiness, their Salmon and Tuna Tartar, their Miso Black Cod, and their Azteca Roll.  If you still have room for dessert - their Mt Fuji - a freshly made chocolate cake stuffed with chocolate mousse and paired with either ginger or green tea gelato is a worthwhile indulgent treat.

My usual delivery order here is the California Roll and the Dragon Roll. Normally I steer clear of California Rolls - since it's often imitation crab - but not at Koo. Their crab is real and absolutely divine. Their Dragon Roll is plump with lightly battered tempura shrimp and I appreciate that it's topped with heavy handed portions of eel. Swoon.

If you're looking for a fantastic dinner - come to Koo. It's truly an Inner Sunset neighborhood gem. Or better yet - do like me - rinse off the day's grime from your face, throw on something comfortable, put on some sweet tunes, and then let it come to you.

Trust.
author: Jessica T.

description:
Hidden gem in the Sunset! Delicious and reasonably priced sushi, from authentic chefs. Great service and, as far as I could see on their menu, great Happy Hour deals!

Loved their special rolls and will definitely be back.
author: Andreea C.

description:
Food is decent but yet overpriced. I came in with a group of 5 and the bill is $400 including tip with 1 beer and 3 house sake. The taste is so so, I had a very small piece of UNI from Santa Barbara in my nigiri which was a bit frustrating. There's a lot of people here. I do believe it's just me being picky because I love Japanese food so much and has been spoiled with the price and quality from AMAMI San Bruno.

Place is packed on a Thursday night, warm lights, a bit warm inside and a little slow on service. Ambiance is good with Japanese decor to have the Japanese feeling.

Parking is terrible, pretty safe neighborhood.

Okay experience overall but I would not recommend to Japanese food connoisseur.
author: Sherry C.

description: Great restaurant!  The service was excellent and friendly, the selection of food was varied, the quality was top notch.  Unfortunately the meal was so enjoyable that I forgot to take photos or grab the names of dishes. But I'll be going back and will rectify that mistake
author: Brian H.

description: Cant say enough good about this place. We shared 4 sushi rolls, sashimi, miso soup, and octopus dish. Everything is good! The fish is very high quality.
author: Kim O.

description:
If you come here for sushi, you need to get omakase from Wayne! He was amazing! He would get to know you well and make sure you get what you come for! He will explain how he made each piece ( instead of just telling you the name and ingredients). For the price, it was unbeatable! 

We started off with two spoons of really delicious appetizers. I usually hate quail egg but the spoon with quail egg was unexpectedly superb. Don't forget to glean your taste buds with sake shot (provided) afterwards! Then, we get 10 pieces of assorted sushi with fresh and fancy fish ( not just salmon/tuna/yellowtail). I always rate sushi based on the quality of fish and this place offers higher quality fish than most sushi establishment of the same price range. 

It was an amazing and affordable experience and I will definitely come back here again!
author: Caroline S.

description:
Came here with my bf for my bday. We got:

Spoon Full of Happiness: yes! It comes with a sake
Beef Tataki : This is not worth getting, very dry, wasn't that tasty. 
Rolls (Koo Roll, UCSF Roll): Loved the rolls, must gets
Nigiri (Kurodai, Shima ji Japan, Iwana): Love the fresh fish, super tasty, melts in your mouth

The owner there was so sweet and surprised me with a sweet green tea ice cream with candles for my birthday and sang for me. Great service. Location isn't too big. I usually don't like unni that much but this place was pretty good. I liked that they give you a shot of sake to sip eat sip eat sip.
author: Amy Y.

description:
I held an engagement dinner between the two families, which met for the first time. 

I arrived early and was able to choose where the party of 10 would sit. The restaurant is a good size, not too big or small.  You get the feeling the service will be very professional, which is was.

We ordered the $65 Omakase, which comes with the Spoonful of Happiness. First off, it's a great deal. Second, it's two spoonfuls. I've never had monkfish liver and was pleasantly surprised. The sake paired with the dish was smooth as well. 

The sashimi and nigiri courses were fresh. The nigiri course was surprisingly broad in the flavor profiles. Great selection. 

I was just overall pleased with out seamless the dinner went. The transition in courses was smooth so it really helped the dinner/meeting of families go well. I will be back again, next time to sit at the sushi bar.
author: Patrick M.

description:
Make sure you make reservations as this place isn't very big. 

I took my friend here for her birthday and we got the omakase courses for $56pp. Came with miso soup, an okra salad, a spoonful of happiness, 6 pieces of sashimi (maguro, harami and another fish) and 7 pieces of nigiri. 

The things that stood out to me were the spoonfuls of happiness (bursting with with different flavors and indeed made me extremely happy!), the harami (super soft, melts in your mouth), Hokkaido uni (so good, worth whatever you gotta pay to try it, and the bluefin toro (also melts in your mouth).

Other than that, my friend and I weren't a fan of all the other foods and fishes. It would have probably been better for us to put in individual orders of nigiri as the ones the chef gave us were a bunch of the fishes that don't seem as popular and weren't very soft. 

The Mount Fuji dessert with green tea ice cream was also delicious. Service was on par.

Didn't feel like it was quite worth a $160 meal. If I ever come back, I'll probably just order nigiri and the spoonfuls of happiness. Definitely glad I got to try this place though!
author: Susan M.

description: Great place. The food is delicious, drinks are well made, and decor is great. Just be conscious of the fact that it can get a bit expensive.
author: Aisha F.

description:
This place was busy when I went. The staff confirmed my reservations the day of at around 4pm by calling me. I found them all to be very pleasant.

This place reminds me of a small, fairly packed manhattan restaurant. It's pretty brightly lit, with lots of doubles tables side by side. There's a sushi bar too if you wanna have a bit of fun.

Prices are good. ~10 dollars (but remember to include tax and tip!) for 4 pieces of yellowtail, tuna, albacore, or salmon, all of which I tried. Very nice textures and cuts.

Non-sashimi items were good. The agedashi tofu and a few rolls put us way over the top.

Finally, there was a bottle of sake. I got one for 60 dollars, something that was semi-dry. It was large, must have been 750ml, and as the patrons filed out I found myself pouring a shot or two for the staff ;)

All in I was looking at a little over 160 on the bill. After tip I put it at 200 flat, or 100 per person.

Overall, an excellent spot for a date.
author: Christophe C.

description:
I adore Koo!

Back in April of 2012, I dragged the roommate here since I was craving sushi. We came after he picked me up from work, so luckily, we made it for happy hour! We ordered from both the HH and regular menu

Happy hour:
*Temaki Handrolls: Spicy tuna (spicy tuna, cucumber and lettuce) & Hamachi and avocado
*Wakame Salad: japanese seaweed salad
*Stuffed Jalapeno: with hamachi, with lime aioli

Regular menu:
*Kumamoto Oysters on the half shell 2pc: served with spicy Daikon radish, green onion and ponzu sauce
Beef Tataki: chilled, sliced shoulder tender loin with apple-ginger soy
*A Spoonful of Happiness: spoonful of uni, quail egg, tobiko ponzu & spoonful of ankimo, wrapped with whitefish, truffle-oil ponzu & a shot of chilled sake
*Hamachi Kama: broiled hamachi with ponzu and grated daikon radish
*Flying Kamikaze Roll: spicy tuna and asparagus wrapped w/albacore and topped with garlic ponzu and scallions
*Nigiri: Hamachi (yellowtail) & Amaebi (sweet shrimp w/fried head)

Spoonfuls of happiness? How can I say no to that?! Most definitely, my favorite item! I love uni and ankimo so each spoonful was like heaven! The uni and quail egg went so well with the ponzu. And the ankimo with a truffle oil ponzu? Yum! Just writing about this makes me want to go there now! Delicious!

Parking can be difficult at times in this area, but we got there around 6pm so finding parking wasn't too bad at that time.

It's been a while since I've been to Koo. I think I'm long overdue for a return visit! Spoonfuls of happiness, get in my mouth!
author: Elena N.

description:
Had dinner on Wednesday night at Koo at 7 pm. I was told that Parking was going to be terrible and it was. I circled a 6 block area for about 20 minutes until I found some leaving. The restaurant was half empty probably because they were looking for a place to park. Koo offers 3 levels of Omakase, $50 level with just Sushi and Sashimi. The $60 level includes appetizer and the spoonfuls of happiness. Then $70 level with tastes from the Kitchen along with the items on the $60 level. We ordered the $70. For the extra ten dollars you get two small grilled pieces of egg plant, 1 small wrap of mango and fish, and a small portion of Japanese pickled veggies. So not worth the extra $10. 

The sushi, sashimi, and the spoonfuls of happiness were excellent. 7 pcs of sushi and 6 pcs of sashimi. Service was good. Reservations were easy. However, I wouldn't roll the dice and try my luck for the night time parking situation at Koo again. Unless there is Valet parking, a trek from the East Bay is an issue.
author: George F.

description: One of the best sushi restaurants in SF. Very reasonable price as well. Chef Wayne is amazing.
author: Joe B.

description: Solid sushi place but also not mind blowing, I think you could get better quality for the price. Seating is crowded and it does get pretty loud (compared to other Japanese restaurants in the neighborhood) recommend the spoons
author: Jessica S.

description:
Honestly I'd say 3.4 stars ....

I liked everything I had here ok.
-sashimi combo
-tekka
-spoon full of happiness
-tokyo crunch roll
- medium fatty tuna
-sakuramasu
-uni

I had high expectations. I thought they were good but nothing exceptinal... 

If I was just looking for decent sushi for lower price, I'd just go to sakesan bistro nearby. 

I'd go back but prob not for a while.
author: C M.

description:
This is the third time I've been here and I will definitely come back here again! I love the ambiance and the service has always been spectacular. I took my mother here for her birthday last week and we ordered the classic "Spoonful of Happiness" and she loved it. My mother continually commented on how soft and tender the fish was here and that she would definitely recommend this place to her friends.

We also ordered the Sashimi Combo (12 pcs. - Maguro, Hamachi, Salmon & Albacore, 3pcs each) that came with Goma Ae (their spinach salad), as well as 2 sushi without rice (salmon roe and one other I forget now), and another 3 or 4 with rice (spicy tuna specialty roll, unagi, and a couple others). For another appetizer, we also ordered soft shell crawfish and that was delicious!

The waiter was very kind to us and even gave my mother a birthday dessert which consisted of two mochis (one strawberry and one mango) along with two cookies. I couldn't find it on the menu but that dessert was incredibly yummy! And, of course, the dessert came with a candle!

All in all, this place is great! A tad on the pricier side but if you're looking for a nice date place or a "special" occasion, this is it. In fact, there was also another lady there celebrating her birthday ON that day as well (as was my mother). I took off a star because I'm leaving room for the best of the best. And parking is not the greatest. My bill was about $110 withOUT any alcohol (except the sake that came with the Spoonful of Happiness - $13). We were both definitely satisfied after our meal.
author: Curtis C.

description: I personally don't really favor the tasting spoon.. but the Omakase meal is good, with approximately 80 dollars per person I believe. Worth a try!
author: Annabelle L.

description:
ordered from the catch of the day menu and added a miso soup and came out to be $90. it was a little unpleasant dinning when I am constantly swapping the fly away from landing on my food. I had to eat the sushi quick. I don't know why there is a fly in there and I can't imagine where this fly goes....

The miso soup was too salty. It had spinach, tofu, and seaweed in it. need to cut down on the salt and I love salty food. 

the chef can spruce up his skills on plating. presentation helps and shows the care of what you're putting out to the customers. it took a bit for the sushi to come out but I didn't mind. it was a Friday night around 6pm and plenty of table open. All the sushi tasted average in terms of freshness. nothing wow'd me. Wished it was colder. 

Green tea is not for free. They charge $1. I got 3 refill. tea is a bit weak. 

I can't say I would patron here again. I have been here many times and finally got around to writing a review for this place.  

After paying with credit card, the staff came over before I signed it to pick it up. I had to tell her I didn't sign it yet. it is like they are rushing me. I wanted to finish my tea before leaving. after 5 mins and I finally signed it, the same lady came over and picked it up. I don't understand the rush. it is not like you're closing your register. it wouldn't hurt to wait till the customer leaves before clearing the table and picking up the check. that irked me a little.
