author: Jules L.

description:
3.5 stars. the 0.5 extra star is for....

three words: SPOONFUL OF HAPPINESS!
highly rated dish - am almost 100% certain this is the best item on their menu (but i haven't tried everything to say for sure just yet). if i could go back and redo this meal, i would order about 5 of these and a large carafe of hot sake and call it a night. it's so good, i almost gave koo 5 stars based solely off this dish - almost.

what makes me hesitate is the rest of their menu. their sushi selections of the day were very solid and are the way to go if you're a fan of sashimi/nigiri. however, the rest of their menu leaves a lot to be desired. the rolls weren't particularly inspired, and even their regular menu nigiri would be considered average at best.

we ordered some other small plates - wakame salad and agedashi tofu - that turned out to be pretty good. but our total bill came out to almost $130 for two people before tip. and at that price point, i feel like i'd rather be somewhere with better sushi. wouldn't you?
author: Yiwen S.

description:
On the hunt for great sushi and I don't regret trying Koo but don't think the visits will stick.

Get me another +'s:
+ Spoonfuls of Happiness. They were DAMN GOOD mouthfuls of HAPPY. The journey with first a sip of sake. Next down spoonful of white fish with truffle oil. Sip sake. Down the spoon of uni and raw quail egg. Savor. Finish sake. It's $13 and bit pricey but I don't regret it.
+ Rolls were decent. Got the standard spicy tuna and the Crunchy Roll which had great texture with each bite.
+ Saturday night wait was just 20'

Going to pass -'s:
- Green tea is not complimentary. It's $1 per patron. Geez.
- The fresh catches of the day just weren't up to par. We had barracuda and halibut. It was not memorable and the slices were somewhat stingy at $7 for two pieces of nigiri sushi.
- Took a while for us to order. Think they were short on staff.

TIP: You may not like uni but the Spoonful of Happiness will make you forget the funny snot like texture. The wonderful mixture and balance disrupts any fear you have of uni or raw eggs. It's that good.
author: Yiven C.

description:
I don't know which had more variety - the food or the clientele.

Check out what I ate:

(^_^) Tokyo Crunch Roll (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/koo-san-francisco?select=VTEfOc2XAi_Cbi-gE9puKw)
(^_^) Azteca Roll (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/koo-san-francisco?select=F4zagHC6hBRNGTySmJAmCA)
(^_^) Barracuda (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/koo-san-francisco?select=esMPEJLwHJXiEU3z_-RSUA)
(^_^) Unsweetened Iced Tea (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/koo-san-francisco?select=BgVr9vjMxFQ5A50XJKhjCQ)
(-_-) Soft Shell Crawfish (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/koo-san-francisco?select=6rkVlpR7ltjLo0--Eavyjw)
(-_-) Sea Bream (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/koo-san-francisco?select=fJkKtvXbrnx1LslnFucbpA)
(v_v) Crab Leg (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/koo-san-francisco?select=kR1b-avUnzqeHB0aDCecjA)

But check out who I saw:

(9_9) Salaryman
(-_-) Nearly-Stood-Up Woman
(-_-) Collegiate Hoodie Grampas
(-_-) Fedex Delivery BF
(-_-) Sweatsuit White Couple
(#_#) Plaid Shirt x Dunks Late Date
(#_#) Loud Sports Asian Twinsies
author: Dan B.

description:
Been meaning to try this place many times Two of us and we ordered:

Spoon Full of Happiness = As the name says it is tasty, definitely get it! You also get a side of sake. I normally don't like sake but this sake was great.
Beef Tataki = I wouldn't suggest ordering it, it was dry
Rolls (Koo Roll, UCSF Roll): they were on point, get them.
Nigiri (Kurodai, Shima ji Japan, Iwana): Apparently they're known for these. The kurodai so was really good. 

The service was great and friendly!

Parking was a bit hard to find, we had to circle for a while before we parked up the hill.

would come back again!
author: Derrick C.

description: Called for reservations on friday about 1 hr before hand and was able to sneak one in for 6:15. We decided to go straight for the Omakase @$71 which included: miso soup, cucumber salad, a spoonful of happiness, 6 pieces of sashimi and 7 pieces of nigiri. Spoonful of happiness was great which included a glass of sake. Fish was very fresh, good quality and most of fish are from japan. BTW it did get crowded midway during our dinner so make your reservations.
author: Eddy C.

description:
I came to Koo because my favorite Japanese restaurant (coincidentally only a few blocks away) had way too long of a line and I needed to satisfy my sushi kick ASAP. I had high expectations after perusing the reviews on Yelp and decided to give this place a try. 

Chalk it up to not ordering the "right" dishes (aka I did not order the spoonful of happiness), but my meal was average at best. I ordered the spicy salmon and the flying kamikaze rolls.

While they weren't bad, they weren't spectacular either. Something about the sushi rice was a bit too sticky in consistency and borderline mushy. And the dried seaweed was tougher and chewy as well. 

That being said, the quality of the fish wasn't half bad at all and had I ordered something like the sashimi, I could see this having higher reviews. That being said, the rolls didn't live up to my expectations, and while I'm open to trying Koo again, I doubt I'll be having the rolls
author: Jay P.

description: A little on the pricey side, but super delicious specialty rolls! I recommend asking your waiter for the most popular rolls and going with those, they are great!
author: Tara N.

description:
I have a soft spot when it comes to Koo. It's an Inner Sunset neighborhood joint, and the fish there is always fresh and tasty. I stick to my favorites: sake, maguro, hamachi, ika, ikura, and sometimes uni. Their fresh fish is always changing (the Chu Toro and Artic Char are my two favorites), so I love experimenting and ordering from that menu. Their Ika Shiso Maki is really good if you like Ika/Shiso - so simple and delicious. 

Their spoonful of happiness is so incredibly delicious, but pricey! They tell you to have one spoon, the sake that come with it, then the other spoon - my piece of advice is to switch the spoons, the second ones slightly disappoints, so save the best (first spoon) for last!

The ambiance is comfortable and casual. The sushi bar is fun, and the usual three sushi chefs are always in their usual spots, which makes it nice for a regular. Usually when I go in I spend around $40-50/person, but the experience is so nice it's worth it!
author: S O.

description: Very average for SF. Nothing special. The spoons were tasty, but I've had similar ones with more of a kick. The nigiri wasn't very specially flavored, so I used a bit of soy sauce and wasabi. I expect to use less at a $$$ joint. The food, except the miso soups, arrived all together, so the wait was long. I would've appreciated receiving one or two nigiri servings at a time, with description of what the fish was because that's the service expectation at $$$.
author: Paulina F.

description:
Last time I came here was over 3 years ago. Thought I would come back and give it another chance. Nothing. Has. Changed. I ordered a roll and it tasted like mall food (it's the rice...the rice here is just terrible). The 12 piece sashimi combo was quite good (especially the hamachi and maguro), but like I said 3 years ago, I've had thicker cuts for half the price.

If it weren't for the good maguro (which I shouldn't be eating because it's probably radioactive), I'd give this place 1 star, But I will give credit where it's due: it's hard to find places with good maguro (a few restaurants in LA come to mind). The prices, though...the prices! I live less than a block away and will not be coming back...unless someone else foots the bill.
author: Tiffany H.

description:
We walked in on a Thursday evening and were promptly seated.  
We ordered salmon and tuna sashimi, hampachi and kanpachi nigiri, Koo roll, U2 roll and a small bottle of sake. Every thing was delicious, fresh and beautifully presented.  Our bill came to $120; $99 and change plus tip.  The service was gracious and well paced.  
We will definitely be coming back!!
author: Keeping It Real K.

description: The most important thing to me when eating at a Japanese restaurant is that the fish has to be FRESH.  I appreciated that the menu at Koo lists the available fresh fish and indicates where the fish came from.  We primarily had nigiri sushi and a couple of rolls.  Everything was delicious!  I'm looking forward to eating there again.
author: Andrea P.

description:
Always 5 stars and totally deserving of it.

Hamachi sashimi (4pc), spoonful of happiness, uni nigiri w/quail egg, and U2 roll comes to $66 for a solo meal. Worth it.
author: Angelica C.

description: Best sushi I've ever had. I usually just get tuna and salmon, but I let the chef pick this time. Everything was delicious and practically melted in my mouth. This is the first time I didn't need soy sauce because the flavor was delicious on its own. The spoon full of happiness was indescribably good as well.
author: Brittany B.

description: Great experience! Would recommend to anyone who wants to get fresh and authentic sushi. We had Omakase style, which was amazing. Worth a trip.
author: Tessie Z.

description:
I love this place! I went in with high expectations (because of the reviews) ...expecting to be disappointed (because that always happens with places I search on yelp). The experience turned out to be great, so I was pleasantly surprised. 

The boyfriend and I came here with reservations on a Saturday night. We started off with the spoonful of happiness and I was hesitant because I didn't have previously tasty uni experiences. It turned out to be very good! My favorite was actually the spoon without the uni. Not because the uni/quail egg spoon wasn't tasty but the texture of the fish on the other spoon was amazing. These came with two shots of cold sake. 

I ordered some nigiri and hand rolls, which were fine. Boyfriend had the omakase and he loved it (except for one fish which he couldn't remember the name of). I was still a little hungry so we ordered the agedashi tofu. These were sooo good! The tofu is wrapped in mochi before fried. I've never had agedashi tofu this way and I really really enjoyed it. 

Will definitely be back!
author: Kelly L.

description:
Came on a Monday night with reservations at the bar. There was plenty of extra seating at the bar and table at 6:30pm that evening. Quality and at a reasonable price. Service is exceptional as well.

Highlights: 
Spoonful of Happiness
Uni
Toro 
Sake Salmon
author: Ashley L.

description:
Koo = one of the best sushi experiences I've had in the States (and that's saying a lot).

If you've heard of Koo, then you've undoubtedly heard of the restaurant's "Spoonful of Happiness."  If you haven't, then let me explain.  The Spoonful of Happiness ($12) consists of:

- One spoonful of uni (sea urchin), quail egg, tobiko (flying fish roe), and ponzu sauce
- One spoonful of ankimo (monk fish liver) wrapped in whitefish with white truffle oil and ponzu sauce
- One shot of chilled sake
Photo: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/koo-san-francisco?select=nUvNLeb85G0xCLRrGZ0umw#nUvNLeb85G0xCLRrGZ0umw

So yes, it's technically two spoonfuls of happiness plus a shot of sake, but the restaurant brands the concoction as the Spoonful of Happiness.  Heck, they even have Spoonful of Happiness t-shirts you can buy.  Is it worth it?  Yes.  Our table enjoyed the Spoonful of Happiness so much we ordered two sets for each of us: one to begin our meal and one to end our meal.  It was that good.

Koo is a small Japanese restaurant tucked away in Inner Sunset.  Sit at the sushi bar if you want to see the chefs work their magic or sit in the dining area.  Either way, the food is spectacular.  Koo is headed by chef-owner Kiyoshi Hayakawa.  I'm from Atlanta where the best sushi restaurant is Sushi House Hayakawa (chef-owner: Art Hayakawa).  This leads me to believe that in Japan, the Hayakawa clan has produced a long line of outstanding sushi chefs.

While Westerners tend to enjoy rolls, I'd forgo them and go with a more traditional and purist approach: nigiri.  The regular menu is very nice -- it contains the Spoonful of Happiness after all -- but the Catch of the Day menu is where it's at.  It has the freshest and most unique nigiri selections with almost 20 different kinds to choose from.  These are separate from the regular nigiri (15+) menu.  Here's what we tried, nigiri-wise:

Uni - sea urchin
Hirame - halibut, with shiso leaf and ponzu
Kamasu - barracuda
Wild tombo - wild albacore tuna
Kanpachi - amber jack
Wild hamachi - wild yellowtail
Oh-Toro (or "otoro") - blue fin tuna, very fat belly
Kasugo Tai - spring baby sea bream
Blue shrimp

Expect to spend anywhere from $4-9 for every two pieces of nigiri.  Otoro is the exception.  It's the fattiest, most expensive cut of the tuna belly.  One order of otoro nigiri will set you back $16.  Expensive?  Yes.  Overpriced?  No.  Order it.  You won't be disappointed.

I was happy to try some fish I've never had at a sushi restaurant before, including the kamasu and tombo.  Over half of the Catch of the Day menu is sourced from Japan.  Other fish come from places like Hawaii (tombo), Spain (otoro), and New Caledonia (blue shrimp).

If you like sushi, especially nigiri, you'll be in heaven.  Every piece of fish, seafood, and other ingredients are extremely fresh.  It's noticeable in each piece in terms of taste, texture, and quality.  Most of the sushi is soft, delicate, and buttery.  They simply melt in your mouth.  After 1,200+ reviews, I rarely, if ever, have used the word "orgasm" to describe food.  I think the Spoonful of Happiness and the nigiri at Koo are worthy of that.

If you visit the restaurant before 7:00pm, you can take advantage of their Happy Hour menu.  You can find good deals on hand rolls, appetizers, and alcoholic beverages (Japanese beer, sake, etc.).  We also took advantage of some of these Happy Hour deals and tried the following:

Wakame salad - seaweed salad
Hamachi and avocado hand roll
Spicy tuna hand roll
Marinated artichoke with shichimi soy mayo

Happy Hour food menu items are only $4-5 per, so take note.  Great stuff all-around.  As with the seafood, the seaweed salad and artichoke were fresh and savory.  The hand rolls, fish, rice, and other ingredients wrapped in seaweed, were simple, nicely executed, and beautifully presented (as were the other items).  If you're wondering what shichimi is, it's seven-flavor chili pepper.  I love putting it in my ramen, so I was pleasantly surprised to see it used with the artichoke here.  The artichoke was grilled.

I didn't even get into the restaurant's salads (e.g. grilled baby octopus salad), other grilled items (e.g. eggplant dengaku), and multitude of shareable plates (e.g. tartare, tataki, tempura).  The sushi is just too good to pass up.

Keiko was our server and she did a marvelous job.  Service was on par with the food.  Polite, attentive, and informative.  Hayakawa-san's wife also works at the restaurant is very friendly.  Cognizant of my enthusiasm of his work, she offered to introduce me to and take a photo with him.  Awesome.

In summary, Koo offers some of the best sushi not only in the Bay Area, but in the country.  Enjoy!
author: Daniel B.

description: My favorite Japanese place in city. Chu toro is the best given the price, I usually order 2 orders of that for just myself lol, so good. Uni also very fresh, must try the spoonful of happiness.
author: Cece Z.

description:
I grabbed dinner with my sister here the other night, it's her favorite place for sushi in the city. We had no problem making a reservation for 8pm on a Thursday night the night of. We ordered starters and rolls to share: 

A Spoonful of Happiness - spoonful of uni, quail egg, tobiko ponzu and a spoonful of ankimo wrapped with whitefish, white truffle-oil ponzu. I was told to take a sip of chilled sake before and in between each bite to cleanse my palate. 'Spoonful of Happiness' is sooo right, this was by far my favorite dish of the night!! All the seafood was so fresh and had such a great combination of flavor. 

House Salad - standard mixed greens salad with house dressing

Hamachi Kama - hamachi with ponzu sauce and daikon. The fish was super buttery and savory.

Azteca Roll - shrimp tempura, white fish, sliced jalapeño, tobiko, and green onions. Unique roll because of the jalapeño, which wasn't too spicy. Whatever dish that had white fish was consistently fresh. 

U2 Roll - I can't completely remember what is in this one, but I know there was spicy tuna in it and it was my favorite roll of the night.. so you should get it!

Tokyo Crunch Roll - tenkasu, hamachi, unagi, cucumber and wasabi tobiko - hamachi was fresh and the tenkasu was had a nice crunch.

Overall the food was fantastic! All the seafood was very fresh and flavorful. The chefs are very detailed in their presentation for all the dishes. The only thing is that I don't think I can afford such a lavishly expensive dinner so often, but I would gladly recommend it to anyone looking for a great meal and dining experience!
author: Elaine N.

description:
This place is amazing! Tucked in inner sunset, it is a really quaint little place. The spoon fulls of happiness is worth every bite! I would order it again, and again, and again, if I could. Definitely dream about it from time to time. 

The sushi we had here were all really fresh and tasty, but portions are small, and alas, I can't come here all the time without breaking my wallet.
author: Cynthia X.

description: My friends and I love this sushi place!  The staff are super nice and helpful with the different sushi specials we aren't familiar with and everything is super fresh.  This is our go-to place in the city for sushi!  It's almost never crowded and is a hidden gem.  There are hardly any of those left in the city.
author: Shawna K.

description:
There are a lot of good Japanese restaurants in San Francisco but few of them deliver quality and originality on the level I had at Koo last night. Everything was exceptional and the service was smooth and friendly. 
There were pricey options--and we choose all of them!--but I know from experience that the same level of food and service in Tokyo would cost three times as much, so it is a good value.
I'm really happy there is such a restaurant in my neighborhood!
author: Chou K.

description:
Had dinner here last night, and had a really lovely time - I'm sure the company I was with helped, but the food was great too! I think overall, it's 4-5 stars, but the Spoonful of Happiness dish deffffinitely bumps it to 5 stars for me, and I would keep coming back just for that.

We ordered some nigiri (4 orders, 2pc each) and 3 rolls, and that was good for 3 people. Note: When you're ordering nigiri, they will also offer to give you as many pieces as are in your party, so very accommodating (do all restaurants do that? I don't know). All of the nigiri we ordered were super fresh, and there was one that especially melted in your mouth -- I think it was the toro tuna? It was on the catch of the day menu, but was sooo good.

For rolls, we got the U2, Azteca, and Flying Kamikaze, and they were all good! I was a little afraid of the garlic and asparagus in the Kamikaze, but all the flavors went really well together, and it also didn't feel like you were eating a veggie roll (nothing against them, but when I eat sushi, I'm there for the fish!). I think the Azteca was my favorite of the 3, and the jalapeno wasn't too spicy at all.

But of course, the highlight of the night for me was the spoonful of happiness, described on the menu as "a spoonful of uni, quail egg, tobiko ponzu & a spoonful of ankimo wrapped with whitefish, white truffle-oil ponzu & a shot of chilled sake". I was DD, so I skipped the sake, but man, each spoonful just melted in my mouth and exploded with flavor. So, so worth the $12. Next time I'll have to get someone else to be DD so I can see how the sake enhances the tastes.
author: Kathy L.

description: Fresh and tasty. A little pricey but worth it for the quality. Some decent options for vegetarians.
author: Anne T.

description: We went there for my birthday dinner, booked the table in advance. Ordered $70 omakase combo. Everything taste ok, only highlight was the assorted sashimi. The rest were just ok. portion was very small. For the $70, it would be nice to add a desert or tempera something like that to the combo, so at least you don't walk away hungry.  Other restaurant give bread to go with dinner.  The table was so tiny and space between tables are so small. I guess it is too easy to make money in SF, people just want to spent their money so that the restaurant owners do not have to work hard to attract customers.
author: Nancy H.

description:
Saturday night rolls around and a spontaneous date night ensues...!

Tired from a long week, but craving a touch of class Koo springs into my head as we drive around. I walk past Koo daily, but have never stopped in. We decided to give it a try! 

Lucked out and found parking RIGHT in front, no easy task for 7PM on Saturday. And to my surprise, the place wasn't packed. We were seated right away! 

Menues Given, Drink Orders Taken, and now we were strolling through the menu trying to find something to tame our Saturday night Hunger. 

We ordered the Oyster's 2 piece appetizer, I am pretty sure I could have eaten a dozen of these, topped with tombiko I was a happy lady! NOM. 

Best Roll topped with Lemon was good, besides the fact they kept the rind on the lemon. I now this is common, but I LOVE lemon, but strongly dislike the bitter rind. I think peeling the lemon then topping with a thin slice of pulp would really help this dish. 

Our other roll was white fish and avocado topped with a spicy tuna.  

A nice quite little spot with very polite staff. I'd return!
author: Meghan L.

description:
Koo has the potential to be 4 star but isn't there because of service and food lacking four star elements. It serves predominately American clientale, i.e. more modern fusion food than traditional Asian style, or traditional Japanese style. Think of it as tapa style neo Japanese food. You will find seaweed salad here, but not the normal tempura, some American rolls, and a few random combos. It is hard to predict, and somewhat innovative but without consistency. The service is sub par with long waiting time, and a receptionist that doesn't smile, who would also come over and ask us to turn off our smart phones when we are watching youtube videos in a decently noisy restaurant. 


Sashimi selection is wider than average Japanese restaurants including Kanpachi, Tai (Red Snapper), but not too fresh or high quality. Rolls are decent but pricey for the quality. 


Though there's one highlight $12 spoonful of happiness: one bite of marinated monkfish liver (spoon), one bite of uni sea urchin + raw quail egg (spoon), plus one shot of sake. That's one special value menu item. Happy hour hand rolls are worthwhile, as they are cheap and filling. 


Service definitely needs to improve for a restaurant with such price tag. 


This is a downgrade from my previous review of 4. I dont think I am coming back soon.
author: Dilys S.

description: As a late valentines date, the boyfriend and I went to Koo for their omakase. SO GOOD! It was a wonderful experience and I'm so glad we went to Koo due to their friendly staff and beautiful food. I highly recommend their spoonful of happiness appetizer.
author: Chloe M.

description:
ITADADKIMASU!!!

My friend and I showed up here because I've been meaning to check this place out for awhile. We walked in around 8pm and to our surprise, we SO weren't dressed for the occasion. The hostess was nice and let us sit at the bar since the tables were full of patrons. 

F O O D:

My friend had the Tokyo Crunch Roll and Saba nigiri, while we both shared the Two Way Scallops and Miso Marinated Black Cod. I went with an 6-piece Omakase, which included Kinme Dai, Mirugai, Takabe, Kamasu, Shimaaji, and Sanma. Never had deep sea red snapper and barracuda nigiri before, so it was an awesome texture to remember! The quality of the fresh fish and ingredients used for the making of the orders were mind blowing!!! Pricing for quality fresh caught fish was worth the price. If you're expecting a cheap roll here, you'd better go elsewhere because Koo doesn't offer many rolls on the menu. Don't expect a beef teriyaki in the menu either. You come to Koo for the fish, fxxk the land animal! 

S E R V I C E:
While the sushi gurus behind the counter were very attentive with replenishing my pickled ginger and served our orders in a timely manner, my only complaint is that the waiters who replenished our water glasses came only when we requested it. Boohoo, I go through water pretty quickly when eating good food. Both the sushi chefs and the wait staff spoke great English and Japanese. I was almost dreading that I would be walking into a Chinese owned place again (and the first thing I see on the menu would be cha-siu won ton noodles). 

EXPERIENCE: Very Satisfied! :)
author: Jason C. J.

description:
Within two weeks we were back again at Koo, thats how much we enjoyed our experience! Sorry for the delay, I forgot to write an update!!!

Calamari-well fried, generous portions and intrigued by the corn verde salsa
Goma Ae Salad-would not order again, didn't care for the sesame sauce
Marinated Artichoke-well cooked, subtle flavors
Kamikaze Roll-delicious, refined, balanced
Spoonful of Happiness = HAPPINESS 

Overall Thoughts

Great Happy Hour, Fantastic Quality, and Reasonable Prices
author: Eddie W.

description:
I haven't been here in years. I remember liking it the first time, and took a friend here yesterday night. We walked in at 9p and got a table. My friend and I ordered my favorite dish - tuna and salmon tartare with guacamole and shrimp chips ($14). She also got the baked king crab hand roll ($8.50 per roll). We skipped the spoonful of happiness since that was a disappointment during my first visit. I was planning on getting the baked scallop roll ($6) that I liked, but since our server recommended the two way scallops, we decided to try that instead. 

At $12, the two way scallops ended up being a waste of money. You get 1) two raw scallop topped with daikon with lemon ginger and 2) two raw scallop on top of beets with yuzu miso. The lemon-ginger daikon was tastier than the beets (which tasted like canned beets), but the scallops themselves weren't flavorful other than being slightly fishy. I regret not ordering the scallop hand roll instead. 

Since we were still hungry, we added another king crab handroll, as well as the kamikaze roll ($13.50) which consisted of spicy tuna and asparagus with albacore, garlic ponzu and scallions on top. Both were good. 

We told the server that we were disappointed by the scallop two ways, but she just shrugged off our comment. 3.5 stars - overall Koo was decent but pricey ($70 for two people). Koo might be better during happy hour. For dinner, I would rather go to my favorite sushi place in the Richmond for consistently better food at the same price.
author: Diana B.

description: Boom! Astoundingly fresh, melt in your mouth sushi right here in the sunset! Our server was so sweet and knowledgeable - we pretty much ordered everything he suggested. We heard about the"spoonfuls of happiness" and enjoyed partaking in the ritual of a sip of sake, followed by a slurp of the spoon, then more sake, and repeat. This was a highlight of our dining experience. The lettuce in the spicy tuna roll was also a nice touch for a variation of the expected texture. I like you Koo. Kookoo for koo. Fresh to death. All the feels.
author: Katie P.

description:
Spoonful of Happiness

Spoon of uni and quail eggs, 
Powerful and creamy, leading to 
Orgasm from eating a dish worthy of 8 out of 10 points. 
Oh such fresh gomae,
Nicely shaped as a bamboo, 
Flavorful yet cleans the pallet before eating the next dish. 
Umami after eating the blue fin tuna nigiri, 
Lusting for another piece. 

OMG where is my tamagoyaki? 
Frustrated for the wait. 

Happy to have finally gotten the dish, 
Apologies from the sushi chef for forgetting about the order, 
Place the sake flavored egg into the mouth, 
Puzzled by the fact that it tasted frozen. 
I enjoyed the miso soup, even though it is 
Not red miso as I expected. 
Excited for the hot green tea, 
Surprised by the waitress who accidentally gave me green tea ice cream, 
Sipping the watery tea that she finally gave to me in the end.
author: May Y.

description:
When it comes to the SPOONFUL OF HAPPINESS, believe the hype.  Seems like "uni plus quail egg plus sauce" is a thing now.  I don't know Koo is a leader or follower here, but their execution is awesome... possibly because they also include monkfish liver wrapped in whitefish, and, wonderfully, a shot of sake.  Their very precise directions were: 
1) Sip sake
2) Shoot quail egg and uni spoon
3) Sip more sake
4) Shoot monkfish liver and whitefish spoon  (yes it's actually TWO spoonfuls of happiness)
5) Finish sake.

I would like to do that again, like right now.  Especially the first spoon which was the best ever.  Unfortunately, I'm using WiFu on a laptop in a cafe that doesn't serve anything made outside Venezuela.

Anyway, Koo also has wonderful nigiri including some beautiful toro AND "Sanma" which I had previously had only in Tokyo and, curiously, at Dash in San Mateo.  The server said it means "Saury Pike" in English but it really means DELICIOUS SAVORY MAGIC FISH.  Too bad it's so hard to find.  I also tried the Hige Tara and Kamasu (barracuda) which were decent but paled compared with the Sanma and Toro.  

On a third visit, had other nigiri: the iwana (artic char, salmon's sustainable cousin - delicious here), and shima aji (which was like hamachi... but a little firmer texture and a little less flavor).

Miso black cod has become a staple as Japanese fusion places but I didn't love it here.  What I did love, however, was the mochi covered ice cream balls for dessert... especially the mango one.

For rolls, the Kamikaze and Azteca are both famous and really good.
author: Aaron M.

description: Called them around 6:30 pm on a Saturday to make a reservation -- nobody picks up. So I show up only to find the hostess chatting away with the person in front of me about something personal and pretending not to see me.  So I wait patiently and say nothing -- she continues to chat away and ignore me for a couple of minutes only to inform me afterward that they have one hour wait. No place is worth an hour wait and she could have just told me that when I walked in.
author: None I.

description:
This past Tuesday, my friends and I came here for dinner (on a whim). Fortunately, they took reservations at the last minute for 3 of us. We were seated immediately once we arrived - it didnt look like there were that many people there that evening for some reason. Perhaps it's early in the week and we were in the Sunset district? Not sure...

Either way, we quickly decided on the following items:
(1) Azteca $14 - this was a sushi roll; I ordered it (crab, avocado, gobo and cucumber wrapped in white fish, topped with a thin slice of jalapeno, spicy mayo, tobiko & ponzu then lightly baked) 
(2) Flying Kamikaze $14 - my friend ordered this item ( spicy tuna and asparagus wrapped with albacore and topped with garlic ponzu and scallions)
(3) Tokyo Crunch $9.50 - my friend ordered this item (  spicy tenkasu, hamachi, unagi, cucumber and wasabi tobiko)
(4) 2 orders of Uni sushi (2 pcs) $9 - i love uni!!! had to order this since this restaurant is suppose to have very fresh sushi! :)
(5) A spoonful of happiness - a spoonful of Uni, quail egg, tobiko ponzu & a spoonful of ankimo wrapped with whitefish, white truffle oil ponzu & a shot of chilled sake $12 - there were rave reviews re: this appetizer so we all ordered one to try. I gobbled it up so fast, almost forgot to savor it. it was definitely a spoonful of happiness and bursting with great flavor and freshness from uni + quail egg! :) yum, why is it so expensive though for just 2 spoonfuls? can't afford to eat more than one order, that's for sure.

We had fun eating here for dinner and so glad they were able to seat us immediately upon arrival at 7:15 pm!
author: Yonnie C.

description: I when to here 2 times. First time uni was really good, also before I order uni, the waiter asked me which kind of uni Do I want. So I recommend my friend come here with me, but this time not, and the uni taste bad. I highly recommend here's salmon sashimi and that two spoon things.
author: Tony S.

description:
Getting a reservation was ironically much easier than I thought. 
I just called a few days before, and my time and party size request was met exactly.

I've heard so much about this place but this was utterly disappointing. 

Tried all the big things: Spoonful of happiness, best roll, tokyo roll, and black rod.

Nothing was impressive.  My brother and I were struggling to even eat everything.  
We left full, but not the good kind.  It's the kind where you ate everything cause it was so expensive, but you wished you didn't and saved your stomach for all the good eateries next door or down the block.

The only thing memorable was the sake that came with the spoonful of happiness.  That was the best sake I've had in the my life thus far.  I would only come back for a sake shot if they let ppl do that.

I know my 1-star review stands out, but it's honest.  I'm glad I tried this at least ONCE, but not coming back anytime soon....
author: David W.

description:
Okay quick, think, if you had 5 minutes left to live and had to choose only one sushi dish what would it be?

I would choose as many Spoonful of Happiness dishes that I could wolf down in those 5 minutes. I mean, that's not against the rules right? Since, it's the same dish.

The Spoonful of Happiness for anyone who doesn't know is a spoonful of uni with a quail egg, and a spoonful of ankimo wrapped with whitefish, white truffle-oil ponzu and a shot of chilled sake... and  it's just mouthwateringly delicious.

I've been coming here for years, and I usually order 2 or 3 of these, no kidding.

I'm also a huge fan of their california rolls, which are so much more flavorful than other places that use real crab. I don't know, maybe they mix rainbows in it or something.

Their sashimi is always fresh. They also have, for an additional cost, fresh wasabi.

So when World War Z is occurring, you can find me here.
author: Jack R.

description:
The sushi is so fresh here - and service is so accommodating and nice. 

Highly recommend - 

1. hotate (scallop) sushi
2. the Toyko Crunch 
3. the Best roll (unique and delicious, wouldn't expect lemon to taste so good on a sushi roll)
4. spoonfuls of happiness (two pricey mouthfuls, but the uni serving is generous, and the ankimo (monkfish liver) is rich)

I'd stick with the sushi here, instead of doing the other dishes. We had the gorilla tofu and the spare ribs with crispy potato noodles, which were good, but nothing extraordinary. I'd also pass on the two-way scallops here; prefer my hotate by itself, everything else is a distraction! 

The five stars are for the freshness of the sushi and the unique and artistic rolls they have on the menu, as well as for the great service!
author: Amelia C.

description:
I came here unplanned on a Tuesday night with my boyfriend and our friend.  It was one of the Tuesday nights where I had such a long day at work, I wanted to go out and have a nice drink with my meal.  The plan was to have omakase at Ichi Sushi but because of the newly finished remodel, the place has been pre-reserved for the past few weeks.  I saw the reviews for Koo  via Yelp in the past and decided to finally it out.

While on the way, the boys mentioned that they both had heavy lunches and that they didn't plan on eating much.  They agreed on following my lead with ordering Omakase but cutting after the 2nd or 3rd sushi/dish.  With that said, I of course, offered to pay with the idea that the bill would be around $100.

Omakase, why haven't I learned my lesson yet?  Koo is absolutely delicious and by far has blew me out of the water.  I didn't expect the sushi chef to be so innovative and variety of fish that night was out of this world.  

Several orders that stood out that night:

The Char, we all asked for a second round.  One of the freshest chars that I have ever tasted.

A Spoonful of Happiness  (a spoonful of uni, quail egg, tobiko ponzu & a spoonful of ankimo wrapped with whitefish, white truffle-oil ponzu & a shot of chilled sake)  You cannot leave this place without trying it.  We were told that it was their staple dish.


...2 bottles of saki later (between only the 2 of us) and countless rounds of fish specials,  we get our bill of $350.  The boys ended up stopping when I stopped.  I came there with an empty stomach and with the alcohol, I was in a mission to continue my tasting until I was fully satisfied.  Plus, the sushi chefs were very engaging and it was hard not to say no to them. The staff here are so personable and very attentive in refilling your drinks and taking your plates, something pretty rare.

Will I come back?  Most definitely and I plan on ordering a long round of omakase just like the last time.  The only difference is that I will be paying for myself.
author: Jacquelynne S.

description:
FRESH. High quality sushi. You get what you pay for here, even if what you pay might be a lot.

UNI. UNI. UNI. Whatever's fresh for the day too. Spoonful made me quite happy so I definitely recommend that. Otherwise peruse the menu to your sushi lover's delight and get some of the best servings here. 

While Koo has slide down my list of SF sushi locations mildly due to location, I'd still say it's amongst my tops in the area if you're looking for a classy and secluded nice sushi dinner. 

Cheers!
author: Joseph L.

description:
Thanks to miss Denise W., I can finally check Koo off my bookmark list. Lucky for me, she took me on a lovely dinner date here for my 27th birthday. 

What we ordered:

Spoonful of Happiness -- BOMB. I love me some uni and this one certainly made me happy
Scallops Two Way -- It's ok. One way was on a beet and I'm not too sure about the other. I could've done without this dish.
Tuna Tartare -- Yummm! I loved it that it came with these chip like crackers
Hamachi and avocado hand roll -- Good. Not excellent but decent
Gozilla tofu -- I prefer agedashi tofu over this type but that's not due to the taste. I think it could've used more flavor.
Some roll -- I can't remember the name but it came with jalepenos and hamachi. It was delicious but not memorable. 

All washed down with a bottle of hot sake. I really enjoyed our meal and thought the small hole in the wall was the perfect setting for two girlfriends to catch up. I'm looking forward to bringing Mr. Dubs back for another try of the Spoonful of Happiness.
author: Tiffany U.

description:
Omakase tonight served by Mike. The young chef Mike is very friendly and hard working. It's great sitting at the bar and watching him swiftly cut the fishes and make sushi for us. Overall the food is 3 star. Fishes are fresh and of high quality. Rice is ok and a bit too dry and loose, or simply put, a little plain. 

Monk fish liver is ok, I had better ones at other sushi restaurants. But the addition of shiso makes me not to the degree of disliking it--without the shiso It would be 2/5 quality--I know I am biased here coz I like shiso.

Hamachi toro is my favorite. Very fresh!

Anago is good though its slightly a bit too sweet. 

Hokkaido scallop is pretty fresh.

Hokkaido Uni melts nicely in mouth. Seaweed could be a bit more crispy. Although I am not blown away with wow...I am satisfied.

Goma is, well, just ok. My least favorite.

I had total of 17 sushi. All the others are ok. Overall a good experience. 3.4 out of 5 stars.

Sake was generously served.

I did not realize that the omakase they have here is different from Wako or Kusakabe or Yoshizumi--whose onakase is a fixed courses of 16 or so with a la carte (extra after the fixed course) On the menu it says 50 dollars and up--that means after five or six courses, they will just kept feeding you until they noticed you are full and asked: you want more? At that moment I knew I have extended the courses. So the total came to 98 or so and with tip its 115. I am 90% full. Overall a good experience. Will come back but next time I will skip the Omakase.
author: S N.

description:
Like everyone else has already said, spoons of happiness are ON POINT. The omakase was very fairly priced. The only thing is that you get all of it at once, so it's more like a nigiri platter than your traditional omakase experience. This might also just be due to the fact that we sat at a table and not at the bar.

Also, this place is a unicorn in the city. Great food, good service, and NO WAITING, at least not your average SF 45 minute type of wait. It's never overflowing busy. Probably a function of the location, but if you don't feel like waiting in the freezing cold or being on a waitlist for 3 weeks to eat some good sushi, this is your spot.
author: Mat K.

description: This place is great. Waiters could be better, but food is quite nice. Highly recommend
author: Dan K.

description:
Being highly recommended by Owen M.,  this past Saturday I took my girl and her parents to Koo.

I made reservations for 7:30 but arrived around 7:15.  Koo had a full house so they weren't able to take us till about 7:35 or so.  But while I waited, I never really paid much attention before to the chefs preparing the sushi.  Watching them was like watching a potter sculpting clay.  Not only is it important that it tastes good but I appreciate how important the appearance of each piece of sushi is to the chefs.  It really is an art form.  Even better an art form I can eat.

When we were seated the waitress took our drink orders.  After bringing the tea and other drinks, here's what we ordered:

Spoonful full of Happiness: (Uni, Quail Egg, Tobiko Ponzu and  Ankimo Wrapped with Whitefish, White Truffle Oil Ponzu and a Shot of Chilled Sugei Sake.). I know other yelpers really like this item at Koo.  I probably don't know what im talking about but this was one item I could pass on here.

Hamachi Kama:  this is one of my favorite dishes of all time now.  So simple but so good.  I've had Hamachi Kama at three restaurants in the past couple weeks.  Koo makes the best one I've had.  A nice portion, tender and smooth like butter.

We got quite a few rolls:
King Crab Roll, Azteca, Tokyo Crunch, U2, Spider, Dragon Rolls.

All were great but I think my favorite two was the Dragon Roll and the King Crab Hand Rolls.  Along with that we tried the Fuji Apple Sake.

Service was good, reservations a must, and parking wasn't bad in the Corolla but if you're driving a Cadillac, Forget-About-It..

Sushi is ranked #4 in CNN's top 50 most delicious foods. Koo is "representing" #4 well.
author: Michael L.

description:
Giving this a four because it is one of the only decent sushi restaurants I've found in the Bay Area.

It's not as good as some of the restaurants in LA, but it was a pleasant surprise.
The sushi seems somewhat decent quality for the price.
Also, they have blue shrimp and crawfish hand roll, which I haven't had anywhere else before.

Sat at the bar.
Friendly and attentive.
author: Heejin L.

description:
STILL MY FAVORITE SUSHI RESTAURANT IN SF!

After nearly two and a half years of trying to avoid Koo, I'm FINALLY back! You see, Koo brings back memories I rather not remember. For a year and a half, my ex and I use to go to Koo almost every Friday for dinner because we were boring creatures of habit. Though we tried other sushi restaurants, the quality of Koo's fish had us coming back time and time again. And, well after the breakup, I refused to go back. But I missed those Spoonfuls of Happiness so darn much that I couldn't resist anymore. 

Yesterday, 8.30.11, my friends and I came to Koo for dinner at 6:30 PM with reservations. Just to note, Koo can be stringent about reservations so I highly recommend making them. The sushi bar is mainly reserved for Omakase (Chef's Tasting Menu) and you will not be seated there without having reservations. There's a $10 minimum charge per a person. I also suggest not coming here after "happy hour" like we did last night because we ended up spending $92/person. *sigh*

After dining here over 40 times, I've tried just about everything on the menu but I recommend sticking with the sashimi and sushi. The Chef/Owner use to part of the highly acclaimed Sushi Ran team so you know everything is top-notch! The sashimi is always extremely fresh and there are varieties from overseas that you won't be able to find at other sushi restaurants. Also, all their rolls are flawlessly made and extremely clean which is perfect for sushi purists. 

FOOD RECOMMENDATIONS
(Note: There's Happy Hour Specials Sunday - Thursday from 5 PM-7 PM with $4 handrolls and $5 appetizers. However, it's only about $1 off which isn't really worth it.) 

*SPOONFULS OF HAPPINESS - A spoonful of uni, quail egg, tobiko ponzu & a spoonful of ankimo wrapped with whitefish, white truffle-oil ponzu & a shot of chilled sake ($11) 
ORGASMIC! The uni is silky smooth with a creamy decadence from the quail egg. Like foie gras of the sea, the akimo was luxuriously buttery especially when paired with the soft whitefish sashimi. A MUST GET!

*SALMON & TUNA TARTAR - Served with spicy guacamole and shrimp chips ($14)
Small soft tender chunks of silky salmon and tuna layered with buttery guacamole makes for a deliciously savory combo with a kick. The shrimp chips are thicker than your typical bagged shrimp chips and have a hearty crunch which is a nice texture contrast to the soft tartar. 

*U2 ROLL - Tempura shrimp, avocado topped w/spicy tuna & tobiko ($13)
Warm crunchy shrimp tempura with buttery avocado with a spicy soft tenderness from the spicy tuna. A sure taste bud tickler!

*BEST ROLL - Tempura asparagus, avocado, wrapped in fresh salmon & lemon thin slice ($9)
Al-dente, crisp tempura asparagus with buttery fresh salmon with a lemon slice make for a rich yet refreshingly light roll.

*FLYING KAMIKAZE - Spicy tuna and asparagus wrapped w/albacore and topped with garlic ponzu and scallions ($13.50)
The spicy tuna is softened by the mild albacore and the garlic ponzu gives it a tangy garlicky kick. 

SERVICE
Depending on who's working that night, service can sometimes be spotty and unfortunately curt which was the case last night. However, the owner's wife who's normally there on weekends is very sweet and accommodating. Nonetheless, the food is always consistently good so I plan to become a regular again. 

AMBIANCE/DÉCOR
Very clean and zen like but very dark. It's good for small parties no more than 4 people. 

PARKING
Easy street parking before 6 PM. 

Koo and I finally reunited again and it FEELS SO GOOD....
author: Cherylynn N.

description: Great food. We try sashimi & rolls everywhere we go & this was very great quality fish.  It was both original & traditional with fast service.  We would recommend Koo to friends for a fun spot but it was VERY crowded, a tad loud, & we would have liked a bit more intimacy.
author: Lindsey D.

description:
Absolutely in love with Koo! Discovered by accident as I live nearby, and it's one of my new favorite restaurants in SF. Perhaps, being new to California, I'm just not used to the quality of the sushi here, but for my taste, this was in line with some of the best sushi restaurants in NYC.

Highly recommended: most things on the special menu, especially the hamachi carpaccio (the ponzu sauce and jalapeno/tomato/onion combo topping the sashimi are to die for) and the chu-toro. Also the U2 roll, tuna & salmon tartare with shrimp chips and gauc, and the miso marinated black cod, which was unusually served in a hearty broth. Can't wait to go back!
author: Vieta K.

description:
Their salmon sashimi is off the hook (hehe get it) but no really it was so buttery. Actually, all of their sashimi is pretty incredible. Their rolls, on the other hand, are overpriced for what they are. I'd say stick to the sashimi.

If you're feeling adventurous, I'd recommend trying their spoons of happiness for a delicious flavor combination you won't ever forget.
author: Kimberly H.

description:
My friend took me out to a belated birthday dinner and said he made reservations for this place called Koo. It didn't ring a bell until I got closer and realized that I've been here before. 
My first visit here was the first time I tried monk fish liver. I've heard about their spoonful of happiness so I decided to give it a try and it was delicious! It's accompanied by a shot of sake with instructions from the waitress. I think it's suppose to cleanse your palate so you can enjoy the flavors from one spoon to another. 
My first time here was more for drinks than food so I don't remember what else we got. 
The second time here we got a bunch of rolls, Albacore Tataki, Sashimi Combo and my friend had the spoonful of happiness which he enjoyed very much. 
We got the negi-hamachi maki, U2 roll and the California roll. Everything was fresh and delicious but the California roll was my favorite. Made with fresh crab and it was one of the best I've ever had. The fish in the sashimi combo was also very fresh and the perfect slice. The albacore tataki was also one of my favorite dishes of the night. The cilantro was a perfect touch with the right amount of drizzle of sweet and spicy fish sauce. 
The service was great, waitresses were constantly checking up on us and refilling our water glasses. 
The ambiance is cozy and I really enjoyed my dinner.  I will definitely be back!
author: Joanne L.

description:
Let me put it this way, if Koo were a boy band, I'd be all over their #1 platinum single "Spoonful of Happiness" (and happiness you'll be in, once you try this -- 360+ reviews and any amount of uni can't be wrong), and I'd be crazy about their other hits: "impressive array of delicious sake" and "super fresh nigiri." The best part was, even for a crab-impaired individual like myself, everything else was so bomb, neither my dinner partner nor I missed that hive-inducing crustacean one bit.

It's fun to sit at the sushi bar and watch your chefs create these beautiful works of edible art in front of your eyes (and if you do order quite a bit, it's nice to treat him to a shot of sake, yeah?), but there are other seating options as well. You'll likely need reservations or to come early / late, but it's definitely worth any and all inconvenience or wait. My mouth is watering thinking about the unagi, the hamachi, the Flying Kamikaze (picture this: spicy tuna, asparagus, wrapped in albacore, topped with ponzu and scallions)... OK, gotta go warm up the car... Point being: whatever you order, I'm sure you won't be disappointed.

Koo may be a no-nonsense, no-frills kinda sushi joint, but that doesn't mean it's no fun... just try a bottle of their Tamanohikari sake: you'll see what I'm talking about. And you'll also see that just a "spoonful of happiness " helps the medicine go down in a most delightful way. ;-)
author: Eunice E.

description: They were able to accommodate our party of 6 to celebrate my Mom's birthday.  Our family used to love coming to the restaurant in it's prior life, Hana.  We thought we'd take our family back to Koo.  It was good, we ordered mostly rolls but it definitely doesn't compare to Hana.
author: Meredith K.

description:
I really really wanted to love this place because it is so close to my house. But I Zushi Puzzle wins out for omakase. The girlfriend and I had reservations for a Saturday night and were seated immediately. Even though the omakase let me down, the service was excellent. The waiters were attentive, cleared out plates quickly, and filled out glasses but the place was relatively empty. 

We ate the famous Spoonful of Happiness as our first dish. After reading the reviews I expected the spoons to blow my mind but they were just average. But the sushi chef was right that the sake paired with the spoons accentuated the food and vice versa. Next, up the sashimi plate, which only had 4 different kinds of fish. I was expected a lot more variety. But I was still trying to keep an open mind. Up next was a trio of cooked bit-sized snacks -- Stuffed Jalapeno, Eggplant Dengaku, and Hawaiian Seared Albacore Wrapped. All three were good but nothing special. Nigiri and fried shrimp head followed. All were mediocre. But the best dish was the Miso Marinated Black Cod. I wish there were more than three pieces. After all that food, I was still hungry so I settled and ordered the Azteca Roll because the chef was all out of ideas. 

For the cost, I would have rather gone to Zushi Puzzle. The hot food was mostly salty, not savory. Although the fish was fresh, the texture and flavor were too similar. I felt like I was eating the same fish over and over again. Even the Azteca fell short of my expectations. The couple next to us also ordered omakase but got very different dishes, all of them were cooked. 

What I recommend: 
Miso Marinated Black Cod
Spoonful of Happiness (have to try their most popular dish)
author: Andrew W.

description:
This place never fail to make me happy. It is definitely the best in the city! This is the only place i give 5 stars for Japanese/sushi restaurant. 
Of course you must order spoonful of happiness PER Person. You don't wanna share this happiness with someone. One order per person is a must. 

Their sushi chef is very professional that they'll adjust sushi rice portion depends on how much you order. If you order tons of sishi(not rolls, but nigiris), they'll give you small portion of rice beneath the fish so you can enjoy all of them. 

Their Uni is always good, high quality! When they had white king salmon nigiri, oh my god, it is soooo goood. But they don't always have them;( 
I like to order nigiri from catch of the day :) 

Oyster spoon was a little bit small, but it was delicious kumamoto oysters:) 

If you don't give this place 5stars, then you don't have good taste buds!
author: Mii L.

description:
A decent, no-frills, bare-bones sushi restaurant with rolls that skew toward the simple stuff rather than the fried/creamy/baked stuff. Even though it wasn't on the menu, the chef was able to make me salmon avocado maki and hamachi avocado maki per my request. The fish wasn't the freshest and had that too-soft, squishy texture that often happens to fish that's been sitting at room temperature for too long. The rice was pretty good, though. The other thing we got was the tai (sea bream) sushi, which was one of the day's specials. It was pretty fresh and tasted delicious. The seaweed salad was nice and que que (or however you transliterate the Mandarin word for chewy) if a tad under-seasoned.

Service was friendly when it happened but there were long, looong gaps in which we thought our food or server was never going to appear.
author: Josephine L.

description:
Wow.. very impressed. I walked here around 6:30pm on a Saturday so I can't attest to the parking or easy of commute.. I had to wait all of 15 seconds to get seated so the dining experience started off a great note, and never missed a beat. 

I ordered predominately nigiri and maki, but also a couple of appetizers.. The variety and quality of the fish is amazingly delicious and fresh. As other have mentioned the Spoonful of Happiness is quite amazing. First spoon has uni and a quail egg, and the second has ankimo wrapped with white fish, all this accompanied with a shot of sake. Highly recommended!

For sushi, I had: Maguro, O-Toro, Wild Hamachi, Hamachi Toro, Kasugo, Kinme Dai, Tamago, and Aji. All the fish were fresh with excellent flavor. Expensive, but definitely worth it. The Kinme Dai and Kasugo were from Japan. I'm not always a fan of snapper since it can sometimes be chewy... but both of these specimens were very soft and tender, with a nice mild flavor. The Kasugo was the best surprise.. the skin had a nice texture

For maki, I had a Negi hamachi and salmon avocado roll. The negi hamachi had a very light and tender consistency and went well with the amount of green onions. I usually expect more green onions, but this combo hit the spot!

I'm not a big fan of salmon of avocado rolls, this one seemed ok, but noting to write home about.

The Gomae Ae was deconstructed, and had a thicker sesame paste. Not quite what I was expecting and I can't recommend it. The Eggplant was ok.. Sauce was thicker as well.

Overall one of the better places I've been to lately.. Great ambiance helpful staff...
author: James S.

description: Went here this past weekend on a Saturday night. We had reservations. The restaurant was crowded but we were greeted and seated immediately. The sushi was phenomenal! Just superb! The service was excellent! We loved it and will definitely be back to Koo soon!
author: Mariama G.

description:
Like others have mentioned, the Spoonful of Happiness is a must try! It was my first time trying uni and it was great, especially with the ponzu sauce and quail egg. Plus you get a shot of sake.

What else we ordered:
Broiled Hamachi - Moist and cooked nicely.
Spider Roll - Huge pieces of soft shell crab, not bad.
Spicy Tuna Roll - Yummy!
Azteca Roll - Fresh tasting whitefish, something unique in terms of flavor as this was topped with jalapeno.

For a Saturday night it wasn't crowded at all. It took about 10 minutes of circling to find parking two blocks away. Friendly and attentive service - our tea cups were always full! Overall a great place for sushi!
author: Josh L.

description:
Koo has some of the best sushi in SF mixed with great izakaya-style dishes.

We've eaten here a few times when we lived in the 'hood, but on our last visit the spoon of happiness was absolutely fantastic (just try it), the smelt was OK, and the green beans were deliciously flavored.

It's pretty hard to go wrong overall since the food is of such high quality, so maybe just get a spoon of happiness and ask what else is good?
author: Amy D.

description:
One of my favorite to-go sushi places in the city (other than Ebisu). I love Love LOVE the Spoonful of Happiness, which comes with 2 spoons (one with uni, quail egg & the other with ankimo, fish) & a shot of sake. 

Now, they have a happy hour menu til 7pm. All handrolls are $4. The tempura crawfish roll with spicy mayo is delish. 

I always order the nigiri off of their specials menu. They ship their fish from Japan & Hawaii, always so fresh. The scallop two ways is unique too. 

It can get pricey, but it's so worth it. Service is quick & amazing.
author: Alysha K.

description: Portions are dainty for prices you pay but you are paying for quality over quantity. They have happy hour specials that might be worth a visit earlier in day so you can order everything off the menu. No bento boxes here so you know it's downright authentic Japanese food.
author: W A.

description: There is a lot of good sushi and sashimi in the neighborhood. But this is simply the best I've had. Highest quality, and generous portions. It's pricier than our regular spot but notably better. Their sake list is superb. Very much looking forward to my next visit.
author: Eekie P.

description:
I'm a bit late on this review, but I most definitely had to write one for Koo. Better late than never, am I right? 

My boyfriend brought me here three weeks ago for my birthday. When I checked Yelp, the ambience said "casual" but my boy wanted us to look good for our date so good we looked ( he looked spiffy spiffy...just the way I like c: ). When we arrived, I noticed that even though most customers were dressed casually, the atmosphere still felt intimate, fancy, and romantic due to the dim lighting.

My boy ordered the following for us:

- Tuna and Salmon Tartar: (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=wL-rbTpV95GI7Y5iiPjXig&userid=VNXuiSVAOdpm5n5gKqs5xw) SO GOOD. Oh my gosh. It is the perfect appetizer. It came with six big circular shrimp chips and spicy guacamole. It was super refreshing and the pieces of fish were fresh. I didn't know guacamole went so well with sashimi...but then again, guacamole goes well with anything. Hehe

- Spoonful of Happiness: (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=Jbun8pVKY1oaNHUdHE0dIQ&userid=VNXuiSVAOdpm5n5gKqs5xw) Goodness gracious....as delicious as everything was that night, this selection was definitely the highlight. One order comes with two spoons: the first one has uni, quail egg, and tobiko ponzu, the second one has ankimo (monkfish liver), whitefish, and white truffle oil ponzu. These two spoons also come with a shot of cold sake. We each got an order and oh gosh...no regrets. This dish is a must-get, must-try, must-eat!!

- Toro nigiri & hamachi toro nigiri: Both were yummy. Fresh fish :3 

- Chef's selection sashimi plate: (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=vNM_qMBwfUy2dGzIueD0QQ&userid=VNXuiSVAOdpm5n5gKqs5xw) Orgasm in my mouth.

- Spider roll: (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=gFCTkQ595FeAUTdHA3IZiA&userid=VNXuiSVAOdpm5n5gKqs5xw) Didn't make too much of an impression compared to the other dishes. It was good but you can get the same quality of the spider roll at other sushi restaurants. 

- Mt. Fuji: (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=oR7biTa1zflTy9nXX3TBAQ&userid=VNXuiSVAOdpm5n5gKqs5xw) Chocolate cake stuffed with white chocolate mousse with a side of green tea ice cream. I wasn't expecting anything but when the boy made reservations, he told them it was my birthday so the chocolate cake came with a birthday candle ^^ The dessert was yummy; smooth and creamy, not too sweet, and it went perfectly with the green tea ice cream.

Every time I reminisce about this night, I want to go back right away. Japanese is my favorite cuisine so I've tried a million sushi restaurants, but Koo is one of the top places on my list. It is pricey so it's not a restaurant to go on the daily. Save it for the special occasions and remember to order all the yummy fresh fish! Mmm...
author: Judith L.

description:
Koo had been on my list to try for awhile - it looks so cute and intimate, the reviews are (mostly) good, and it's in the inner sunset - home of some of the best Asian restaurants in the city! I found Koo to be "meh" though.

The wakame salad was drenched in dressing - biggest seaweed salad faux pas in my opinion...I didn't even finish it. 

I ordered the salmon maki, negi hamachi maki, and tuna maki - they were all fine, but the rice and seaweed weren't the best. The seaweed came apart on several pieces (sloppily made), and the rice just wasn't great...any good sushi begins with perfectly made sushi rice! The rolls were also a little pricey for just maki - $7 each.

Glad I satisfied my curiosity, but won't be back.
author: Jessica C.

description:
Saltiest Japanese food I've ever had.

We had the spoonfuls of happiness, fried calamari, crunch roll, flying kamikaze roll, scallop sushi, and hamachi toro sushi.

I'd recommend just ordering nigiri sushi and sashimi... else prepare for salt overload.
author: Maida C.

description:
The sashimi menu here is intense! They know the country each fish is from (or at least do a good job pretending they do). But I really liked this place! It is small and with excellent friendly wait staff. We tried the flying kamikaze and another roll (I am blanking on the name) both of which were excellent combinations of fresh fish. We got the king crab hand rolls, which tasted great and had a thicker rice than I'm used to (but good tasting), but they went light on the crab in my opinion. We also each got the spicey tuna, hamachi, and maguro hand rolls. All these tasted great, fresh, with a generous amount of fish. I will be back to Koo soon. 

PS. I didn't get to try the dessert, but I was eyeing it from the table next to us, and it looked pretty bomb.
author: Nikita K.

description:
Gee, last review was in 2006.  All these years later, we still love Koo!  

The fish is consistently the best!  Even the cooked food is always perfect.  Their uni is always a must get as well as their briny so fresh oysters.  Of all the sushi restaurants we have enjoyed, we always run back to Koo.   The service is top notch also.  If you love soft shell crab, you will die at the size of the ones served here.  HUGE and not oily at all.  I wish I had one right now.  My favorites are blue fin tuna and hamachi belly.  Oh, the Spoonfuls of Happiness says it all.  We love you Koo!
author: Kell M.

description:
Finally got a chance to try this place last night after wanting to for a long time, especially after reading elsewhere on Yelp that the sushi served here is pretty authentic Japanese style. The menu shows a pretty good selection of "special" fish (likely from Japan) but I went for the regular sashimi combo along with negihama roll. The combo was supposed to be 12 pieces total with three pieces each of tuna, salmon, albacore, and yellowtail. However, mine came with extra salmon, like five or six pieces total (I forgot exactly how many). I considered that a bonus.

Overall pretty good. The albacore was definitely "meh" (but then it's not my favorite, except for one Chinese-owned place which I think serves great ones). The tuna and yellowtail was good, but the salmon was quite good and fresh, similar to my favorite place for it (same place alluded to earlier). Afterwards, I ordered the mackerel sashimi which was quite good, with a bit of "fattiness" that I notice which especially made it good (and it's in a way that I don't think I noticed much elsewhere).

Good and friendly service too. Worth coming back to sometime.
author: H K.

description: The food is very good, I love the spoon full of happiness. It's also pretty near Golden Gate park and the museums.
author: Mona L.

description:
hard to add anything to somewhere that has 800+ reviews.

With that - This was a great sushi/omakase experience.  Fairly reasonable (considering how good the meal was) and friendly staff. And, it was ea cake walk to make a reservation about 2 hours prior to deciding that we wanted to come here for sushi.

I've had several good meals in SF, but this place alone may make a trip back worthwhile.
author: Josh D.

description:
Took a spontaneous trip to Koo this evening and had no trouble getting a table right away on Sunday evening at 6:45.

I was pleasantly surprised by the nice ambiance, the room feels cozy, the lighting is perfect and the candles add an element of romance. The service is way better than average; my tea was always full, everyone on the floor was very attentive to our needs and pleasant to interact with and our server even took the time to wipe our table prior to bringing the check. 

That said, the food itself left something to be desired. We ordered 12 nigiri, shrimp dumplings and the garlic tofu. The garlic tofu was tasty but the sushi was lacking. The rice used for the nigiri was dense and underdone and the fish was mostly just okay. The Uni and Pike were good, the Saba was disappointing and everything else fell somewhere in between. Also, the nigiri took a significant amount of time to make it to the table. 

Based strictly on the people and ambiance I would really like to recommend Koo, the sushi is fine and the tofu was great but if you want high-quality, tasty nigiri, I would look elsewhere. 

TLDR: Ambiance is romantic, service fantastic, sushi is just okay
author: Sara A.

description:
came here on a tuesday for a birthday dinner at around 830ish, surprisingly it wasn't too busy in there.

we had:

-spoonfuls of happiness :5/5- i was definitely after eating this. Something about the flavors just combining in your mouth and working really well together in harmony. The first spoon had uni, a raw quail egg and ponzu sauce. All three melted in your mouth and it was a foodgasm in your mouth. the other spoon had sashimi and some sort of sauce and that one was tasty as well, but not as delicious as the first spoon. i'm drooling thinking about it.

-scallops-two ways 4/5: it was beautifully presented and it was so tasty. it was scallop and beets, it had a sweet taste to it that i never had with a scallop. the other one was also tasty but i forgot what was on it. 

-miso glazed black cod 5/5- it was so tender, it definitely was not overcooked, it was cooked just right with the right amount of flavor and seasoning.

-the best roll  3/5- not the best roll, ive ever had. but it was decent. tempura asparagus with sashimi on top. 

-sashimi combo 5/5: extremely fresh and delicious

-mt fuji chocolate mousse cake 4/5- it wasn't too sweet, but it was at the right amount. the cake was not dense, which is good! and the mousse was to die for. i would eat one of these by myself!

Total for 2 people: $96, pre-tip. With tip, $110.  It can be a pricey meal, but its worth it! =)
author: Stella J.

description:
Wow. Delicious. We never even made it to the rolls, as all the sushi was sooo good. The fish was really fresh. 
The scallops and tuna stood out, and also, try the mackeral, you won't be disappointed...and definitely get the skeleton they offer with it (that's not what it's called, though, but I can't remember the 'proper' name, haha). Service was great. The sake menu was extensive. 
We were there about an hour before closing on Friday night, and the place was about half full. I can't wait to go back!
author: Elizabeth R.

description: My friend and I came for a dinner on Friday evening to see this new place that we have found. We were both satisfied with the quality of the food which was delicious. We are definitely coming back for more!!!!
author: Yana Y.

description: Cute little place with an intimate setting. Decided to try this place out since ebisu was so busy. The food was great but not worth the price! There are other sushi spots just as good and much cheaper!
author: Michelle H.

description:
Came here a couple weeks ago and before that about 2 years ago for omakase.  This time ordered a la carte.

Still super solid with very fresh fish.  The nigiri sharidama is the perfect size, some may find it to be very small but the superstar is the fish or any neta that is on top not the rice.  That's probably why I ate over 20 pieces of nigiri but had the chance to try most of the fish.  

Spoon full of happiness still makes me super happy.  Ordered another one towards the end of the dinner.

Draft Asahi or any draft is very important to me when I visit Japanese restaurants.  Bottles just don't cut it.

No complaints.  One of my favorite real deal Japanese restaurants.
author: Kevin L.

description:
I've been here for happy hour and I've been here for dinner.

With happy hour they've got good beer & wine specials and the hand rolls are tasty and inexpensive.

For dinner I ordered the Flying Kamikaze and the Shrimp Tempura Roll, while my boyfriend got the sushi combo. We both loved all of it.

We lucked out and got in before it became packed, but I highly recommend a reservation for this place. Seems like a popular date spot although it is rather small so you do overhear your neighbor's conversation.
author: Katie S.

description:
Yummy! Ok this probably is one of the best sushi restaurants in the Bay Area. By sushi, I mean the actual fish. I did not order any rolls. I came here because of an article about "Best Sushi in the Bay" and Koo was listed. Came at 5pm on Saturday on a whim and I was aware they didn't open until 530. I called at 5 just to make sure we could be accommodated and someone actually picked up and made us a reservation for 3. They opened the doors right at 530 and seated us. 

Service was prompt. Waitresses did their jobs, not too talkative or friendly but that's not what I came for. We ordered sooo many things. 

Spoonfuls of Happiness - uni and ponzu was yummy and the monkfish liver was probably the best I've had. Came with a shot of sake but I did not partake in that. 

Miso soup- I don't recall seeing any bits of seaweed but they did use a different kind of green. 

Hamachi jalapeño- spicyish nonetheless good but very small appetizer. 

Beef tataki- a little on the salty side.

Hamachi Kama- I didn't try because I'm not a big fan of cooked fish my boyfriend and his friend definitely mopped it clean. 

Eggplant miso- yummy with rice. 

Miso black cod- they serve it really wet and in a soup here. New to me, I prefer it the less soupy version but it was still good.

Waygu nigiri- the best!!! Meat quality was amazing. 

Fresh catch of the day (nigiri):

Uni (japan)- the pieces were very small but it was not skimpy. Texture was so smooth and delicious. 

Toro- sooo fatty I couldn't even handle it. Hahaha

Negitoro roll- delish 

Hirame- delish

Maguro- delish 

I forgot what else but here are some pictures. The fish quality was definitely fresh and the best I've had so far in the bay.
author: Rosanna T.

description: Delicious delicious delicious. We got the sashimi platter that was good. Fresh fish can't go wrong with that. We also got the Kama and that was prefect with the rice that we got on the side. Just prefect seasoning. Would definite go here again.
author: Knastayyy M.

description:
I was seriously craving some sushi on Halloween, and so to avoid the frightening(ly expensive and/or awful) establishments downtown, I booked date night at Koo.

We got there on time, but our dressed-up host, Mario (yes, of Mario and Luigi), asked us to wait. A green witch noticed that we'd been waiting and offered seats at the sushi bar. We accepted, sat, and were brought menus immediately. The three Asian men dressed up as sushi chefs were delightful and truly talented at their craft. (Har har.)

We ordered:
+Sushi combo with fresh wasabi: three pieces each of maguro (tuna), hamachi (amberjack), saki (salmon), and white fish. Delicious and fresh. The wasabi is the real deal, so use with caution.
+Best roll: tempura asparagus and avocado wrapped in fresh salmon with a thin lemon slice. Refreshing and very tasty.
+Tokyo crunch roll: spicy tenkasu (crunchy tempura flakes), hamachi, unagi (eel) with cucumber and wasabi tobiko. A bit of a mess to eat, but pretty good.
+Tempura shrimp roll: with avocado, cucumber, and asparagus. The usual tempura shrimp roll minus the accompanying glob of mayonnaise (thank Jah!)

Speaking of Jah, our sushi chef noticed my date had dreadlocks and to coerce a smile, he grabbed his "Halloween costume": a Rasta cap (complete with the Jamaican flag-colored cap and added dreads) and gave us his best Jamaican accent. Given the fact that I've only conversed with austere sushi chefs, it was a complete delight to see the lighter side. I'm just glad I wasn't drinking my tea as I nearly spit out my sushi roll from complete laughter and surprise.

With good food, good service, fair prices, and a side of comedy, Koo's a solid sushi establishment.
author: Adena B.

description: I can't express enough about how much I love sushi. The fish here was good.  The spoonful of happiness was the highlight of my whole meal. The reason for the 2 star review was because the customer service was horrible. The server was a female with a strong accent I wish I asked her for her name. Anyways everything started out great but throughout the meal she disappeared and was very helpful to the table next to us.  It was impossible to flag her down to order more food or to get water for that matter. Since it was my first visit and the food was delicious I was excited to find a hidden little gem that was fairly priced. However because of the horrible service I will not be back for more.
author: Meredith L.

description:
Spoonful of Happiness. Oh my god. Its actually TWO spoonfuls (uni+quail egg, and ankimo) and a shot of sake. Delicious.
Their fish is fresh and very well prepared. Service is a bit awkward at times but not a problem.
author: Jason L.

description: Spoonful of happiness!  That was awesome! I normally do not like uni but this will definitely do.  First time here.  Service is excellent.  Great ambience.  Mint spare rib butter lettuce cup has tender beef and a perfect crispiness.  Fish is of course extremely fresh.  Yum!  I'm happy that I found out about this place.  Definitely coming back!!
author: Jacklyn B.

description:
Food: 4-5 stars
Service: 4 stars
Pricing: expensive

Spoonful of happiness (not on the HH menu)  is definitely TASTY!!!! You dont want to leave Koo without trying it! 

This place definitely has GOOD QUALITY fish if you're willing to fork out some money.

My gf and I came here and we were full from lunch, but decided to eat here for an early dinner. To say the least, we weren't full, maybe 75% full, and we paid about 30/person out the door. 

I will come back and try some more food! HH menu is decent but not great.
author: Jen H.

description:
Spoon Full of Happiness.

That is all you need to know and order.  Uni and a quail egg in ponzu with fish roe and Ankimo in Suzuki sashimi with truffle oil.  This was the most amazing dish of the night which is served with a small glass of sake has a palette cleanser.  

Stick to their nigiri:

+Amber Jack
+Salmon
+Scallop
+Hamachi
author: Carli F.

description: Spoonful of Happiness is pretty great. Service is good and quick. I've been back twice now, and it's been consistent. Small spot, but I haven't had to wait yet.
author: Kris F.

description:
Has a meal ever made me coo with delight?  Perhaps, but none stands out in my mind more than Koo.

I loved walking in and see simply dark, and sleek wooden tables.  The settings caught my eye with a mellow yellow napkin that popped against the dark wood.  Our waitress was great, she was always there when we needed her, and never there when we didn't.  Glasses of water always full.

Upon Yelper's suggestions, I ordered the Spoonful of Happiness, and oh boy it definitely was!  You get two spoonfuls and a shot of sake in the set.  One is ankimo wrapped in hamachi with white truffle oil ponzu.  Take a shot of sake after the first one to cleanse the palette if you wish.  The second spoonful is uni, quail egg, and tobiko ponzu.  Both spoonfuls were delicious, but my favorite was the uni, quail egg, and tobiko ponzu, absolutely creamy and delicious!

I also had a fresh order of the shashimi combo, which included about 4 selections of their freshest fish, and an order of unagi ngiri.  I was completely satisfied after this meal.

I hear happy hour is something to try, as well.  I'll definitely be back
author: Roenna N.

description:
I bookmarked this place for a while. And finally got to try it this weekend. Called at 8PM Saturday for 8:40PM reservations for two. They accepted and we headed out to find parking in the semi-business/residential UCSF Sunset Area. Finding street parking is not the easiest, but we lucked out and parked on Irving and 8th.

Walked in and was seated immediately. Great!

The order was 

Spoonful of Happiness $12 (4 of 5) was so fun and DELIGHTFUL to eat!!!
Spoon 1 is a spoonful of uni, quail egg, tobiko ponzu. 
Spoon 2 is a spoonful of ankimo wrapped with whitefish, white truffle-oil ponzu 
A shot of chilled sake.

The steps to eating Spoonful of Happiness. You can eat either spoon first. But I ate the Uni First.
1.) Sip chilled sake.
2.) Eat Spoon 1.
3.) Sip chilled sake.
4.) Eat Spoon 2.
5.) Sip chilled sake.
