* Toro sushi - Spain, Blue fin tuna fat belly $16 (4.5 of 5) Oh. I guess I would call this the fillet mignon of tuna. The marblization was amazing and it was really soft. $16 is a little expensive, but I guess it was worth the splurge. Chomp Chomp Chomp!
*Spider roll large and portion $13 (4.5 of 5) Oh. So huge spider crab. I thought this was one of the better spider rolls I have had. Chomp Chomp Chomp! Big and tasty!
* Beef tataki $13 (3 of 5) Chilled, sliced shoulder tender loin with apple-ginger soy. Fresh and yummy. But a little more acidic than I would like. I guess I didn't favor apple-ginger soy. I rather have ponzu sauce. 
* Sashimi combo 12 pc $24 (4 of 5) Maguro, Hamachi, Salmon, White - fish 3pcs each. But I don't like white fish. And the waitress was kind enough to allow replacement. So we had extra salmon slices.  
* Kumamoto Oysters on the half shell 2pc $5 (4 of 5) Fresh.

I had a really good time at this place. Food was good. Place was clean and slightly dim for intimate romantic eating. I would go back and take a small group of friends there. I don't think this place is good for large groups.
author: Janice T.

description:
Found this gem on Yelp while in town for business. AWESOME!

Take your time looking for it; because, it's very easy to miss and the parking is HORRID.  But, in the end you will be glad you went.

Their california rolls, which are so much more flavorful than other places, use real crab. I rarely ever get CA rolls, but for some reason I did that night and I am glad.

All their sashimi melted in my mouth and was uber fresh.

Decor was simple and tasteful.  Not some Ikea decked out spot that you would see in LA on every corner.

Staff was quick, polite, and accurate...what more can you ask for?  Check out Koo...it's mui bueno.
author: Josh A.

description:
I liked the fact that it is Japanese owned and run. The staff was nice. 
We were pleasantly surprised by the happy hour til 7pm. That made it worth it to me. 
The sushi was good but not the best I've ever had. I enjoyed the handrolls more. ESP the scallops dynamite. Did not really care for the r&r which is the unagi. 
Would go back but only for happy hour.
author: kiomi k.

description:
I've been in SF for 3 weeks for work (this is starting week 3), I've visited Koo twice and plan to once more before I leave.

There's not a ton I can add that has not already been said, but I will reiterate the highlights and add what I can that's new:

Fresh wasabi, this is great.  My preference is to sit at the sushi bar and have the sushi chef simply use this instead for my sushi (I like it traditional style on the inside and typically don't season after the chef).

The Spoonful of Happiness is exactly what it claims to be.  I typically stick with plain nigiri or sashimi, but the chef said on my second visit I needed to try it.  He was right.

They have a great selection of fish, some local and some deep-sea Japanese ones too, their daily catch has yet to disappoint.  And the quality is excellent, very fresh, good sized pieces, and the right amount of rice.

While there I also tried Yebisu, a rice beer.  This was a bit flat and dry, but I mean flat in a good way.  If you have ever tried Boddingtons, you'll understand.  It's not as flat as that, but it's reminiscent.

The service was also very good, my water and hot tea were never empty, the chef was very prompt with my orders, and they called me a cab at the end of each evening.

If you love sushi and want a great experience in SF, go to Koo.
author: Mark G.

description:
Look, I don't know what's wrong with the other six people that I was with, but my dad was the only other person that was game to try the Spoonful of Happiness. 

It was about $11, and it comes in a spoon. Believe me, it isn't often that Happiness is as easily obtained. When it is, you take it. That's my advice to you. Other things I'd advise you eat while at Koo:

The Godzilla Tofu.
The Kamikaze and Tokyo Crunch rolls.
The Sour Green Beans.
The Miso Marinated Black Cod (I would drink this broth).

Everything was served with a smile. I'm assuming because they dipped into the Happiness in the back.
author: Peter D.

description:
ok
That's about it. The service was good. The place wasn't too crowded. The fish was average. The sushi was decently cut. The prices were expensive. It wasn't extraordinary, it wasn't terribly underwhelming. Can't say the place is unique or distinguishable. There are definitely better places and worst places in the city to have sushi. For the high prices, I did expect a lot more.
author: Naomi K.

description:
Three words:  Spoonful of happiness.  Three more words:  Just do it.

This place exceeded my expectations and is definitely at the top of my list of favorite sushi bars.  The fish was so fresh and delicious; the sake was bomb... what a great date night.  The restaurant is pretty small and I imagine the place gets packed, so I recommend reservations.
author: Crystal R.

description: I been here twice.. so far every year when we make our trip out to San Fran. They have a very good menu and they have a great happy hour menu. The sushi is always fresh and everyone must try the spoonful of happiness!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! This is the one thing that brings me back to this place.
author: Ngoc C.

description:
Heard about this place from a friend and was not disappointed.  Nothing against Korean or Chinese run sushi places, but I definitely prefer a sushi place run by Japanese.  

The fish quality was quite good, reasonable prices, good service, very nice meal.
author: Greg N.

description:
This place is overrated :/ 

Food is mediocre and for the price you pay it should definitely taste better.

I've ordered sushi rolls and cooked food here and I wasn't impressed by any of it.

Service here is also pretty blah. I'd recommend going elsewhere for sushi.
author: P M.

description:
It's difficult to find really good sushi in the US. Most places serve fish on bland rice and call it a day. It's a pleasure to find a place that takes pride in an experience. Koo's sushi chefs pay attention to every aspect of sushi. They're inventive while staying true to tradition. My favorite is the spoonful of happiness. It truly was happiness dancing in my mouth. The only downside is that there are only two spoons. I did my best to savor the bite as long as possible but alas I had to order a second helping. 

I can't wait to be back for another bite.
author: Steve L.

description:
Came here with a friend for dinner on a Sunday night. Our reservation was at 7pm and it was the perfect night for a quiet dinner. It was not overly crowded nor it was empty. About half an hour into dinner, more and more people showed up. Even then it was not too noisy. They had a good selection menu, nothing too over whelming. My friend did most of the ordering and I am glad he had good taste. I really like what he ordered. What I enjoyed most was the Toro, obviously, it was so buttery. It melted on my tongue leaving a taste that I want to savor.

Originally I want to try this place because of the Spoonful of happiness, but I realized it had uni in it and I am not a fan. However, all the other fishes we tried was delicious and most importantly fresh. 

Will have to come back to try other things on their menu.
author: Tiffany C.

description: Some of the best Japanese I've had in SF. Had: agadashi tofu, eggplant ganpaku (sp) lion king roll.
author: Charles D.

description: Good selection on the menu. I like they have a happy hour menu. Atmosphere and quality of the food is good, but compared to others could be fresher. Overall, good.
author: X P.

description: Excellent sushi that is fresh and innovative. I highly recommend the spoonful of happiness to start and then going with whatever is on the fresh daily menu. You really can't go wrong with anything here. It isn't cheap but you are getting what you pay for -- high quality sushi experience.
author: Victor W.

description: One of the better places in the city for sushi. If you love sushi do not skip this place!
author: Melanie M.

description:
3.5 stars

This place was pretty good! But I didn't think it was anything terribly special, to be honest.

I had the spoonful of happiness and that was pretty great. I really enjoyed the different flavors and the order you have to eat things. It made a lot of sense and the dish felt very thoughtful.

The nigiri was good. Can't complain about that. I didn't like the miso cod, though. I thought it was kind of... bland. 

The ambiance is nice here. It's like half a level up from casual. Not bad!! Not sure if I would return, though.
author: Jade R.

description:
I have to give this place 5 stars simply because of the amazing food that they serve here. I felt a little bit misguided by Yelp at first because when I arrived here, it looked very little like the picturesque first view on Yelp but I settled in anyway and figured this many people can't be wrong.

I suppose I was expecting it to be a little nicer, or a little shabbier because usually really great sushi places are either fancy or really hole in the wall. This place was sort of an inbetween. The crowd definitely threw me off as well since most of the very excellent sushi spots I've been to you seldom see folks of non-Asian descent. (I hope this doesn't offend anyone :) it's just an observation). I had similar negative feelings as nobu k. had mentioned due to the decor as well.

Either way, I was wrong on so many accounts on this place because it was absolutely delicious! Before I walked in, I told the bf I was so hungry I wanted to order everything on the menu. I actually did! The spoonful of happiness was definitely well worth it, even at $11 bucks a serving because they were well made and the flavors coordinated with one another very well. 

We ordered all of their fresh catches of the day and snuck in a few favorites of ours like the marinated sea bass and some hand rolls. It was all so fresh, delicious and good! The bill reflected our gluttony but I don't think we regretted it at all. I actually think I like this place a bit better than Sushi Sam's in San Mateo because they don't sauce everything, in fact they don't really sauce anything so you can truly taste what the fish is supposed to be like. Love love love, love. Cannot say enough good things about this place if you're a raw fish lover!
author: Lorrie M.

description:
THE GOODS:
- crawfish handroll (happy hour and tasty)
- hamachi & avocado handroll (happy hour)
- hotate nigiri (fresh)

THE BADS:
- maguro nigiri (past its prime and ugh! there's nothing worse than eating raw fish where you can taste the fishiness --YUCK!)
- saba nigiri (borderline fishy taste)
- godzilla tofu (happy hour and not worth the happy hour price. it's those chinese fried tofu that you can get at ranch 99 smothered in some miso sauce --flat, unappealing and nothing japanese about it!)
- the service (while the service was friendly, the waitress was slow and forgetful)
- famlies with small children seated on all four corners of the restaurant, i feel like i was at pee wee's playhouse.

THE AVERAGE:
- hamachi nigiri (meh, couldn't taste the freshness but it didn't taste old either)

What's all the fuss about?!
author: Anne S.

description: Disappointed and over priced. The rice for nigiri is muddy and doesn't use vinegar. The fish is not well prepared to have good flavor. The air is full of oil smell. I am allergic to the air and running nose all the time.
author: Xuejun X.

description:
Super cute environment with great food! 

Get there early because there's little to no wait when they first open. Over the course of the night though, it gets super packed.

What everyone else has said. Spoonful of Happiness is life. Great service. Everything is fresh. Nom nom nom.
author: Yanni L.

description: Pricey was sooo good! So fresh and flavorful! Came here with some friends. Will definitely be back!!!
author: Thomas C.

description: Authentic and delicious sushi. The mood was very warm and romantic making it a great place for a date
author: Sammy S.

description:
My first time trekking out to the Sunset but it was totally worth it!

First impression was that there was a small and crowded sushi bar, but the main dining area was very roomy. The decor is modern, but the beams in the ceiling reminded me of Japan. Lighting was a sultry low, so this is a great place for a date if you can get one of the booths (tables are not as private).

As other reviewers have highlighted, the Spoonful of Happiness is a must. One spoon is uni, a quail egg, tobiko, and ponzu. This was amazing! You taste the uni first, because it's sweet and rich and just all around delicious. Then you taste the egg, which is rich and creamy and, well, eggy. The crunchy tobiko is a great addition to the smooth textures of the uni and egg. Ponzu adds slight acidity and saltiness to balance the sweet. I didn't have the other spoon, which was monkfish liver, sea bream, truffle oil, and ponzu. (I have bad experiences with monkfish liver.) But judging by the ingredients, I'd say the textures and flavors are very well balanced too. Great way to start off the meal!

We also got the black cod, which comes in a bowl with dashi, tofu, and bok choy. This dish has never been presented to me in a broth, it's always on a plate with some grated daikon. I didn't mind the dashi, but hoped it didn't make the fish too soggy. Although it wasn't the best preparation of miso black cod I've ever had, it was pretty good. The fish was fresh (rule #1) and it wasn't overcooked (rule #2). The result is buttery sweet flaky goodness!

Koo has a wide selection of sushi and crazy rolls. We didn't opt for any of the crazy stuff, but stuck with the spicy tuna instead. It was one of the best spicy tuna rolls I've ever had: chunky pieces of tuna, spicy mayo was not too spicy, and I liked the nice addition of a leaf of lettuce.

Definitely would come back to try some of the crazy rolls and fresh sushi!
author: Sherry L.

description:
Overpriced. Overrated. 

I had a great time because I came for Valentine's Day. However, the food is nothing to talk about. I'm getting tired of going to expensive sushi spots that like to hike up prices because they think they can.
author: Catherine W.

description: Spoonfuls of happiness x 100 please! Ugh, heaven in my mouth. Luckily we had reservations because there was a bit of wait. If there is one thing you should know about me, it's that I LOVE Japanese food. I can't ever get tired of eating it. Koo serves fresh sashimi individually and in their sushi rolls. Salmon is my favorite fish and definitely had fresh ones here! They do not serve your typical-sauce-overdosed-American-type-of-sushi-rolls so beware. Only authentic Japanese restaurants serve simple rolls. I can't wait to make a trip back soon!
author: Laura T.

description:
Solid spot.

The bullet points:
-friendly, good service
-really tasty rolls (I was pleasantly surprised by the deep fried asparagus)
-quality fish
author: Rachel R.

description:
This is definitely one of the better sushi restaurants in San Francisco. I have been here twice and left pleased both times and I am not a huge fan of Sushi. The location is convenient to get to with easy parking and plenty of transportation options. The service is very good and the staff is friendly. The fish is fresh and there are plenty of options, all at a very reasonable price.

There are tons of options on the menu and plenty of specials to choose from as well. My wife's favorite is the Spoonful of Happiness, but I am not a huge fan - probably the texture. Everything else I have had here is worth reordering though. I will definitely return for a third time.
author: Frank J.

description:
Love love love! For the past year, I've not only enjoyed Japanese cuisine, but I've actually been craving it on a routine basis. I've been in search for a place with fresh sashimi, high quality sushi, and simple yet flavorful hot dishes. 

The salmon toro and hamachi toro were melt-in-your-mouth yummy. Of note, the sashimi servings were pretty tiny - a little smaller than at other restaurants such as Ebisu. The spicy tuna roll was amazing - the tuna was pretty generous. I have a liking for grilled eggplant, and this hot dish did not disappoint. The slightly sweetened miso sauce didn't mask the flavor of the eggplant. 

The restaurant is fairly small. It is dimly lit and has a very intimate feeling. Seating at the sushi bar is quite limited. My friend and I were in the dining room, and I felt like we could have a quiet conversation.

Dishes were quickly served and the waiters were pretty attentive. This restaurant is conveniently located close to me, so I'll definitely be a frequent customer.
author: Tiffany L.

description:
The sushi here is great, albeit expensive. I got the Rock'n'Roll and the Spider roll. Both were delicious. Both were small.

Also, it took a very long time to get our food. I would say most of the time spent at Koo was spent waiting for food. Our waitresses were really attentive to our drinks, but that food took forever. 

Basically, it's good, but not worth the wait.
author: Sam D.

description: Spoonful of happiness, Toro Sushi, Uni, flying kamikaze, spicy tuna crunch we're all good. Unfortunately, that's it for my tummy, thus, my comment is limited to sushi and rolls.
author: Richard C.

description:
Last night a friend and I went here around 6:30 without a reservation.  The hostess was extremely reluctant to seat us even though there were several empty tables.  We ordered as soon as we sat down and ate efficiently.  At around 8Pm we paid our bill and then sat  for 1-2 more minutes to finish our conversation.  At that point the hostess came over to our table and told us it was time to leave since people were waiting.  

Although the food was good, there are many excellent Japanese restaurants in San Francisco that treat their customers with respect.  No reason to EVER go back.
author: susan f.

description:
GOOD SERVICE.  GOOD SUSHI. GOOD JAPANESE AUTHENTICITY.  

Koo has the usual Sushi bar with several seats in front, and then has a separate fairly large dining room (for a sushi restaurant, but not in general).  In many times in larger Sushi restaurants like this the quality goes down, but not at Koo.  Koo is Japanese owned.  The Sushi Chef and owner Kiyoshi Hayakawa who works with 2 assistants at the Sushi bar, and a friendly Japanese woman (I believe Kiyoshi's wife) who runs the dining room along with some assistants to serve the customers.

I asked the waitress if I can order Omakase.  She hesitated for a moment, not because she didn't know what I was talking about, but because she was surprised I knew what that means, so she asked if I would like Sashimi or Nigiri, and I said Nigiri, and she served me 8 pieces (every piece of Nigiri with a different type of sashimi) MORE FISH VARIETY.  JUST THE WAY I LIKE IT!  Then I ordered Tekka Maki and Tamago for my final piece, and the waitress was telling me how impressed was with my knowledge and choices.

SO IF YOU'RE IN THE INNER SUNSET DISTRICT LOOKING FOR A GOOD SPACIOUS SUSHI RESTAURANT WITH AUTHENTIC JAPANESE SUSHI AND SPECIALTY ROLLS THEN KOO IS THE PLACE FOR YOU!
author: Rudi A.

description:
Koo was not cool

Food is way below expectations, especially for a high rating place like this with $$$ sign.  

Spoonful of happiness $ 12 was probably the highlight of the entire meal.  

Sashimi combo was ok- $24  The albacore has no flavor.  Salmon was cut into tiny pieces.   

Amaebi was good but the fried shrimp heads came out warm and borderline burnt.  

Special catch of the day

Toro -$14 was decent 
Red snapper -$10 ok 

Overall the food was not worth it.  Spent over $100 for 2 + 1 child (nothing for kids he only had California roll)  & left hungry.  

The portion + price + quality + long wait, just go somewhere else.
author: Anna W.

description:
I seriously found a little piece of heaven at Sushi Koo and still have dreams about my eating experience here. Ate here as a pat on the back for landing a job recently and I might have spoiled myself too much by coming here to eat ;)... no regrets. 

We started our meal with "spoonful of happiness". Thinking about starters? Don't think just do it. Order it now. Are you sitting at Koo right now and already put in your orders? ORDER IT NOW. The spoonful is actually 2 spoons of deliciousness served with a shot of chilled sake. Two amazing and distinct flavors that complement the sake well. There are no words to describe this other than what is on the menu... happiness :)

Oysters were another little bite of happiness. Good addition to our meal! 

We also had a salmon grilled (on the seasonal menu... take a look at it!) Most amazing little piece of grilled fish I have probably ever had in my life. The skin was crispy and just right. It was cooked to perfection... no dry nothing tasting fish here! 

For sushi we also tried the Best Roll and Flying Kamikaze. Great. Fresh. I am always a fan of garlic or slices of lemon on my sushi.

This place does get a little pricey but honestly for the flavor it is something you have to try. MAKE RESERVATIONS. We had made the mistake before of trying to step foot in here on a Friday night without reservations and was not successful.

Cannot wait for the next time I can spoil myself! :) 

Tip: Keep the menu around you... you're going to want it :)
author: Tracy Joy K.

description:
Three words... "Spoonful of Happiness"

Run, don't walk, to Koo and try this dish. It is simply amazing. The flavors of the ingredients, the sake, they all combine to produce one of the best single dishes I have had in quite a while.

Damn you Yelp, now I am craving it again. I know where I am going tonight!
author: Yum N.

description:
The two star rating has to do partly with a matter of expectation (would give it a 2.5). I searched on yelp for the top sushi places in some of the surrounding neighborhoods near where I live and this was the top result. The sushi was definitely below expectations.

The location is just outside of the main Inner Sunset restaurant area, so a little bit out of the way and fun of the rest of the neighborhood. When I got there I was a little disappointed to see the sushi bar awkwardly removed from the rest of the seating.

The server took us to the main dining side and sat the two of us in between two other groups when there were plenty of other open tables. The tables are pretty squished together on the far wall.

Ordering the food was find, our server was nice and very timely; service was definitely the highlight of the meal.

The food itself was only OK. There was a limited number of rolls and none of the three we tried were stellar as the reviews suggested. The Best Roll for example, was not very good. The Dynamite Roll also was nothing special, just hard to eat. The best was their Spicy Tuna Roll, which was very unconventional for a STR.

And the scallops two ways was overpriced and not very flavorful.

Food:
Overall, the portions were small, overpriced, and only average (some even below average) sushi. Spent ~$70 for two people and were still hungry afterwards.

Environment:
The ambiance was not too great.

Service:
The service was good.

Overall:
Way below expectations. Overrated.
author: Peter M.

description:
17-December, Monday:
Personal and unpretentious Koo specializes in unique sushi preparations with modern flairs such as the Spoonful of Happiness: A bit of uni (sea uchin), a quail egg, tobiko, and ankimo (monkfish liver) are wrapped in whitefish, ponzu, truffle oil, and a shot of chilled sake.

As complicated as it sounds, it is simply delicious.
Also a great place for takeout.
author: Ty T.

description:
Spoonful of Happiness!  If only you were closer, I'd want to have you every week!

Koo is one of my favorite sushi restaurants in SF, hands down.  I love sitting at the sushi bar and trying all the fresh fish they have to provide.  This is not a place to go if you're tight on cash, let me tell you.  Easily, for a party of 2, we can rack up a bill of $150-200 including a bottle of sake.

When I feel like splurging and/or having great sushi, Koo is always a place I'll trek out to.

Great intimate date spot! *****
author: FrancEs K.

description:
First time for everything :)

Kiiiiiiiiiiind of expensive. At least the quality is good.... but common. 2 teeny tiny tacos for 9 dollars?!???!?!?!?! Thats freakin expensive.

This place is great.... but there are alot of other AMAZING sushi spots that actually source their fish using Monterey Seafood Guide, and are ALOT cheaper. 

Conclusion: Probably wont come back here. It is delicious, but too expensive for my tummy.
author: Julia D.

description: We were a group of 9 all together, 2 kids below 5 years old who liked the julienned daikon, we requested to give us a bowl and our order for the little girl was denied! It was so appalling to think that my niece is a regular customer"They only give the daikon with sashimi order". Our bill totaled $580.00 and they denied the little girl of the pathetic daikon noodles. I will never again set foot in this restaurant, ever!!!!! I requested for extra lemon and they gave me another 2 small slivers of the pathetic lemon. They are very STINGY!!!!
author: Demetria D.

description:
Staff here is really anal and made us a party of 5 sit in a table for four and with one sticking out right outside of the kitchen where the waitresses are running in and out like chickens without heads bumping into me many times- are they trying to get me to get up and dance with them?
Food is ok.  This Japanese restaurant does not serve udons nor unagi-don (unaju).
author: Troy M.

description: Here is a beautiful hole in the wall Japanese that sets a high bar for cuisine excellence. The sushi features fresh off the docks quality, with a special focus on Japanese species. The king crab hand roll and the Tokyo Crunch roll are simply superb. The more interesting side of the menu includes a grilled octopus salad, which is perfectly cooked, subtle not chewy.
author: Richard B.

description:
Two spoonfuls of Happiness, of course!

Sit by the bar - friendly, informative and fun to watch. Top notch edibles.
author: Vina A.

description:
I'm not a sushi guy. I'm not. As far as I'm concerned I can  munch on a slim jim and get more protein than I would get from the average sushi place. After going to the DeYoung on a Friday night our friends recommended we go to Koo. I'll admit that I was very hesitant, but I've never been one to make the whole group go somewhere else because I dislike a particular type of food. 

The sushi here was AMAZING. This is probably the 4th sushi place I have ever been to in my life. I had been to two other expensive sushi places on dates, and this place was far better. 

Being a sushi-phobe I started with the California roll and thought it was pretty amazing. 

My friends convinced me to step away from the safe choice and I progressed to the shrimp tempura. I'm not one for shrimp, but since it was breaded it was very tasty. My favorite roll had to be "The best" roll. It was aptly named. 

The ambiance was very clean and modern. It seemed like a quiet place which we disturbed with our antics, but so is life. 

The service was good and the food was affordable. 

I will definitely be coming back.
author: Carlos A.

description: Really authentic Japanese cuisine, the Uni imported from japan is incredible!!!
author: Linxuan L.

description:
This is probably my favorite sushi restaurants. Been here a couple of times and everything we've ordered were always good. You HAVE TO try Spoonful of Happiness. I would totally order two orders for myself, but I need to try other things on the menu!.. One day, I'm going to do it, two orders, maybe THREE!! 

There is really not too many bad things to say about this place. Good atmosphere, it's clean, nice friendly service. We usually make reservations so no waiting. Fish always fresh and rolls/ nigiri always tasty. One time, my gf and I sat at this weird corner table that they had. I was facing the walls and my gf was facing the window. I don't know, I guess that spot only allows for that type of seating.. 

Like most restaurants around the 9th/ Irving area, parking's a b*tch, but don't let that ruin your experience eating here!!
author: Roger N.

description:
I visited here with my friend on a Thursday night. We just made our decision coming here this afternoon and had no problem making reservation. Anyway, though we didn't have to wait in line, the food here was really good. 

We ordered many dishes, like:
Sashimi combo
Beef tataki:
Two way scallop
Urchin nigiri, spanish mackerel nigiri, water eel nigiri
Yellowtail& avocado temaki, dynamite temaki

My friend and I love all the dishes we had here, the sashimi taste good. The two way scallop is pretty interesting and creative, there are four scallops, two with lemon sauce, other two on the beets, both of the two flavors are new adventures for me. The nigiri there are good, too! I love their eel nigiri so much since the eel served warm and very tender. In addition, I love the dynamite temaki, I suggest everyone add a quail egg on it! The dynamite temaki was served with baked scallop and wasabi, but the quail egg mix with wasabi and made me feel the flavor of wasabi was not too strong. I would recommend people coming here to enjoy a nice dinner!
author: Jia-Ying X.

description:
Always a delight for fresh sashimi. Been going here for years. 

Pros:
-Spoonful of happiness ( price went up to $12; I remember when it was $10, but still delicious) JUST DO IT like everyone says (trust me)
-service is excellence ( the owners are the chef and usually the wife is the hostess; very sweet)
-sashimi is very fresh! 
-free parking in front ( if you can find it) or around the restaurant
-takes reservations for parties of 2! 
-great date spot

Cons
-on the pricier side, but well worth it 
-not a lot of rolls; focused more on fresh catches
author: Annie L.

description:
Spoonful of Happiness is a must try!  I was craving for the uni and quail egg, but the ankimo somewhat tasted better to me.  It also came with a shot of sake to cleanse your palettes, which definitely complemented the two very well!

Sashimi combo - Suuuuper fresh!  The tuna was dark red, and the hamachi was so so creamy!!! The Negi Toro roll was a bit plain, but you can totally taste the fattiness of the fish!  We also had the chef recommend the eel and hamachi roll, but I was a bit disappointed.  It didn't turn out the way I imagined it to be or tasted like, but I could taste the freshness and warmth of the eel!  Nomssss.
author: Nancy S.

description:
Having never been here, I'm surprised I missed out on what a gem we had in this location.  They've got great stuff here!   I mean, maybe I had it bookmarked for the last 5 years, but finally did it take a friend's birthday for me to make the move to eat here. 

The menu is innovative and the waitress was helpful in helping us decide what to get.  

-Spoonful of Happiness with uni and quail and then ankimo with toro - GET IT.  if you love uni like I do, you'll love this.  Beats out Kabuto easily.
-Grilled baby octopus salad - delicious and the baby octopus were meaty and fresh tasting.
-Tempura Wakasagi curry-salt - interesting but i probably should have went with the regular tempura.  It's certainly nice to try especially with the curry touch, but smelt tends to get less interesting after the 2nd one.
-Tuna and Salmon Tartar with spicy guacamole and shrimp chips - easily a favorite
-Flying Kamikaze - with spicy tuna and asparagus wrapped with albacore and topped with garlic ponzu, delicious
-O Toro Nigiri - great and buttery as expected with the temperature served perfectly
-Hamachi Toro - probably not as good as the o toro, so get this before the toro.  
-Baby Bream - It's just like the adult bream (Snapper) but sweeter.
author: Vincent K.

description: Great sushi! That spoonful of happiness rocked! It was really good. WISH THEY WERE OPEN FOR LUNCH!
author: Andrew K.

description:
Great food quality with nice environment. A good place for a treat. 
Recommended : a spoonful of happiness 
Toro, amaebi and uni 
Azteca roll
author: Coco S.

description:
The food was amazing, the price is reasonable and there was absolutely no wait!  

This restaurant is located further out than what I'm use to but it was totally worth it!  I started out with the Japanese oysters and Spoonful of Happiness and both were orgasmically delicious.  I don't think I've ever had anything that good in my life.  Next, I got the dynamite hand roll which was also yummy and some sashimi (very fresh and big cuts).  My boyfriend and I ordered the Aztec roll and it was good but not great.  I wasn't a big fan of the main fish they used. My boyfriend and I came here with another couple and it was a lovely experience.  They took reservations, we didn't have to wait to get seated and the place wasn't too loud so we could actually hear each other and have a conversation. 

 I wish I lived in San Francisco because I would definitely be a regular here.
author: Julia P.

description:
I took my BF here for date night and was surprised I hadn't taken him here sooner.  We got lucky and got seated at the bar with the rest of the restaurant being full and we also didn't have a reservation.  And we also found parking right away.  Double score!

We split the Spoonful of Happiness.  I gave him the white fish truffle spoon since I knew he wasn't big on the "egg" aspect of the uni spoon.  I loved mine and he also loved his too.  Next we were on the fence about the calamari but got it anyways.  The dipping salsa was what carried the dish.  The calamari was just OK.  The hamachi and maguro nigiri were super fresh.  Next came the Best Roll, OMG, this was so good!  The combination of the crunch from the tempura asparagus, the salmon I was in heaven.  And the key to this roll is the THINLY sliced lemon on top.  Sometimes they're cut too thick and becomes a little overwhelming.  The black cod, my favorite dish here, came last.  It was just as good as the first time I had it.  Perfection.

Koo has always been one of my favorite sushi restaurants in SF.  But my bf just claimed this was the best sushi experience he's had in a long time.  5 stars!
author: Rosalind S.

description:
WE LOVE KOO!
We can always get a table, the spoonful of happiness is my favorite thing on earth and they are delightful. Plus the sushi is amazing, especially the sea urchin.
yum!
author: Ms S.

description: 5 star price for 1 star food, service and atmosphere. Walked in and been told its 40 min wait. No surprise we been seated within minutes, places like that pretend to be overrated. Enough said, quality of food, atmosphere and everything in between is standard for a regular sushi place. 30 min wait for a smallest roll ever. NEVER coming back. Feel ripped off and hungry ;(
author: Yana B.

description: This place has good quality rolls I was not impressed with the tuna sashimi I have had much better.
author: Peter T.

description: Went with friends, two of which had stomach problems after eating the uni. Very small cuts of fish and dry. Very over priced  uni nigiri $14. The rolls were good, but also small. The pictures posted here are nothing like what we received. Perhaps we got an off night, Saturday?
author: Derk L.

description:
Came here to celebrate my birthday expecting wonderful things and got a mediocre sushi and dining experience for $$$!  

Going on everyone's recommendations, ordered as a starter the Spoonful of Happiness and it was really good. The name describes it to a T.  Delightful! I wished I had just had three orders of the Spoonful of Happiness then left! 

We then had a large number or sashimi/sushi orders, and was really disappointed by Koo.

Dessert was bad, the Mt. Fuji is apparently "Made fresh in our kitchen" but it seemed like a microwaved desert, and the Mochi, well I've tasted better.

It is overpriced for the quality of fish and dishes here.  By all means stop by, try the Spoonful of Happiness, then if you wish to remain happy.... leave and hit up another sushi joint to maintain that smile!! :)
author: Angela D.

description:
Came here for Valentine's day with the bf. It was a great place- nice ambiance, interesting menu items, and good service. I recommend the lychee sake if you like fruity sake. It tastes like lychee juice... so yummy!

Our favorite thing we ordered was the salmon and tuna tartare served on top of guacamole, with shrimp chips on the side. It was like the Asian version of chips and dip!

We also tried oysters and they were the tiniest oysters I had ever seen (see photo and compare to size of lemon!)

Spoonfuls of happiness were interesting.. they come with a glass of sake, and you are instructed to eat it in the order of sake, spoon, sake, spoon. I really enjoyed the spoon with the uni and quail egg, but the other one was only so-so.

We tried Azteca roll and Best roll... both were okay, but nothing spectacular.

Lastly, we were both a fan of the softshell crawfish handroll. It was kind of like a spider handroll, but crunchier!

Overall, I'd probably give this place 3.5 stars. Perhaps slightly above average for its price range. Of all the sushi places in sf, I'd probably rather go try a new one than return here... and it definitely doesn't beat out Kabuto as my favorite sushi place in sf!
author: Kavita S.

description:
Can't go wrong coming to Koo for happy hour. $5 sake bottles, great hand rolls at $4 each, and almost anything you try will be above average in quality. 

Artichokes - cooked tender with a very dipping sauce
Stuffed Jalapenos - a little small, but the hamachi filling was yum
Spoonful of Happiness - i think this changed since the last time I was there, but the monk fish liver and the uni paired with the sake was unique and tasty.
Chicken Teriyaki - not over-cooked has many serve, tender and yum
Tempura  Shrimp - came out piping hot, and its what you'd expect for tempura shrimp
R&R Handroll - substantive and made one by one (the unagi isn't just sitting and wrapped, they cook it a serving at a time)
Hamachi Handroll - sashimi size serving (two-three pieces in it)
Salmon Handroll - see hamachi
Fish quality was good (on a Thursday)
House hot sake - easy to drink, and didn't taste like a std cheap house sake
Tamago - slightly sweet, as good as it gets
Uni - Santa Barbara - very well priced, and good, according to my wife.

All in all, I'd come back here any day of the week.
author: Raymond H.

description: The spoonful of happiness really is as it's named.  I've ordered it every time I've been here.  The sushi is always fresh and service is friendly.  The location is a bit out of the way, but the quality of the sushi is worth the extra drive.
author: Debbie L.

description:
We went in Friday night and needed a reservation at 8 to be seated

The waitstaff was incredibly kind, personable, attentive without being overbearing.

We had a mixture of sushi rolls - all of which were excellent and fresh

The Black cod was fantastic and recommend as a must-try for anyone who comes here!
author: Shaft S.

description:
SUSHI in der Hafenstadt San Francisco ist eigentlich kein Problem, allerdings sind die meisten Läden in Down Town  touristisch recht überlaufen. Auf der Suche nach etwas Besonderen  hatte es mich ins KOO verschlagen. Das KOO liegt abseits der normalen Touristen Ströme. Man sitzt in der Nähe des Golden Gate Park entweder an Tischen im kleinen Raum oder nutzt (so wie ich) einen der 6 Plätze an der SUSHI Bar. Hier kann man die 3 SUSHI Meister bei der Arbeit beobachten - und das macht Spass! Die Auswahl und Kreativität ist hoch , so auch der - der durchaus berechtigte - Preis. 

Neben einer Standard Karte gibt es im KOO täglich nicht ganz alltägliche   Empfehlungen. Wie mir der SUSHI Cheff Meister berichtete, richtet sich das nach aktuellen Angeboten, wo bei der Fisch aus Japan kommt, also nicht viel älter als 8 Stunden ist. Damit ist auch klar, dass SUSHI ist "not frozen" - im Innland kaum zu bekommen. 

Ich bin dann zusammen mit einem ASHAI, das frisch gezapft wird, diversen NIGIRI,s bei einen einem erstklassigen Tempura hängen geblieben. 

Das Ambiente ist authentisch und strahlt zusammen mit dem überaus freundlichen Personal Ruhe aus. Nach einem harten Arbeitstag ein willkommener Ausklang.  Ich komme wieder !
author: Torsten P.

description: Due to the sweet ass reviews, I was thinking this place would come through with some super sashimi.  Sadly, the sashimi was tasteless and I could tell had been frozen.  Maybe the rolls are better but the sashimi sucked. Sorry koo.
author: Chelsey G.

description:
Never have I left a restaurant where a whole party of 8 left upset! 

Did you know?! It was a $20pp minimum and mandatory 18% tip for bad service?! Think twice before you come here!! 

Our waitress took our order, didn't check up on us, dropped our food down and didn't even tell us which roll was what?! We were also was missing a roll, but she kept stating we received it. Keep in mind there was a language barrier. She kept saying " do you understand" I told her "no I do not understand and just give me the check". 

You would think a 4 star rated yelp restaurant would have computerized checks , so you can actually see the prices and what they were charging. NO, it was all hand written like a Chinese restaurant not knowing what you are getting charged for. Sashimi didn't have prices listed on the menu,.. and the waitress kept saying "market price, market price."  

Never come with a big party, cause 18% tip is automatically included. That means even if they serve you or not, the waitress still gets the tip,.. For providing no SERVICE! When our bill came , they had automatically added tip.  The table all agreed that the waitress does not deserve a $38tip. We were nice enough to leave a $30 TIP. Tip is optional , NOT MANDATORY.  

As we left the restaurant, the women owner chased after us, stated we were short $8 and had to pay her.  We told her straight up that her waitress deserves NO tip and should be happy we even left a $30 TIP for NO SERVICE. 

Horrible horrible! Will not be back nor recommend this cheating scamming Japanese restaurant to anyone!!  It's Like eating at a restaurant and getting hit with hidden fees?! We all still left wondering,. WTH?! was that extra 10-20 that was charged on our bill.   

I will take my money elsewhere to an HONEST RESTAURANT!! Foodies DO NOT, DO NOT come here!!!!
author: Chanel L.

description:
Okay so four stars is a little generous but I thought three would be unfair.

Unfortunately the first impression was not the best - the hostess asked if we had a reservation - we did not but we got there right when they opened so I didn't think it was necessary - so she said you can sit at a table as long as you are done by 7pm. Okay, now I feel rushed. But we took our timely chances (as it was only 5:30pm).

The rest of the service was spot on, very on top of clearing plates and filling water/tea and polite. Everything was pretty tasty -  all the nigri we had, the gomae and peppered octopus salad were memorable. I must say the salmon nigri was theee freshest I've had. I even ordered more, something I rarely do. That is what made this experience worth the price tag (very high) and the B-list treatment at the door. 

Skip the eggplant (from the grill) - very oily and you don't get much. The price being as steep as it was (no alcohol purchased either) I feel like I can get more for my money at other spots. But like I said - the salmon was simply to the best I've ever had and thus why this spot has gotten four stars from me.
author: S. M.

description:
I'm so glad I finally got to go to Koo after I had bookmarked it more than 2 years ago!

Everything we ordered was delicious:

Appetizer: Grilled eggplant - Really flavorful and tender.

Sashimi: Copper river king salmon and hamachi toro - Both super fresh and basically melted in my mouth.

Sushi rolls: Spicy tuna and Tokyo crunch - Spicy tuna had a nice kick and was a pretty generous portion. The Tokyo crunch was a great combination of hamachi/unagi/cucumber with spicky tenkasu on top.

Miso black cod: A must. Super tender, not too salty, and great with the fried tofu and baby bok choy. Easy to split.

The restaurant is fairly small and had good ambiance. Service was great and we were able to call ahead and get a reservation fairly easily. All our dishes came out at just the right pace and the additional roll we added came out quickly.

I'll definitely be back here again, hopefully sometime soon. :P
author: Kenny J.

description:
I LOVE KOO!

It has become the neighborhood go-to restaurant when my bf & I are in the mood for some good sushi :) Kind of on the expensive side to go often, so try to take advantage of the happy hour specials ($4 handrolls, $5 small plates).

Favorites include:
*spicy tuna handroll
*salmon & avocado handroll
*best roll (basically can't go wrong with any roll they have)
*sake sashimi (and if you ask for recommendations, they are very knowledgeable!)
author: Miss H.

description:
I was pleasantly surprised at how good Koo is. I'm sort of surprised I had never heard of it before.

Great nigiri and sashimi and we had some really nice cooked plates as well.

The decor and ambiance are nice. You'd think it was too slick glancing in, but it's actually pretty tastefully done.

Good, fresh fish, friendly service, nice decor. I'll be coming back.
author: Mara S.

description:
My husband and I came for our anniversary and dinner was fabulous.  We ordered the following:

1. 2 orders of spoonful of happiness
2. Two Way Scallop
3. U2 Roll
4. Sashimi Combo
5. 2 Dynamite hand rolls
6. Mt Fuju chocolate cake

As I typed out what we had, i suddenly felt compelled to change my review from 4 to 5 stars because although it wasnt the best meal of my life, it was a damn good experience. i think our bill was close to $120, which is really reasonable for the amount of food we had.  the quality was top-notch and everything was done very creatively.
author: R A.

description:
Another review in the bucket here, but when I see a big line a few blocks away at Ebiso, it doesn't phase me, because Koo is way, way better and about the same price.

I've never had a bad meal here, and I've come in groups of all sizes. My favorite meals are always if I venture in alone and sit at the bar. You do tend to have a better experience if you are "more adventurous" by American standards and indicate your interest in the food. I always order a beer, some sashimi, and go from there (though it often ends up being $50-70..for one).

One thing I particularly love about Koo is that they have a big selection of salads and vegetable dishes. These are really hard to find at most Japanese restaurants. Their warm grilled eggplant is great, their Goma Ae salad is a staple for me (it's like, an actual serving of vegetables--spinach and asparagus), etc. I never get rolls here, except for an occasional handroll to fill me up at the end of a meal, if it was sashimi heavy, etc. It's also smart to order off the paper insert on top of the menu, primarily, as those really are the recommendations the main chef/owner would give. 

Having a bit of trust in their expertise goes a long way in making sure you have a fantastic meal.
author: Caroline C.

description:
We were NOT impressed by the Spoonful of Happiness -- it was a Spoonful of Disappointment.  The servers also cannot follow simple instructions.  I like the ambiance, but it is definitely not worth a trip across town.  I would only go again if I were in the neighborhood.

Yes, this place is authentic, but it is not that good.  The quality of fish in Ocean Blue Sushi in Sunnyvale (South Bay) is much better.  I just don't get the crazy good reviews.  Come on, San Francisco, you can do better!!  Give me a sushi restaurant with fish quality to rival Ocean Blue, and then there is Sawa Sushi also in Sunnyvale just across the street from Ocean Blue!  Eesh.
author: Evelyn K.

description:
I have never eaten so much sushi in one sitting, which is absolutely a testament to Koo. Not only is their name amazing (disclosure- that's my last name) but the stellar sushi and service creates a super supper situation. 

Following early drinks at Bourbon and Branch, we brought a visiting friend, who loves all things Japanese and sushi, to Koo. It was a bit risky since I'd never been myself and would've been horribly embarrassed if I wasted a meal outing. Given all the happy reviews here I felt pretty confident but all it takes is one bad night or dish to ruin the fun ya know?

We got a perfect corner table w/out reservations on a Friday night, ordered promptly from the two page menu and were soon on our way to enjoying sake, Yebisu, and freakin fantastic sushi. 

The experience at Koo is very SF. Warm, friendly, casual, low key, no 'tude. Fresh, delicious and well portioned servings. See photos I posted of our lip smackingly awesome spoonful of happiness, sashimi, sushi and rolls. Yes, my friend was impressed!

I have been all over Sushi Yasuda, Nobu, Blue Ribbon, Sushi of Garu etc etc but none have lingered in my mind so long after the experience. I'm officially an addict and can't wait to go back!
author: Kim K.

description:
Came to Koo last night at 8pm without a reservation, and there was 1 table available - perfect! I was impressed with the menu, as they offer a great variety of dishes beyond the typical sushi and rolls. They have daily sushi and sashimi specials, and I love that each one lists the source of the fish. Unique starters and yummy-sounding shared plates (both hot and cold) made it hard for us to choose what to order! 

We really enjoyed everything. Decided on the miso soup (x2), stuffed jalepeño, sour and spicy green beans, and the crunchy roll. The miso soup was a highlight for me. I enjoyed the hint of extra citrus flavor. The stuffed jalapeños were presented nicely, but the lime aioli (on the side) overpowered the other ingredients, even when I used a super small amount. I was surprised at how tasty the greens beans were and would recommend them. The roll was delicious and expertly made, exactly what I expected.

The service was fantastic. In addition to being greeted and seated promptly, our server noticed when were ready to order, but he was tied up at another table. He asked another server right then to come take care of us. We had the hot tea, and like clockwork someone was coming around to top us off. The staff were attentive but also not in our faces. Our bill for 2 people was $31 including tax, which I find very reasonable for a quality sushi establishment. Great experience, and I will be back for sure.
author: Lisa H.

description:
Koo (the informal, masculine of "to eat" in Japanese) dishes up reasonably priced, fresh, innovative sushi in the Inner Sunset.

An alumni of Sushi Ran, Ace Wasabi,  and Tokyo GoGo, chef Kiyoshi Hayakawa knows his stuff.  His "fusion" menu that includes traditional sushi as well as an extensive variety of salads, shared plates, sashimi, and hand rolls, Koo combines old-world Japanese cuisine with new-world menu items to deliver dishes that will wow you.

Freshly cooked, Edamame were still warm and perfectly salted.  With just the right amount of sesame oil, Wakame (Japanese seaweed salad) was a perfect beginning to a parade of wonderful creations.  First in line, the miso soup was delivered a perfect dose of umami.  Across the board, the nigiri was super-fresh, and the cuts of fish were reasonably sized.  Tombo tuna from Hawaii was rich and tasty.  Hamachi (yellowtail) melted in my mouth.  The "best roll" (tempura asparagus and avocado, wrapped in fresh salmon and topped with a thin lemon slice) really is the best.

Service was friendly and attentive.  Dishes arrived promptly, but did not make you feel rushed.  Servers were always available, but did not make you feel as if someone is standing over their shoulder.  

A host of premium sakes, wine, and beer are available.  

If you are in or near the Inner Sunset, Koo should be your "go-to" place for sushi.
author: CJ G.

description:
I've been agreeing with naysayers rather frequently lately for a number of hyped spots and Koo was no exception.

-The spoonfuls of happiness were very good and offered unique flavors and textures in each one.
-Sashimi Combo was pretty good, but not exceptional.  I've had fresher, less expensive fish elsewhere.  Loved the use of fresh wasabi though!
-Dynamite hand roll was average...not even worth the happy hour price.
-Delicious blue shrimp sushi and would consider coming back to sample their other catches of the day.

I'd definitely recommend the sushi specials and spoonfuls of happiness, but the traditional sushi/sashimi offerings were not quite worth the cost.  I'm more than willing to pay for high quality sushi...it just needs to actually be worth the money.
author: Eric F.

description:
My friend and I came here for a nice but casual girls night out dinner. 
The ambiance and decor was very modern and classy - great for "i don't mind spending money tonight" nights with friends or a date. Service is polite as well. 

Things we ordered: 

1. 2 Spoonfuls of Happiness, of course, after all the hype on yelp
2. Tempura Wakasagi Curry-Salt 
3. U2 Roll
4. Tokyo Crunch

The verdict: 

1.  Spoonful of Happiness - 5/5 

This dish came first and it was THE highlight of the meal. Hands down, best uni and quail egg combo I have ever had in the bay area. 

It came as a spoonful of uni, quail egg, tobiko ponzu and another spoonful of ankimo wrapped with whitefish, white truffle-oil ponzu with a shot of chilled sake. Both spoons brought me such great joy and explosion of happiness in my mouth =D "Thats what she said". 

The chef recommends you take a sip of the chilled sake first and then one spoonful of happiness and then another sip of chilled sake and the other spoonful of happiness. It really works to cleanse your palette in between the amazing creativity that it is, spoonfuls of happiness. 

2. Tempura Wakasagi (smelt fish) with Curry-Salt - 3/5
It was a valiant attempt at putting a twist on the usual shrimp or veggie tempura. However, it was a little underwhelming and heavy on the breading. The slight curry taste didn't really add to the dish. 

3. and 4. The Rolls: 2/5
Nothing to write home about, for sure. 

So overall, this place would have been only a 3/5 but because of uni with quail egg, i have to rate this place 4/5. Next time I come back, it will only be for their spoonful of happiness.
author: Lily S.

description:
Get the raw fish and the "spoonful", but skip the rest and try to ignore the staff and surroundings.

Koo needs a better restaurant manager. Waitresses run by the front door and never greet the arriving guests. At least try to say something when the line of guests is going out the door. Also, don't take 9 reservations at 8:00pm and none at 8:15pm (I saw the reservation book while waiting). They should be spread-out. The sushi bar was also backed up, so the foods from the kitchen arrived first and then the sushi items appeared which meant the order of the food was incorrect.

The food from the kitchen was typical. The first dish to come out was the spinach and asparagus in a sesame mustard sauce. The spinach was traditional, but it was oversauced. The grilled eggplant in sweet miso with ginger was straight-forward and usual. Although we should have had this at the end of the meal, the tempura fried smelt with curry in the coating came at the front end. They used a nicely delicate amount of curry in an otherwise ordinary fry coating.

The food from the sushi bar was the highlight of the restaurant. As seen in the other Yelp reviews, the "spoonful of happiness" is the signature dish here. One order is hard to share. So if there are two diners, then order two. It also comes with a sake shot so make sure someone at the table likes cold sake. One order comes with two different spoons. Start with the egg spoon with uni, raw quail yolk, and tobiko caviar and then the savory spoon with monkfish liver wrapped in raw fish and dressed in ponzu with white truffle oil. The decadent ingredients create decadent results for the taste buds.

Our sushi order finished the dinner. We selected sushi from the "Catch of the Day" menu in hopes of getting really good raw fish. Our emphasis was to taste fish caught in Japan regardless of the variety (or radioactive isotope count) which covered the smooth-flavored deep sea red snapper, the mild barracuda, the average Spanish mackerel, the sweetly buttery sea bream, and the more delicately flavored baby sea bream. The baby sea bream was so good, we ordered more. We also tried the wild king salmon from Alaska because it's salmon run season. It was tender, but not overly flavorful.

All the sushi suffered from being under seasoned. My guess is that the dining crowd wasn't very savvy because the majority of the guests ordered soybeans and sushi rolls. Perhaps the chefs expect their common guests to drown the sushi in an overpowering slurry of salty soy and hot wasabi instead of accepting the sushi as complete when served.
author: Brian U.

description:
My favorite sushi restaurant of all time! 

I've been coming here since It opened. All these years, I've never been disappointed. The sashimi is always fresh and I love the Best Roll!  I've been to many sushi restaurants and find Koo superior.
author: Krissa B.

description:
One of my top sushi spots in SF. 
+ They take reservations (most sushi places in sf don't)
+ - Unique rolls you can't get anywhere else

I recommend the Best Roll and Spicy Tuna. 

Overall, always a good experience for some quality fish at a decent price (not a steal, but not over the top expensive).
author: Naveed B.

description:
I've made two trips into Koo and it was fantastic both times.  The sushi was some of the best I've had in the area.  The fish was fresh and everything was presented beautifully.

The first time I stuck with some specialty rolls.  The Tokyo Crunch was great and I really enjoyed the Flying Kamikaze.  And then the next time I went somewhat more exotic (rather, my dining partner did).  We started with the Spoonful of Happiness.  I didn't know what to expect.  I'll admit that I didn't enjoy the uni spoon all that much, but the ankimo wrapped with whitefish was phenomenal.  I can see why this is such a popular item.  He tried the baby octopus salad, apparently it is quite good but I wasn't in love.  Perhaps I'm not adventurous enough...  We had a smattering of other great items, and I definitely enjoyed the Best Roll.

Koo happens to be on the pricier side, so I don't know how frequently I'd return when I'm paying for myself.  But it is cute for a more romantic date night or a night out with friends.  I suggest reservations if you are going to be there at a popular time (after 7pm) as it can get crowded.
author: Michelle K.

description: Decided kind of last minute on where to take one of my dearest friends for her birthday dinner. However, knowing she enjoys sushi treats and hearing many good things about this place, I went ahead and called in for a reservation. The rest of the experience went smoothly. Upon arrival, we found great street parking (right across the street) and was seated immediately. Upon staring at the menu, you don't see the omakase option but you can ask your server to bring that menu out. The omakase is definitely worth the price you are paying for. There are 3 omakase options. Obviously, the higher the price, the more you get to try. I wanted to enjoy a little bit of everything on their menu so we opt for the $70 omakase and there were no regrets. Everything was perfection from the start to finish. The food was amazing! My friend couldn't stop saying "This is so f*cking delicious. This is the best sh*t ever!" --- Well, well, someone was enjoying herself a little too much! The only bad thing is that I won't be able to have this everyday! :( I WILL BE BACK FOR YOU ONCE MY WALLET SAYS IT'S OKAY.
author: Betty P.

description:
A no-nonsense Japanese restaurant in San Francisco. They have a simple two-sided menu with dishes you'd expect at a Japanese restaurant: nigiri, rolls, grilled items, etc. They also have a "fresh catch of the day" menu which is a sheet of paper attached to the laminated menu. Items on this menu are fish imported mostly from Japan (they have specials from the Fukushima area), but also from Spain and other parts of the world. This special menu doubles the number  of nigiri they offer.

The ambiance is very unassuming, clean, and simple.

Their uni was very sweet with no metallic flavor - something you'd get from lesser restaurants.
author: Thomas C.

description: Friendly staff.  The Rock N' Roll is delicious, and I highly recommend the Gozzila Tofu and stuffed jalapenos.
author: Christina S.

description:
Verdict: Tasty, ultra fresh, authentic nigiri sushi/sashimi. I AM A FAN!
Order:  10 different items from catch of the day menu + Sake
Service: Friendly. We sat at the bar and we ordered directly with the chef. He also made some suggestions that weren't on the menu and they were delicious!
Best bite: Kanpachi nigiri with shiso leaf... The aroma of the leaf infused in the fish and it was a unique refreshing bite
author: Patty T.

description:
My best friend and I stumbled upon this place randomly after a long day of studying at the library. 

I have to admit l really love the atmosphere. It was very quaint and for a sushi place surprisingly not very chaotic like your typical sushi restaurants.

We ended up ordering a few rolls: the best roll, kamikaze roll, a spicy tuna roll, ahi taco, and a U2 roll. 

All of the food was really great and had amazing flavor. Especially the ahi taco, although I do wish there was a little more spiciness to it. 

The staff was very friendly and attentive. I wouldn't mind going back here again.
author: Lena S.

description:
I really wanted to fall in love with this place, especially when I saw pictures of the spoonful of happiness. But it wasn't meant to be. I would really give Koo more of a 3.5 stars but opted to give it the 4 because the spoonful of happiness was really good. 

It's pretty awesome. I mean, its wasn't orgasmic like the 1849 oysters at kabuto but it's pretty close. Initially, I felt like the Ponzu sauce was a bit overwhelming that it masked the natural and complex flavors of the uni, but this spoon was all about textures. Once you get over the excess Ponzu sauce, it really was delightful with all the tobiko and quail egg popping in your mouth. 

The second spoon was yellow tail wrapped around ankimo. The crisp crunchy hamachi really complimented the creamy ankimo well. As a palate cleanser, smooth sake went in between spoons. It was an innovative and exciting culinary adventure, so thrilling, I ordered 2 helpings. 

In addition, we ordered the uni + tobiko ($5.50), hamachi and avocado, and dynamite handroll, all for $4 each. They were ok. The uni was creamy, slightly bitter though. Another honorable mention was the salmon/tuna tartare on shrimp chips, it was flavorful and aesthetically reminded me of salsa, but the taste and texture was much more sophisticated than your typical salsa ($13.00). All and all, the spoonful of happiness was the star player at Koo, everything else fell a bit short. 

Servers were pretty nice as were the chefs, but I felt like we were rushed with the bill and our orders when the place wasn't full.  So that was a little obnoxious. Otherwise, i think Koo is worth a try to at least test out the spoonful of happiness. It will leave you in a blissful state.
author: Wendy L.

description:
My new favorite sushi place in all of SF!  When the catch-of-the-day list is longer than the regular menu, you know it's the real-fresh-sushi-deal :).

As a starter we tried the Spoonful of Happiness people rave about ($10.00 per person, can't share).  Basically comes as two spoons (one of uni and quail egg, the other of ankimo (monk fish liver) and whitefish) and a shot of sake to sip before and after (see my pic!)  Not sure I'd order this every time, but it's a must-try experience for first timers!!  The uni is quality stuff -- so you can prob do with half the amount of ponzu.

My suggestion is to skip the rolls (except the black cod), and stick with the fresh nigiri.  We tried quite a few, but our top 3 favs are below. All nigiris are about $6.50 for 2 pieces, which I think its affortable for this type of quality:
--blue shrimp ...so so sweet.  people usually think i'm nuts for eating raw shrimp, but pretty sure they'd change their mind if they only tried this.
--Moi (Sea Bass)
--Haramasa (aussie yellowtail)

Other items I tried that were decent, but not o-em-gee: 
Grilled Baby Octopus ($5) -- more like a octopus spinach salad...octopus was a bit bland.
Wild Salmon nigiri ($6.50) -- not the traditional buttery salmon -- texture was more rough like smoked salmon crossed with tuna...so i'm not a fan.
 
For those that don't like sashimi, the menu has lots of good cooked options too. Black cod ($15.00) was the only one i tried but OH MY COD ..i mean GOD :P..was it amazing.  I thought buttery reside only with sea bass, but Koo's cod literally melts in your mouth.  Dish comes in a light soy soup with baby bak choy...which is a good contrast to the grilled cod.  

I know I had sworn that The House's Sea Bass dish (North Beach fusion restaurant) was the best fish I've had..but now i think it's a close tie.

Will be back again for sure!

P.s the beer and sake is good here too.  Ladie friends -- try the the fuji apple sake if you like green jolly ranchers :)
author: Kendra W.

description:
Can happiness really be contained in a spoon?  From the moment your tongue dances with the whitefish, followed by the caress of the uni and quail egg yolk . . . yesh, I'm a happy camper.  Although it is a different story when the bill comes.

This is fresh fish done right!  Highlights were the hamachi toro and aji.  Oh, and who can forget the spoonfuls of happiness.  I'm not even a uni fan, but there is something magical about how the uni and egg yolk complements each other, delicious!  And then to top it off with cold crisp Asahi?  Hallelujah!!

Their service is hit or miss, but my visit this time was good.  In summary, I'll save this in my books as a place for special occasions.  They have some stellar stuff but it also comes with a hefty price tag.
author: Leeseuh K.

description:
Just came here with my BFF and we FEASTED !

Things we ordered:
1. Spoonful of Happiness ( a MUST) We both got two orders each ! And it comes with a complementary shot of sake.
2. Saba - amazing
3. Ikura - nomsssss
4. Uni - FRESH!!!
5. Hawaiian Wild Albacore wraps - citrusy and fresh
6. Stuffed Jalapenos - lime aioli is bomb.com!
7. Wild Tombo - not a favorite but it was okay
8. Barracuda - My first time trying it, it was mediocre
9. Dynamite Hand Roll - The wasabi tobiko was a nice touch
10. Unagi - Hot and steamy ! yummmm

I've had the Azteca Roll during previous visits and its also a favorite. 

The sushi chef had the hots for us so he gave us each a Sake Salad with miso dressing on the house! It was amazzzinnnggg. 

Our bill came out to around $108 which might be a little steep for some people but it's definitely well worth every. single. penny. 

Will definitely be back a million times and more!
author: Tammie P.

description:
Q:  "Christine, you are deathly allergic to seafood.  Why do you keep tempting Death by going to Japanese restaurants?"
A:  "My friend said a Spoonful of Happiness from Koo is worth tempting Death.  I'll trust her on that one."

A long day at the Jean Paul Gaultier exhibit with a friend and we needed to eat.  Maybe not too much but getting off of our feet for an hour or two would be good.  Oh snap I finally have a reason to eat on Irving Street!  Yelp-fu recommended Koo (is it pronounced 'kuu' or 'koh'?) so off we went.  I didn't have a huge appetite.  Whatever I ordered had to count.  Did I mention that I have seafood allergies and can't enjoy a spoonful of happiness?

Things That Were Awesome:
+++Presentation.  Everything looked good.  I looked at the tables next to us with envy.  Damn I should have gotten salad instead of beef tataki!
+++Prompt service.  Maybe we came in on a good time.  It seemed like my friend and I were the only guests in the restaurant.
+++Big plates.  They encourage you to share meals with their hot and cold plates.  Sushi and sashimi (and Spoonful of Happiness) are individual portions.
+++Portion.  There is literally just enough food to feed you.  You're not here to stuff our face with okay sushi.  You're here to enjoy a few pieces of really good sushi.

Things That Were Not So Awesome:
---Price.  Yeah the price tags are going to be a huge hurdle.  Be smart when you order.
---Small groups.  I wouldn't recommend swinging by if your party is more than 4 or 5.  A lot of tables for two up in hurrr.
---Taste for price not matching.  Certain items could be priced better (looking at you, entree).  Sushi/sashimi/spoonful of happiness match, but not everything else.

Things I Ate:
*  Shiitake nigiri. - Best shiitake nigiri I ever had.  Lightly grilled and just a tad sweet.  Why must the vegetable sushi selection be so limited :foodie tears:
*  Beef tataki. - Enough for two people.  My fatass ate all of it.  (GG Christine only 1 cup of yogurt =/= lunch.)  The tataki taste seemed to be masked by the sauce and everything garnishing the plate.
*  Mint spare rib lettuce cup. - Enough for two people.  Topped with a whole lot of fried noodles.  Once I dug out the spare ribs they were cooked just right.  Might have used more spice.
*  Yuzu creme brulee. - Yuzu is a mild citrus between lemon and lime in flavor.  This place does flavored creme brulee right.  It wasn't drowning in yuzu rinds and the texture wasn't fluffy cream.  This dessert made a chocolate addict switch teams for a night.

If nothing else, have the spoonful of happiness while you're here.  Pricey but some things are worth the premium.
author: Christine L.

description:
So reading all these reviews on Yelp and the boy living so close and hearing some people on Muni talking about, I told the boy that we had to go to this place. LIKE HAD TO. So, we went. We went there right before 7..on like a Tuesday. No need for reservations. Although when we left, maybe around 8:30, the place was packed. We ordered things as per suggestions of people on Yelp.

Spoonful of Happiness: we ordered one for each of us. They were good, but the one with the quail egg was very overpowered by the egg. The other spoonful was much better.

Aztec Roll, Tokyo Crunch, Flying Kamikaze: all pretty good rolls. We were definitely very full after all these. 

My suggestion: if you can, make it for happy hour. cheaper alcohol and not as many people.
author: Nina Y.

description:
This is just a quick review to say: do not be misled. This is not a cheap neighborhood place. No, it's a high-end, fantastic sushi place that can compete with the fanciest in San Francisco or anywhere. It doesn't have the greatest decor and ambiance, but it has the freshest fish, most innovative dishes, and real talent behind the sushi bar and in the kitchen. It is highly highly highly recommended. The only reason not to go there is if you're taking a date who needs to be impressed by how a place looks, and I recommend finding a different date in that case.

(It also is the best sushi in the Inner Sunset/Parnassus area -- Ebisu is better known and runs a close second, but Koo is just better in every respect except decor and ambiance.)
author: Frank W.

description: Overall a wonderful experience with a good mix of sushi as well as Japanese dishes. They have a wide variety of fish brought in from Japan as well as a bunch of local options. We had the omakase which was great overall, but some of the pieces could definitely have used some seasoning.
author: Mattheus K.

description:
Like Kazu, this place doesn't serve bento boxes. So  If you're looking for bento boxes or expecting HUGE portions, I suggest you go elsewhere. No seriously. If you want cheap and big portions, go to Kiki's or something...You're paying for quality here, my friend. 

We (bf and I) came here on a Friday night hoping to take advantage of their "5th anniversary happy hour" special. ($4 Handroll, $5 Appetizers,  $5 Alcoholic beverages. Sunday through Thursday. between open-7pm.)
 Unfortunately, they don't have it Friday OR Saturday nights. Bummer.  But that didn't stop us from enjoying their yummy food.....

We stuffed our faces with:

*Tuna and Salmon Tartar (served with spicy guacamole and shrimp chips. $13)http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/4GAsfSjaB1XewzS3TKOtTg?select=4jkhTwQx0MKiaUdKOy_6Og - This is your Asian version of chips and salsa. Instead of tortilla chips, you get shrimp chips. Instead of guacamole and tomatoes; you get guac, salmon, and tuna. It was good. I really liked it. Makes a great appetizer to share. 

*3 orders of hosomaki and an order of aji nigiri http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/4GAsfSjaB1XewzS3TKOtTg?select=Na1Xn_O80-1HCYePJmSkLw -
-Negi hama ($5.50)-One of my favorite rolls to order. It was sooo good I had to order another one! Probably one of the best I've had in a while. Its all about the sushi rice and their fresh hamachi. Delish! 
-Saba shiso-Eh..I thought it was okay. Don't think I would order it again. Bf wanted to try it.
-Ika shiso ($5)-First time I've seen Ika shiso on the menu so we had to try it.  Very tasty!

*1 order of Aji Nigiri- Fish was sooo fresh! Bf wanted to order another one! 

*Tokyo Crunch (Spicy tenkasu, hamachi, unagi, cucumber and wasabi tobiko. $8.50)http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/4GAsfSjaB1XewzS3TKOtTg?select=-zu385Zj6JlbHQTEX-DPKg - Eh, you don't need to dip this in shoyu. Just dab some fresh wasabi and you're good to go! I don't really like those "Jive ass rolls" but this one was quite tasty.  With the sauce, the size and everything, I don't think I would order it again. It was just too intense for me.  Nobu K., you were right. They did a good job on their "J.A.R." =P

*Tempura Wakasagi Curry-Salt (Smelt-fish. $6)http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/4GAsfSjaB1XewzS3TKOtTg?select=pZnjuXqJTpewe6GoLxGpPg - Omg, I LOVED this!  If you like smelt, then you will probably like this. You get a nice portion of deep fried smelt sprinkled with curry powder and salt. Not too much batter and it definitely had a great flavor.  It might be a little too salty for some people but I enjoyed it. Very addicting. Would probably taste good with beer.

*Stuffed Jalapeno (stuffed jalapeno with hamachi, with lime aioli $6)http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/4GAsfSjaB1XewzS3TKOtTg?select=x4aybkfDAykDsQ-Ggl5FAw -  Very interesting dish. I was expecting it to be stuffed with raw hamachi. But instead, it was cooked. I liked it. Their lemon aioli was good! Oh and FYI, it only came with 4 pieces.

Did I mention they have FRESH wasabi here? However, they charge you $1 for it. Taste sooo much better than the powdered stuff! This is the second Japanese restaurant I found that carries fresh wasabi. Kappa is the other one. 

Our total was around $98 (including tip). Yes, I know, kinda expensive for 2 people (plus my bf ordered 2 drinks). But when you go to a GOOD Japanese restaurant, I expect to drop $50 a head regardless. I mean, c'mon, you're paying for quality over here. Not like those non-Japanese owned restaurants that REALLY overcharge you. Just sayin. Oh and the interior/ambiance is very romantic. Great place to take a date.

 I'm TOTALLY coming back for happy hour! Next time I'm ordering their spoonful of happiness! Don't forget to make a reservation! This place got really crowded around 6:45pm. Parking around 5th and Irving was not as bad.

Like Sonny, I think I'm going koko for KooKoo puffs! Get it? Think hard! Okay, that was pretty dumb. haha. Sorry, I was just trying to make a funny. =P
author: B B.

description: Pound for pound this is probably the best date place in the Sunset. Maybe that's the sushi bias talking but I wouldn't know because I am blind due to mercury poisoning from loving sushi too much. But in all seriousness, this place has a great atmosphere and is cozy for those whisper date conversations where you're trying not to tell that embarrassing story to EVERYONE at Koo. Trust me they don't want to hear it. Shut your pie hole and enjoy the best sushi in the Sunset.
author: Danny A.

description:
I've been here twice and I'm dying to go back. 

I think everyone that steps foot in this place should try their Spoonful of Happiness. I don't usually eat uni because of the texture but this was actually very pleasent to eat. The flavors went every well with the sake that they give to you. 

Tuna and Salmon Tartar: omg. please make me of a large bowl of this. I can eat this alllll day. The shrimp chips gave this dish the extra texture that tartar needs. The guacamole was damn good too. Everything just blended so well! 

Mt. Fuji: this tiny little cake is also very good. I love chocolate and green tea ice cream so if you put the two together. I'm happy. Green tea gelato was nice and milky, great balance in the tea flavor!

Happy Hour: The boyfriend and I had god knows how many hand rolls (temakis). I think we've tried all of the except the crawfish since I don't think they had that when we went. Hand rolls are always fun to eat. We had a beer or two. 

This place is small so if you want to go and not wait then either make a reservation or come early. Decor was nice. Had that very old fashion japanese house feel to it. Service was one the spot. Bathroom was clean. I really can't say anything is wrong with place except for the fact that it makes a serious dent in my wallet every time I go here. Damn those spoonfuls of happiness! i need to go back....asap.
author: Tiffany N.

description: This is my favorite sushi restaurant in San Francisco! It's pricey but the quality is worth it. The owner is Japanese (who I also think is one of the sushi chefs) and the hostess and waiters are also Japanese. Coming from Japan, I have found this to be very hard to find in the United States. You can't get any more authentic than this place and you can't go wrong with any of the dishes you get. My favorites are the tuna and avocado temaki and the negitoro maki (tuna and scallion). The negitoro maki was about 6 pieces for $12, which is pretty expensive for what it is. You can get that for about $5 in Japan. But the quality of the tuna is so good that it didn't bother me. The waiters and the hostess were so sweet and friendly and I loved the cozy atmosphere. They had some nice Japanese wall art as well. If you're thinking about eating sushi and price isn't too much of a concern, then I would definitely suggest this place!
author: Hana K.

description:
Some (not all) of the fish was amazing.  Ordering off their catch of the day list is strongly recommended.  Pricy but worth it.  

The service was a tad slow but it was a busy Friday so take that with a grain of salt.

Would definitely go again.  The maguro we had (off the catch of the day list) was quite possibly the best I've ever had.  The others were just good, but that maguro...I would go back just for that.
author: John D.

description: I had dinner here on a Friday night. We had to wait a few minutes to get a table, but when we sat down we enjoyed the sushi rolls. We had three plates of rolls and sake. Service was alright, but reading the other yelp reviews I should have tried some other dishes. Next time...
author: Jennifer G.H. W.
