description: Couldn't say anything bad about this place! It's so damn good! Their seafood is incredibly fresh and exotic. We always go with the sashimi plate and their desserts are excellent and like less than $5!! We have tried almost everything and it's all just so good. Will always sit at sushi bar if possible. Expensive but for quality!!
author: PK R.

description:
Really wonderful food and service.  I'd go to Koo far more often and give it 5 stars if fewer parents brought their vocal infants and toddlers there to dine.

http://news.yahoo.com/who-knew/brat-bans-no-children-allowed-movement-growing-28600621.html
author: D. T.

description:
So delicious!  I am having a bit of a sushi renaissance and am happy to say that Koo gets the credit.  

Taking heed of Yelp recommendations, we ordered the Best Roll and the Spicy Tuna.  Both rolls melted in your mouth with subtle but complex flavors.  The combination of miso soup, fresh mixed green salad, and bowl of rice helped round out the meal (check at the bottom of the menu for this combo, it's in fine print).  

Overall a fabulous experience, but a bit pricey for sushi.  Be prepared to spend $40+ for dinner for two.
author: Kim K.

description: Realllly dont get how this has four star rating. Overpriced and there is no service, decor, or taste to merit that. Won't be back.
author: R C.

description:
My first five star restaurant review.

Allow me to preface this review by saying that I love rolls, not a huge fan of raw fish, though I can certainly appreciate good quality fish. That being said, their rolls... are... to... probably... I mean think about what you'd do for your absolute favorite dish on your last day on Earth. If their rolls were the prize, you'd say yes to any dare. 

Their tuna roll, you gotta get it. you gotta get it. you gotta get it. got it?
I ordered a few other rolls and some fish, but their tuna rolls were out of this small beautiful world. I felt like I was biting into heaven. I dreamt about the rolls that same night, stop reading and just go try Koo!
author: Rosa L.

description:
3.75/5 really, but whatever...

The sashimi here is really good and fresh, but ordering it may be a bit confusing. You had the selection from the 'fresh catch' menu (which were originally all sushi) and you doubled the price for the sashimi price. I don't know why it's ordered like this, but I'm sure there is a method to the madness. After a while, we just stuck with the "sashimi combo" because we felt it was a lot simpler. $23 for Yellow Fin Tuna, Albacore, Salmon, and Striped Bass. DEAAAAAL. Too bad it was the only combo.

I haven't tried the Spoonfuls of Happiness, but my friend did and he said it was nothing short of it's name. He assured us that we NEEDED to get it next time so I will just recommend it to you guys it in blind faith. I'm sure you won't be disappointed.

The Miso Tofu was bombarded with salt. I actually felt a salt burn at one point after trying to finish it. On the flip side, the Edamame lacked salt altogether. 

The Tempura Sushi Roll was the only roll we ordered and it wasn't too impressive.

I'm quite sure we didn't order anything this restaurant is known for, but nothing stood out other than the sashimi and the Spoonfuls of Happiness.
author: Andrew A.

description:
one thing

THE SPOONFUL OF HAPPINESS IS SOOOO EFFING DELICIOUS!!!
I've tried ankimo before because my sister is in love with it and i didn't really like it. However, the ankimo in the spoonful of happiness was so good, that i think it converted me into an ankimo lover.

Other parts of the dinner weren't as memorable, but i'll rate each item that we got.

duck salad - mediocre, would give it three starts
crab hand roll - i've definitely had better handrolls, but this one was definitely up there. however, i think that it was more expensive than it needed to be
sashimi- my boyfriend and i ordered the sashimi combo that came with the 4 different types of sashimi. i reallyyyyy disliked the tuna, but i LOVED the salmon and hamachi.

I would come back, but probably for happy hour, and would maybe just order 5 spoonful of happinesses (:

i'm getting happy just thinking about it!
author: Michelle L.

description:
High quality fish.  Sit at the sushi bar on a weeknight and order all the sushi specials for the day.  The standard salmon and hamachi are amazing, but we always liked the other fishes we could never get elsewhere.  

This is a great place if you've got your sushi taste buds dialed in and want to savor the subtle fish flavors.  If you want fun festive rolls, Koo has those too and they're awesome, but are not what sets Koo apart from other high end sushi restaurants.
author: Brandon G.

description:
3.5 stars

With all of the hype of this place, I really hoped that the rolls would be amazing, but every roll I've tried (they don't have a hugeee selection), were all mediocre. For the taste, I could get it at any other sushi place for a bit of a cheaper price.

However, I do really enjoy their spoonful of happiness. It comes with two spoons and a shot of sake. 1 with uni and quail egg, the other with monk liver or something like that. Both really really good! I was expecting the sake to taste bad but you can barely taste the alcohol at all.

I'll probably be back.. mainly for the spoonful of happiness though!
author: Valerie T.

description:
easily one of my favorite japanese restaurants. 

thank you fellow yelpers for the food suggestions, everything that was recommended was delicious! and totally worth the money. the fish is super fresh here, the blue fin is to die for. we loved a spoonful of happiness, how could you not want to order this dish with such a cute name. its a spoonful of uni, quail egg, tobiko ponzu & a spoonful of ankimo wrapped with whitefish, white truffle-oil ponzu & a shot of chilled sake [taken from the website]  and one of my favorites of the night was the hamachi kama. basically a hamachi fish head. so fatty and salty, but oh so good if you love grilled fish. 

didnt try any of the rolls, but they looked very good. great service, very friendly.
author: Serena L.

description:
Another place to add to my One Hit Wonder list.  The only thing I enjoyed here was their sashimi.  The fish was so fresh, probably the freshest I've ever had in San Francisco.  Two thumbs up for the sashimi.  My friends and I should have each ordered one for ourselves because the rest of the meal was disappointing.

The rest of the dishes were either mediocre or borderline fail.  I really wanted to like Koo but I was not impressed at all.  We listened to the Yelp community and ordered the cod but the dish came out cold and tasted like bad milk.  The sake in the sauce was terribly strong so the dish was hard to enjoy.  We told the waitress and asked her about the dish but she didn't apologize about the cold fish or say much about the rotten taste.  All three of us noticed something was off, so it wasn't just my tastebuds.    We also tried the Azteca Roll.  I knew it was going to be baked but I didn't expect the fish inside the roll to be cooked.   The warm sushi roll threw me off. And lastly, the Tuna and Salmon Tartare was just okay.  

Probably not coming back here unless I was really craving premium sashimi.
author: Helen V.

description:
I don't like sake (unless it comes with beer, chopsticks and obnoxious pounding on tables).

I don't like uni.

But somehow, I love the spoonful of happiness which is 2 spoonfuls of random, awesome raw ingredients, chased with sake.

And to repeat 50 other Yelpers... DAMN that miso cod was good. I drank the sauce when no one was looking. Shh!!
author: Jess C.

description:
Let me start off by saying I am a sushi snob. I am addicted to fresh fish. 

My first experience was taking my mom here for her birthday. We tried the spoonful of delight and that was AMAZING. 

I had such a pleasant experience there that I brought my other sushi snob friend to the place... and we went through tray after tray of sashimi and nigiri... and 2 bottles of nigori sake. 

Service is good. We were never ignored, nor where we overly bothered. I've always made reservations because I don't like to wait to eat. and I've never had a problem having to wait either. 

I think the bottom line of any sushi spot shouldn't depend on anything else but the quality of the food. Fish was the most fresh I've ever had. and the flavor palettes presented were DELISH.
author: Elisa T.

description:
http://www.sushikoo.com/ 

I went koo koo for Koo. DK found this place and sushi was the perfect meal prior to a weekend of dragon boating. He had reservations and we were seated immediately. 

Took a while for someone to bring us drinks and a menu, but once we got it, the party started. We had to order the "Spoonful of Happiness," because even if you're a mean SOB and you hate the world, you can't really hate anything with a name like that. 

It's really two spoonfuls with a shot of chilled sake. One was fish and the other was uni and boy, was it a lot of uni. Might be intimidating to someone who's never had sushi, or who can't hang, but it's definitely an accomplishment to just throw back those two spoonfuls. I'm not a fan of uni and have only had it once before, but really enjoyed both spoons (AK was going to go with the fish one first and I was like, "Are you crazy? You want to end with the uni??"). It helped to have the sake to wash everything down though (eat one, sip the sake, eat the other, shoot the rest of the sake). The sake was smooth and a perfect complement to the fish. 

We ordered a few things between us and each item had the familiarity of what you would expect from a roll with those respective ingredients, but had just enough of a twist to it to make it unique:

(Rolls vary between 5-8 pieces)
Awesome: Catch of the Day - Tempura crab with a garlic ponzu dipping sauce. (not a roll, just an appetizer)
Great: Tokyo Crunch - Spicy Tenkasu, Hamachi, Unagi, Cucumber and Tobiko
Great: Spicy Tuna - Spicy Tuna, Cucumber and Lettuce
Okay (my least favorite): Azteca - Crab, Avocado, Gobo and Cucumber Wrapped in White Fish, topped w/ a thin slice of Jalepeno, Spicy Mayo, Tobiko & Ponzu then lightly baked
Awesome: Best Roll - Tempura Asparagus, Avocado, wrapped in Fresh Salmon & thin slice of Lemon 
Great: Flying Kamikaze - Spicy Tuna and Asparagus wrapped with Albacore and topped with Garlic Ponzu and Scallions

Service was good, food came out in a timely manner, and it got really crowded, especially around 9 pm.

With all that, the bill came out to $107 or so and we were all stuffed with happiness. Will definitely be back. 

Good date place, if you like your date. If you hate your date, take them to Little Star Pizza and you won't have to talk to them (http://www.yelp.com/biz/little-star-pizza-san-francisco#hrid:m7ffc1s3jT8X-1K58OvyBw)
author: Ming-Jou C.

description: Extremely fresh sushi, very good and attentive service and easy to get a reservation. My only recommendation is to change the music to be more suitable.
author: Eric W.

description:
Hands down my favorite sushi place in the area.  

I almost want to vote it 1 star so stays off peoples radar, but I can't in good faith do that.  Keep in mind it's a little small so there isn't a huge amount of seating, it's also a LITTLE on the pricey side (for sushi), but totally worth it.
author: Justin R.

description:
The spoonful of happiness was delicious! Everything else was mediocre and not worth the price. I would much rather spend the same amount at Zushi Puzzle or less at Sushi Zone.  Besides the spoonful of happiness, nothing about this place would make me want to return.

Service was good though!
author: K V.

description: The spoonfuls of happiness is AWESOME!  The fish is good quality and the rolls were good.  The service was also good
author: Will L.

description:
This is still by far my favorite sushi place in the city. Better than Ino in my opinion even if it's less traditional. They can be traditional if they choose to (the 3 chefs are all experienced and trained from Japan) but their menu has a wide array of choices that make it more American (for instance..the rolls).

Top notch..
author: Veronica S.

description:
Just to close out the controversy, I will say that perhaps my rant about restaurants and ego was reactionary to feeling belittled. The owner obviously values customer input, which is admirable in itself. Thank you, Kiyoshi, for reading my review and offering your input. Miscommunication happens. If I would have known there was a minimum, I would have been happy to order more because I wouldn't have felt unwelcome. Really, my review had nothing to do with not being served on account of our unacceptable order-- who wants to serve someone asking for tea and beans? My review was for the attitude, for the quickness of dismissal rather than treating a customer as a guest. I hope no other customers experience the same treatment.

Yelp drama!
author: Jen N.

description:
Everything I had was good. The staff was fast and friendly. The sushi Chef were serious and the atmosphere Nihon.

Since Suzu changed owners this might be my new favorite Japanese spot.

Wish they had Soba or Nabiyaki or at least a Ramen.

One thing, I like my Edamame hot not cold.
author: Anthony M.

description:
Apparently, I have been going to really slow restaurants lately.  After 15 minutes of waiting, I had to flag a waitress down so she would get someone to take our order.  The 3 of us ordered: spoonful of happiness, sashimi combo, dynamite handroll, hamachi handroll, salmon handroll, fried tofu, chicken teriyaki, and a bowl of rice.  I asked for no wasabi in the dynamite roll and the waitress kinda looked at me crazy.  I couldn't understand her until finally I realized she was trying to say that if I don't want wasabi, I can't have tobiko too cause they're together.  Weird, but okay, as long as there isn't wasabi.  

Food came out one by one, as if we were having a # course tasting meal.  It took quite awhile for everything to come out.  And they forgot the rice, so the chicken teriyaki was getting cold as we waited for the rice.

There's really not much to say about the food.  It was very forgettable.  The total came out to be just under $70.  Totally not worth it because it felt like I just had an appetizer and was ready for the main course!  We left hungry!!
author: Kat E.

description:
Koo is my favorite sushi restaurant in SF.  I have to have a Spoon Full Of Happiness every few months or life just is not that good.  I have never had a bad meal here and the service is always so friendly.  

We've tried a lot of things on the menu, I don't love all of them, but that's just personal taste.  The quality is always great,  Parking is a little tough, but it's well worth it.
author: Gabriella C.

description:
My friend took me here a few weeks ago and I've been craving this place ever since... too bad they were closed for the holidays.

Extremely high quality and well balanced flavors.  The spoonfuls of happiness, the Black Cod and the Tartar was scrumptious!

I can't wait to go back!
author: Miss Bonnie B.

description: THE best sushi in all of SF. Tried it all, and wouldn't go anywhere else. Everything is amazing here, including the service, but my personal favorites are the Best roll, Azteca roll and the Japanese eggplant. The specials are always worth trying, too. I cannot recommend this place enough.
author: Katalin G.

description: Love that restaurant. Fresh and delicious food. Good atmosphere. Not crowded like most places in the city.
author: P. C.

description:
came here for the first time after a friend recommended it. first of all, the KOO sign is behind a tree so we walked past it like twice before we saw it, but iss coo(koo! har har). we ordered two spoonfuls of happiness, the the hawaiian seared albacore wraps, azteca roll, salmon sashimi, and we were feeling ambitious so we also ordered the shrimp dumplings. overall it was a little pricey (total bill came out to $75), but the food was so dank i practically threw my credit card at the waitress.

i know the $12 price tag on the spoonful of happiness is a red flag when you first skim the menu, but for the sake of your taste buds, ORDER IT. YOU WILL NOT REGRET IT. also order the hawaiian seared albacore, it was SOOOO deelish! the azteca roll was yummy, with a little spicy kick perfect enough for you to feel it but not have to immediately reach for your water. the salmon sashimi was super fresh and delicious, and the shrimp dumplings were good too. they tasted a little like dim-sum though (like ha gaos), but it came with some sweet sauce that made it taste amazing too. woop woop! yikes, writing this review is making me want koo again right now -_-.
author: Caitlin C.

description: Arrived at 5:30 for happy hour and end up ordering off the happy hour menu.  The spoonful of happiness ($12) was a delight!  The sashimi is super fresh and buttery.  I will be back for more..
author: Lisa Z.

description: I've only been here for its happy hour; which makes this place slightly more affordable. Normally I don't mind paying much for Japanese food, but the food here really wasn't that impressive, so I don't know why I would come here unless there's a good reason.
author: Aleck L.

description: Got seated quick, ordered quick, food came out quick, staff were really nice, food was okay , but then again never really been to a good sushi place that I really enjoyed
author: Amai M.

description:
IMO, this is the best sushi place I've been to in the City for last 5-6 years I was in the Bay Area. Been coming here for 3 years now... Too bad it's popular now... Hahaha.

Sure... Maybe Sushi Sam has a little edge over this place,
but this is the place to beat in the city for me.

Yes. Everyone talks about the Spoonful of Happiness. 
No need to talk about that great invention anymore.

But this place got the best nigiri and oysters.
Actually, for years I visited here, I have not experienced one low quality nigiri here.
The best indeed.

I love the fact that a restaurant has philosophy too. 
They don't serve americanized (or butchered) rolls such as Philadelphia rolls or lion king, etc. They have rolls named as corny as U2 rolls, but all their rolls give flavors other than meaty and oily feelings - which is actually great! 

What can I say... How can I really describe it... 
It's like...hmm...Sure, tuna bellies have more fat than other fishes or tuna parts, but you don't find them as much oily as you'd be in need of beer or soda to chug down and refresh yourself. All the rolls in this place have that taste of neatness and cleanliness that would not require carbonated drinks.

Oh that darn great roll called Azteca with a scent of jalapenos.

But who cares about rolls when they got nigiri/sashimi quality as great as here! and the oysters! I don't like oysters, but I can eat their oysters all night! (Because it tastes so good, not because it's aphrodisiac...)

Sure it's pricey, but I never feel bad spending for those high-quality foods that deserve their prices... and I've spent like $100 here just on spoonfuls (note plural) and nigiri without sake (only for myself)... and it only makes me smile when I think of those times!

One more note: I've friends lived in Tokyo for a majority of their lives and they praised this place for several days after having dinner here.
author: Andrew Y.

description: Very authentic Japanese dishes !! The uni dish is out of the world. Very fresh sashimi and delicious !! Service is great and friendly. Highly recommended.
author: Annie G.

description:
The sushi was good, better than what you can get on the east coast.  It tasted very fresh.  Yum. 

I think I liked the dessert better than the sushi to be honest.  Green tea ice cream and mochi = Yum. Yum Yum Yum.  This is why I am giving them 4 stars instead of 3.
author: Jen F.

description:
Koo has a extensive menu full of excellent selections.  One of their most intriguing dishes is their "spoon full of happiness," a spoon of uni with quail egg and another spoon of ankimo all washed down with a shot of sake.  Another plus is that they serve o-toro that is super fresh and melts in your mouth.  

The only disappointing dish was the raw oysters, they were puny and definitely not worth it.  Other than that, the other dishes either met or exceeded my expectations.  

The restaurant is located right in the middle of a residential block and conveys a welcoming and laid back environment.  Parking can be a bit tricky due to it's proximity to UCSF.  Overall, Koo is a solid Japanese restaurant that I would recommend.
author: Wei K.

description:
Definitely great sushi but not worth counting down the days for. 

I've always ordered the sashimi platter and been happy with it. We've also ordered some of the rolls and really liked them as well. Got the soft shell crab one (Tokyo Crunch) and then just a simple salmon avocado one last time and thought both were excellent. 

The service was just fine. We didn't need to ask for anything nor was our waiter overbearing. Excellent! 

The crowd is generally well-dressed though I wouldn't call the place particularly fancy. So don't stress about heels or a tie but maybe consider showering beforehand.
author: Zoey S.

description:
I don't know what's the hype about this place...all I liked here was the spoonful of happiness, but even that didn't blow my mind like everyone else's. 

the sashimi was alright. I've had much better...
and since everyone was raving about rolls( I don't really order rolls ),  tried it and was bland.
author: Cha C.

description: Went there with my parents and bf. Great place. Awesome food. The best part is that you can order the fresh seafood from the menu called 'catch of the day'. Highly recommended appetizer ' A spoon full of happiness'. Interesting dining experience.  Love it!!!
author: Wendy Z.

description:
The best sushi I've had in SF.  Be sure to sit at the sushi bar, where the sushi chefs make your sashimi and nigiri fresh in front of you.

From start to finish, I enjoyed every bit of this meal, and was thoroughly impressed by the quality of fish that they serve.  In no special order, I had the spoon of happiness, hamachi, kamasu, aji, hokkaido hotate, kanpachi, hirame, ikura, hosihikari, takabe, kinme dai, sanma, tamago.  To describe all of them fairly would make this review too long to read; please, just go and try for yourself.
author: Josh Q.

description:
Spoonful of happiness is SO delicious!  One spoon with uni and a raw quail egg in a small pool of ponzu sauce while the other spoon had hamachi wrapped around monk liver in a pool of ponzu sauce.  My effin lord is it GOOD!  It was so good I had to have 2 servings of it.

The rest of the items on the menu such as the uni and toro were very flavorful and fresh while the miso cod was a pretty thick piece that was also flavorful.  

The food here is excellent and nothing came short of anything.
author: Oanh N.

description:
YUM!

I came with two others right when they opened, so the place was empty. 
They had HH $4 handrolls, $5 appetizers, beer and sake.

I ordered the 
Rock and roll- unagi and avocado, pretty good, nice big unagi
hamachi avocado- really fresh fishies

we tried the spoonful of happiness, pricey for two little spoons but SO GOOD! I liked the monk fish? the first spoon the best. the uni....sea urchin, not as much, it was slimey and smushy. you get a shot of sake to drink with it. 
they had kumamoto oysters! my favorite! so we each got that, yum. small but fresh and tasty.
the fruity yuzu alcholic drink was very freshing and good, light taste, great with dinner.
 we had some very yummy complimentary dishes, which i wish I knew the name of, but oh so good.
shrimp dumplings...very interesting! not the dumplings we were thinking of, but good.
the jalepeno stuffer....it was okay, a weird taste to me.
and the hawaiian....something with mango...very good, love the combination of flavors

I THINK that's everything....we did order a lot....
oh but dessert! we ordered the chocolate cake with green tea gelato and mochi ice cream. Not spectacular but a good ending to our meal.

everything tasted how it should, raw fish with enhancing flavors. For 3 it was $125, so around $50 each.

pricey yes, but a great date place or chit chat. really nice waitress.
author: Christine M.

description:
Spoonful of happiness! (what a name..hahaha).   My first reaction was how the hell am I going to gulp down that raw quail egg.  Happiness starts kicking in after that one shot of sake.

Happy hours!  I had a couple of handrolls. The salmon and hamachi were fresh. "Stuffed Jalapeno" goes perfect after finishing the spoonful of happiness.  Stuffed Jalapeno was small and medium spicy.  Great service, clean, food was above-average for the price.
author: Cece Y.

description:
1. All of the staff is Japanese.
2. All of the chefs are over 50.
3. All of the fish is fresh.
4. Every roll I've tried has been perfectly executed.

Need I say more?

P.S. The $4 happy hour hand rolls are bomb. Best way to make it  affordable.
author: Jay A.

description:
Koo: An Inner Sunset gem that offers great service, a delicious menu and reasonable prices.  

The boyfriend and I  ALWAYS get the best roll (the name speaks for itself!!), but are also quite fond of the negi toro, U2 and dragon rolls. Sometimes when we're feeling fancy, we'll top it off with the maguro nigiri. And if you want to top that, end the night with either the Mt. Fuji chocolate cake or green tea gelato with homemade cookies. Yum! Service is typically prompt depending on how crowded it is on a given night. Regardless, I can always count on a nice, hot cup of green tea to warm me up as I wait for dinner to arrive.

Reservations do help on weekends to ensure quick seating at Koo, but the sushi bar is a great alternative. Overall, the low lighting and moderate noise level create a comfortable and intimate atmosphere. It's an SF sushi fave in my book and I highly recommend you check out when in the area!
author: Lauren K.

description:
Just came back from dinner at Koo.  Wow!  Took advantage of the happy hour menu which is a sweet deal.  $4 hand rolls, a selection of $5 appetizers, and $5 sake and beer.  Everything was delicious and the service was attentive.  What more can you ask for?

From the regular menu, we each ordered a "spoonful of happiness" and boy it was all that!  It's really 3 separate items for $11.  You get a shot of chilled sake.  I took a sip.  It was quite good and cleansed my palate.  Then I followed it up with the spoonful of ankimo wrapped with whitefish with white truffle oil ponzu.  My palate was swooning.  Yum.  I paused and took another sip of my chilled sake.  Then I delved into the spoonful of uni, quail egg, and tobiko ponzu.  That was even better than the previous spoonful.  They call it a spooful of happiness.  If it doesn't make you happy, I don't know what will.  I loved it!!!

From the happy hour menu, we got the following hand rolls:
- dynamite (scallop)
- spicy tuna
- hamachi and avocado
- salmon and avocado
- crawfish

We also got the artichoke as well as the fried tofu for appetizers.  We topped it all off with a large hot sake and we were stuffed.

The handrolls were incredibly good.  I've always preferred sashimi over sushi or handrolls only because I tend to not like the rice that most restaurants use.  Guess what?  The rice Koo used for their handrolls were amazing.  It was yummy goodness!  Did I just say that about rice?  Someone slap me!!  I have a habit of scooping out the raw fish from sushi or handrolls because I hate the rice.  I ate every grain of the rice on these handrolls.  That says a lot considering I'm not a big fan of grains.  It was incredibly good.  

Koo, I can't wait to come back.  And yes, I will take advantage of happy hour again.  I've heard the regular menu can generate a pricey bill.  Our bill with gratuity and taxes came out to $83.
author: Chrys S.

description: My favorite place for sushi! So happy it's in my neighborhood. Always simply delicious!
author: Kim K.

description:
Quick service, professional staff, spacious layout. 

Spoonful of happiness was a delight. Unique combination of flavors that is a must try.

Black cod was meh, but I don't like cooked fish in general so don't read into that.

Tuna and salmon tartare was good, but nothing spectacular.

Thoroughly enjoyed the crawfish hand roll.
author: Art S.

description:
I had a good experience here the first time . The second time was a little disappointing. I wanted to give this place another try, so third time's the charm right?

I was really excited about this place because the catch of the day fish selections were exciting and different from your typical sushi restaurant. 

But when the nigiri arrived.. the fish was a bit mushy and bland. The three different kinds of fish (tai, kinmadai, kohada) tasted the same and having had these nigiri before at my fav sushi joint of all time, I know what it could taste like if it were fresh.

Eh. Did these more uncommon selections of fish just not sell to the masses? Was it sitting in their display case for a week? Sigh.. Even the uni was mediocre and fishy tasting.. it's the kind of uni a first timer puts in their mouth and can't fathom why people would eat something like that. 

For that price, I expect more. Maybe I happened to go on a bad day.
author: tessie n.

description:
I wanted to grab some dinner after my PRK/Lasik surgery, so Lester W. did some Yelping and found something new to try.  We had reservations at 6:30, but got there at 6:00.  No reservations needed because nobody was there yet!  

The restaurant is very cute.  When you walk in, the sushi bar is to the left and general seating to the right.  I couldn't really see much, but Lester W. said there was some interesting Japanese artwork on the walls.  The service is great.  They're very attentive and check up on you to make sure everything's ok.

I had to leave the ordering to Lester since I couldn't get my eyes to focus yet.  Here's what we got:
-A Spoonful of Happiness( http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/QmRJupXOKW90T7z5wq8GtA/l ) - spoonful of uni, quail egg, tobiko, ponzu and ankimo wrapped with whitefish, truffle-oil and  a shot of chilled sake.  
-Best Roll - tempura asparagus, avocado, wrapped in fresh salmon & thin slice of lemon 
-Azteca - crab, avocado, gobo and cucumber wrapped in white fish, topped w/ a thin slice of jalapeno, spicy mayo, tobiko and ponzu then lightly baked
-Flying Kamikaze - spicy tuna and asparagus wrapped with albacore and topped with garlic ponzu and scallions
-Tokyo Crunch - spicy tenkasu, hamachi, unagi, cucumber and tobiko
( http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/nPyxydN4JaZ6vdfrVu1EYw/l )

My favorites were the Spoonful of Happiness, Azteca and Best Roll.  The jalapeno on the Azteca gave it an extra little crunch which I liked.  The Tokyo Crunch was good, but the sauce was too salty.  I'm starting to like Uni alot more now, so the Spoonful of Happiness was just what the doctor ordered.  The quail egg gives the uni a sweeter taste, and the sauce gave it an extra burst of flavor!

I'll definitely have to come back when I'm not feeling so miserable, so I can fully enjoy the food!
author: Patra I.

description:
came here for just happy hour

great handrolls for $4. good amount of fresh fish in each hand roll and avocado! :D

spoonful of happiness with the shot of sake was yummy. two spoons for $12 seems a bit pricey for me though to come back for more, but id definitely recommend it, especially for those who love the uni+qual egg combo
author: Katherine C.

description:
This is good. And a lot less pricey than I expected. I must have walked past the place a few dozen times and always just wrote it off as being too expensive for anything but a special occasion yet not special enough to be on my list whenever one of those occasions arrived. Then we didn't get into any of the extra-fancy places we'd wanted to for my birthday dinner so I went and looked up the nearest-bestest sushi place. Which was this.

Highlights:
Soft shell crawfish handroll - temporary, special, and to die for. We kept ordering more. It comes with little red claws sticking out of it (I have a picture somewhere on here). My favorite of the evening.

Caledonia Blue shrimp nigiri - it really *is* blue

Two way Scallops - also to die for, although the lemon-ginger was my favorite

Lychee sakei - fantastic, if tiny

FRESH nigiri - including many on the "catch of the day" list which had comparable prices to their happy hour specials

Dessert - I don't think I've ever been in a sushi restaurant before where (once you're over the novelty of mochi) it was worth sticking around for dessert. Try the chocolate and the cheesecake.
eavesdropping - for some reason our neighbors were extra entertaining this evening

Lowlights:
Miso Black Cod - we might have liked it if we had not already been irreparably spoilt by Sushi Kazu down the street. (Don't bother with Miso Cod anywhere else IMHO) Also, the bok choy it came with was stringy.

Lychee sake - the serving is 2-3 oz, but it's listed in the same column as a bunch of other sakes which are 5 oz. So we were disappointed when it came.

I don't know if the place has changed, or if it was because we ordered so many things off the special menu or what, but I didn't think Koo was that pricey. I'd put it on about the same level as EOS, which is costly but not exceptionally so.
author: Amy T.

description:
Koo offers a fairly authentic experience with excellent sushi.  Rice was seasoned just right, and the fish was extremely fresh.  

Service was friendly and attentive.

This place is more for those looking for sashimi and nigiri.  If you mostly eat rolls and do not eat raw fish, you'll probably save yourself some money by eating elsewhere.
author: Jonathan M.

description:
With Ebisu and Ariake in this neighborhood, Koo has some competition. But for reasonably priced, quality fish, Koo really fits the bill. They have both sushi and izakaya-style cooked food.

I particularly enjoyed the spoonfuls of happiness, which consists of a small spoon of sea urchin, quail egg, tobiko and ponzu sauce; another small spoon of monkfish liver and whitefish. These are both served with a shot of chilled sake that is meant to be sipped between spoonfuls. The sake pairs nicely with the food but also cleans your palate just enough to ready your taste buds for the next spoon. All in all, it is a marrying of flavors that complement each other. 

You will also find here the much coveted Asahi Kuronama beer. If you like Japanese beer, this is a good choice even for a dark lager.
author: Gail S.

description: Consistently excellent.  I've never had bad fish here.  Probably the best sushi I've eaten in the bay.  I always end up with the best roll and sashimi combo.
author: Click C.

description: This place is Koo!  I love the spoonfuls of happiness, it's like an IV of delicious cholesterol straight to my veins.  Parking is a bit of a challenge.  It's not a cheapo sushi place, but it's not expensive either.  You will most likely have to wait for a table.  I took some out of towners here and they loved it.
author: Erika C.

description:
Hmmm, for a pretty pricey place, I've yet to see the commotion.

I will come back though, I always give 4-star establishments at least 3 tries before giving my final score, but for now it's gotta be 3 stars.

Beer here was good, but when is Asahi ever bad? I went to Tokyo and the locals say Asahi is the best beer there.  Can I argue?

The handrolls were ok.  I suppose you can say the quality was superb, but I feel there has to be a better balance between quality and taste before my palette agrees.

Service is really friendly.  I will be back very soon to give it another go!
author: Christopher N.

description: Best hamachi Kama yet!  Everything else is good.  On the smallish side with average prices.  The spoon shots were just okay, not what people wrote about.  Friendly efficient service .
author: Joel M.

description:
Yummy yummy yummy I got a Spoonful of Happiness in my tummyyy and I feel like loving yooooou...

Koo is delicious! I'm really digging the Happy Hour hand rolls. Add a quail egg and viola! Pure delicious. In addition to such deliciousness, Koo also sports an extensive sake list.

The catch of the day menu is a very nice touch!

However, I'm not sure if I'll come back very often, for two reasons. One, it's more expensive than my current favorite sushi place. Two, the menu doesn't look like they've given much thought towards sustainability, which makes me a sad panda.

Besides those things, it was a fabulous experience!
author: Rachel H.

description: Consistently great food, friendly staff, and easy parking. I love this place - especially their happy hour specials and short rib lettuce cups.
author: Jason C.

description:
Oh... YUM! Dined here last weekend and really enjoyed the food. I used to live in the neighborhood a million years ago when it was another Japanese restaurant called Hana. 

The smelt fish was really, really good - very similar in taste to Singaporean noodles. We also enjoyed the salmon/tuna tartar very much. I loved that shrimp chips are used as the serving vessel to the tartar. The sashimi was also very fresh. 

I can't wait to go back if I'm ever in the 'hood.
author: Christine T.

description:
I've been wanting to go here for some time! I love sushi and wanted to try a new place. In regards to cost, they're actually really affordable and should be $$, not $$$ as Yelp shows it to be. 

I'm not going to rate this restaurant on their food (it was ok), but I'm going to rate them on their service. I have a gluten allergy, so it's difficult to find delicious asian food without the evil soy sauce. Our waitress was so wonderful and made sure everything I ordered was gluten-free. She double checked with the chefs! When I wanted a house salad to start with, she told me there was gluten in both of their house dressings. I looked bummed, so she went to the chef and asked him to make me a special dressing. It was really yummy! She was so incredibly helpful that I would go back for the sake of service!
author: B K.

description:
We stopped in for a quick bite and ordered the dragon roll, and a Spoonful of Happiness. The roll was great and I literally have dreams and cravings for the Spoonful.

The location is easy to get to and the parking wasn't an issue.
The bar here is small with only a few seats but the seating area is larger.
Nice decor and atmosphere is relaxed, modern, and fresh.

They really pay attention to presentation and little details.
I will definitely be back.
author: Bosco R.

description:
Koo Rocks!

Sushi's always fresh.
The staff is always super nice.
The Spoonful of Happiness lives up to it's name.
The Marinated Artichoke is the best ever anywhere I've ever tried it.
The Best Roll is... the best!
author: Shane L.

description:
Updated (12 Jan 07)
We just came back from the best Omakse course in SF!  Thanks Dan V., we had an amazing meal with great sake.  Credit to their excellent food, we finished an entire bottle of sake (& another glass) in no time .  The meal was a nice balanced mixture of 'nama-mono' (raw fish dishes) and cooked dishes.  What really separates places like Koo from 'the pretenders' is the details.  From wasabi to goma-sauce, they put in an extra effort to make it the best.  Quality of gyu-tan (beef tongue) was the quality you get at a nice restaurant in Tokyo.  You can count on 'professional' quality dishes at Koo.  For what you are getting, their prices are amazingly great value.  Having the kind of omakase course meal in Japan for less than 10,000 Yen ($100) is unthinkable.  With sake and desserts, it was about $90/person, but if you don't drink alcohol or order dessert, you could enjoy their course for around $60/person.

Original Review (01 Apr 06)
Living in SOMA near financial district, I normally avoid driving to Sunset district for dinner, but after seeing some good reviews about Koo by Yelpers --- including #3 Best SF Japanese Restaurant according to Dan V. --- we decided to go for a hike.  As predicted, Friday night traffic from Harrison to 9th , to Hayes, to Gough, to Fell, and finally to Irving was painful, but I quickly discovered that it was all worth it.  

Wow!

Great find!  Restaurant is not so big (max capacity sign read 48) so calling 30 minutes ahead for a table was a smart move.  As you walk in, there is a nice well lit sushi counter area to the left, sort of separated from the more dim lighting dining area to the right.

FOOD:  Awesome authentic Japanese food --- so far best I've had in SF.  We ordered a bunch of dishes to share along with sushi and sashimi.  Some of the highlights include:

* Tuna and salmon tartar: If California roll is good with avocado and tuna, why not tuna with spicy guacamole with shrimp chips?  It was a very nice creative dish.

* Eggplant dengaku:  Nice miso sauce!  Excellent.

* Grilled Asparagus:  Such a simple dish, but the flavoring was tasty.

* Tempura wakasagi (smelt fish) curry-salt:  Never had smelt prepared this way.  Great with beer.

* Miso marinated black cod:  By keeping the sauce flavor just right so that you can taste the fish.  Very good.

Sushi and sashimi was also very good, but I was more impressed with their prepared Japanese dishes.  We had a load to eat (knowing we didn't have to pickup the check), drank beer and sake, yet it came out to $40/person, which was very reasonable.  We could have easily kept it under $30/person and still could have had a good meal.

In other part of the country, a place like Koo targeted Japanese businessmen, but that wasn't the case with Koo.  Most of the customers we saw were non-Japanese, yet most of the wait staff were Japanese and as earlier stated, they serve solid authentic Japanese food.  What I'm trying to say is that I'm quite happy that restaurant like Koo could survive and stay popular without Americanizing their taste and service.  Hats off to customers that support restaurants like this.
author: トモ T.

description: Everything was excellent! But Spoonful Of Happiness is definitely a must at this place. Not only is it appropriately named, the quality of the ingredients are top notch. You can literally taste the freshness! It has the perfect ratio of sauce and other toppings which enhances but not overpower the STARS of the dish, uni and munk fish liver. I literally smiled after the first bite.
author: Linda N.

description:
In brief: A solid neighborhood sushi joint, good for a casual date, favor the rolls, go light on the nigiris. 

I was back last night and yes I can confirm it's still a very nice sushi restaurant in the Inner Sunset. The rolls were par excellence, particularly the Tokyo Crunch. The nigiris however, were a disappointment. I had the toro ($14) and while it was generally the right color the texture was neither fatty nor soft enough. I also had red snapper which was ok, but not remarkable. Service was great, our water glasses stayed full and our waitress frequently checked in.
author: Jeremy S.

description:
After reading several reviews from my friends and hearing about their awesome Happy Hour specials, the bf and I decided to give it a go.

At first glance, Koo is almost very easily missed if you just drove by and wasn't looking for it. It's centered on its block and hidden behind a couple of trees. 

As I stepped into the restaurant, I noticed the lighting and decor. It was very different from what I had expected. The lights were slightly dim and the hangings on their walls were kind of a traditional Japanese with a modernized twist. It was simple and not too over the top elegant, so dressing casually won't make you feel out of place. 

Maybe since it was a Tuesday, it wasn't crowded and we were seated right away. We were given the HH menu along with the regular dinner menu. We aren't big on handrolls, so we passed on those on the HH menu. We did order the large house hot sake for $5, the wakame salad $5, and another salad, forgot the name of it....also $5. Good deal.

For the main dishes, we decided on the Azteca, Tokyo Crunch & Dragon Rolls. The bf got the beef spareribs with butter lettuce wraps and I got the miso marinated black cod. Of all the rolls, my favorite was the Azteca. It had a "punch" of spicy ness to it that was not over powering. The fish was fresh and they didn't make it with a ton of rice. The butter lettuce wraps were very refreshing and definitely something different that was very worth trying. My miso black cod tasted good, but it was floating in a bowl of soy sauce soup....it made it a bit too salty. 

Of course, as everyone recommends, we had to order the "spoonful of happiness" ....amazingly, it was delicious. I'm not a huge fan of uni...but with the addition of a quail egg, it made it less fishy and more buttery. Not bad. The spoon with the sashimi was so yummy! the shot of sake that same along with this dish really added on to the experience. It definitely is a must try....at least once!

For the service, this is where they lost a star....sadly, I have to agree to with gf Natalie...who also yelped about their slow and inattentive service. We had to ask the waitresses twice for ginger, and when they asked if we wanted to see the dessert menu, we said sure. After about 15 mins, they never even came back to see what we decided for dessert. We got very impatient and just changed our minds and asked for the check instead. That was about the downfall of our experience tonight. The place wasn't even busy, so they don't really have any other reason to forget or not follow through. 

Good sushi spot, but not the only one out there...if you do come, try the HH specials and must get the "spoonful of happiness".
author: Christina T.

description:
First time at Koo and we enjoyed our meal, overall 3.5 stars.  Some of the reviews on Yelp were helpful.

We made reservations for Sun 11/30, slow night I guess, it wasn't necessary.  We picked the sushi bar since that's where the sushi chefs are so you can talk to your chef if you want.  That was cool.  The bar only fits 6 people so I recommend it.

We got:

Spoonful of Happiness $10 - comes w/ two spoons: One Spoonful of Uni, Quall Egg, Tobiko, other Ponzu & Ankimo wrapped with whitefish, Truffle-Oil  - Plus  a shot of chilled Sake.  It was all good.  We got two orders, one for ea of us.

Marinated artichoke w/ shichimi soy mayo $6 - it was nice though wish it was a full artichoke.  It was only half & small.  Where are they getting artichoke in Nov?

Albacore tataki $13 - tiny slices, thought it was good not great.

Kamasu sushi -Japan, Barracuda) $5.5 - it was 2 pc of nigiri.  Thought the fish was fine, rice fell apart while eating.

Ma Dai Sushi - Japan, Sea Bream $5 - 2 pc nigiri.  Fish good, rice just ok.

Azteca Roll $14 - recommended by chef.  It was tasty, 8 pcs.  Crab, avocado, gobo & cucumber wrapped in white fish topped w/ thin slice of jalepeno, spicy mayo, tobiko & ponzu lightly baked.  

Dynamite roll $5 - Baked scallop w/ wasabi-tobiko $5 - handroll, tasty.

Mt Fuji dessert $4 + ginger gelato $2 = $6.  Small tasty homemade cake, very chocolately & rich.  Ginger gelato - no ginger taste at all, from Ciao Bella gelato.

Total w/ tax, not tip was $79.75.  Not cheap, but tasty.

Bathroom: One unisex had toilet & urinal. Sink is outside.
author: Ann L.

description:
After dinner here last night it's become one of my favorite sushi spots in San Francisco.  Why?

- Authentic sushi chef.  Ask to sit at the bar.  They'll churn out mouth-watering, eye-catching works of art.... feast on them!
- Clean, comfortable interior.  Sometimes it doesn't matter how good the food is if the interior looks like somebody's basement.  Sorry.
- Mellow French music in the background.  Don't ask... just sit back and enjoy.
author: Kristen S.

description:
EDIT: okay so my #1 Fan Dfens T. thinks this is a lot of food. Actually, 1 order of oysters is only 2 pcs. We had 2 orders = 4 oysters. Also, it's SMALL PORTIONS HERE! plus it was split between 3 hungry girls
that is all.
Okay but my betch and I do grub like crazy amounts NOM NOM NOM NOM NOM NOM. You reading this betch!??! I said "I HAS A CARROT. NOM NOM NOM NOM NOM"
_______________________


My girlfriends and I ordered all this:
salmon & tuna tartare
the grilled eggplant smothered in miso
spoonfuls of happiness
kumamoto oysters

for sushi:
the best roll
uni nigiri
aji nigiri
tobiko + quail egg nigiri

The salmon & tuna tartare was good. What I liked most about it was the chips it came with, and the fact that the tuna and salmon were diced. Usually the tuna tartare is a disgusting mush which is why i don't normally order it.
we all enjoyed the eggplant, it was grilled perfectly and the miso gave it a nice sweet taste to offset the smoky bitterness of the grilled skin.
our oysters were fresh, we liked them. nothing new there. 
SPOONFULS OF HAPPINESS!! honestly, the best thing we freaking ate all night. 
I felt that the spoon with the quail egg and uni was much nicer, smoother and rich. My betch enjoyed the ankimo (steamed monk fish liver) wrapped with albacore and white truffle oil better. I agreed that it was good, but i felt that the aftertaste of the truffle oil overpowered the monk fish liver. 

All of our sushi was the usual standard fare. The rice maybe should have been cooked a little better because it all fell apart every time I attempted picking up my nigiri with my chopsticks. 
Originally my review was going to be 4 stars, but I had to deduct another one because my friend's best roll had the butt of the avocado in it. oh COME ON you're supposed to chop that part of the avocado off! nobody freaking eats that.

Other than that, this place is sort of overly hyped. The only thing that truly stood out were the spoonfuls of happiness.
author: Susy C.

description:
Thanks to iTunes I've been listening to The Alchemist on my iPod.
And one of the things I've picked-up on was signs (or omens).
And now I think my life is too inundated with too many signs.

Case in point:
We found parking less than a block away from Koo.  Not only a sign but a miracle.
We didn't make reservations but a party didn't show up and we were seated almost immediately.  Yet another sign.
While leering over at the sushi bar to see what was being served up, I caught the eye of one the sushi's chef's and we slightly bowed to each other.  I know its customary to bow but I still took it as sign since I maybe a little sign crazy.
Regardless, I couldn't help but think that all signs were pointing to a good meal.

And it was a good meal, but I was hoping for something that I could yelp about.
I ordered the chef's sushi special and a Yebisu.
The special came with tuna, salmon, yellow tail, and white fish sashimi.  The tuna was fresh and firm and the white fish was outstanding.
The salmon and yellow tail were only average.
Maybe I should've explained to the sushi chef I wanted to try something more exotic.
And why I drank a beer instead of sake is still kind of a mystery right now.

I guess I'd be willing to go back for more fish and to drink sake, but for right now, I'd need a pretty big sign for that to happen.
author: Dan B.

description:
I've had Koo on my list of places to try for a while now. Last night, I got my chance. A friend of mine who lives in the Sunset but had never been to or even heard of Koo joined me. 

We ordered the:
Tuna and salmon tartar
Japanese eggplant
Chicken teriyaki
Spicy tuna roll
Best roll
Kappa maki

We didn't quite finish everything but I was really impressed with both the quality and the presentation. The chicken teriyaki came with two types of grilled squash. The tartar was accompanied by guacamole.

Koo pays attention to the details, I like that.

Service is quick and friendly and the prices are reasonable.
author: Miriam W.

description: Freshest sushi, the special sushi page cannot be beat. My favorite was the whitefish with monkfish pâté spoon
author: Calvius W.

description: Whenever I crave Japanese food this is the first spot that pops into my head. The entrees are excellent, the rolls are tasty and the service is on point. I've been here a total of four times within the last two months. Each time I've been here there were some orders that stuck and some that came and went. For example, the miso cod (served hot) is something that I MUST order when I revisit this place, as well as the duck heart salad. Im actually craving that cod as I write this... Hmmmm
author: Jennifer F.

description:
nice flavors, gorgeous presentation (see my photos), and friendly attentive service. my first dish tonight was the spoonful of happiness. two chinese soup spoons  - one with the freshest uni and quail egg yolk swimming in ponzu. the other was a house made ankimo wrapped in suzuki sashimi. OMG! so good! awesome way to start the dining experience.
next were the pair of kumamoto oysters on a half shell.
simple, clean, and tasty.
a happy surprise are the $4 temaki hand rolls.
we ordered a bunch of them - unagi with avocado, hamachi, spicy tuna, tempura shrimp, crawfish, and a real crab cali roll.
all perfectly assembled and wrapped in crispy nori.
by the time the seasoned tofu and mint short rib lettuce cups came i was pretty full but i forced myself to taste them.
more winners.
and to cap off the evening
mount fuji dense chocolate cake which was so yummy i could ordered a second round.
another tasty dessert this evening was the fresh strawberry tiramisu.
nice sweet fruit from the strawberries and subtle coffee flavor from the tiramisu.
this meal hit on all cylinders.
JYW likes!
author: Jeff W.

description:
We dined here in late October 2011, I'm just late on posting the review.

The Spoonful of Happiness (actually 2 spoonfuls per order) is a must - they're bursting with flavor and have a creative and attractive presentation. This was our first visit and we also tried the Dragon, Best, Spicy Tuna and U2 roll. They were all okay, but nothing special. We ordered the sweet and spicy green beans but they never came (didn't think to make sure they weren't on the bill until we were already home, but doubt it was included since the price was reasonable) and the green tea tasted burnt.  We'd come back for the spoonful of happiness and a quick basic roll or two sometime if it was convenient.
author: Heather M.

description:
Came here for the 2nd time and the food did not disappoint again. I'd give this place 10 stars if I could!

BEST. SABA. EVER.
BEST. UNI. EVER.
BEST. IKURA. EVER.

SPOONFUL OF HAPPINESS = BEST. THING. EVER.
author: Denise L.

description:
lovely meal on a friday night when the bf and i couldn't decide where to eat.  It's in the neighborhood and I mean to go back more often.

The first time we went maybe about a year ago I remember not being super impressed by it, especially because the bf got the vegetarian combo that turned out super bland.

This time we ordered a bunch of the vegetable small plates instead and he looooved the flavor of the eggplant and the tofu.  I liked the sour and spicy green beans too.
 
Next time I gotta try the spoonful, but I had a scallop hand roll that was so flavorful and some awesome sashimi.  

Service was great and because we ate early like around 630, no wait!
author: Tiffany D.

description:
love this place.  excellent service, clean and friendly, tasty tasty sushi & japanese food.

-must try is spoonfuls of happiness, especially if you are an uni lover.  also the hamachi kama is buttery and melts in your mouth.  they crisp & charr  the skin just right.
-pass on the squid, it's rubbery and not that great.  wish it was fried.

great place for a date, sit at the bar or cozy corner.   candlelight helps you look extra cute and kissable :)
author: Josie M.

description: I've been coming here for years now & it's the BEST sushi in San Francisco. Spoonful of Happiness is my favorite. We don't really do rolls. Nigiri & sashimi all the way. Love you, Koo!
author: Laura P.

description: Went for a quick bite before the holiday shopping kickoff with some friends.  We were all first timers.  The staff was super nice, the fish was fresh and the happy hour handrolls awesome that we kept ordering more and more...  Need to go back soon!
author: Michelle S.

description:
absolutely freaking delicious (and expensive, but worth it) 
Came here with my BF a couple of days ago. Coming here for the first time I was torn between just ordering more of the classic japanese dishes or their own creative concoctions....
Ended up going for the fun creative stuff and all I can say is I cant wait to go back....
We had a green salad which was perfectly dressed, spicy green string beans which were super tasty, miso which was also good, the tuna and salmon ceviche type dish with the shrimp crackers, the jalapeno halibut yummy deliciousness which is actually not that spicy, and a roll...i forget which one....I know it was lightly baked and had delicious crab in it. OH and of course...i had the crawfish handroll.....YUM!
My only regret is not getting the spoonful of happiness. Which I will FOR SURE get next time.
author: Yuliya R.

description:
Koo- when I move to San Francisco, you won't be able to get rid of me!!

Four of us ate here- we had the seafood salad (the bamboo tower), a dynamite hand roll for each of us, the azteca roll, the u2 roll, the flying kamikaze roll, and the sashimi platter.

Every single thing was delicious - my favorites were the azteca roll (I could have eaten a whole one myself!), the dynamite hand roll (wasabi tobiko- can I sprinkle u on everything?), and the salmon from the sashimi platter (like delicious fishy-butter).

They also were veeeeeery accommodating to make everything gluten-free (gf soy sauce, ponzu sauce on the side, plain shrimp instead of tempura shrimp).

With a glass of wine and a beer, the bill was 150 after tax and tip for all of us. So worth it. I'd go here again tomorrow.
author: Karen E.

description: Love this place! First time here. The people were friendly, everything was clean and sushi was fresh! I will be back!
author: Emily B.

description:
Hubby and I were feeling for Japanese with a lil' fusion this night.. we decided to come here since the last time we ate here was 3 years ago.  I originally wanted Kabuto =(.  But thought okay lets give it a try again for it was one of our fav. (3 years ago)..
Spoon Full of Happiness ~ I'm usually not the one to be observant but instead of three spoons of happiness, it's only two spoons. We asked and the waiter said it's always been two instead of three.  NOT!! It used to be three spoons and two shots of saki.  You take the first spoon in your mouth, then take a shot, take on another spoon, another shot and the last spoon.  They were also out of the monk fish liver, out of the my favorite king crab dynamite. boo.  Sashimi slices were even smaller than before.  We left very disappointed and said to ourselves that this dinner is a bye bye to you Koo...
author: LENA D.

description:
We've been back to Koo several times and have to say that we definitely feel exceptionally lucky to live 2 minutes away.  We've also been able to sit at the chef's counter and it's definitely our favourite spot.  Sometimes we're extremely lucky to be seated right away if we arrive around 7:45 (without a reservation); on our last visit we were happy to wait a bit (1 hour) for a spot at the counter.

Make sure to ask for the chef's recommendation of what's awesome for that day.
author: Claudine C.

description: I came here for happy hour, but it's really not that much cheaper.  Hand rolls are only about $1 cheaper, although they are pretty tasty and made well.  The Stuffed Jalapeno has a nice kick.  I also had the Miso Marinated Black Cod, and while it was very tender and was a big portion, it was way too salty.  A bowl of rice would have been perfect with it.
author: Karen L.

description:
sashimi: very fresh and sliced very thinly. I highly recommend it here.

tea: very hot!! which is perfect! Even when they come to refill your half filled tea cup, the tea still comes out hot! (they charge you for the tea though =|  )

sushi rolls: they are big and filled with lots of substance as opposed to filling it with lots of rice and barely any fish/crab.

spoonful of happiness: sip of sake, first spoon, 2nd sip of sake, 2nd spoon.  
I have heard the first spoon is pretty delicious and the 2nd spoon is average.

godzilla tofu?   the description said that the tofu would be  crispy and they weren't kidding! the edges were actually a bit crispy.

service: waitresses are very friendly and actually speak japanese
author: Jessica T.

description:
omg I want another!!  without even knowing the name of the dish, the first thing my date said was "wow, that was really good, i'm so happy right now...." it's like the sushi version of ecstasy, and worth every penny.    get the "spoonful of happiness."  

the rest of the meal was also excellent..  we had a couple sushi maki rolls which were all delicious, as well as the spicy tuna tacos, which were amazing and a steal at only $4 each.  

due to the rave reviews on yelp, we also ordered the miso cod, but i was't impressed; it was definitely good, but after the 10-star performance with the "spoonful of happiness," even this above average dish tasted blah.   i'd recommend sticking to the sushi.

skip dessert, order another spoonful of happiness.  

fair warning that they close a tad on the early side and can be a bit aggressive about last call.  and it's a small restaurant, so i'd recommend reservations. it's a nice ambiance though, especially if you're in a corner or along the wall.
author: Greg B.

description: Loved every bite! Fresh fish and great service.
author: Lauren C.

description: Order off of the daily menu and you won't be disappointed.  I love sashimi so I usually judge sushi restaurants on the quality of the fish, rather than rolls, and the fish here is fresh, clean, and tender.  The small plates are also crowd pleasers.
author: Allegra H.

description: Attentive and pleasant service, fresh fish and a good mix of traditional and inventive twists on Japanese cuisine. This the only place I go for sashimi in the Inner and Outer Sunset. The avocado-tuna-salmon poke is a fun and tasty appetizer, too.
author: I Like T.

description:
FOOD:
1.) Salmon Sashimi (4pc) = Holy crap!!! Their sashimi is soooo soft!!! It blew my mind!!!!
2) Maguro Tuna Sashimi (4pc) = Again!!! Soft as hell!! Oiishiii!!
3.) Toro Tuna Nigiri = This one was supposed to be chef's choice, but sure it was soft, but it was also stringy too. Didn't like needing to chew through it.
4.) Seaweed Salad = Sesame oil and seeds adds a nice touch
5.) Scallop Handroll = Ooh! The first time eating a handroll! It really is like eating an ice cream cone! But not! This scallop handroll tasted good.
6.) Spoonful of Happiness = O yeah, can not forget... Spoonful of happiness!! These are REALLY good!! Burst of flavor n yumminess. Served with a side of sake, to accentuate the flavors. *dies*




SERVICE:
Service is great. Kioshi-san is a great sushi man. Love his marbled neon pink glasses. lol. And the waitresses refill my hot tea many a times ;) Love sitting at the bars. It's totally my new thing now. Get instant service plus get to ask random questions like... "How do you say happiness in Japanese?" lol.. And ordering random sides like avocado and getting it right away



ATMOSPHERE:
It's cute, it's nice. Good detail to decor and cleanliness, with Japanesey touch to it. Small sushi bar to the left, seating maybe 10 ppl. Dining room to the right with about 10 tables maybe. Not too big.
author: Angela L.

description:
Koo is definitely one of the better Japanese restaurant I've been to in a long time.

Parking:  I recommend parking at UCSF's parking garage, two and a half blocks east from Koo on Irving St.  

Service:  Our waiter was patient and went through the menu, informing us of their specials and recommendations.  We were chatting away and it seemed our food was brought out quickly.  During our meal, he checked up on us periodically to see how we were doing.  Our hot tea were constantly refilled and empty plates taken away once they were finished, yet we didn't feel our privacy was interrupted.

Food (dinner for two):

2 orders of A Spoonful of Happiness: I thought they gave one spoonful per order but it's actually two spoons per order (one with uni and one with a whitefish and ankimo) with a shot of cold sake.  The uni was fresh and was a good mouthful; they don't skimp on it.  This is definitely one order per person.

Tuna and Salmon Tartare: Not too generous on the amount of tuna/salmon, but it was the right amount for the number of shrimp chips they give you.  Slightly dry; I wished they marinated the tuna and salmon with lemon juice.

Miso Marinated Black Cod: It was succulent and tasty.  Portion was not too big.  It doesn't come with rice, so we had to order some on the side.

Azteca Roll: The whitefish topped with jalepeno and ponzu was nicely put together.  The jalepeno definitely gives it a kick.

Rainbow Roll:  I always order a rainbow roll at every sushi restaurant I first go to.  This basic roll is a good way to judge the restaurant based on fish variety and quality and chef's presentation and style.  The fish was fresh, but I wasn't impressed.

Mt. Fuji with a scoop of Green Tea Gelato:  I love green tea and I love gelato.  The Mt. Fuji was rich and delicious.
author: Bruce M.

description:
Mmm... Definitely one of the best sushi places around, hands down! We ordered so much food and it was worth the food coma even though I had to drive back to Oakland!

I never never EVER like raw oysters but I don't even care if these came from Kumamoto, it would be worth the nuclear radiation! They were mouth wateringly orgasmic!
Spoonfuls of Happiness immediately calmed my initial anger because it took me 25 mins to find parking! Smooth and beautifully put together flavors.
Crawfish and King crab handrolls melted in my mouth and gave me a boost in flavor.
Icing on this delectable cake! We ordered an assorted amount of Nigiri and the best one, best best one (after 2 different types of Hamachi, Uni, Tuna, Snapper, and Maguro), the most delicious one, the extremely fatty tuna, I don't even like Tuna! But this one was sweet and muscle-less. Thinking about it makes me want to jizz in my pants! Must order! BUT- it is $16/2pcs. Well worth the price, we must've eaten like 20 though. 

Oh and the actual cake was a rich well-made lava cake.

Please ask the chef if he needs a personal taster, because I will eat anything he wants me to. *Pac-man face*
author: Winè C.

description:
After reading all the great reviews from this place I decided to give it a try. I came away with a weird, scary, and disappointing experience.

I ordered a couple rolls from this place. The weird part is that the food looked and tasted good, BUT I ended up getting VERY SICK, breaking out with hives all over my body for weeks.

*** I ordered the same sushi that I have ordered at TONS of other sushi restaurants and never got sick or broke out with hives. I am not allergic to sushi, or the type that I ordered. 

The disappointing part was knowing that they did not take the proper precautions that one should take when handling raw fish and eel. I'm fairly sure that it was some kind of bacteria from the fish or eel. It was either bacteria that was on the cutting board (i.e not properly sanitized) or it was improper storage of the fish (not at the right temperature, or left out).

Could I have been the 1 unlucky exception to getting sick? Yes. But once is way more than enough for me not to want to have anyone experience that. There are plenty of other Sushi restaurants in SF that have better sushi that won't get you sick.

So the real question is...do you feel lucky punk...well do you...?
author: Nick C.

description:
Came here last Friday night with the Bf. We made reservations day of in case it would be super busy. We got seated immediately for our 8 p.m reservations. The restaurant itself isn't impressive, but the food is pretty good.

We got:

- beef tataki: cooked rare with a nice tasty sauce

- the best roll: my favorite! asparagus tempura is super yummy

- spoonful of happiness: I made my boyfriend eat the uni one because I wasn't brave enough, but the other spoonful, Idk what it consisted of, but it was DELICIOUS! must get!

- another roll I forgot...

- the Mt. Fuji: SO GOOD. I LOVE CHOCOLATE MOUSSE!
author: Jackie M.

description: Hands down the best Japanese food I have had in San Francisco, and very reasonably priced for the quality. Flawless dinner. Enough said.
author: Isaac T.

description:
I can't understand what everybody is raving about. Their rolls are fine, nothing creative or exciting, and they don't resemble Japanese home-style or traditional rolls either.  Their fish is nothing special either. If the fish was spectacular I could understand their lack of effort. 

The worst part of eating here, was finding scales in my food. I think that is entirely unacceptable for a place with these prices. 

Last thing, and this might just be a personal problem, but I don't like that their sink and mirror is outside in the hallway, separate from the toilet. What if there is something in my teeth and I need to floss? I don't want to do it in front of people eating their food. Kind of ridiculous.
author: Irina S.

description:
*** STAY AWAY FROM THESE SCAMS ***

I seldom give few stars but this place scammed us THREE times in 1 evening and I have to forewarn my fellow Yelpers even most people have given it a high star rating.

In short, they scammed us 3 times in 1 evening-- deceiving us saying they had live uni, giving us scraps of fish, and lying about sea snail being raw while it's totally boiled.

Here's the detailed experience:

We were looking for a place that served live uni. I called this place and they said they had it. When we arrived, I asked twice more, once when we walked in and second when we were sitting down. I spoke very slowly and explained very clearly that we wanted the LIVE uni and were told they had it. When we started ordering the server immediately said they did not have it at all. I was too shocked as I asked a total of 3 times.

So as we were disappointed but figured let's make the best of it.

The second scam was we decided to order sashimi. We ordered wild king salmon, maguro (tuna) and albacore tuna. The fish came out stringy, somewhat irregular shapes as they were like scraps of the fish as my date promptly pointed out. We were so dismayed we called onto the server, whom sent the original server away and told us the other server was off duty while he was still working at the table as we can see. She then told us the sashimi single [sic] were smaller because the bigger pieces would be "MORE EXPENSIVE"! 

WHAT?!!! First, there was no separate pricing for "smaller" pieces. Second, they insulted patrons as if we would not be able to afford them. We were so upset and described that they cannot serve scraps to customers, period. My date pointed out that the pieces were so small you can't even taste them properly. And the albacore was still having the frozen ice in it. We returned the dish.

Third scam was we ordered the sea snail and we asked twice if they were served raw or cooked. The server said raw, twice. They were served boiled.

This restaurant was arrogant and thought they could scam customers by thinking patrons were stupid and would take whatever they were served.

We had ordered a bunch of other things in between the scams-- spoon of happiness had way too much ponzu sauce and the fish was not too good as it's not smooth taste and stringy. Salmon and tuna tartare and Ice fish nigiri were just okay. The only saving grace was the uni nigiri which was better.

But I would not have to track out there to have regular uni.

I would tell all my friends and Yelpers to stay away from this place because they disrespect their patrons.
author: T L.

description:
expensive, packed on a weekend night, BUT you get what you pay and wait for..delicious and fresh sushi

im not a big fan of sushi rolls or cooked items, i'd rather have nigiri and sashimi (isnt this the staple of all good japanese restaurants? their fish..), all the fish were fresh and delicious

yes the black cod was good, and yea, the thing that's raved about most here is the spoonful of happiness, i can eat 3 spoonfuls each time i come here...the only complain i have about this, i'd realy opt for two spoons of the uni and quail egg, the other spoon with the fish is a bit too salty, FYI if you pay an extra dollar you can sub out that spoon of fish for another uni, definitely the way to go

other stuff that were good, the raw octopus and the clams, amazing!
author: Long C.

description:
A great Sushi Ran alternative that is IN the city!

My benchmark is when little old Japanese couples are in the restaurant, you know it is a fabulous place.  I took Mike L. here a while back when he first got his job with Google... yes, my review is very much outdated but I still think quite relevant! 

All of the rolls were fabulous - so fresh and so tasty.  The place is small, but the wait staff was quite attentive and speedy.  The only negative is trying to find parking in the Irving area - it can get quite tricky during dinner hours.  Koo doesn't have the reputation of Sushi Ran, but I think it is just as nice (and delicious) and less pretentious. 

I'll be coming back - the next time I crave sushi and am in the company of sushi connoisseurs.
author: Lisa L.

description:
meh! kinda disappointed. 
Spicy Handroll-3 stars. nothin special. not spicy IMO.
California-3 stars.
Fried Tofu-2 stars.
Stuffed Jalapeno-3 stars
Toro-4 stars. fatty but cost $15. I've had better
Spoonful of Happyness-3 stars. soy sauce over powered the dish.
Amaebi-3 stars. Amaebi was good but fried shrimp head was soaked in oil.  
King Crab handroll-4 stars...Highlight of the nite...very good! but wish they would use better quality seaweed.  Soggy seaweed made the handroll hard to eat.
Overall experience: felt got fooled by ambiance.  Not impressed.
author: Chloe H.

description:
This place really surprised me.  I've passed by it many times and had never eaten here, but I really enjoyed my dinner here a few weeks ago.  

Service was attentive and friendly, refilling water glasses and such without being over-bearing.  We sat at the sushi bar, which I always enjoy because watching the chef's knife skills impresses me.  I also like being able to check out the seafood before ordering.

My date and I split everything we ordered...Wakame Salad, Uni, Hamachi/Avocado Handroll, Mackerel, and the most delicious Scallops I've ever had in my life.  Everything was fresh and tasted great, and I can't wait to come back here again!

Bonus points for having a happy hour menu (Sun-Thurs) on select rolls, salads, and drinks!
author: Lindsay B.

description:
The sushi here is, quite frankly, awful.  The fish is extremely fishy, the rice is served cold and is a little undercooked.  I had the sea snail, which tasted like cardboard, the uni, which was still sandy, and I had to spit out the scallop.

I can't believe this placed was given four stars. I didn't try the grilled food, as I went for sushi.  The ambiance and service was fine, but you can't seriously call yourself a sushi joint and serve dismal pieces of fish.  

Perhaps SF just doesn't do sushi the way LA or NYC can?
author: Josephine H.

description:
Fresh sashimi and the Spoonful of Happiness is killlllller good!  One spoon is uni with a quail egg and tobiko, and the other is monkfish liver wrapped in whitefish, and it's served with a shot of sake.

We also got the sashimi combo which had slices of salmon (best ever), hamachi, tuna, and striped bass.  The striped bass had an odd taste to it, and I would request not to have it next time... We also got the amaebi (they also give you the shrimp head fried..yum!), hamachi, red tuna, and unagi nigiri (which my bf loved), and then....the oh-toro nigiri ($16 for two pieces? omg) which is fatty blue fin tuna.  Delicious, but it was definitely fatty alright.  I'd probably get the regular blue fin tuna next time because toro is just too mushy and oily for me.

Must get: Spoonful of Happiness
Don't get: Azteca (unless you like salty sushi..). Disappointing.

The ambience is pretty intimate and a great place to bring a date.  There was no wait for dinner on a Friday night (huge plus in my book!).  Koo is pretty pricey, at $100 for the two of us.  Fortunately, the meal at least filled us up, since the worst feeling is when you empty your wallet, and your stomach is still empty.

I would come back for the Spoonful of Happiness, but for the $$$ and the taste overrall, I still prefer Okoze Sushi.
author: Betty W.

description:
I was almost persuaded to give Koo 4 stars, 1 less because it is pricey... (between two people, the bill always seems to be over $100). However, that would not do it justice simply for its quality, ambiance, service, and owner; all exceptional for a Japanese owned Japanese restaurant. You get what you pay for. Everything I have ever ordered, was always fresh (and delicious). The owner, I can't spell his name and don't want to offend :P, makes helpful recommendations on the catches of the day. He made suggestions based on previous choices I made (I was sitting at the bar) and introduced new delicacies I would not have thought to try otherwise.

Spoon Full of Happiness, everyone seems to love that and I am no exception-- if you haven't already, you've got to try it!

The oysters are rather petite but it is the type of oyster it is; there are several breeds of oysters. Though small, these were still fresh and goood like must oysters-- yum.

For dessert, their homemade cookies, they really are homemade! Thin and flavorful without being too heavy or rich.

This is and has been for years, my favorite Japanese restaurant yet!

Quick note on the ambiance; it is great for catching up with a friend or a date. It is a smaller venue so reservations are advised. Lighting is dim and overall the place is quite clean.

By the way, I love the taste of O-Toro (fat Blue Fin Tuna) but it's being fished to extinction... just sayin'

Have a good eat here!
author: Tammy H.

description: Koo were very sweet and found us a table when we had no reservation.  However, that was a total aberration since the next several groups behind us were told the wait was an hour and a half -- we just walked in at the right time.  I tried their special "a taste of happiness," and it was so wonderful!  I have never experienced the "umame" taste so strongly -- it lingered and really stood out.  Everything else we ordered was very pleasant and fresh.
author: Tasha D.

description:
I typically enjoy an early dinner so I've never had to make reservations at Koo. As long as we are there before 7pm, there is generally no wait. An additional benefit of eating early is there is usually parking in the area. 

The customer service is excellent. The service is speedy and without feeling like they are standing over your shoulder.

I love rolls including hand rolls so I've tried almost all of them. The fish is fresh and delicious. I also love the generous portion of tuna and salmon tartar with guacamole and shrimp chips. 

The decor is modern and clean but the tables are quite close together. This can be a problem because I feel like I'm talking to my date and the table next to me. The fish is worth that inconvenience.
author: Fatima J.

description:
