This is the good ish right here.  Tried this place for the first time several nights ago and like what Arnold had said was, "I'll be back!"  We got there a little early for a quick dinner so had no problems getting seated at 5:30.  I went with the Tokyo Crunch roll and had to try the crawfish handroll (say whaaa?) and the lady friend went for some salmon, asparagus, lemon concoction roll.  The TC roll is pretty damn good, it's got all these little fried crunch tempura bits dumped on top it with a drizzle of some special saucy-ness on top of that.  The crawfish roll was a'ight.  It really didn't have a distinct flavor but anytime I can crunch down on an entire crustacea I'm good.  I was still on hunger-hurt so I had to order the hamachi handroll as well and that was damn goood.  Hamachi was fresh and tasty.  No real fishy taste going on there.

Waitresses were attentive and kept the cups overflowing with the genmai.  I like this place...I LIKE IT A LOT!
author: D L.

description:
Since I was craving for sushi, Yelp recommended Koo. 

I ordered the salmon & avocado handroll, best roll, flying kamikaze, uni sashimi, oysters in shell, spoonful of happiness, and marinated black cod. The spoonful of happiness was AMAZING.

itty bitty random raw stuff on a spoon with a shot of sake. First you sip the sake, followed by slurping the first spoon. Next, you sip more sake, and slurp the second spoon. The purpose of sipping the sake is to help prevent mixing the tastes of each spoon.

On the other hand, the black cod didn't really rock my world. The tofu was a bit bland and the cod was over-marinated. It had a taste of sweet, tangy, and salty flavor to it.
author: Brenda C.

description:
We went here for my baby sister's 21st birthday over the weekend. It's been a while since I've had sushi in the Sunset area so Koo was definitely a pleasant surprise. It's trendy, the prices are reasonable and the sushi/sashimi is great!

We ordered the Spoonful of Happiness, kumamoto oysters, wild salmon nigiri, and seaweed salad. All were great. I especially loved the kumamoto oysters and wild salmon. Fresh and top quality. 

For sushi rolls, we got Rock & Roll & Dragon rolls. Both were good too. I like more adventurous stuff so I prefer the items from the kitchen.
author: Chi N.

description:
I have been eating here for years. Last time, we went to happy hour and that was reasonably priced and quite tasty, though not terribly filling. Oh Koo, why must you be so expensive?!

Location: A pain in the butt to get to if you don't live nearby. Plus the restaurant is small, but with warmly elegant ambiance.

Food: The best sushi I have had in SF. I have not tried every restaurant, however, having tried a few, it has been my experience that SF sushi is just mediocre. For that matter, so is everyplace BUT Los Angeles. I have had the BEST sushi for CHEAP in LA and I am sorry, SF, but you just can't cut it. Well, KOO can, but it will cost ya'. Nigiri and Sashimi are amazing!! Best cut, freshest fish, even their rolls are yummy! I love their Miso soup as well.

Service: Fast, efficient and helpful - the trifecta.

Price: Noooooo!! Go for happy hour. Note: they are about as expensive as any other Japanese Restaurant in their class in SF. I suppose if you want fantastic fish in the city, you must pay.

Conclusion: Yum!
author: Erika T.

description: Yes... Koo Sushi may have unique looking japanese food... Yes.. Koo Sushi also may have a nice environment... Staffs were all very attentive and nice. But I truly think its a bit over priced... for its portions and also for its quality... not saying that the food were bad ... i personally think that u can get the same type of food quality else where with a lower price... I doubt i will be back anytime soon....
author: Annie Y.

description:
Hands down my favorite spot for sushi in the hood. The Inner Sunset has a lot of great options, but Koo stands out as the best. Consistently great service, fresh sushi and I have enjoyed everything that I've tried on the menu. 

Two items I have to get every trip: Tokyo Crunch and Mocchi ice cream.
author: Dan H.

description:
Moderately-priced sushi, but great quality!  "Spoonful of Happiness" is always a great starter--I had two for myself during one visit!  It's dangerous because it will coax you to order the other fabulous rolls (Azteca and Best roll), nigiris, and sashimi they have to offer, despite trying to be good to not overindulge.  Service rocks too! (they're closed on Mondays, and usually open at 5:30pm everyday)

Try the ankimo.. monkfish liver... everytime I eat this, i feel like my tongue is making love to the liver... mmmmmm... sooo good!

The best part is that I only live 2 blocks from this place.... I can literally roll outta bed to grab me some rolls!


AHHH it breaks my heart when one of my favorite restaurants started treating me badly.... that's why I removed a star ( I should remove more)....SEE BELOW.

Be warned.. I went there the other day with my friend for just desserts (the mt. fuji chocolate cake and the strawberry tiramisu)... and they told me that we have to leave if there are other people who come for dinner..  I thought that was hella rude, granted I AM A REGULAR at their place, not to mention we sat at the corner where we sat at right angles from each other.    We were there well over an hour before they were expecting parties with reservations.  I told them it was so rude.  Hell naw, we won't go!....

okay.. lately i've been having a love-hate relationship with Koo.  I tried their Bamboo Tower salad... SOOO GOOD.. it's my new favorite.  $11
author: Grace M.

description:
Now it's a bit of a splurge if you want a good variety, but the quality is exceptional.
the Albacore Tataki is one of a kind delisiyous, light, flavorful...
the Spoonfuls of Happiness is one of my personal favorites.
What they have is a good variety of simple combinations that aren't in other establishments, (or they've renewed it with an ingredient or two extra).  They definitely have UNCONVENTIONAL combinations, while still faithful to a few old-world fundamentals.
And of course, Sake!  Chilled sake with that Albacore Tataki is a sophisticated mirienda, if not enough as a light dinner (well, pair it up with an Unagi roll).
A+ Koo!
author: Jay M.

description:
Spoonful of happiness is the best thing here! Order at least one per person. I came with a friend who thought the item could be shared LOL, no way, and even if you could, you'd probably want to eat more than one order of this! Even our waiter asked how many orders of the spoonful of happiness we wanted.

Don't come here for the sushi rolls because they're mediocre. Everything else is great though. We had the Kumamoto Oysters on the half shell, flying kamikaze, best roll, stuffed jalapeno, and spicy tuna taco.

Ambiance is intimate and so romantic with candles and perfectly lit lighting. Servers were constantly refilling our water before it was even half-glass - wow! I've never had any restaurant refill our water as often and as quickly as Koo so far. I love Koo!
author: Candy L.

description: I came back here for their $4 happy hour uni handroll and was disappointed to see that it's an extra $1 for the uni. The uni wasn't as plentiful as the first time around but still heavenly with added crunchy bits of tobiko for $0.50 more. Of course, I had to get the Spoonful of Happiness, which is still just that - happiness in my mouth.
author: Tina T.

description:
Lets get down to business. Food is awesome! That's what everyone wanted to hear right? The "Best Roll" (I know stupid name...) is really the best roll on the menu. Everything else is great too! 

So why the one less star of being perfect? Service. My girlfriend and I had a reservation for 8. We arrived at 8. We were seated at 8:10. You're thinking "What a jerk! so what it was 10 minutes" Normally i wouldn't have a problem but my girlfriend and I and another group were ignored completely! There was no, "Sorry we're busy. Can you wait another minute?" We were never acknowledged. not even a smile. Just felt invisible. 

Once you're seated you are treated much better. All in all i would go back again, it was a good night.
author: Zachery H.

description:
I am not the first and will not be the last to say this place is fantastic.  Thanks fellow yelpers for giving such great reviews about Koo.  The atmosphere is clean, cozy and full of cool ambiance. 
Our small party of 4 tried the Bamboo tower, and wild arrangement of sushi, but what I come back for is the Seabass.  Yummy and perfectly presented in a mild tasty broth.  Can you say heaven in a bowl?

You will need to make reservations unless you prefer the sushi bar.  And when you visit this place, you will not be disappointed.
author: Marie S.

description:
Definitely one of the top sashimi (not stupid rolls with a bunch of brown and orange sauce drizzled on the top) establishments in the city.

When you want fresh raw fish and a relaxed environment go to Koo!
author: Mike C.

description:
Pros:
Very solid fish, great selection; I particularly enjoyed the shrimp dumplings (sounds lame, I know, but these were unique), and the scallops and kanpachi were quite good.  Tokyo Crunch came highly recommended and I thought it was good but not great.

Cons:
I would like to se more menu items that take risks, fusing different flavors or doing things unexpected.

Fun:
There is a UCSF parking garage two blocks away on Irving.  Score!  Makes coming here soooo much easier.
author: Mike G.

description: The only thing you need to know? Soft shell crawfish handroll. Done. Best sushi in the city.
author: Stephanie W.

description: Best sushi in the city!  Incredibly friendly chefs, top quality seaweed and delicious rolls and nigiri.  I'm definitely heading back.
author: Corie C.

description:
3.5 stars (rounded down).

The main reason I likely wouldn't return here unfortunately has nothing to do with the cute space, the friendly staff, or the decent sushi - it's just that's it's too far (so the above doesn't warrant the trek)! 

We ordered:
- Azteca Roll (pretty good) (~$12)
- Best Roll (enjoyed - but could've done more with the salmon / lemon) (~$12)
- Kamikaze (not great) (~$12)
- Dynamite and King Dynamite Hand Rolls (very good) (~$7 / hand roll)
- Catch of the day - negi-toro (very fresh fish) (~$12)
- White King Salmon Nigiri ($6 for two pieces)

The rolls were good and the fish was fresh.. but neither was exceptional enough to warrant the drive there.

Really friendly staff and cute spot, though. Recommend if you live closer :)
author: Helen D.

description:
This was my first time dining here and honestly, they could have served me garbage after that Spoon full of Happiness dish and still would've gotten 4 stars!
We also got the Tokyo Crunch and Azteca rolls which were pretty good.  The pulled pork mint BBQ was also very good.  We didn't eat the BBQ with the bib lettuce, but rather with white rice and some soy sauce.  It was excellent!
author: Thomas O.

description:
A spoon full of happiness!

The gf brought me here for my bday dinner and boy was I happy. Ive always wanted to come here but it was too expensive to ask of my friends to come with. Well, she said I can pick any place I wanted... hahaha! 

The dark Asahi was great! Ordered a few rolls, sashimi, hamachi, and started off with the Spoon Full of Happiness. That was the best part of the meal other than spending it with my gf. 

If you like fresh Japanese food thats authentic, try Koo!
author: Gordon L.

description:
Fabulous experience.  

Friendly staff, inventive plates, fresh fish and nice neighborhood feel.  I adored my sake - it was elegant just as the decription noted.  

(Perhaps could use more selection in rolls, but sheesh, I'm actually looking for something to complain about with that one.)
author: Mac M.

description:
Whoa. This was seriously good. I don't remember everything we ordered, but i listed a couple below. Everything was fresh and had clean flavors.  

-A spoonful of happiness is an understatement. It's a spoonful of amazeballs.
-Best roll - clean and refreshing taste
author: Michael H.

description: Fresh, tasty. And the spoon of joy is really cool. Will come back
author: I B.

description:
Went on a recommendation from Dan V.  The sushi bar was full, but moved there from a table and after eating a round of appetizers after the counter opened up.

Ordered 'sushi omakase' which did not disappoint.  The highlights: smoked anikimo, fresh wild toro (as opposed to crappy farm raised), 'yamamori' uni gunkan, deep fried aji bones.  Also a must is 'spoonful of happiness', an appetizer of 2 spoons, one with uni and eggs topped with ponzu, another with sashimi(?) topped with ponzu.

The wait staff is very friendly, and the sushi chefs are very knowledgeable.  One of the best sushi bars in the bay area.

Top notch, although I went with a regular. YMMV. (rated 5 stars for Bay Area standards, would be 4 stars if rated to Japanese standards)
author: Marc Y.

description: I've always wanted to give this place a try and I finally did! Too bad I was a little full from earlier so I didn't eat to much. I got their best roll, and Yesssss! It is their best roll... for the first few bites. The lemon became too overwhelming and I had to take it off my sushi to eat the rest. it is so pretty good regardless. Shared an appetizer with some friends too, that was delicious. Too bad this place is so hard to find parking, took me a good half hour to find panning and it was really far away. Definitely expect that to happen if you want to go there on a Friday night.
author: Ruo Yuan L.

description: One of the BEST sushi restaurants I've ever been to. This place is expensive, it was amazing, and not something as low quality as Old Town Sushi from San Mateo,sorry. We ordered a plate of sashimi ($25), and it included 3 pieces of salmon, 3 pieces of yellowtail, 3 pieces of tuna, and 3 pieces of another type of fish. The sashimi was fresh and the slices were perfectly cut. From what I know, sashimi HAS to be sliced thinly to showcase flavor. Sashimi taste bad when it is thick. The sashimi was also very soft,creamy, and buttery and it literally melted in my mouth. We also ordered miso soup($2.50), nd it was delicious! Then we got a plate of eggplant dangku, dessert and 8 other pieces of sushi. The sesame mousse and mochi was the BEST I've ever had. The texture of the mousse was very creamy, and the green tea mochi was creamy. The atmosphere was also very nice! Oh yeah, we arrived around 8pm and we were seated right away. The total was $76, with tip it was $86! Overall, I had a very nice experience here.
author: Debby L.

description: We go here quite often (sometimes twice a week ha), it's about as authentic as you can get in the city.  They have the best rice I've had in the city, which is not to say that I understand why people get rolls when they come here.  Omakase or just nigiri is the way to go here.   To the person who gave Koo a low review because they could get "thicker cuts of sushi for half the price elsewhere", do not go to Japan, you will hate all the sushi there.  The Japanese quantify good sushi by not just the quality of fish and rice, but also the knife skills of the chef.  FYI, each pieces of nigiri are meant to fit perfectly in your mouth, not spilling out of the side so that you can get "more bang for the buck".  Chef Hayakawa cuts each slices of sushi perfectly, I recommend to ask him about his knives- he has quite a collection :).    To end my review-  you NEED to get the Spoonfuls of Happiness.  Lots of imitations in the city, but none can make it quite as good as Koo.  It's like crack for me.  I'm craving for it right as I'm typing out this review, see you tonight Koo!
author: Christina L.

description:
So fresh and so clean clean....this song reminds me of Koo's fresh sushi.  

I came here with my family this weekend on our food adventure in SF after hearing good reviews and we were all craving for some fresh sushi.  We came around 6pm with no reservations and luckily didn't have to wait.  The place is small and quaint and easily passable on the streets.  

Parking: It may be more difficult to find parking on the streets, go more towards Golden Gate Park area and there should be plenty of parking there and it's only a few blocks down.

So the four of us ordered quite a few things on the menu, afraid that would still leave us hungry.

- A Spoonful of Happiness:  A spoonful of uni, quail egg, tobiko ponzu & a spoonful of ankimo wrapped with whitefish, white truffle-oil ponzu, and comes with a shot of chilled sake. ($10)
- Bamboo Tower (Crystal sesame-ponzu, mizuna green with fresh white fish, scallops and shrimp)
- Chicken Teriyaki with potato salad (Chutney-teriyaki glazed thighs of chicken)
- Sashimi Combo 12pcs (Maguro, Hamachi, Salmon, White-fish 3pcs each)
- Azteca Roll: (crab,avocado, gobo and cucumber wrapped in white fish, topped w/ a thin slice of jalepeno , spicy mayo, tobiko & ponzu then lightly baked) 
- Tokyo Crunch (Spicy tenkasu, hamachi, unagi, cucumber and wasabi tobiko) 
- Miso Soup in Black Cod: (Dashi branched baby bok choy and fried tofu)

A Spoonful of Happiness: It lived up to their hype on yelp. It really is two spoonfuls of happiness into your mouth. ::mouth salivating::  It was something different I've never had and it was delicious. I slurpity slurp the first bite of Uni and it was so SMOOTH.  The whitefish was really tender as well.  I took a little sip of sake before/after each bite and the  sake worked well with the saltiness of the ponzu sauce.  I could have had 5 more of these. Yum.  Due to my one shot wonder, I didn't even finish the sake and was buzzing real good the rest of dinner.    

Bamboo Tower:
This salad is like the perfect summer salad. It was tangy, sweet and crisp.  They presented it by pulling out the bamboo and all the seafood towered over the salad. Great starter. 

Chicken Teriyaki with potato salad:
Out of everything we ordered, I would say this was mediocre.  Don't come here for ordinary american-japanese food, come here for the tender fish/sushi! 

Sashimi Combo:
Um, can I say TENDER? (That's what she said.)   Each type of sashimi was so soft, my family demolished this dish fast.  I wish they gave a little more considering the price. 

Azteca and the Tokyo Crunch Rolls: 
Delicious and crunchy! The waiter recommend these two and both were freshly cut and baked with a great crisp to it. 

Miso Marinated Black Cod: 
Um. Yes. Wow. Tender. Juicy. Soft. No bones. The soup was so tasty along with the tofu/bok choy in it. Best way to end the meal.  

I give this place five stars purely for the spoonful of happiness and the black cod.  It was more on the pricey side, but you definitely get what you pay for.  Everything was delicious and fulfilling to our taste buds, unfortunately not filling enough for our stomachs.  Good thing we got Humphry Slocombe ice cream after and had Ike's sandwiches take out.  I will definitely come back for only the special dishes and to try more sushi!
author: Cam C.

description:
Koo is an exceptional place. The food is fresh, the service is excellent, and the experience won't leave you disappointed

Located in San Francisco's Inner Sunset neighborhood, Koo may otherwise be missed in its residential surroundings. That just leaves more for the rest of us who know about Koo's exceptional Japanese cuisine.

I highly recommend the sashimi platter, "spoonful of happiness," and marinated black cod. Many of the hot entrees, like the black cod, are excellent, but the sushi is truly exceptional.

Be sure to get a reservation in advance. It's not too hard to get one, but I'd suggest calling at least a day or two in advance.
author: Greg M.

description: The Spoonful of Happiness (with uni and quails egg) was delicious and quite the experience. The sushi was pretty good and the service as well. Not really a romantic place, but pleasant.
author: Lauren D.

description:
Had a fine meal this evening, slightly marred by a few service oddities.

Veggie tempura had a delicate crust and the veggies themselves were al dente. I think I had a slight allergic reaction to the dipping sauce (msg?), but otherwise 5 stars.

The black cod with tofu and bok choi in miso was tender and pleasant. It's in the shared plates category, which makes the choice of bok choi seem odd as it's a difficult construction to split up. Mild taste but high quality. Anyway, 4 stars.

The Mt. Fuji cake is so intensely chocolatey I'd give it 6 stars if I could. As it is, I'll give a high 5 to whoever came up with that recipe.

Miso and edamame were typical, but I never expect any good or bad surprises there.

Service was friendly but a bit poorly timed. 

Pro: They sat me at a decent table, they refilled my tea and water without asking. They cleaned up my chopstick clumsiness when bringing the dessert menu; you'd be surprised how many places fail to do that. 

Con: However, in an uncrowded pre-holiday crowd, the tempura came out while I was still drinking the miso and the cod came out while I was still eating the tempura, with the corresponding impact on the hotness of the food. I'd rather have waited a few minutes between courses and had hot food. After all, I had the edamame to snack on. They asked me about dessert while I was munching on the edamame. The place was half-full at that point so there was no need to rush.

Also, they placed the menu on top of the bare chopsticks and the dessert spoon directly on the table, which, as I've mentioned in reviews of other restaurants, is a squick for me.

Nevertheless, the quality of the food and the pleasantness of the environment earns this place a place on my splurge list.
author: Charles B.

description: The food was delicious!  We sat at the sushi bar, and had an Aztecca (amazing!), Rock n Roll, spider roll, shrimp dumplings and more. Everything was very tasty and I would order all of the same next time.
author: Wesley L.

description:
We walked into Koo at about 6:30pm on a Saturday night and even though there were obviously a lot of reservations booked they were able to squeeze us in. The restaurant is really small, with about 15 tables and a  small sushi bar, so it was nice that they were so accommodating. 

We started our meal with Nigori sake and each of us got a spoonful of happiness - this is a must try in my opinion, with a perfect complement of flavors and textures; sweet, salty, umami, creamy and crisp - yum!

We also had the seaweed salad, godzilla tofu and a few rolls to share. It was solid food - fresh, tasty and well-prepared - but, in all honesty, nothing quite compared to our first dish. One of my dining companions even ordered seconds of the spoonful as her dessert. 

If you are in the 'hood, definitely give this one a try!
author: Erin K.

description: Came here a couple days ago. This was one of the more upscale Japanese restaurants in the area, but definitely one of my favorites. The spoonful of happiness (?) was very good. I had to try it after reading some of the reviews on yelp and it was as good as expected. Their Hamachi Kama is also great. If you know how to eat it, that alone can easily fill you up for one meal. The tataki was ok, next time I want to try the beef tataki and see if they can make up for it from the albacore. Their sushi is good, a lot better than some of the other places in the sunset. Probably in the same tier as Ebisu.
author: Cody M.

description:
Catch of the Day... you should see this menu when you come in here... 
I ordered the chef's choice sushi and sashimi. The place is perfect... Jazz music comin out the speakers, nice ambiance for eating peacefully and classy enough to bring the lady for some major points... 
The highlights: 
Baby Squid sashimi...
Ice fish from Japan....
Baby yellowtail...  
Japanese Scallops....
Echigo.... 

Downside: they served sushi per piece(omakase)...  but other than that it was totally excellent...
author: John R.

description:
A good balance between entrée and sushi.  Great quality cuts of fresh fish along with the quality entrée make it more versatile than say Hama-Ko Sushi, the other standout sushi place in the area which is only traditional sushi.

Even though the sushi is the best in Inner Sunset, it's the other Japanese courses that get the rave reviews, but believe me it's all good here.

Have yet to try the spoonful of happiness that everyone raves.  Alas, next time.  And, yes, there will certainly be a next time.
author: Zack S.

description:
This place is hidden in the middle of a residential area. I would have never expected to find such a great japanese restaurant here. 

I really liked my first as well as my second experience here. Both times I ordered pretty much the same. Second time, we tried even more things.  Love the food, the service and the place itself. It's pretty cozy.  There's a dining area and there's also a sushi bar. Both times I ate at the dining area and happened to sit on the same table. weird. i know. 

First time I had:
Best Roll
Azteca Roll
U2 Roll
Flying Kamikaze Roll

My favorite of the four rolls would have to be the Best Roll. It consisted of all things I like to eat. I loved the fresh taste of the salmon that had a thin slice of lemon which added a little zest to it. I also really like asparagus and I thought it went really well with the roll. You can also never go wrong with avocado in sushi.

My second favorite of the rolls was the Azteca. It must have been the ponzu sauce and the fact that it was lightly baked, which made the white fish taste a little seared. It was delicious! I don't like spicy and I thought I would not like it because of the spicy mayo and the slice of jalapeno, but it wasn't too bad for me. I just scraped off the slice of jalapeno and the spicy mayo gave it a little kick!

Then I liked the Flying Kamikaze Roll. We were really appealed by the name of the roll so we decided to order it. The deep fried bits of garlic really made this roll special. Even though it consisted of spicy tuna, which I am not too fond of, this roll wasn't too bad. Yummy asparagus and albacore.

My least favorite of the four had to be the U2 roll due to the spicy tuna. This roll was just way too spicy for me. I thought I would like it because I like avocado and shrimp tempura, but I actually found this roll to be really dry and plain.

Tuna and Salmon Tartar
served with spicy guacamole and shrimp chips
I absolutely fell in love with this dish. I love the thickness of the shrimp chips. It was perfect so that we could scoop the tartar onto the chip without the chip breaking. I've tried tartar at a lot of places, and this one really stands out to me. I loved the presentation of it as well as the mixture of the guacamole with the fish tartar. It was seriously perfection in my mouth. I was so hooked on this!

Second time:
I had the spoon full of happiness. Definitely worth the try. There's two spoons filled with a variety of sashimis.  It's definitely worth a try.

Handrolls: 
We got here when they were serving happy hour still and so we decided to order it. It was so fresh and filling and so cheap.

I loved both my experiences here and I would definitely come back again. I think the prices are really reasonable and the food is delicious!
author: Sarah F.

description:
still my favorite sushi place in the whole city!!!

you can't beat koo when it comes to the freshest fish. and you won't even break the bank.

their nigiri is melt-in-your-mouth phenomenal, and i also highly recommend the best roll, and the scallop dynamite roll.
and of course their famous spoon full of happiness.... the name says it all.

yay for koo!!!!
author: Molly E.

description: Sat at the sushi bar and had a great experience.  Everything tasted fresh and was high quality. I'll definitely be back again soon!
author: Britney R.

description:
I knew it was going to be expensive, I just hoped that it would be worth it, and mmm, it so was. 

I knew that the Spoonful of Happiness ($10) was going to be awesome, and it was, but what I didn't expect, was for the shot of cold sake that came with it to be the first cold sake I have ever appreciated. I ordered a full glass of it ($7) after I finished my mockable large hot sake ($5 on their 5 year anniversary special). 

The Catch of the Day selection featured a lot of tempting nigiri offerings. I sampled the Tairagai (Korean Pen Shell - excellent) & the Sazae (Japanese Baby Sea Snail - bland). He was impressed by the Kinme-dai (Japanese Deep Sea Red Snapper).

Immediately upon swallowing the uni portion of my Spoonful of Happiness I ordered a pair of uni handrolls ($4 on anniversary special) & while the quality of the uni was just as fantastic & the portions of all the handrolls we ordered very generous, I wish I had just had another order of the Spoonful of Happiness, it's just that good. 

I could go on & on. Almost everything was fantastic. My only real complaint is that the smelt tempura really should come with a dipping sauce. 

$115 after tax & tip for two greedy eaters who had skipped lunch. 

Oh, two more notes:

1) 6-7pm on a weekday seems like a good time for families to come in - there were several seated with small children while we were there (I envy the parents who can afford this place). 

2) The edamame was cold, which seems to be a recently reoccurring problem for us, boo!
author: Jenn W.

description:
MENU: 

The menu is split between sushi/sashimi and small plates. There are no bento boxes, donburis, or noodle items. There is a nice sake menu though. 

VIRG SAYS "MEH": 

I wasn't wowed by the small dishes offered here. The corn bread encrusted calamari and the miso-marinated sea bass were just okay and frankly, too salty. 

VIRG LIKES: 

I would return for the sushi and sashimi selections, which were definitely what I would expect from a quality establishment. Super fresh offerings, where you could taste the sweetness of each fish, scallop or shrimp. 

But take note, HERE IS THE REASON WHY THIS PLACE IS DIFFERENT: they have a list of say 15 or so "catch of the days." Here you will find items that are in addition to the usual sushi menu. Most notable for me on this particular visit was the New Caledonia blue shrimp (it was really blue) which blew my all time fave, amaebi, out of the water - no pun intended. They were also featuring Australian young yellow tail (Hiramasu), which we compared to the Japanese wild yellow tail (tenjyo-buri) - both very good, but the Australian version had a deeper, sweeter flavor. Also good to try, if available, was the shad gizzard (its a fish and has nothing to do with a chicken) and the sea bream. Both were from Japan. 

SEE THE DOLLAR SIGNS:

In terms of pricing, two pieces of sushi ran somewhere between $5.50 to $8.00, which is about what you'd expect to pay for good quality...dare I say it was a good value? I'm not a roll fan, but just for your info, they had them for about $15. So alcohol notwithstanding, you could walk out of there for about $50 per person.

AMBIANCE:

At night, they feature tea lights on the black tables, which creates a nice, intimate glow to the place. 

Check it out, peeps...I think you just might like this place :)
author: Virg Y.

description:
Great stuff. Fresh and well prepared fish sums this place up.

Spoonful of Happiness... Yeah, you better get it. The more skeptical you are, the better it tastes!


Note - This restaurant is really intended for iPhone users ONLY. Droid people...Stay away ;) The few occasions I've been here - EVERYONE had an iPhone. It's quite amusing but if you go during a normal meal time, I guarantee that there will be at least one iPhone visible at a table next to you.
author: Con L.

description:
Spoons of raw stuff + shot of sake + mt fuji= as good as it gets

Spoonful of Happiness.... write that down! 

Tucked away in sunset but worth the treacherous journey.  On paper, the spoonful of happiness sounds disturbing.  But once in your mouth... you will be taken on a magic carpet ride with dragons and samurai warriors.... it's that good!

I didn't get the rolls because I'm awesome.  Sashimi was fresh and buttery.  OOOOO... the kumamoto apps were like orgasms on the half shell, sweet and delicate.  

I believe they have really great traditional Japanese items but wifey and I were in the raw mood....

End your meal with the Mt. Fuji dessert..... I promise you will Mt. Fuji in your pants!

Waitresses and hostesses were like modern day geishas, very helpful with the menu and can hail a cab like a mofo... yes, mofo.

Do yourself a favor and go....
author: Christopher P.

description:
So I'm rating this place a five star specially for their Miso Black Cod dish. 

I need to visit this place 3x to confirm the consistency and perfected Black Cod. If you are a fish person, order it. I can bet you that you won't regret. So buttery, delicate, and with a perfect char on the side. It's everything anyone could ever wish for in a magic. If you're not a fish person, you'll turn into one after you tasted it.

Service is decent. Never had a problem with them. If they are busy, the food could take some time to get to your table. Get yourself a reservation to be seated promptly as it's usually crowded most of the time.

Not a bad sake list and they serve Asahi Black which most restaurants don't. Keep your stomach ready for dessert. Mt Fuji is excellent!
author: Rika P.

description:
I used to go to Hana before it changed hands to Koo back in the day,  The new place is on the pricey side.  Value is no longer there.  Portion sizes are small, the fish is not as fresh, and the dishes aren't unique.  

It's a place to go to if I didn't want to wait to get seated elsewhere.
author: MTBer I.

description:
Came here once... loved it.
I'll definitely have to go again before I can write a full, enlightening and interesting review but I thought that everyone would like to know that I loved it.
author: Christina L.

description:
The shari(rice) was good, and the fish was fresh, with a good selection.

On the famous "spoons", I thought the uni was a bit overpowered by the ponzu sauce. The anago was nothing to write home about. Our server was not very knowledgeable about their nigiris, and the service was so-so.
author: maruko c.

description:
Best Sushi I have ever had in the US. Seriously!


I had real fresh sushi in Japan.  I have the right to comment.  This Sushi restaurant is exceptional.  Fresh fish everyday from Japan, Spain and east coast everyday.  Chefs are really friendly and skillful - They are all Japanese.  Price is half of what we got in NY, but much better value. 

Love Sushi Koo! BTW, Sushi Koo means "eat sushi" :)  Just eat everything on the day fresh list, that is called authentic Sushi
author: Jacqueline X.

description:
Delicious. Absolutely fantastic. Realllllly fresh sushi and creative hot dishes (the shrimp and potato dumplings with a whole shrimp in each and mouthwatering perfect dumpling with chili sauce was outta sight). I love sushi and Japanese food in general so I eat it quite a bit and this is the best Japanese food I've had in San Francisco. The rice in the sushi rolls is very high quality, not too sticky or gummy like cheap (I assume) sushi rice. A superstar of a roll was the Best Roll (real name), which was a unique combo of ingredients and flavors I hadn't seen at other sushi places - Tempura asparagus, avocado inside and salmon with thin lemon slices on top - it all worked together so well. Even their standard spicy tuna roll was the best I have ever had.
AND...The prices are very reasonable, given the high quality and generous portions (the amazingly good spicy tuna was $6 for 6 large pieces, Best Roll $8.50). My husband and I had 3 rolls, 2 small hot dishes and each had a glass (generous size) of sake for $60. Pretty great for the best sushi I've had in town! Going back soon and bringing friends!
author: Rachel M.

description:
At the end of a recent phone conversation, I wanted to pummel one of my good friends.  

Turned out, I was just misunderstanding him.

Every time I asked him where he wanted to eat, he kept saying "cool."

It wasn't until I met him at the address and read the sign and realized that in fact, he was saying "KOO" and not "cool."

I mean, can you blame me?

Where should we eat?  Cool.
What?  I said, cool.
I know, food is cool, where the F should we eat?  I told you, cool.
I am going to beat you down.  Cool.

Anyways, Koo is indeed cool and definitely worth a trip.  

The spicy scallop rolls are delicious and not to be missed.  

Plus they have a killer happy hour.  

I still, for the life of me, cannot figure out why, no matter how much I spend on sushi, I am still hungry 15 minutes after.  

Must move through me faster than Metamucil.  

Yuk.
author: Archie R.

description: My boyfriend and I came here to celebrate our 2 year anniversary.  We usually get omakase at Zushi Puzzle, but we wanted to try something new so we came to Koo.  Unfortunately, the chef had a limited selection of fresh fish as the Japanese fishermen were all on holiday so we got pretty standard nigiri, nothing exotic or special.  It was all delicious and fresh, but not the same as Zushi.  The Spoonfuls of Happiness were amazing though!  We spent $160, which is a lot less than Zushi (we usually drop $250 there for omakase).
author: Jen Y.

description:
TERRIBLE service. We walked in and stood in the reception area for 5 minutes before the hostess briefly asked us how many (it was just my husband and I). She then walked back to the kitchen and stayed there for another 10 minutes. 

After another 5 minutes of her ignoring us AFTER she came back to the front, we walked out. 

I would have loved to review the food, but the service was so bad we didn't get a chance to try it!
author: Beth D.

description:
This is my favorite sushi restaurant so far since moving from LA. I didn't realize how difficult it would be to find good sushi in the bay. Maybe it's because there are so many sushi restaurants in the city that it seems like there are more bad ones than good ones.

I know it's been yelped before but I'll yelp it again. If you come here you must try the Spoonful of Happiness and you mustn't share it. You won't even want to share it, and there's no reason you should because there isn't enough goodness in the spoonful to go around.

The fish is fresh, delicate, and buttery. And it's actually cold, not room temperature like some of the sushi I've had at other restaurants. My only complaint is that some of the sushi selection of the day was sold out, so I didn't get to try everything raw on the menu. 

Did I mention the sushi men here are smiling? They're nice. They're happy, and they're funny. Don't be afraid to let your sushi men crack a joke.

Come here hungry. Leave here happy.
author: Elettra R.

description:
Tried the omakase here so we had a big selection of fish and cooked dishes. The big hit was the spoonful of happiness, which comes with a spoon of ankimo with seabream, and another spoon of uni with a quail egg. Suffice to say, we started and ended with this dish. 

Surprisingly, some of the fish was on the fishy side, but for the most part everything was fresh and cut well. 

Of note, they serve real wasabi here.
author: Derrick V.

description:
Koo is great!  Everyone should try their Spoonful of Happiness! 
It's 2 spoonfuls of goodies and comes with a shot of sake.  That sake was smooth! 

Also must try their different daily catches.  I'm totally in love with the toro and the Fresh Scallops.  
I can't believe it took me that long to try this place out.  Their handroll is really worth it too.  It's $4-5 (depending if you come during Happy Hour or not) and there are a lot of ingredients in the handroll.  The salmon and Rock n Roll hand roll had so much fish in there!  Totally worth it! 

Service was great!  We never had a hard time flagging down our server.  He was very soft spoken though and at times I wished he spoke just a bit louder, but other than that tiny flaw, the service was perfect.  The other staff members were courteous and our tea and water were refilled literally every 5 minutes.  

Their dessert was also very good.  We tried both the chocolate one and the mousse.  Both were delightful!  
I can't wait to come back!
author: AhLin C.

description:
I had been wanting to go to Koo for a long time and last night found myself drifting home late after work with no boyfriend (he always makes a face when I suggest sushi). I decided it was the night I would try Koo and I walked in the door at about 9:30.

Koo has some very nice atmosphere. Low warm lighting seems to keep people speaking in hushed tones and the servers were all very nice and welcoming.

The grilled squid salad (special) was delicious as was the roll and individual pieces of sushi I ordered. Next time I go back I have to try the hand rolls!

Koo was a little expensive so it might be a place for "special" dinners but I will definitely be coming back!
author: Alex W.

description: For the price, this place is the best sashimi joint in the Bay Area.  Everything is so soft.  I'm beginning to think there's quite a lot of good sashimi restaurants now.
author: Byron L.

description:
Absolutely amazing. Spoonful of Happiness is a winner.

There are two types of Sushi locations: 1) the kind that just serve food and 2) the kind that make the food an experience.  This is definitely the latter and, while the price is higher than your average Sushi place, it is absolutely worth it!  

I've been  there twice and hope to dine there again soon!
author: Tyler D.

description:
Thank you Kiyoshi and Suzuki!! 

I live in L.A., and I travel for business to San Francisco quite often. Kiyoshi and his crew make me feel like family and they never disappoint as far as the food is concerned. 

I like fresh, exotic fish! I like to be surprised with something new (which can be hard since I am a hard-core sushi addict for more than 15 years). I like the chef to choose for me. After several years of enjoying Koo, they still manage to surprise me. Last time I had Shirauo and Tairagui. 

I am not a fan of the happy spoon, or any of that other stuff that they offer, but I know Koo does this stuff very well also! 

Typical Sushi you can count on here: 
Kinme Dai 
Kamasu 
Seki-Aji 
Toro-of course 
Hamachi Toro 
Kampachi 

Just to name a few... 

I sometimes find excuses to get to S.F., just to go to Koo! So my Update, is really a Thank You!
author: Rockit O.

description:
we went there for the first time tonight because over 500 people on yelp rate it 4 stars.  But as a native japanese, I feel a bit responsible to be honest here.  The sushi fish was not fresh...at all.  
And I know this place is geared towards American sushi lovers who like Salmon, Tuna and those large fusion roles such as dragon rolls and rainbow rolls.(not that there's anything wrong with that!)  But still, even rainbow rolls can use fresh fish, right?

I will be willing to try this place again though.  Lots of times, if you sit at the counter and talk to the chef to see what's fresh at the time, you have different experience.  But tonight, my Japanese husband and I sat at the table, we left the restaurant quite disappointed.

ps. we liked the service though!
author: Mei O.

description:
Koo is one of my all time favorite japanese restaurants in the city!  Luckily for me, it's also right in my neighborhood.  

The food is amazing - sashimi is always so fresh, and the service is top notch!  I've been here a countless number of times and I have never had anywhere close to poor service.  The owners and the staff are just great!

I seriously have probably tried the majority of the menu already and some of my favorites are the tuna and salmon tartar, the tokyo crunch roll, hamachi kama, and of course their famous spoonfull of happiness -- it's a MUST.

Koo is a small hidden gem and definitely a must try!
author: Carmen Y.

description:
I went here for dinner by myself and I thought it was very good. I ordered two rolls and had left overs- the bill was 20 bucks with tip. The sushi was tasty and fresh. The place was also nicely decorated . If you want to sit at the sushi bar, I recommend a reservation, even during the week- I didn't know sitting at the bar was that popular!

Anywho, The reason its 4 not 5 stars is because there weren't very many choices of sushi rolls. I would like to have seen more of a variety.
author: Katherine B.

description:
Cute venue, I liked the mood lighting and modern decor - I'd describe it as a cute date place.  I'd rate the food and service about the same (4 stars).  

We ordered the spoonful happiness which was quite interesting (one of the items felt like melted in my mouth but I didn't exactly know what it was - and didn't question it).  Also ordered a Sake bottle, Dragon roll, and a couple of special rolls.  The Azteca was my favorite, it had avocado (a must in all sushi rolls), crab, and had a strong kick of spicy which i love!  For dessert we ordered strawberry tiramisu which was quite good but wasn't amazing.  Overall it was a solid restaurant
author: Heather Y.

description:
I have never had anything like their "Best Roll" or a California Roll with REAL crab meat! So good!

Good service and delicious Green Tea. If only they had homemade Mochi and this would have probably moved up as my favorite spot in SF so far.
author: Barbie L.

description: Spoonful of Happiness...is a must have! Don't think about what's in it, just allow it to melt in your mouth and follow it w/ sake. I am not a fan of sake so I asked for pinot grigio.  Not sure if it had the same effect but it was delicious. I can't remember what I had after that! It really is orgasmic! :-)
author: Neelam M.

description:
Had a great time at Koo this past weekend.  The menu offerings are really unique and unlike most Japanese restaurants in the area.

The halibut sashimi (roll it yourself with daikon and scallions and ponzu) was fantastic, as was the Flying Kamikaze roll.  The godzilla tofu was tasty too although I would've preferred a little less garlic miso on top of the crispy tofu.

Everything was really fresh, the ambiance is good, and the Mt Fuji and mochi ice cream desserts were such a nice ending to a great dinner.
author: Priscilla T.

description:
Koo came highly touted by friends and Yelpers alike.  So, we made a reservation for Saturday night and it did not disappoint.  The hostess  was responsive and attentive and took us to our table right away.  The table was the best seats in the house.  We had the corner of the restaurant all to ourselves with a window view.

Food:  We had the Flying Kamikaze and Tokyo Crunch rolls, the bamboo tower salad, the godzilla tofu and 4 piece sashimi albacore tuna.  We also had butterfish, striped sea bass, and giant scallop nigiri sushi.  The bamboo tower consisted of shrimp, white fish and scallops.  The flavors of these ingredients complemented each other well.  The butterfish was fresh and melted in our mouth whereas the scallops were large and tasted fresh.  The godzilla tofu was similar to agedashi tofu, but was marinated in a garlic miso sauce and extremely yum!  The rolls had fresh ingredients and are unique combinations that tasted wonderful.  For dessert, we had the chocolate cake with white chocolate mouse filling and green tea ice cream on the side.  We also had strawberry and mango mochi ice cream.  The petite sized desserts provided a sweet and satisfying ending to a delicious sushi meal.
author: Betty C.

description: Tuna and salmon tartar is very good. Six crunchy cakes and delisious tuna and salmon with avacado. Duck salad.aztec roll. Spicy green beans. Everything was delicious. This place is a must!
author: Chuck G.

description:
3.5 stars****

This review is for happy hour and rolls only.  I did not get a chance to try their nigiri or sashimi.

Decor-cozy, modern, CLEAN.  Bar to the right of the door and regular dining to the left.  

Service-friendly.

Beverage selection- I LOVE how they have Asahi Black.  You get the malty richness without the bitter bite like you'd get from Guinness.  It's like a lighter version of Guinness.  Don't get me wrong, I love Guinness, but there are certain days where I want something lighter and Asahi Black does the job!

We ordered:

Happy hour items:

1 Dynamite hand roll-it was really good.  I definitely recommend this if you like sauce with a little heat.

2 Hamachi hand roll-it was fresh.  Can't go wrong with fresh fish!

Stuffed jalapeno peppers-filled with hamachi, slightly on the salty side.

We ordered two more rolls that were not on the happy hour menu, but nonetheless they were good.  But not memorable enough for me to remember the name.

2 Asahi black-good if you like darker beers, but only comes in one size.  No large :(

I heard good things about the spoonful of heaven (there's ankimo in it, that's all I remember.  It confused me when they did not service ankimo on it's own).

I will come back to try the sashimi & nigiri.

Price wise-came out to about $30 per person for the items listed above.
author: Michelle S.

description:
As good as it gets is on point...so far at least.
 I had a crummy rainy XX mid week birthday this year. But this was the highlight of my night.
What can I say? Oishi! Plus impeccable service. But we were the first diners of the night!  I'd skip on the happy hour hand rolls but the catch of the day menu is a must. The Oh-Toro, Hirame, Uni.. monkfish liver pate... SPOONFUL OF HAPPINESS...my God. My mouth is still watering. Endless house sake was nice. 
Let's put it this way, happy hour stuff/rolls not much of a specialty here -- but even their least tasty roll was sufficiently better than what most other sushi places in SF offer.
Koo is a place you come for quality not quantity. And it ain't cheap. So make that paper boo boo.
author: Ms T.

description:
I would go ahead and order most of the fish off of the catch of the day menu, which is where we had the tastiest fish (esp. the blue shrimp)

excellent:
red snapper (COTD)
blue shrimp (COTD)
grilled octopus
miso-marinated black cod

good:
best roll
tamago
seaweed salad
california roll

okay:
tekka maki
yuzu creme brulee (it has a weird non-traditional texture because of the yuzu in it)
author: Jenny S.

description:
Koo has great service and the ambiance isn't bad.  Parking on Irving is hit or miss depending on if you're there on the weekend or not.  The Spoonful of Happiness is the signature dish and it is amazing!  The Flying Kamikaze is good too.

the one complaint i have is that the rice isn't consistent.  One night it's perfect and the sushi tastes amazing, then another night, the rice is dry (as in little to no vinegar).  If they were more consistent then I'd give them 4stars

Overall, a good date place (especially on the nights they get the rice right).
author: Anthony L.

description: Awesome sushi. Highly recommended. Great service. Can not get enough of this place.
author: vahid r.

description: Love this place. Fresh, tasty sushi and friendly staff. Go, you won't be disappointed.
author: Michael W.

description: My Japanese friend had told me about Koo and I decided to try it. First of all the place is popular and even though they open at 530pm, by 6pm it was almost full. Inside is not fancy but classy enough. I rarely say that everything I ate was excellent but this is one of these times! From beginning to the end, I loved it all! It was cold outside so Miso Soup, Hot Sake and Seeweed salad to begin. Followed by Dragon Roll, Hamachi Sushi, Red Snapper Sushi, Scalop Sushi all so delicious we ended up re-ordering the red snapper and the dragon roll. Also had the Jalapeno with Aioli (not spicy at all, very sweet). Thought I would ruin it all by ordering the strawberry tiramisu but even that tasted really good (feels more like a soft cake topped with fruits served in a glass)... I will definitely go back!!..
author: Jean-Francois R.

description:
I give this place 4 Stars because the last time I came here it was over salted but all the other times were really good.

My favorite items are:

2 spoons of Happiness and Tuna-salmon tartare

The chocolate cake with green tea ice cream is really good for dessert. Nice and rich.

I enjoy the sushi here a lot because they don't use too much rice. This way you can taste the freshness of the fish. I highly recommend this place. Definitely try my fav. dishes.
author: Karen L.

description: An excellent Sushi restaurant. Fresh food, good service, and a fun environment. Only disappointment was the Calamari, but more because all Calamari pretty much sucks. Worth a visit and would definitely go back.
author: Henry J.

description:
I'd say 3.5 stars.

Had the following $4 anniversary happy hour specials:
Uni handrolls
Spicy Tuna handroll
Hot Sake
Large Asahi beer

In addition to the above, we ordered Ikura nigiri with quail egg, hamachi nigiri, tombo tuna nigiri (Hawaiian Tuna), and an aztec roll.

All the items/fish were the freshest and it made a significant difference. Sushi was satisfying and delicious.

Ambiance was warm and somewhat homey.

DINGS:
-Lacks creativity (particularly with the rolls), not much to choose from.
-Took a very long time for our dinner to arrive.
-Nothing special was given to customers (had to ask for water), no small cucumber salads, no hot towel, no oranges, no mints, nada.
author: Kimbalee W.

description: Limited menu, but the sushi is amazing and prepared traditionally. Their appetizers were also great and they have hamachi kama and miso cod. Our favorites were the goma-e and amaebi.
author: Caroline D.

description:
While this place's decor and ambiance was quite nice.. the food was mediocre at best. We had several appetizers including the calamari, fried tofu, and oysters. I only tried the calamari and tofu while my other two friends tried oysters (they said it was good but it was tiny). The calamari was average while the fried tofu with miso sauce and garlic was way too salty and tasted like someone poured a pound of salt into it. We ordered seven rolls and they were all pretty much tasteless or way too salty. The only ones I can remember were the Azteca and the Spideroll (which I think was undercooked) though the Unagi roll tasted fine (and was the cheapest on the menu). For the price they charge for the sushi, I would think that it'd at least taste decent. 

Note that they have dessert service charge of $2 per person so if you bring in a cake or something it will add extra $$ to the bill. We had 4 people so that was 8 extra dollars spent on a cake that we have forked a bit of money over. However, they were nice enough to give us a candle so we can wish our friend a Happy Birthday. The service was alright as they brought our food in an acceptable amount of time and refilled our teas several time since were were there for about 2 hours. The food was alright but a bit salty and I doubt I'd go back there unless I was in the area and desperate Japanese at the same time.
author: Annie T.

description:
This place is absolutely AMAZING.... Probably the best sushi I have had in San Francisco to date!

It's a little on the pricey side, but OMGGGGGGGGGGG you get what you pay for : PURE, INSANELY FRESH. UNIQUE dishes! TOTALLY worth it!

My boyfriend ordered just about every Nigiri off the menu! He loved each and every one! He also ordered the "Spoonful of Happiness"... such a unique and incredibly delicious idea!

I am however almost vegetarian and only eat a few pieces of fish here and there sometimes. I ordered the vegetable sushi combo... Which consisted of 9 pieces of super fresh types of vegetable creations.... the avocado and eggplant being my favorite! I also ordered the stuffed jalapenos with hamachi (cooked) served with lime aoili sauce ... what other sushi restaurant is going to have THAT? no where! it was A-M-A-Z-I-N-G!!!

I really wish we had room for dessert... I know normally a person doesn't go a sushi restaurant for dessert... but with main courses and appetizers THIS good, I'm sure they are just as good too! WOW!
author: Erin K.

description:
Whenever I visit California, I must get sushi at one point during the trip. The sushi just tastes fresher than it does back home. My trusty Yelp app guided me to Koo and I was not disappointed. 

The restaurant is not very big, but our maitre'd said she could seat us if we ate quickly (she had another party coming in with a reservation). The service was very quick and efficient so we were out of there in plenty of time, but we did not feel rushed at all. 

I ordered the sashimi assortment and I was surprised by how big the cuts were for the price. The tuna was my favorite of the bunch, but the sea bass and salmon were also very good. For $6 extra, I added miso soup, seaweed salad, and rice to my dinner. 

I shared the mochi and green tea ice cream with my sister. Mochi was pretty standard, nothing special about it. The green tea ice cream was great to cleanse the palate though. 

The decor was pretty sparse; this was no Megu (my favorite sushi joint in NYC). I did like that the atmosphere forces you to focus on quality, rather than ice sculptures or other forms of opulence.
author: Dana F.

description: best sushi in the inner sunset.  maybe in the world!  can't wait to go back.
author: Audrey K.

description: Delicious, DELICIOUS sushi, I don't think you can go wrong with anything here. We just ordered like crazy off of the nigiri menu then added some maki, but I think it's best to go for the nigiri. Next time I come I'll write a better review...
author: Shang S.

description: My favorite sushi in Inner Sunset.  The sushi was fresh, the atmosphere is clean and modern.  The happy hour menu makes this place very affordable, we spent $47 for three people.  We will be back!
author: Christy L.

description:
ive been wanting to try koo for a while being that some of my friends love this place.  we came one friday for the bfs moms bday dinner

we tried the:
bamboo tower-crystal sesame ponzu was delicious even though it was a jelly

grilled marinated artichoke

two way scallop - beets and daikon a bit weird

hamachi kama

black cod

also a bunch of sushi.  the freshwater salmon we got was really good.
author: claudia y.

description:
Came here with my mom with high expectations.  This spot used to be home to Hana, which was a staple for us growing up.  We thought we should give Koo a try given the awesome reviews.

Ultimately, the meal was very so-so.  The fish was fresh but pieces were small, and the miso black cod wasn't anything special.
- freshness of fish: 4 stars
- service: 3 stars, maybe less - waitress kept coming over with a sneer on her face...very unappetizing
- value based on price: 3 stars

I haven't tried to omakase, so maybe I'll return to try that.  It seems that many of the more tasty things they offer is off-menu...which for me is a bit of WTF!  Maybe it's just my vast disappointment speaking...
author: Fontane L.

description: this place is goooood.  sit at the bar and you'll get assigned your personal sushi chef!  just tell him what you want and he'll whip it up right in front of you.  everything i had was fresh, no complaints whatsoever.  just come and give this place some love and it'll return it and then some!
author: Melissa Y.

description: Happy Hour Sushi is the reason I have been here several times in less than one year. $4 handrolls (the tempura shrimp is super succulent and has asparagus), $5 large beers and hot sake, and $5 appetizers make this a winner.  You can fill up on handrolls and catch a decent buzz for about $20 a person. What's not to like?
author: Damon K.

description: Very nice place!!! The food is delicious and rich of flavor! My favorite is special sushi served on the spoon!! It's worth a Michelin Star!!! Thank you Chef Suzuki very much! I come back soon!
author: Madina C.

description: Such a comforting place to come to.  We, my partner and I, have been here a number of times over the years, mostly after visiting mom on her stays in nearby UC Hospital.  Tonight was no exception.  After spending a day in the hospital comforting a loved one who's in pain, this place is chicken soup for my soul.  Spoonful of Happiness gives us a good start with such great combination of flavors with their ingredients and rounding them off with a shot of ice cold sake.  Their temaki rolls are also very fresh and, for Happy Hour prices, ver.y generous with their fish to rice ratio.  Their service has always been top notched, mindful and friendly.  I can imagine coming here for years to come.
author: Yvette F.

description:
We went here because of the high Yelp ratings and the sushi was good - not great, but good. It was a little expensive for what we got which is why I gave it 3 stars.

The "spoonful of happiness" sounded amazing but tasted not so amazing. The uni spoon was good, but the ankimo with whitefish was a little on the fishy side.

We tried an assortment of sashimi and they were all pretty good. Fresh tasting and not too fishy. The Striped Bass was my favorite. A real treat.

Their Uni was also really delicious and fresh. I ended up ordering 2 Uni handrolls.
author: Janelle R.

description: The spoonful of happiness could not compensate for the rude and lack of service we had here. After sitting for ten to fifteen minutes we had to ask to place an order. When asking for a dish without wasabi our waitress looked at us like we were aliens, like we were ruining the name of Japanese food!! The food came out very staggered and it wad not the shit. I really expected some good food from this place for it's four star rating, but I was so disappointed.  The fresh fish was tasteless, the grilled tofu was too salty, and everything else was very regular.  When we tried to pay the bill with two credit cards the waitress made an annoyed face. This place sucks!!
author: Amy C.

description: Nice to know there are still neighborhood restaurants like this: great food, great service (when's the last time a server poured your beers for you in THIS town?), and very kid-friendly. Don't miss the happy hour specials!
author: Joshua W.

description: U2 Roll!! no not at a concert had that for dinner tonight. It was not as exciting as going to a U2 concert so no clue why they named it after them. I was bummed about their special rolls, problems, mushy rice! No bueno! We also ordered raw oysters= very good, tuna, salmon tar tar= good, had a bite of I think sea bass, it was very tasty. I would give them another shot maybe I'll just order sashimi. Ohh and NO BUTTERFISH!!! WHAT!!
author: Karen T.

description:
A small gem in the sunset area. This place is very tiny, but cozy. The decor is very nice. I have literally tried just about everything on the menu. Fantastic! They have great appetizers. I love the tuna & salmon tartare, spoonful of happiness, steamed scallop & shrimp dumpling with that yummy sauce... As for sushi rolls, I love the best roll, rock & roll, flying kamikaze, and azteca. Everything is absolutely amazing. If you haven't gone there, you are definitely missing out.

Just be prepared to pay a pretty hefty bill.
author: MJ T.

description:
Very good sushi can be found here!  I loved the decor and the beautiful creations coming out.  The menu I loved because there were so many options to choose from!

My foodie friend Jen in honor of her b-day was the gal who selected this place for her celebration so props to Jen for finding another great spot for us to try!  Jen had heard of the Spoonful of Happiness and was pretty impressed by it.  I loved the presentation and the fact that it came with a sake chaser - gotta love an appetizer that has a liquor aspect to it.  I tried the sake which was clean and crisp.  Next time I come I will try the Spoonful for sure.

We ordered the Tokyo Crunch roll which was great - I am still trying to determine what the crunch consisted of because it was so yummy!!  Hamachi was very good and I loved their spicy tuna roll because it was the way you are supposed to make it!  We finished out meal off with desert and it was very yummy.  Mt. Fuji (chocolate molten cake with a scoop of green tea ice cream).  I loved every bite and it was the perfect side after a nice meal!

I recommend people checking out this spot - great service as well - the waitstaff knows exactly what they are serving you and were very friendly and informative!
author: Heidi S.

description: I went here for HH and I went here on a date and overall they were both good experiences. HH is Sunday through Thursday until 7:00 except Friday and Saturday and I basically ordered the handrolls and a beer. The prices are decent too, but it's kind of hard to get full off of just handrolls. Anyways, the one thing that always stands out at this place is "A Spoonful of Happiness" which is a spoonful of uni, quail egg, tobiko ponzu & a spoonful of ankimo wrapped with whitefish, white truffle-oil ponzu & a shot of chilled sake to wash it all down! You have to order that when you come to KOO or it's just unacceptable lol. I can't even explain how delicious it was....I wanted to order another one haha. I also got the wakame salad, edamame, spicy scallop roll, the Miso Marinated Black Cod served with dashi branched baby bok choy and fried tofu, and some nigiri, and beer.
author: Diane L.

description:
The place has a very nice ambiance. The staff was attentive but nothing special. 
We got a roll, tuna sashimi, and a hamachi stuffed jalapeno.
Fish was delicious, tasty, and FRESH. 
However, portions are small and pricey. 

Good taste and freshness but too pricey and small
author: Chris M.

description:
I'm still dreaming about the appropriately named spoonful of happiness. It's the perfect amuse bouche to get your palate warmed up for the amazing sushi that Koo artistically serves. 

Be sure to order the fresh wasabi for $1. It doesn't compare to the powdered stuff you find at most places and packs a punch. 

Definitely the best Bay Area sushi I have experienced thus far.
author: Lee H.

description: Best Japanese in the neighborhood. We had the grilled artichoke and eggplant hot from the fire. A delicious  preparation and excellent presentation. The sushi was perfectly fresh and wonderfully tasty. Prices are good for the high quality food.
author: Helen M.

description:
I didn't order any of the specials.  Maybe that was a mistake.  However, my overall impression was that while the Spoonful of Happiness is everything that it has been said to be, everything else was just so-lala.  They like to do small plates here, but that only works if the food is really flavorful.
The pieces of sashimi were tiny and bland.  The eggplant was merely okay; I tasted mostly salt.  Ergo, this restaurant is rather overpriced.  However, 4 months after my visit, I still have fantasies about standing outside the restaurant and slurping down Spoonfuls of Happiness.
author: Angband A.

description:
I am basing all the positives of this review on the freshness and amazing quality of the fish we had. Hamachi tends to be ordinary wherever you go, but here it's melt-in-your-mouth fresh! We had to get a second order of sashimi- it was that good. 

Also delicious was the ikura, kani, and Azteca Roll. I'm not usually impressed by maki rolls but the Azteca was complex and extremely flavorful!

The service was very attentive and the space was cozy and clean. We walked out fully satisfied at $80 for 2 people, including 1 small hot sake (standard Ozeki).

Minus one star for charging $30 per bottle of local Nigori that other places charge $10 for, and that I can get at the grocery store for $7.
author: Jeannie C.

description:
08.18.2010: 
3.5 stars. The vegetable dishes were salty to the point of being inedible, and the appetizer one wiped out my palate and made the dishes following (nigiri, maki) tasteless. 

07.11.2009:
4 stars. Lovely setting and our favorite place in this neighborhood for sushi. Ebisu is a close second but it is usually too crowded or closed. 

What's good here: the Best roll, Azetca roll, and the fresh fish of the day. Not a place for healthy vegetable dishes -- tried a few dishes but all were too salty. Once the avocado in my sushi roll was old -- I don't send food back but that would have been a good candidate.

Koo tries to use fish that is sustainable whenever possible... for that I usually pick Koo over other places for fish. (Update 2010: Serving farmed salmon and bluefin tuna is not that sustainable actually... Still this is better than most sushi restaurants which don't even try.)
author: Yvonne C.

description:
The food here is amazing and fresh. 

I also really like the atmosphere of the place. It's obviously clean and well-kept. I ordered my food to go because I was by myself, but I'd love to take somebody here and have a relaxing dinner. The take-out was quick so A+ for service from me!

I tried the Tokyo Crunch because of some recommendations here. It was delicious, but if you like sushi because of the fish taste and texture, I would try something else. I couldn't taste much of the fish because it was covered by the other ingredients. I tried eating the fish separately too just to see if it was fresh and good quality, and it was. The flavors were all really good though!

Next time I will probably order some Nigiri since the fish was so good by itself and come with a friend so we can try a few different rolls.

Oh, and it's not cheap! Save it for a semi-special occasion, or just to treat yourself :)
author: Carly J.

description: very mediocre sashimi, didn't taste fresh.  i'm not sure what all the hype is all about
author: Prashant C.

description:
The people who give Koo a low rating are doing it wrong. 

First, this place is not about rolls and I do not eat hot food at a sushi place.

What this place is about is usually a long menu of fresh fish you can order as nigiri and sashimi. I came here and ate nearly every fish they had on the menu (somewhere around 8-10 different kinds) and all were great. Also, they have spoonfuls of happiness which are delicious. However, I love Uni on its own so I would probably not be satisfied with just the spoonfuls of happiness; I would need more Uni.

Beer is standard Japanese beer. The sake is also good here. 

I have not gone to every sushi place in the city so I have yet to find out what the "best" is, but this place is good if you are not searching for rolls and want some good fresh fish. However, they do have good rolls, but not many total.
author: Alex D.

description: Way overrated. The sushi isn't that fresh. I don't care how good the sushi's are if it ain't fresh it ain't good.....especially for a place this pricey. disappointing.
author: Emier A.

description:
BlaH.

Came here on a wednesday - i never know which day is the bad day for fish, so if it's this day, well, that would explain the experience.

The spider-roll was atrocious, if i hadn't had normal spider roll before, I'd be put off soft-shell crab for life. Probably sushi too.
The shrimp dumplings were shrimp... in a dumpling skin. The shrimp were nice, sure. But... well, I expected more. Like, say, an actual dumpling. 5 of them, so $2 a pop.
Black cod in miso something was too intensely flavoured, and the fish itself was just not nice, not succulent, just there. The sashimi though - that was good. Fresh, tasty - but still, the rest of the meal was not passable.
For $80 for 2 (one glass wine, one hangover), this just isn't good value for money, and the food isn't great. I wouldn't come here again.

Nice place though.
author: Andrew I.

description:
Over 440 reviews, and 80% of them gave either 4 or 5 stars.

Nuff said.... 

Be careful, spoonful of happiness will give you orgasm. :o)

Their fish are very fresh. Toro (fatty belly tuna) is a must try!!!
author: Eric N.

description:
We were walking towards Ebisu when we came across Koo and decided to have dinner here instead.  I'm glad we did!  We sat at the sushi bar and asked the sushi chef what he recommended and he first said the Spoonful of Happiness.  Now, I'm not a huge uni or monkfish liver fan, but this dish was a hit with us.  The ponzu sauce went very well with the monkfish liver.  My husband had the uni and he said it was amazing.  Next time, we're getting our own rather than sharing.  

Next, we had the grilled octopus salad and the kumimoto oysters.  The oysters were great but I didn't love the octopus salad.  It lacked something...salt?  I knew my husband felt the same way when I saw him dipping it in the soy sauce. 

We then had several of the nigiri.  The cut of fish were not as large as other places I've been to, but they were still good and very fresh.  My husband ordered the geoduck and he thought it was a little fishier than others that he's tried before.

Finally, despite all this food, I was not full (story of my life), so, I ordered the hamachi kama.  Once this dish came out, I didn't look up until after I devoured it.  Very good and, again, went so well with the ponzu sauce.  The citrusy sauce was perfect against the rich hamachi.

Overall, great meal.  We probably won't come here for just the sushi but we're definitely going to come back to try the other dishes on the menu.
author: Abby N.

description:
I'm still going to give you the 5 star review because I am a forgiving person and maybe you'll make it up to me.

However, I was very disappointed in my experience.  Incredibly disappointed.  It was a Thursday.  Class was canceled after Crim Pro and I had my little car (or maybe there was no class, I couldn't remember).  I found terrific parking.  I made it a point to come during the happy hour because I love uni and I wanted to have uni until I just couldn't handle it any more.  

When I sat down and ordered, the chef told me they were out of uni.  I understood it to mean that they were out of uni, period.  And there was nothing I could do about it.  So I contented myself with other things.

BUT THEN, tray after tray on spoonful of happiness went out.  What?  I thought you were out of uni.  By the time I noticed that there was obviously SOME UNI SOMEWHERE, i was already full.  Because, if I had known that they still had SOME UNI, I would have ordered the nigiri, or the Spoons.  But they led me to believe that they were just completely, simply, utterly, out of uni.  

And that left me really disappointed.  I do not get to go out very often, I definitely do not make it out to Koo, and I normally do not have my car with me.  This was a special treat for myself.  A little special afternoon just for me.  But without uni, I could have gone anywhere.
author: Christina C.

description:
I went to koo tonight with my parents who are VERY picky about their fish. We had the sashimi platter, a fatty tuna roll, azteca roll, best roll, and I had the spoonful of happiness (YUM). 
All the fish was wonderfully fresh and literally melted in my mouth. (even my parents agreed!) The hamachi was delicious! The salmon too was realllllly good especially served with that subtle hint of lemon. 
My mom really enjoyed the azteca roll bec. it had a a little bit of spicy but wasn't overpowering. 
My favorite roll was the best roll because I loved the texture of the asparagus tempura and the taste of the lemon and salmon! 

I would definitely come back as long as someone else was picking up the tab ... me being a poor grad student =( 

Its so refreshing to find a quality sushi place with actual good SUSHI. not all those nonsense rolls and cheap, not-fresh fish (*cough cough* korean owned sushi places - and no offense, I'm korean and my aunt owns a sushi place! hehe)
author: Tim B.

description:
Aside from having great sushi, Koo does an excellent job with their share plates. 

Highlights:
-Spoonful of Happiness: shots of yum, paired with sake, and a great beginner's course for eating uni.
-Belly Trio: absolutely amazing fish belly sushi that unfortunately isn't always available
-Miso Marinated Cod: relatively dependable cooked dish
-Spare Rib Lettuce Cup: tender meat and crispy goodness you wrap in butter lettuce. It's flavorful enough that it doesn't come with or need any dipping sauce
-Eggplant: perfectly cooked, sumptuous and sweet
-Chu-toro sushi: bluefin tuna belly, medium fat. A whopping 5 bones a piece, but oh so worth it!
-Tokyo Crunch: a roll that comes under a pile of crunch
-Mt. Fuji: a little chocolate cake pyramid filled with white chocolate mousse. Absolutely great dessert for chocolate lovers, but don't do this one if you're full--it's not light!
-Asahi Black: a not so common beer with chocolate notes that is considered the Guinness of Asian beers

Notables:
-Tuna and Salmon Tartare: a more common dish, but a favorite with those who might be less daring
-Bamboo Tower: a very unique salad with gelatinous sauce. Be aware that the minty flavors of the greens might not be for everyone's palate
-Tempura smelt-fish: very fragrant curry for the nose, I found it a touch bland in the mouth
-Chicken Teriyaki: uncommonly made with thighs instead of breasts
-Hamachi Kama: simply, but deceptively daring dish. The meat has great texture, but be wary of bones
-Yuzu Panna Cotta: light and well-flavored with cherries, but a bit imperfect where it comes to texture

Koo isn't a large restaurant and I threw them a bit of a challenge by bringing in a group of ten. They handled it well, but for those who are going to put them through the same test, you should know that they charge a $200 minimum for that number of people! Otherwise, food and service were prompt with no drops in quality. Kudos!
author: Esther L.

description: This place was poppin when we got here.  It was probably around 830pm and we were ready to grub.  They seated us right away and the server was pleasant.  I thought that the menu was a little steep but it was good.  Nice presentation.
author: Grace P.

description: Koo means happiness which also means they have the freshest sushi in San Francisco, hands down. As long as you make reservations you'll never have to wait nor will you ever be disappointed, the sushi is always top grade. If you wanna know what heaven is like, I suggest you try the spoon full of happiness. Its nothing short of magnificant. Koo is THE BEST SUSHI SAN FRANCISCO HAS TO OFFER!
author: Toni T.

description:
Spoonful of happiness.  Mmmm.

The bathroom is hilarious...turn to go wash your hands!
author: Anda K.

description: The sushi was high quality (nigiri and rolls), I loved the decor (and I usually don't care about the decor), and the service was phenomenal. This is one of the only Japanese restaraunts I've been in the United States where the quality of the service was reminicient of Japan (I lived in Japan for a few years and they are the leaders of the the hospitality and service industry). 1 star off for being a bit on the pricey side. I would definitely go there again.
author: JJ M.

description:
A bit on the spendy side for sushi, but totally worth it every now & then. 

Let's start from the beginning - the spoonful of happiness is SO good. Definitely a must have. I really like their miso soup & edamame too. 

We usually order from the fresh catch menu & I've always enjoyed it. I'm having a hard time remembering exactly what we had, but I remember butterfish & blue shrimp being two of the stand-outs. The toro & scallion roll is super good too. 

Reservations are recommended, but I've never had a problem calling an hour or so before for a table for 2.
author: Susan K.
