description: I haven't liked uni before but the Spoonful of Happiness definitely made me happy! It's a cozy little sushi place but the service was prompt, the sake was smooth and warm, and the rolls were tasty and fresh. I'm definitely coming here again!
author: Liz L.

description: I appreciated the quiet space and efficient service. The veggie tempura was blah though. I found it overpriced because of that.
author: Sushi C.

description:
4.5 Stars:  offers sushi specials, some fish I had not previously encountered.  I recommend the Hamachi Kama (really delicious) and Azteca roll (light and subtle).  

Main downsides are (1) it's a bit too noisy inside for me and (2) parking can be murderous in that area.
author: Yum Y.

description: Koo is a place for 5 star sushi, especially the King Crab Dynamite Roll. But why so skimp on the dessert? The name "homemade cookies" lured me in, but I was shocked to see that they were thin biscotti chips about twice the size of a quarter.
author: Alexa M.

description:
Recently I've been on a sushi kick and have been roaming the city for places with really fresh fish. Koo is my newest discovery and I am definitely adding it to my list of favorite sushi places (along with Yuzu, Ozumo, and Kabuto).  Koo is a no-nonsense sushi joint with yummy rolls and most importantly FRESH fish. 

We ordered:

Kamikazi Roll- Yum! Spicy tuna roll covered with albacore tuna. SO delicious, the best thing I had that night.

Best Roll- Good but I wouldn't call it the best roll there. It's a roll filled with avocado and asparagus tempura, and covered with salmon and thin slices of lemon. 

Hirame (halibut) sashimi special- several thin slices of very fresh halibut served with a side of ponzu sauce (I would recommend pouring it on top of the halibut since halibut is pretty flavorless) and a little pile of green onions and spicy grated daikon.

Wild White Salmon nigiri- This was a special catch of the day and it was amazing! I've never had raw white salmon--it looks and tastes almost like Toro- light pink fish with a buttery taste and feel. Very good.

The sushi rice here is also made very well in my opinion--nice and firm and just the right amount of seasoning. 

The SERVICE was what I would expect in a casual sushi joint on Irving St- attentive and polite, but nothing special. They brought our food out fast and filled our tea regularly. 

The DECOR isn't particularly special either- just a nice clean sushi place with modern decor, not fancy at all though. It would still be nice enough for a casual first date though.

I'd definitely go back for the fresh fish and yummy rolls, and the prices were really good too ($56 total for 2 rolls, 1 order nigiri, 1 special sashimi plate).
author: amy k.

description:
My search for a Sushi place to frequent continues.

I did challenge them:

Uni, good when masked with quail egg and soy sauce in the spoonful of happiness, not so good nigiri.  I love uni when it's like a lovely sea-flavored sauce.  This was off, which was surprising because it was on the "specials" menu.  Perhaps it was a "special" not because it was special, but to turn-over inventory...

Kani, I like a nice piece of leg meat on my little ball of rice; Koo offers a crab-salad that tastes of mayonnaise.

Shiitake mushroom similarly could not hold a candle to fondly-remembered culinary delights.

Things that were tasty:
Oysters
Fried calamari
The famed spoonful of happiness
Soft-shell crab handroll

I really wanted to like this place, because it's so near to my home.

Here is why I cannot go back:
     We had a party of three; my friend and I arrived and told the hostess that the third member of our party would be arriving at 6:15, about 25 minutes later.  The place was pretty empty.  So, we ordered drinks and appetizers.  At 6:15, our third called, to apologize, because she was having trouble parking.  At 6:40, the hostess came by our table and told us we had to be out by 7:30.  We told the hostess that our third was looking for parking.  She explained that people were coming in and she needed the table.
     This was probatively false.  There were plentiful open tables, and naturally we started monitoring the foot traffic.  There was no crush of eager diners, more like crickets.
     If we weren't ordering enough to pay their rent, our server surely could have handled one more table of non-existant diners...
     Along these lines, I conform to the etiquette of taking-up restaurant space for protracted periods and was planning on tipping double.  Unfortunately, the hostess felt the need to lay down the law, leaving us no chance to reassure her, or to make a bargain.
     When our third walked in not long after that, we had guessed what she'd like to eat and ordered.  Needless to say our suppositions were not spot on.

     Our primary dining experience was very hurried and unnecessarily stressful.

     Koo gets one star back, because our server was great.  In toto, I shan't be returning, and the quest continues.

     I would be eternally grateful for a recommendation to a place where I can acquire Kani and Uni as described above.  The ideal location will be a bit closer than Samurai in San Diego.
author: Genevieve H.

description: Ichiban desu yo!  I've been making the drive to Koo out near UCSF from Berkeley for a number of years now and have never been disappointed when I am in need of a large variety of the highest quality fish.  It's always a good sign to see the owner working the sushi bar. I sit in front of him and his two hard working assistants while his well dressed wife keeps the beer and sake flowing.The prices are reasonable and the kitchen items are good too.
author: Matt F.

description:
Everything on the menu was delicious!!! We have 7 girls and ordered almost everything that was on the menu and cleaned the plates. Our billed came out at $51 per person, but there was lots of food. 

I love the ambiance. Quiet and romantic for a girls night out. 

I haven't have sushi in a lot of SF restaurants but this is going to be my first one!
author: Irene C.

description:
Great sushi! Very fresh fish!  Nice selection of appetizers-tasty.
Service could be better but we had a great night anyway.  Drinks were plentiful even though slow at times.
Interior is quite nice and the restaurant was packed.  Reservations are definitely required.   

Will return very soon.  ;-)
author: Lizete S.

description:
totally recommend sitting at the bar! it's totally separated from the dining room so i felt special sitting there! also you can talk to the sushi chefs yourselves to know what's fresh and their recommendations. plus, you get your food faster!

spoonful of happiness is a must for sure! it's koo's signature appetizer that separates themselves from other japanese restaurants. some may think its $10 price tag is on the pricier side (especially since you can't share it), however, it provides FRESH sashimi grade quality ingredients, truffle oil, AND a shot of cold sake! i would say it's pretty worth it for the price.  it makes me wonder if 21 and younger people can order this dish... haha.

anyways everything else me and boyfriend ordered was yummy. we had fresh sashimi of: salmon, tuna, scallops, hamachi, and toro! we also had the bamboo tower, which was a sashimi salad, and the black cod! mm so delicious! 

in the addition of a large sake, the total came close to $100 without tip. but it was worth it!
author: Dominique L.

description:
It has taken living in the city for three years to beat it into me that I have to get out of my comfortable neighborhoods. I had yet to eat at ANY restaurants in Inner Sunset and I have my eating buddy, Lisa, to thank for bringing me here. Apparently it helps to know the chef or at least insist at sitting at the bar to ask what is special and fresh.

We started with the ubiquitous "Spoonfuls of Happiness" - two soup spoons, one filled with a tai-wrapped smoked ankimo dressed with a bit of truffle oil and tobiko, the other a preparation of uni with quail egg and house-made ponzu sauce. The spoonfuls are served with a specialty sake and being an ankimo fan, I thought I would prefer that bite, but the freshness of the uni and the subtlety of the ponzu made the uni the preferred bite. 

Not wanting to get full on rice, we specifically requested sashimi -- with two slices each of maguro, tai aka, sake, hamachi, and and kanpachi. Note that the fresh, real wasabi is certainly a treat.

Indicating we were definitely interested in "unusual" offerings, the chef made us a salad of light mizuna greens, thinly sliced cucumber, and baby raw whole shrimp and squid. I don't recall ever having been served whole squid the size of my thumb. Incredibly tender and lightly dressed, this was an amazing offering.

As my client requested salmon, a special offering of crudo was presented -- thinly sliced white salmon, so tender and bright.

There was also an unagi course, but I'm not remembering exactly how it was offered.

We finished up with my one request of the evening; ama-ebi, as my good friend, Lance (visiting from London), had never had a fried shrimp head before. Perfectly fresh sweet shrimp and the fried heads were light and crunchy. Just perfect.

I brought a potential client and I'm sure we must have been given some deals as we drank a lot of sake, ate a lot of sushi, and the tab was only $300 for four.
author: Carolyn T.

description:
I have found my culinary twin. LOL It is unbelievable to have the same review as other yelper...
I was looking forward to the spoonful of Happiness and other fantastic sushi after reading the reviews. But... the sushi was just Ok. We did enjoy the spoonful of happiness (again, only the spoonful of Uni) and would say that this is the best dish at the place.  Kumomoto oyster, Magro sushi (Blue fin tuna from Japan), fresh scallops, hirame and baby snails - all catch of the day don't have much flavor.  Also, the rice has no vinegar taste and was hard, maybe because we were sat at the table and all orders come out at once?!
I am trying Ino in a week and hope it won't be as disappointing. Keeping my finger crossed!!
author: Prascilla L.

description: Great sushi spot!  But nothing really stood out and wow'd me.  But I would come back here.  The sushi was good.  Their california roll was actually really good and I don't usually rate CA rolls or even order it.
author: M. T.

description:
My first 5-start review.  I've eaten at Koo four times and each experience has absolutely blown me away.  I'm an old Idaho boy, grew up on meat and potatoes, having only ventured in to sushi in recent years.  I was never very impressed by sushi until some friends took us to Koo.  My reaction?

This is why people love sushi.  The U2 roll.  The Best roll.  Spicy Tuna.  Maguro.  All amazing.

I have since eaten sushi at the popular Japanese joints at 9th and Irving but find myself going back to Koo. It's just too good.
author: Joe M.

description:
Here I'll help you decide what to get.
10 orders of 'a spoonful of happiness'......each.

Thats ten spoons of uni and whocares, ten spoons of ankimo and whateverelse, and ten shots of heythisstuffismakingmewarmandtinglyandsortahorny.  

Thats it.  Youre done.  Thats all you need.  Youll be rubbing your swollen belly while joking that youre pregnant...with twins.  

No seriously why waste your time with tempura or gyoza or teriyaki?  Go with the Sea urchin roe, monkfish liver, flying fish roe, quail eggs, white truffle oil!!!!   Sounds like ingredients in an Iron Chef dish.  And a shot of Sake to go with it??? Mmmm..... Only thing that could possibly be better is 'a buttload of happiness'

Davids Bottom Line-  This place makes your clothes and hair smell like fried food.  Im talking REALLY REALLY SMELL.  First time Ive really experienced that at a Japanese place.  Other than that its YAY.  Fast friendly service, good food, and a buttload of uni and ankimo.
author: David L.

description:
Koo makes me absolutely coo with delight! It is my favorite Japanese restaurant in San Francisco! The menu focuses more on new and creative Japanese influenced dishes, but also has favorite sushi items. The atmosphere is cute, relaxed, and quaint, and the Spoonful of Happiness gives me a warm feeling in my tummy (figuratively & literally!).

Since, I typically order from the sushi menu, I prefer sitting at the bar for really attentive and friendly service. I usually indulge in the following dishes: A Spoonful of Happiness, Dynamite Hand Roll (Baked Scallop), and various orders of nigiri (Hamachi, Sake, Tamago, Unagi, etc.). The fish is always fresh, the unagi is not watery, and the presentation is superb. Looking forward to my next visit :)
author: Jaclyn T.

description:
I haven't gone to Koo in a while, this is the first time in a couple of years, I'm glad I've gone back. 
Went here on Sunday. They had their 5th anniversary special going on. Me and my girlfriend had the giant tofu and one hand rolled uni each. The uni was so good we had to order it again. We also had the dynamite hand roll, which was good also.
author: Peter L.

description:
Dr. P told me that being back in SF felt like coming home, like she had never left.  I am going to take that as an indication that she will be moving back one day soon.  To hammer that point in, on our first night back, I brought her to Koo for omakase with the most Japanese person I know. 

I ate things I'd either never had before or that were prepared in a completely different way.  Everything was off menu except for the Spoonfuls of Happiness.  I can almost taste some of the flavors now.  We ate so much but I think Kiyoshi-san was disappointed we didn't have room for more.  He said we needed to give him fair warning of our capacity before we started next time so that we could get an even fuller experience.  I don't know how that would be possible but I'm willing to give it a shot.

Dr. P had room for dessert so we got them all.  They were a very refreshing and not overly sweet end to a  memorable meal.  I bet she's coming home.  She has to.  All this saying goodbye business is getting too hard.
author: Seong P.

description: I like how they have a large selection of imported fish.  Very fresh and yummy and very friendly staff!
author: Ray L.

description:
Honestly, I do not understand how this place got such a great rating. Yelp 4 star rating fooled me. I have definitely had better sushi and rolls. 

I could tell they used frozen fish for sushi. The dragon roll was okay okay. The spoonful of happiness was alright. The tuna tartar was good. 

I would probably never go back to Koo again. I feel like I wasted my $100 on mediocre food.
author: Hyo Jin L.

description:
I don't know how to start because I was skeptical, very suspicious and doubtful about this place.

I think it was a Japanese restaurant called "Hana" before.

The reason why I had those negative feelings was because the decor, the size of dining area, and 3 men inside at the sushi counter.
That made me wonder.
But, I was totally wrong.

100% Authentic Japanese.

This place is well done Japanese and sushi place with true authentic manner and flavor.
One head sushi chef and 2 assistants at the counter with 7 seats.
This sushi trio has such good coordination and teamwork.
They took each order really seriously.
Even though they got orders for Jive Ass Rolls.
Yup, JAR (Jive Ass Rolls),
But,
They do 100% good job on the JAR.
I could tell by just lookin' at them.

Great Shari (rice), 
Good Fresh High-End Neta (fish).
I've never had Sanma-Nigiri before! Man, it was Good!

I didn't order any but I don't mind eating "Jive Ass Roll" in here.
Yes, it's that good.
Really good.
The man who owns this place and is the head sushi chef has worked for Tokyo-a-Go-Go and Ace Wasabi before.
But he kept his traditional style and he is able to create and manage West meets East kind of real Asian Fusion cuisine.

What ever.

I hate Asian Fusion Cuisine in general because it sounds like Half Ass, FXXXin' fu-fu, lame piece of Shit.
I like bold. solid GOOD SHIT!

This place has GOOD SHIT!

KOO CAN KICK EBISU'S STINKY ASS SO EASILY!
Ebisu is piece of CRAP!

No more talking, 
No more explaining,
I can hear my buddy sayin', " Nobu, shut the FXXX-up! You talk too much, Just eat it."

Koo is great deal. The chef is something. Something really good.

Koo, this sound, Kuu in hira-gana, means "eat" in Man-Japanese.
So, you'll reply " Umai", means "good" in Man-Japanese.
Girls say, "Oishii". just in case.
author: Nobu K.

description:
[ prelude ]
Apologies to the stank ass... I mean 'vintage' jeans wearing resident Japanese food expert Dan V. for lagging on the write up. I know, I know, it's been close to a month.. but thank you so much for taking me. Now that that's outta the way, on to the show!

[ curtains open ]
Friday night, Koo is packed to the brim, but as we walk in the entire staff stops to greet us and we're immediately shown to our seats at the counter. Right smack in front of Kiyoshi-san. Dan V. is VIP

[ Act I ]
After introductions and obligatory small talk (not a requisite but I am Japanese and we are bery bery porite -very very polite w/ a Japanese accent), Kiyoshi-san asks my likes and dislikes. Normally my 'like list' in first time establishments mirrors that of a lactose-intolerant-glucose-allergic-organic-vegan's "Can Eat" list. read: I am ridiculously picky unless the place has been tried and tested. However, I trust Dan, so I decided to put myself in the chef's hands (in case you don't know, 'omakase'  translated = "I am in your hands" kinda sexy)

[ Act II ]
.Scene 1: We get our drinks (Sapporo, in case you're wondering. I'm all about beer!!) and our first dish. Thinly sliced salmon and carmelized onions dressed with yuzu that blended beautifully. Dan liked his so much he inhaled it in 3 seconds. Ok I lied. It was more like 5 seconds. HA

.Scene 2: Spoonful of happiness w/ the accompanying sake. It was everything I read about and more. Five minutes of heaven.  (no need for redundancy, this is one of Koo's signature dishes. If you're interested in descriptions, please read the other reviews)

.Scene 3: Sugar snap peas in dashi based cold soup-like marinade. From the temperature, texture, to the flavoring, it was close to perfection. I woulnd't be surprised if they homegrew the peas on a mother of all pea plants in the back, it was that good. And I don't even like sugar snap peas.

.Scene 4: Trio of bite sized appetizers.  In flavor-o-meter order (light to bursting!) 
un = salt and pepper giant prawn atop thinly sliced grilled potato   
deux = salmon and tuna tartare on a shrimp wafer like cracker 
trois =  shishito filled ebi 

Extremely fresh shrimp is at times overly sweet  -especially when passed through heat, and I usually crave a lil kick. Kiyoshi-san prepared the prawn with a tad more pepper than salt. The natural sweetness was subtly enhanced while my kick was satisfied without any imbalance of flavors. Amazing. AND all three had distinctive tastes, yet not too far away from the other that my palate got confused. Pure genius *The tartar and shishito are on the regular menu. 

.Scene 5: Oysters on a half shell. Self explanatory. I think the oysters had a fancy name but I forgot. I was too busy eating.

.Scene 6: Crab tarine.... or in plain Engrish salad in cylinder form. Chunks of THE meatiest, freshest, sweetest crab tossed with avocado, lil mayo, a lil mustard(maybe?), and some other ingredients I forgot. What I DO remember, is that even though I consumed avocado two dishes before, I was not bothered by its presence. At all... which is rare since similar tastes, textures, and ingredients bore me. 

Kiyoshi-san also chose this time to tell me Dan gave him the heads up that I was a homesick ex-Bay Arean visiting from Manhattan so he themed our menu 'Tastes of California' ...and it worked. Perfectly. I can't even begin to imagine how much thought and creativity was put into this omakase.



[ intermission ]
15 minute break from writing the review, not the actual dinner



[ ...cont Act II ]

.Scene 7: Smoked Ankimo. pure luxury. just try it.

.Scene 8: Live hotate and kimo sashimi on the shell. SUPER fresh. amazing.

[ climax ]
shashimi (i forgot exactly what was served. go figure) then nigiri galore (not in order: akagai, aji, iwashi, saba, toro, anago, hirame, kinnmedai, and a few others i forgot.... ) super duper fresh. everything good

[ conclusion ]
aji no hone,  the bones w/ a little bit of meat attached toasted to a crunchy, non prickly perfection. it's like... non-fishy fish chips, if you can imagine that. one of my favorite 'desserts'  when drinking. it refreshes my palate

[ encore ]
i HAD to try the mt. fuji (chocolate cake w/ a white chocolate base) w/ muscat dessert wine since it's hand made by the chef's wife, Ayumi-san... and was NOT disappointed. Quite the talented pair I tell you.


That night i was the happiest girl in the whole entire world
For anyone stating Koo is mediocre, please sit at the bar and order omakase. (ask Dan V if you can drop his name too)

...and this concludes my longest. yelp review. ever. EVERRRR!! 

[ Curtains Close ]

*i got a tad lazy w/ descriptions after the intermission
ate lunch and brain fell into a food coma

edit!! i forgot one of THE best dishes, the chawan-mushi, the most satisfyingly complex with tons of layers that tickled alllll my senses. ok now i'm really done. the end
author: Mona N.

description: Wow. Spoonful of Happiness. What a great start to a dinner! We decided against getting any rolls and only ordered nigiri and handrolls. It can be quite expensive here and not as filling but you are here for the quality not quantity. Food Highlight: blue fin
author: Rich L.

description:
Insane.
This is by far the best sushi I've ever enjoyed. 
I lived in Japan for 6 months and this place kings it. The highly suggested "Spoonfull of Happiness" was a great reccomendation and I can only pass on the same suggestion to anyone new to Koo. 

Special menu was out of control, we enjoyed the Hokkaido Scallop, grouper, snapper, and Hawaiian Amberjack... all to die for. The Tokyo crunch was hard to eat (roll size is huge), but delicious. 

We also had the Mt Fuji and it was a great way to end an amazing dinner. 

We had a bottle of decent Sake ($30), appetizers, tons of nigiri, and 2 rolls, dessert and it barely broke $100. For the best sushi I've had even considering Japan it was worth every cent.
author: Aubrey J.

description:
Cootchie Cootchie Koo - I am tickled pink with the super fresh fish and lovely atmosphere at Koo. Mix with a dashing dining companion and you have one fabulous dinner. Standouts included the Hokkaido scallop, Coho salmon and melt in your mouth, butter-soft Otoro nigiri. The Albacore sashimi was good, if not mouth-boggling.  The weakest link was the seaweed salad, although a large portion and palatable enough, it seemed off the shelf to me instead of freshly made. The tempura shrimp roll was filling and tasty, rounding out the lighter offerings. 

We enjoyed some excellent, well-balanced sake with our meal served in cute boxes with a layer of cold water at the bottom to keep the cups well chilled. I would be happy to go back anytime and tickle my taste buds with more fine fish feasting. Kanpai baby!
author: wendella a.

description:
I took a friend here for his birthday and although neither one of us had ever been to Koo, I was sure that we would have a splendid meal. 

I was not disappointed.

I was practically vibrating with anticipation to try the Spoonful of Happiness.   Was it everything I expected?  YES!   So much so that I briefly did some math in my head to figure out how much it would cost JUST to eat repeated Spoonfuls of glorious Happiness until I was full.  Yes, I would totally do it.  Anyone want to come with me to give it a try?

But, to be fair to the rest of the menu, we went ahead and ordered the deluxe sashimi selection as well as the hamachi kama, fried tofu, and grilled miso eggplant.  Everything was outstanding.     

The only minor squabble I have is the difficulty in finding parking... however, it is well worth it for a special evening out.
author: Courtney Y.

description:
there is a japanese idiom(kotowaza) that goes something like- if you don't have money(okane), you better have connections(kone).

this really sums up the number of experiences i have had over the course of the year at Koo.  thanks to my super-nihonjin-insider pal, i have been invited 2 times and each experience has set a completely other-worldly standard in SF dining.

the numerous times coming prior i dined solo or with a companion- sat in the beautiful, simplistic dining area...ordered with ease and was impressed with the overall sophistication and sexy factor found (ala Bossa Nova).  but really...even the omakase experience, didn't call for a prayer to Amitabha or in yelp lexicon, a 5 star ranking.

now enter dining here with Dan V...
six or seven courses of pure namamono, conversation and drinking with kiyoshi-san and his dynamic duo that holds things down at the bar, introduced to special treats like kinmedai and a seasonal otokoyama namazake- Yukishibare..just flat out good times.

there is an intimacy you feel with all the staff as they all seem to be carefully observing how you are interacting with various tastes and handling certain portions through the rotations, so they can adjust and ensure balance in your experience.

incredible pairings of fresh eats with sake, lovely jazz selections playing in the background, genuine service that makes you feel compelled in sharing stories and end up laughing at each other, in some cases to the point of crying..

Koo is like Keiko-san said, FLAWLESS.
author: omar b.

description: Great food if you love sushi! Fast service. Pretty pricey though!
author: Emily H.

description:
Koo made me coo like... a pigeon? No, that's weird. A baby? Yes, Koo made me coo like a very happy, excellently fed foodie baby.

First of all, I am a fair weather uni (sea urchin) eater. I only like extremely fresh uni and will wrinkle my nose and stick out my tongue if it's not perfect (let's face it - bad uni can be gross). I loved the uni here! In fact, all the sashimi/sushi was high quality, and the rolls were inventive. Beyond the sushi, we also ordered shared dishes: the miso marinated black cod and the mint spare rib butter lettuce cups were both delicious!

This is one of my new favorite Japanese spots... dare I call it my very favorite sushi in the city? I just might dare.
author: jenn h.

description:
reservations for prompt seatin'....a chilled bottle of sake on ice with sapporo to quench....sashimi combo (twelve pieces) a great start with fresh morsels of fish...soft 'n' meltin'...excellent....orders of oh toro (two orders)..fatty tuna...butter of the sea...finding toro just borderline decent..chewy tendons in toro?..oh toro..oh no......yet...a spoonful of happiness (three orders)...two spoons each of pure glee and taste...words can not describe the goodness..but...poor quality shots of complimentary sake to compliment the spoonfuls....a small disappointment....

goma ae...basically a sesame sauce spinach salad...while presentation unique and roll like...too densely packed..makin' eating an effort.....than the second salad...the favorite of the night...bamboo tower...white fish salad....citrus 'n' ponzu dressing over fresh tasty greens...pleasin' to the max....

delightful dinin', but some nots....eggplants with sweet miso...found the sauce too thick and overbearing the eggplants.....too sweet to really enjoy the soft tender eggplants........and..shimichi crusted tuna 'n' mushrooms...speckled with tangy rasberry sauce....the fruity tangy sauce overpowering the tuna....just a drop, yet so potent the rasberry flavors.....unenjoyable for the palate....

black cod...excellent the sauce...light and enjoyable..fried tofu a treat....cooked to perfection.......the second fish...hamachi kama...grilled collar....meaty and well-done....sealin' in moistures and meat tender 'n' moist....

$230 for four....overall an excellent dinner in the 'set...zoo definitely top-notch japanese for unique presentation.......creations going beyond the norm.....medley food 'n' beverage selection.....
author: Hen A.

description:
I took the bf here just to try the spoonful of happiness and was not disappointed. That dish alone gets 5 stars. We also had a couple rolls, the monster/godzilla? tofu dish and the miso marinated fish. Those were ok, but not spectacular.

However, I subtract 2 stars for the god-awful waitress/hostess who demonstrated monstrous service. We were ten minutes late for our reservation and she snapped at us for not calling, even though the restaurant was half empty when we arrived and remained half empty throughout the evening. Then she gave me a third degree burn on my face when she poured tea rather carelessly (seemed intentional to me) and it splattered all over my face. I don't know if they offer dessert because she brought our check and slammed it on the table without ever offering us a dessert menu. Did I offend her in a previous life that I don't remember?
author: Deb I.

description:
I'm torn about this place.

On the one hand, if someone as meticulously critical as Nobu K is going to give their sushi 5 stars, who am I to argue?  The sushi-savvier folks in my party agreed that the quality of the fish was unimpeachable, and, frankly, every roll I ate was like a drop of rain in the desert.

On the other hand, I wonder if that's because it took nearly an hour for the sushi to come out, and in the meantime we'd been downing sake, hardly an appetite suppresant.  Starving stomachs rarely make for picky palates.  Not that the wait was unenjoyable--the dark wood beams over cream-colored walls and the just-right lighting make an ideal atmosphere.

But I guess my biggest complaint comes down to this: for these kind of prices (there's a $20-per-person minimum that you'll have no problem reaching well before you're full), where's the flair?  The boldness?  The fun?  Aside from a couple well-placed jalapenos, all the rolls were awfully stodgy and conservative.  Those Jimisan guys aren't afraid to put raspberry dressing on their sushi, even at the risk of stealing the thunder from the fish itself.  I dunno, maybe that's just where the hard-core sushi lovers and I differ.
author: Wes M.

description:
I'm in love with Koo.  I wish I could eat there once a week.  Heck, once a day.  Unfortunately can't quite afford that habit.  So I'll go whenever I can.  

As an update to my previous review...  The service ever since has been top notch.  Not overly fawning mind you (which I wouldn't really want anyway), but very very good.
author: Liz B.

description:
That sushi Koo has been serving happiness the last four years is no secret, but regularly incorporating more of this level of high quality ingredients (down to the nori which ends up costing the restaurant thousands of dollars more per year) and exquisite fish featured here just might be my ticket to unlocking the fountain of youth.  Have you seen head Chef Kiyoshi and his hot wife?  He's a cradle robber!  Not actually.  I will not disclose their ages, but let's just say Ayumi puts "asian youth" to shame.  Shocking.  I'll have whatever she's having, please.   

As those in the know have already recommended, sit at the bar, clink sake glasses with the three chefs and prepare to be indulged:  spoonfuls, blue ebi, moi or pacific threadfin (once reserved for Hawaiian royalty), grouper, snapper, mackarel, negi toro roll, seared bonito, cured wild salmon, scallop, toro, miso black cod, stuffed grilled jalpeno, japanese eggplant dengaku, conch salad served in the shell...and I don't recall what else because my brain shut down after the twelfth plate.
author: Irene S.

description:
After the concise, thorough, meticulous review by Paulina C, I finally made Koo our dinner destination for the lovely Friday night evening with my girl.

I went prepared, and memorized some signature dishes all the reviews seem to rave about, to make sure I wouldn't miss anything. After an hour or so, and $130 at Koo, I had to say I was solely disappointed, and here is why in detail.

While Koo had abundant selection of some hard to find fishes, they fell short in the presentation of these high end seafood. Blue Shrimp, or the special Agi would taste more scrumptious with a gentle touch of lime, or a bit of ponzu sauce. If you have tried out Sushi Sam Omikase you'd know what I am talking about. 

The poor quality of sushi rice marked the downfall of Koo on Friday night, as it was way too salty and lacked sweetness and texture. This is really unforgivable, as sushi rice should always been sacrosanct at high end Japanese cuisine like this. I couldn't be any more let down. :( Places like Sushi Sam, Shimo, and Live Sushi bar all have authentically prepared sushi rice just to name a few.  

The overall quality of raw food here was at least decent, but nothing to die for. Uni sushi did regain certain reputation for Koo, as the Uni stayed true to Paulina C's review, it is sweet and fresh enough even with the unimpressive sushi rice.  

I would assume Koo isn't totally bad for a neighborhood favorite, and maybe they do have better quality sushi rice on any other day, but it will never justify my 30+ minutes of driving all the way from San Mateo.
author: Wei H.

description:
I always enjoy my trip to Koo. As in other reviews, the spoonful of happiness is worth the trek alone to the neighborhood.  I also appreciate their daily white paper menu addition that boasts their fresh specials, including the barracuda and the amberjack.  Yum! 

As for the rolls, the Azteca roll with the jalapeno on top, the Best Roll  (garnished with the slimmest slice of lemon on top) and Tokyo Crunch are a few of my all-time faves.  My hubby says that the unagi there is the best he's ever had in his life. 

All in all, I highly recommend Koo.  It is very affordable and for the price, quite delicious and fresh.   We had a group of seven last night and the bill was only $270 including tip! (Worth mentioning though that no one drank , that is, with the exception to the shots included in the spoonfuls of happiness.) 

Staff is extremely attentive and courteous too.
author: kathi k.

description:
I was craving sushi and was looking for a new place to try. I saw good reviews for Koo on Yelp and made reservations for me and two friends at the sushi bar. Reservation is a must, especially for a weekend night, since their sushi bar only has 6 seats. They seated us as soon as we walked in and I noticed that there was a cute guy sitting next to me and he was by himself! Score! However, I was with my two girlfriends and we were pretty engrossed in our own conversation, even though I kept stealing glances over to the guy sitting next to me. I have a soft spot for any man who knows how to enjoy good sushi. Sadly, he left shortly after we got there and then I was left with no cute guys in the restaurant... 

Okay, onto the food part, Koo's "Spoonful of Happiness" (1 spoon of monk fish liver wrapped in halibut sashimi and the other spoon is uni with quail egg and truffle oil) is a must and my friends and I all felt very happy after that. We then had various sashimi, ranging from pen shell to Hawaiian amberjack to white tuna belly (our favorite) and of course toro. The service was good too, as they always kept our teacups full and cleared our plates as soon as we finished something. 

Koo is a fairly authentic Japanese restaurant ran by very friendly folks. If you are looking for fresh fish in a quiet setting, this is a great place to go!
author: Elizabeth L.

description:
I found Koo very average and over priced.  

hamachi kama - it was fine, nothing special
string beans - overly flavored both sweet and sour, and I'm NOT a fan of bland food
fried tofu - wasn't hot
beef tataki - overcooked
Spoonful of happiness wasn't bad, $10 and it comes with a shot of sake too.
Amaebi  - my friend spat hers out as she didn't think it was fresh, somewhat chewy

The rest of the sushi was ok. 

oh...and I asked for extra wasabi...that'll be $1.  WHAT?????  I don't care that it's the "real" wasabi.  I've been to plenty Sushi restaurants that offer real wasabi and they don't charge extra for it!
author: R L.

description:
A japanese husband and wife team have gifted us SF'ers with some all time authentic treats of top top quality. If you are ready to pay for what you get (and fairly priced as well) and not the type that prefers standing on the chairs dropping sake bombs, this could be your spot. 

SPOONFULL OF HAPPINESS - everyone at your table MUST get their own order of this and that is MANDATORY!!! You will run around 9th/Irving streets after like a heaved pinball bouncing from corner to corner until you finally collapse all warm and fuzzy.

Also, if you leave your wallet there in a drunken stupper they will hunt you down and find you.
author: Amy E.

description:
Been here a few times now and never been disappointed with anything. 

I could tell you about all the great dishes that other people have said about!!!! Won't bother...

Great to take friends... Great to take a Date.... Just great to take yourself for lunch and hang at the sushi bar eating what ever the chefs recommend!!!

By the time the bill comes you probably have racked up a small fortune!!! But hey you pay for what you get....
author: jae f.

description:
Oh. My. God.

Some of the most amazing sushi I have ever tasted. Everything was impeccably fresh and absolutely delicious. The service is great and they take reservations!!!!!! I LOVE that, since so many Japanese restaurants don't and you end up waiting for hours. It is a elegant, refined atmosphere. I was there on a Wednesday evening, and it was relatively quiet around 8pm. My dining companion and I sat at the bar and basically had one sushi chef to ourselves. Pretty f-ing rad! (Yes, I am singlehandedly reviving the word "rad").

You HAVE to start with the "Spoonful of Happiness" -- Spoonful of Uni, Quail Egg, Tobiko, Ponzu & Ankimo wrapped with whitefish, Truffle-Oil &  a shot of chilled Sake -- absolutely mind-blowingly full of complex flavors and textures.

We had the halibut sashimi special which was wonderful... It came with a Ponzu dipping sauce and the fish was sliced so thinly that you could see through it!

Also had the aji (Spanish mackerel) nigiri and the kona kanpachi (Hawaiian amberjack). Both were absolutely delicious and the aji was the best I've ever tasted. The hamachi sashimi was so rich and fresh that it simply melted in our mouths. 

We had the negi-toro roll, which was probably the weakest fish of the evening, in comparison to the others. As Fong later explained to me, negi-toro is simply the lowest grade of toro cut up into tiny pieces so that the less impressive flavor is not as noticeable.

The dragon roll, with tempura shrimp, unagi, and avocado was perfectly done... very light and tasty.

Notice and enjoy the fresh wasabi: it tastes amazing and makes such a difference! My mouth is watering just thinking about all of this amazing food. I can't wait to go back. I've finally found my favorite sushi joint in the city.
author: Jill M.

description:
A Spoonful of Happiness makes the medicine go down. 

You start with uni, add quail egg and tobiko, take ponzu & ankimo wrapped with whitefish, add a hint of truffle-oil, washed down with a shot of chilled Sake. Splendor. Oh, and while we're releasing some epicurean endorphins, why not add the Bamboo Tower? Crystal sesame-ponzu, mizuna green with fresh white fish, scallop and shrimp. There are a lot of contestants biding for my last meal on earth. Why not treat each meal as if it is?
author: Suzanne R.

description: This is the best sushi I've had in a very long time! I went with a friend for dinner and we stuffed ourselves, sampling even premium items, for only about $100. Sushi is expensive, but Koo provides excellent value in a very nice environment, even with the K line trains rolling past.
author: John C.

description:
I am giving this 2 stars because our experience did not live up to the Yelp-hype. At best, it is probably a 3 star. It is not the "best" restaurant in the Sunset as others have claimed. In my opinion,  Ebisu still stands a cut-above for sushi. But, it is definitely worth a visit, especially if you a looking to try a different place around Sunset, and want some nicer ambiance. 

We tried Best and Tokyo Crunch rolls - the former was good and the latter being too salty, and I like salt (so, this gives you an idea). The blue-fin belly was very good - rather pricey ($7 per piece). Also, steamed Cod in Miso tasted great, and priced well for the value. For something unique, try the Spoonful of Happiness - the ankimo was fantastic!
author: MandS R.

description:
A friend couldn't stop yapping about how good this place is or how often they'd frequent it and after a while, my expectations were set pretty high. After all that, I was sure to come here thinking it would be good but, not phenomenal. Boy, was I in for a treat. The quality and food here is excellent!!

Everyone seems to talk about the Spoonful of Happiness and now I understand why. The Spoonful of Happiness is to Koo what Dried Fried Chicken is to San Tung?
author: David D.

description:
Koo is a small and very quaint restaurant. The food is visually stunning, from the way the sushi is rolled to the spoonful of happiness, it all looks amazing.  

A few recommendations of rolls I have if you are having trouble deciding are: 

-The Azteca Roll. It has a lot going on but all the flavors and textures go very well together. From the crunch of the cucumber to the smooth texture of the white fish to the spiciness of the jalapeno and mayo, blends very nicely.
-The Flying Kamikaze Roll. With the smoothness of the spicy tuna and albacore it's nice to have the asparagus and scallions to add a bit of texture and it goes together brilliantly.
-The Best Roll. Now finally onto my favorite roll of all of them. Tempura asparagus in the middle wrapped with the avocado, a slice of the most fresh salmon laid on top, and topped with a supremely thinly sliced quarter of lemon. All of which compliment each other perfectly. the crunch of the tempura asparagus, the smooth textures of the salmon and avocado, all finished off with a very refreshing citrus taste from the lemon.

I would also recommend the Beef Tataki. Thinly sliced rare beef, with an apple ginger topping and green onions and alfalfa sprouts. It's a great way to start the meal.

Just a great restaurant all in all. The flavors, textures, and visuals just all go together so wonderfully as signs of a proven and very experienced sushi chef.
author: Brendon L.

description:
Great Place to get Sashimi. It's definitely not the cheapest in town but they quality of the Sashimi is superb!

Whenever we have guests in town and especially when they come from areas where Sushi is not as common, we take them to KOO and they always leave impressed!
author: John K.

description: I am in love with this sushi place.  Ever since I moved and am too far from my old regular sushi hang out I have had a sadness in my heart.  Then, I went to Koo.  The sashimi is where it's at.  Love Love Love.  They don't have everything I like to normally order but what they do have they do well.  Let's say you want something hot for a change or you happen to be going here with some raw fish lovers of which you are not?  Get the Miso Marinated Black Cod. OMG so yummy.  It says to share but I never can.  I always want to eat every last bite of it by myself.  Make a reservation cause this place can get packed!!!!  Enjoy!
author: Kylie L.

description: Spoon Full of Happiness , toro sushi, Hama hamachi,
author: Sonny S.

description:
Fresh Japanese food at a cozy restaurant.. here you actually get the real Japanese food that is not smothered in mayo and sugary sauces! This place is small yet not too crowded, so it's perfect for a dinner with a small group of friends that you've been long overdue on catching up. 

I highly recommend starting the dining experience with their Spoonful of Happiness. It comes with a shot of sake to make the night start off on a truly happy note :)
author: Lindsey O.

description:
Quite possibly my favorite sushi joint in the city.  The fish positively melts in your mouth!  And, as if that wasn't already a reason to go back. . . let me just tell you: Save room for dessert.  The Mt. Fuji chocolate cake is to DIE for (and, very quite possibly, my favorite dessert in the city--but I'm open to other suggestions on that point.)

Cozy intimate feel, low light, great place to take a date!
author: Mark N.

description:
Really good SUSHI!  The sushi was amazing and the ambience was perfect.  I ordered the Dynamite, Tamago Nigiri and their specialty roll, Tokyo Crunch.  All were fantastic!

Minus 1 starshine because the hostess asked us to leave when we were cutting close to the next reservation.  What a BITCH!
author: Keika L.

description:
Great happy hour selection with top notch quality fish. I love everything about this place except that it's not a good place for a birthday celebration. I've been wanting to celebrate my bday here for the last 3 years but have been turned away each time do to the size of my party. 

Either way...One of the best if not the best sushi joint in the sunset area.
author: Jon W.

description: This is my go to place now if I am craving sushi. I really love the freshness of the fish! It is pricey but it's really good quality. I also like the chocolate dessert they serve here. A small dish to end a wonderful meal at Koo :)
author: Angela D.

description:
Located on the less hectic part of Irving, is this innovative Japanese restaurant-Koo.  Their menu is filled with non-traditional items mixed in with more recognizable dishes to accompany the sushi/sashimi.  The service was great, but the infused sake was even better.  My lady and I were hooked on the Fiji Apple and Lychee.  You'd better order the bottle to save yourself money at the end of the meal!

Dont miss:
Flavored Sakes
Sashimi
Thinly sliced Hamachi with the Engawa  served with ponzu 
Spoonful of Happiness!
Mt. Fuji dessert

The only miss:
Fried fish with the hint of curry.  Pass!

We enjoyed it so much that we're planning a return visit next week.
author: Jason A.

description:
Date:
    Saturday, Nov 16th, 2007

Cast of Characters:
    Furui-san - older, slightly plump female hostess, looked like she came directly from a 1957 Japanese movie
    Atarashii-san - younger, skinnier, female hostess
    Obi-san - waiter whose belt clashed with his clothes
    Megane-chan - busboy wearing glasses
    Tsugu-chan - sitting across from me, kept filling my beer glass
    me

Tsugu-chan and I arrived around 7:30p, only to find all the seats occupied and a warning of a 45 minute wait.  But, after Tsugu-chan and Furui-san exchanged pleasantries, Furui-san took our phone number and said she'd call when a table was ready.  Tsugu-chan and I went to a local watering hole to pass the time and down our first beer.   Within 20 minutes or so the precious call from Furui-san came.  Atarashii-san seated us immediately upon returning.

Tsugu-chan quickly spied Megane-chan, an old acquaintance.  I thought "Great, we'll get the inside scoop of the best fish".  Unfortunately, despite being happy to see Tsugu-chan again, Megane-chan was only the busboy and didn't have the skinny for us.  :(    It would have been useful as the menu of special fish had at least 10 entries and insider knowledge to navigate could have been handy.  Nonetheless, Tsugu-chan and I quickly settled on the following:

Appetizer - Spoonful of Happiness
Sashimi    - Hirame (or was it Hamachi?!) and Engawa
Nigiri         - Kuro Dai (Black Snapper, if I translated correctly)
                   - Gindaro (Black Cod)
                   - Akamutsu (Red something, snapper like, but not Tai)
Veggies    - Goma Ae (Spinach with Sesame)
Maki          - California Roll
Beer          - Sapporo

The Spoonful of Happiness was actually two spoons and a jigger of sake.  One spoon contained Uni (Sea Urchin) with Quail Egg and the other Ankimo (Monkfish Liver, tastes kind of like Foie Gras) with a dab of a white fish (don't remember which one).  Although both of us really like Ankimo, Tsugu-chan selected the Uni Spoon and I had the Ankimo.  It was tasty, maybe 3.5/5, but not as good as the name.  After a swig of sake that 3.5 turned into a 4.  :)

The sashimi and nigiri, however, did not disappoint at all.  The sashimi was sliced very thin, reminiscent of carpaccio.  It came with ponzu as a dipping sauce and some minced green onion.  It was very good and I got to eat most of it as Tsugu-chan started talking to Megane-chan again.  :)    The nigiri arrive quickly after the sashimi was consumed.  The arrival of the nigiri ignited a debate between Tsugu-chan and I about "fingers v chopsticks".  I'm a finger-method man.  Tsugu-chan said that's correct at the sushi counter, but at a table chopsticks are OK.    I still think Tsugu-chan just didn't want to lose the debate!  :o  In any case, what really matters is that in all cases the fish was extremely fresh and the rice was well-made (although I still think Sushi on North Beach has the best shari [thanks to Noboo's reviews, I've learned a new word]). 

The goma-ae and california roll were quality dishes, but nothing to write home about.  Although, I'd feel remiss if I didn't mention that the goma-ae also had some asparagus.  Though, as it should be at a sushi place, the fish was the star of the show.

Next time -- reservations for the sushi counter. That should be fun.
author: Tom Y.

description:
Hey, just because we were the only folks there getting drunk, it doesn't mean you can get away with serving us BAD sushi. Don't think we didn't notice.

SHAME ON YOU!
author: Nance W.

description:
The other morning I had a very stressful dream.  I was standing in line in an Asian pastry shop.  When I got to the front, I was asked to step aside while others behind me were being served.  After a while I spoke up and was told to go to the serving window outside.  Outside, I eventually asked one of the staff for service and she said they had just closed.  I was fuming.  O Yelp stars for you!...that's when I realized I was having a Yelp Nightmare.

Fortunately this wasn't the case at Koo.  In fact I had the complete opposite experience.  I arrived for dinner without a reservation.  They were pretty much booked up ~ I hadn't realized how popular they were.  The host was apologetic and said all they had was a table for 2 available for the next hour.  I was moved by how accommodating they were.  My friend showed and we sat down.  Service with a smile, friendly and super efficient.  Orders promptly taken, glasses kept full, and the food was enjoyable.  Got a nod and a thank you on the way out.

Will definitely come back.  I hope to revisit this place in my dream sometime too.  5 Yelp stars for you!
author: Cathy K.

description:
Are you smooth?  Clean?  Rich and smooth?

Ooooh yeah!  I wish we all wore descriptions like the hot names for the cold sake selection.  

It's fun to order a bunch and try to figure out which ones fit the name.
Since I'm not much of a connoisseur, it's sometimes a safe bet to go with price.  tacky, i know.  but....
by the third one, I could care less what price it is anyway...

They should change their website from sushikoo to sakikoo since the roll  and sushi choices don't hit you over the head.

I'm all about sharing and trying out each dish possible. 
Top on my list is the tuna and salmon tartare - deelish.
Ordered and only ok...the dragon roll, tuna and mushroom, and beef tataki
author: Anh V.

description:
Koo is so close to my house that the chef could fart and it would probably waft in my bedroom window. Yet, I didn't eat here until like, what, a week ago after living here for three years? 

Well, here's the deal. I would occasionally eat sushi with friends or girlfriends (what's up with girls loving sushi so goddamn much?), but I never really was a huge fan. So I take a friend out to dinner who wanted sushi, and I didn't just like it - it was stellar! I honestly don't remember what we ate, but it was amazing. 

Five stars for nice people and my first time loving sushi.
author: Brandon B.

description:
It was too far to drive for average sushi.  It was decent, but so are a lot of places in San Francisco.

Decor was nice, but the lighting was way too bright.

I felt rushed, but that's OK, I was ready to go.
author: jennifer j.

description:
As sushi goes, for quality of food - they pretty much just meet the standard.  The five rolls we ordered were tasty enough, but not anything to write home about.  I will say that the fish was pretty fresh. 

I'll pay for great food and great service.  For sushi and service of this quality, we should have paid significantly less.  

Underwhelmed.
author: Dee B.

description:
I'm a super fan of Japanese food! Came here after reading all the great reviews about this place, and it was in fact amazing! We sat at the sushi bar though the dinning area wasn't full early in the evening. I always like eating at the sushi bar, chatting with the sushi chefs and admiring their cooking skills. Services were good except for the grumpy old chef. 

They surprised us with the happy hour menu, score! The $4 uni hand roll was the best, and the $5 large hot sake! We filled up with the hand rolls pretty quickly and couldn't try the items, including their daily nigiri selection and the spoon full of happiness, which I would totally order next time. Then I'll come back to edit my review!
author: Kai Z.

description: We came here on accident a year ago, intending to go to Ebisu but what a find! This cute neighborhood spot was perfect. The service was sweet and attentive, albeit it was pretty empty since it was a Sunday night. The shaking beef was delicious and the sashimi and sushi rolls were fresh and tasty. My second trip I really enjoyed the salmon and tuna with guacamole..sounded odd but was yummy. Some of the rolls have so much stuff you don't taste the fish but it was still quite good. The menu is unique without trying too hard. This is my favorite in SF for reasonably priced, fresh sushi and Japanese fusion. Too bad parking is impossible..
author: Lainy C.

description:
Okay, what in the hell is the secret password???!!!!!!!!!!!

People I know personally, Yelpers whose reviews I trust, and magazines/newspapers all rave about Koo. I was going to write this review over a year ago but kept delaying it because of all the adoration this place receives. I have eaten alone at the bar, dined with a friend in the dining room, and dined with a friend at the bar. I have ordered the cooked food from the menu, picked my favorite sushi, and chosen the entire fresh catch section. I finally sat at the bar with a friend and ordered Omakase style. So, enough is enough.

This place merits a solid 3 stars. If you need a reliable sushi joint but nothing spectacular then this place is fine. For me, most of the nigiri and sashimi had what I dub the refrigerator taste. When sushi is not that "fresh" (FDA mandates fish eaten raw must be frozen first, tuna being the exception) every cut of fish has a similar flavor. Everything becomes the commodity of sushi. Admittedly, there have been one or two pieces of nigiri or sashimi that were quite good every time I went. But ONLY one or two pieces. And yes, the Spoonful of Happiness is delicious.

The chefs are knowledgeable and the wait staff is friendly. The interior has a nice understated, minimalist decor. 

What really irked me (and my friend) is the price we ended up paying at the end of our Omakase. After tax and tip our bill was over $200. I have shelled out close to $100 for sushi on several occasions but those in the past were all worth it.  Definitely NOT this time. 

So tell me. What is the fucking password or secret handshake that you must do? I still can't obtain the ethereal state of bliss everyone is bragging about!!
author: Shawn T.

description: Very fresh sashimi and sliced just like the chefs would in Japan. When your squid sashimi is almost translucent and tastes like the sweet sea, the chef is doing something right.  Decent sake selection and unobtrusive wait staff.
author: Lauren C.

description:
I'm originally from Minnesota, where raw fish is only eaten by other fish as bait.  Well, and by my cousin, Adam, when we were 10 years old.  "Hey, Bert, watch this! (gulp)"  Eeeeeew.

After nearly a decade in California, I can now call myself a sushi aficionado.  And not just relative to my upbringing.  I'm proud to say that I objectively know good sushi.  (I do have to admit that I still let my husband order because I have no idea what anything on the menu means. Perhaps, I could work on my ordering mojo.)

Koo beat out my previous favorite sushi joint, Ebisu, due to its warm, spacious dining room; its friendly staff; and its fantastically fresh fish.  The scallops were melty and smooth.  Seaweed salad was salty and bright.  The light fixtures were fascinating.

Five stars, despite the pricey-ness.  You get what you pay for here.  Make a reservation, though.  They get full fast... as will you.
author: Bert M.

description:
This is one of my favorite sushi places in the city.  The fish is always fresh and the service is always decent.

Make sure you order the spoonfuls of happiness...and oh let me tell ya....is it soooo happy!  If you aren't a huge fan of uni or ankimo, order this and you just might change your mind!
author: Susan P.

description:
This is my favorite sushi restaurant in the city--and I've been to a lot of them. It's been harder to get a table lately since they were on the Best Of Sushi list for CitySearch so make a reservation.

The sushi chef/owner used to work at Tokyo Go Go so a few of the rolls appear on both menus. Koo does them WAY BETTER though.

Must orders: The Spoonful of Happiness and the Azteca Roll.

The Spoonful of Happiness is an appetizer for one person. Every time I go here with my fiance, we order two. It's actually TWO spoonfuls of happiness and a shot of premium cold sake. Each spoon has a perfect combination of sushi (monkfish liver, sea urchin roe, etc) and ponzu. You eat one spoonful and do half the shot of cold sake. Then do the other spoonful and finish off the sake. The sake blends with the ponzu and fish PERFECTLY.

The Azteca Roll is a roll with thin slices of jalapeno on top. The jalapeno is the perfect size and spicyness so it doesn't overpower the amazingly fresh fish. Other places have the jalapeno thing but none of them do it as well as Koo.
author: Cindy P.

description:
My favorite sushi in SF.

I have been to Koo several times with a bit of a mixed experience (all good).  When seated away from the bar I find the sushi excellent (easily as good as Ebisu down the street minus the hour long wait, and they take reservations!), the menu well planned and laid out, and the service very good.  When my wife and I sit at the sushi bar, however, we are absolutely swept away by how great the fish is and how fantastic the chefs are.  I wish I had a specific recommendation, but every time I go I find something else that's fabulous.  We love to sit at the bar and just let them start dishing out what's fresh and good today.  Always a surprise and always great!

YOU should absolutely NOT go there though, its perfect just the way it is without being packed with Yelpers taking up my beloved bar seats!
author: Clay G.

description:
No complaints, just good sushi. My yellow tail was delicious, as was everything else. The selection of Sake I choose (from a nice list) came in a Masu set (sake in a cup, which is then in a box).

The staff is clearly Japanese, which gave me a warm and fuzzy feeling. The sushi bar is well kept and is a nice place to watch your sushi being made. It has a coat rack in the room if you don't want your coat to end up on the floor. The main dining hall is fairly large and has enough tables to be bring some groups in. Parking is the usual Inner Sunset joy, except this restaurant is further down, so you may find easier street parking nearby.

Is it expensive? Of course. This is sushi after all. If you want cheap go hit T-Bell. You can get a whole meal for the price of the Miso soup here.
author: Andrew M.

description:
My friends and I shared a fun selection of rolls - great to go here if you like rolls but get bored of the same old same old and want to try new combos.

Tokyo Crunch = 3 stars, good and yummy crunchy topping but the sauce was too salty.

Best Roll = 5 stars, a great combination of flavors including salmon, asparagus tempura, and a thin lemon wedge.  Pretty, and different from any other rolls i've had.  Would it be obvious to say it was refreshing, since it has lemon on it?  I think it's a good roll to add to your order if you are ordering a bunch of the classics or salty rolls.

Spider Roll = 4 stars

Flying Kamikaze = 5 stars, perfectly amount of spiciness (for me)

After the fun roll experimentation, I had predictable but dependable mochi and gelato and butter cookies, yum!  Some things are great as predictable staples, like mochi :)

Oh yeah, and I think the prices for the rolls are lower than they'd be in more downtown SF.
author: Jen X.

description:
Spoonfuls of happiness you make me happy.  Okay, one of the spoonfuls do.  I'm not a fan of uni so that spoon didn't do it for me.  But the ankimo spoon is FANTASTIC.  It's my friend's favorite restaurant and i think she's there at least twice a week.  Fresh fish and the staff are really friendly.  
A must try if you've never been.   A little bit pricey but once in a while isn't a bad thing.
author: Susan Z.

description:
I went on a Thursday night with two girlfriends. I like the ambience and decor, which is clean and contemporary with quirky artwork. The food is what I'd call upscale or fancy (I'm a pretty low-maintenance chick with a rep for being, how shall I say it... cheap.) The food is interesting. We had:

1) A Spoonful of Happiness  
My comments: Not for me. Extremely rich. Fantastic presentation, however.

2) Seaweed salad 
My comments: good

3) Mackerel sashimi appetizer special
My comments: tasty and interesting. Like nothing I'd ever eaten before. Beautifully plated.

4) Frlying Kamikaze Roll
My comments: delicious.

5) California Roll
My comments: average.

It's interesting to see that the reviews for Koo are all over the board. Makes me think the place may be inconsistent in quality and service. I think the prices are appropriate.
author: Kathryn T.

description:
I went here a couple months ago and felt I was too drunk to actually write a decent review, so I ate here tonight.  YUM!!!

So after reading other Yelper reviews, I decided to try the Spoonful of Happiness....WOWSERS!  A spoon full of uni, quail egg, tobiko and ponzu and another spoon full of anikmo (monkfish pate) with whitefish and truffle oil, served with a shot of sake.  We took a sip of the sake, swished it around, took a spoonful of heaven, swished it around and then finished with another sip of sake.  Great pairing.  

As for starters, we tried the steamed scallop and shrimp dumplings and the spicy green beans.  Both were extremely tasty.

Sushi rolls, ordered the Best Roll, Azteca, Spicy Roll and Flying Kamikaze.  Perfect choices.  My mom wasn't down with the gobo in the Azteca roll, but I enjoyed the texture contrast.

For drinks, Asahi and Sapporo.

Great sushi dinner.  Fresh fish.  Inventive rolls.  I will be back.
author: Christina S.

description:
We have been avoiding Koo due to some the reviews. We were a bit intimidated. We thought it would be extremely overpriced. We also are more neat but casual dressers and thought we had to dress up for this place. So we were saving it for a special occasion. To our surprise, most of the sushi prices were no higher than most decent Japanese sushi restaurants. The early bird only reduced items by a dollar so it was not a big deal maybe unless you drink. We did not look at the drink menu b/c we don't drink alcohol. We were disappointed by the calamari $9... not cripsy and the dipping sauce was not quite there. Did not like the texture... cornmeal? The Gozzilla Tofu was nice and crisp but the miso sauce missed some cubes resulting in some "very salty" cubes and some kind of tasteless. The beef tataki was tough... I'm ok  with a few less pieces of meat and instead, a better grade as served at Izakaya Sozai. The hand rolls were fresh but didn't wow us. Our avocados did not overflow like in the photos. The combo sushi was ok. The Azteca  Roll didn't do a thing for us. It didn't have a bite. It tasted like a warm california roll with a slightly fishy white fish on top and decorated w/ a ring of tasteless Jalapeno. No tea offered because when we sat down we asked for water? 
What really annoyed us, was the waitresses. Please don't get me wrong. There were more than enough wait staff and the ladies were very polite and sweet. But...One after another would grab the serving dishes away while we were still chomping on our rolls, etc. After the 3rd time, I was determined to eat a bite of the ginger but away it went while I had 2 hands busy with my hand roll. 6 hand rolls, 1 combo sushi, 1 azteca roll and I only got one bite of the ginger. My kids got none.
This is a nice, clean Japanese restaurant. It is in the cold foggy Sunset where I live and work. As we sat there, we yearned for a bowl of ramen or donburi to go with the sushi. Ochauke? Maybe it was my mistake, we should have asked for some hot tea. Sushi taste much better w/ hot tea.
We are spoiled by very good sushi. We've spent 5 summers in Japan. We love going over to Berkeley to Kirala at least once a month. We are used to paying extra for the yummy sushi. Koo was not bad, decent, just not great. Total bill w/ tax and tip $108.00 for 3 for an average meal. We might go back but my sushi crazy sons showed no excitement during the meal. I would not avoid it. It can be a very nice cozy place to have a quiet decent dinner. Order the hot tea, miso soup. Rotating the tables by the window so all can gaze out might help. There was something missing with my back to the window.
author: jane f.

description: Kabuto don't hate me....having been to Koo twice now they might get my vote for best sushi in the city.  Best fish.  So good.  Worth dropping some cash on really enjoying yourself here.
author: McKenzie M.

description:
The food here is good... but the service sucks. Sorry, it doesn't SUCK suck, they just seem to forget you're there after they seat you... On the night we were there almost every table needed to ask for service. 

But about the food: Our favorite is their mint ribs in a lettuce cup (yeah, they also need to work on the names of their dishes). But you can get this in a Chinese restaurant  for half the price (and more flavor). The other Chinese inspired dish that's good is the stuffed jalapeo... but again, kind of expensive for what you get. 

The sushi is good, but pretty basic stuff. The one standout is their Tokyo Crunch which has little bits of what I'm assuming is tempura batter and drizzled with a nice teriyaki-like sauce.

We've been there twice and I think it's a good neighborhood place... but don't think I'd travel across town, or circle the block 50 bazillion times to eat here.
author: L. M.

description:
I came here during a Thursday happy hour. They have good rolls, I got two of their sea urchin hand rolls, which were really fresh and a good deal since it was only 4 dollars. I treated my friend who doesn't eat raw fish to the sea scallop hand roll which she enjoyed. I found the sea scallop to be just ok. 
Overall This is a good place to get cheap appetizer hand rolls. 
Just a warning-- I struggled to find the location because they have a tree blocking the name of their restaurant and the name of the restaurant is pretty hard to read. So look hard if you wanna find it.
author: A. L.

description: I went there almost two years ago, and I've been looking for an excuse to go again - super fresh fish, creative rolls that really aren't that expensive when you compare to other sushi places, and a really nice atmosphere. A bit cramped, though, so yes for dates, no for big group dinners.
author: Ming S.

description: It is my absolute favorite. (And I'm gd picky.) That's all i'm going to say about that.
author: D'arcy N.

description:
The food here is delicious and super fresh
Pricing is reasonable and in line with what you are getting
Service is always warm, friendly and helpful
Some of the best Japanese I've had in SF
author: Kate B.

description:
I was sad when I left my old digs over in the western addition (I mean NOPA, or whatever the kids are calling it these days), because it meant that tsunami sushi was no longer within walking distance (wwd).  

Enter the inner sunset, home of fog, the N-Judah, and koo, my new fave sushi restaurant wwd.  This is GREAT sushi and you don't feel like you're paying an ambiance or attitude surcharge.  They gave the gf and I a cute table in the corner.  

Koo is very cozy and minimalist, not in the "let's hire a team of interior designers to give us that ubiquitous Asian minimalist look, and we'll play the Gotan Project in the background" kind of way,  but more in a "we are proud of the food we make and we are classy" way.  Did that make any sense?           

Yeah, anyway, you should try it.
author: James M.

description:
Great fresh sushi and very reasonably priced.  We tried about 4 rolls and some hamachi nigiri and saba sashimi. All fresh and delicious. 

The $6 house sake is a great deal and excellent. 

$25/head with tip and sake.
author: Phil M.

description: Definitely one of the best sushi restaurants I've been to. I ordered the Shichimi Crusted Tuna and the Dragon and Flying Kamikaze Rolls. The Shichimi Crusted Tuna was AMAZING. The fish was fresh and seared perfectly. The rolls were delicious too. Their dessert was not as impressive, however. The Mt. Fuji was a little too dense and heavy for my liking, though the green tea gelato was fairly good.
author: Sophia B.

description:
Daaaaaaamn. The fish and quailty was soooooo good!!!   Came here with my brother a few Wednesdays ago and took him cuz he appreciates sashimi the way I do.  We had a few handrolls for happy hour and those were good.  Tried the Spoonful of Happiness and it was soooo worth it. I love ankimo and uni and both spoons had that, Plus, a shot of Sugei sake that comes with the spoonful of happiness!!!
We had just about every fish: sea bream, scallop from Japan (the best scallop I ever had), aji, blue fin toro, hamachi, maguro, and many other types that other restaurants don't serve.  I can't remember the names of the fish.  We ate (just the 2 of us) $150 worth of sashimi.  It was perfect.  We had dessert...mango and strawberry mochi ice cream which was great.  My brother had the black sesame panna cotta which he said he enjoyed.  
The only thing I ordered from the hot menu was grilled baby octopus that came over a bed of mixed greens. Perfectly grilled and had a nice char on the octopus.
I only wish they offered more things on the hot menu, such as a nabe or maybe more items.  I will definitely go back soon.
author: natalie y.

description: My wife and I had dinner here on a recommendation from a friend of hers. We ordered an assortment of rolls and a few orders of sushi. The place wasn't busy when we arrived but got busy pretty fast. Our food took (seemed like forever) a long time to arrive but it all came at once. It's a small intimate place that doesn't seem very trendy (which I liked). There was a good mix of people from young to old and singles to families.
author: Steve M.

description:
I'm on a sushi tour this week, so back to Koo I go. Been here 4 times and I have never been disappointed.  For today, I just dropped in for a quick happy hour before heading to the gym. So I ordered the Dynamite hand roll- baked scallops with wasabi- tobiko & the Suzuki sea bass sushi. Both were absolutely delicious. 

I highly recommend this spot for sushi & sashimi. Koo is not cheap, so just be aware that you will spend more money here, but the freshness and the creativity of the meal/s are well worth it.
author: Al G.

description:
Someone told me a few months ago that Koo is the best sushi in San Francisco. I laughed. 

But now that I've been back a few times, they might be onto something. I'm still not sure it's my fave in the city, but it is pretty damn good. I'm all about the Best roll - tempura asparagus, avocado with salmon and a slice of lemon on top. It's a bit of a trek for me to get out here, but it's well worth it.

Minus one star for the gross curtain separating the dining area from the restroom. Ick.
author: Carolyn C.

description: I's always nice to come here for a real Japanese food. They have great happy hour deal! Sushi is fresh, and the location is good for Inner Sunset neighbors. Maguro and Avocado temaki is so good!
author: Maitai N.

description: I decided to give this place a second chance and now I am changing my review because the food tasted a lot better than the first time I came. Customer service was the same. 4 Stars =)
author: H. A.

description:
I'm so thankful to my co-worker for introducing me to this place. WOW --the food is fresh and delicious! It has definitely become of my favorite Japanese restaurants in the City. It's a great place to take someone on a first date or a night out with the ladies or fellas. The prices are a bit pricey for the neighborhood but the service ROCKS! I never had my tea cup or iced water half empty. 

Try the "best roll" --- it was definitely one of the best and freshest sushi rolls I had in a long time. The tuna/salmon and avocado tartare appetizer was amazing too! It came with crisp shrimp chips and was a delight to dip them in the tartare. The lettuce cups were yummy as well. We also tried the shrimp and scallop dumplings, which were good but not as memorable. All in all, the food was wonderful and I think I can order the best roll and tartare all to myself...and I'm not sharing! haha

I would recommend making a reservation, esp. on Fridays and Saturdays.
author: La C.

description:
Overall a good experience at Koo.
Good service.
Fresh Sashimi.

But in San Francisco, you can definitely come across even more creative Sushi.

Koo is worth a visit though.
author: Jennie L.

description:
As a lover of Japanese cuisine,  I am enamored with this place for its delicious and reliable fare. We went here on cupids day, 'nuf said.

Spoonful of Happiness is an intense experience for any sea urchin lovers out there, or just anyone looking to try something new. Specialty Rolls are great (big fan of the U2 and Dragon) especially for those who do not wish to visit the raw side. 

Basically you can't go wrong with Koo.
author: Yana C.

description:
Love this place.  One of my most favorite places for sushi in the city.  

I used to live in the inner sunset and I tried to go here once a month.  Service is fantastic and when the sapporo and sake runs it gets even better!  They don't do too many funky rolls (there are though) which I appreciate.  Give me Sashimi or give me liberty!

It's not a huge place, so I'd recommend reservations on weekends.  Larger groups of more than 4 will have a more difficult time with walk-ins.  it is romantic..and it is dim like a lounge.  I did read that having dim lights makes you feel more sexier...does that mean it made the food more sexier and tasteful?  Certainly felt like it.
author: Yup S.

description:
The catch of the day menu is fantastic and delicious.  So many different varieties to choose from.

It's expensive and adds up quick, but you get what you pay for.

Don't really like how they can't wait to clear your dishes in an attempt to turn the tables around as fast as possible.  On one plate I had to tell them I wasn't done eatting yet.
author: Sandra L.

description:
After a horrible experience at Yoshi's we came over to Koo's for dinner.  I came here on a recommendation from my sister and after my less than stellar experience at Kitaro's, I was super iffy on how good her taste buds actually were.

We ordered 7 rolls:
1.  California
2.  Flying Kamikaze
3.  Dragon
4.  Best
5.  Azteca
6.  Tempura Shrimp
7.  ????

In addition to that we had the Dynamite hand roll, a few sashimi pieces and two shrimp heads.

The seafood was absolutely outstanding.  I can see why they have such high reviews on yelp.  Every single piece of fish was fresh and it's safe to say that this is one of if not THE best sushi restaurant that I have been to to date.  

The only downfall is that parking sucks big time.  There is a great dim sum place down the street that I love but I rarely go to on account of the lack of parking.  I will definitely come back here the next time I am in NorCal.
author: Anna H.

description:
Great quality sashimi at moderate prices.  A few notables are:

Hamachi sashimi is melt-in-your month good.
Best Roll with salmon sashimi topped with ultra-thin slices of lemon is delightfully refreshing.
Mt-Fuji is a wonderful molten chocolate cake that is not too sweet. 

Other dishes and sushi are also pretty good. However, Unagi nigiri has gone down-hill. It used to be so perfectly grilled the fish is slightly crispy on the outside and juicy and tender on the inside, but not anymore during my recent visit.
author: C L.

description:
I like the spoonful of happiness. It's a dish that has the flavor of Japanese fusion, creativity, and unexpected WoOoOoOo..Two spoons and one glass of cold sake cost $10. But it's worthy of trying!!!!  

Visit the restaurant when you're not super hungry. Otherwise, you might end up to be paying more than $50 per person. =..="
author: Chiqui H.

description:
Absolutely love KOO.  Sad when we can't make it more than 3 times a month!!!  The quality, creativity and service makes this a very special place in SF.   Glad to see them busier every time we are there, even though it is starting to get harder to get a table.
The Spicy Scallop roll is the best in SF.
author: Emi C.

description: Left happy with a spoon full of happiness--it really is as good as everyone says. Everything we ordered was excellent. Not over priced, great location, good place to bring friends or a date, parking wasn't too bad, liked the vibe--not too fancy or casual. I would definitely go back.
author: Ashley B.

description:
Of all the sushi joints, in all the neighborhoods, in all of the city--you really should walk into Koo. It's my go-to pick for raw fish.

Classy place. The gourmet variety never misses, time and again. 

A $75 meal for two (with drinks) that's well worth repeating.
author: christopher r.

description:
The sake was good - event though they didn't have 'beautiful boy'.

Dishes tried: 
* Happiness in a spoon: Fun presentation. Scored 3 out of 5 taste wise.

* Duck salad: Very bland and boring.

* Blackened Cod: The bok choy and tofu was over done but the cod was excellent.

* Soft crab spider roll: Tasted like any other spider roll.

Service was slow but passable.
The only reason I'm not giving this place a 3 is because I didn't try any nigiri sushi and I'll hold off on the final rating until I've done so.

The only problem is that I don't think I'll go back.
author: Rich S.

description:
MMmm.  Good sushi!
