I had the usual assortment of maki and nigiri (I don't exactly remember what) but what I do remember was that the fish was fresh and good quality---no needing to slather wasabi and soy sauce to cover up any strange tastes!  The lighting is soothing and a great place to just get something good after a long hard day's work.

Times visited: 1
author: Amy L.

description:
Remains my favorite (and lucky me, local) purveyor of fine sushi.

Sadly Minoru, a kindred moto fan, has moved on, but the team here is still tops, Kiyoshi san is one koo dude.
author: GIR ..

description:
Koo is a real neighborhood gem! The decor is a fusion between japanese simplicity and modern chic. It's a nice place to enjoy a meal with a few friends, but cozy enough for a date, too!  A friend and I sampled a variety of their sushi, including hamachi, uni, scallops and the eel. I was so impressed by Koo's offering of FRESH fish. 

Other things we tried:
-- duck breast salad: duck was lightly marinated and very tender.    dressing had hints of ginger and citrus, perfect.
-- godzilla tofu: silken interior, crunchy outside. sauce was miso 
garlic based, and just a hint of spice.

Koo's prices are pretty standard for quality sushi. The quality of fish here, really, is excellent. Their sushi is full of little touches that elevated my dining experience from ordinary to extraordinary. I will be back!
author: Kelsie L.

description:
I had REALLY HIGH expectations for Koo but I went away disappointed.  Overall, we felt the meal was good but it lacked the depth I was expecting based on all the reviews.  

We ordered 2 appetizers (Oysters & Fried Tofu) and an assortment of Nigiri.  Generally one of my favorite items is the Ama-ebi shrimp head, but the ones they served us were seriously lacking presentation, the flavor was mediocre.  These shrimp heads were under fried and didn't have the outer shell of the head. They were just ugly which is not acceptable!  It's like they took off that shell and then fried the shrimp.    One was a normal size and the other one came extremely small.  As for the Oysters they were very good and the sauce on top was excellent but one of the four oysters was extremely small in size and did not look quite fresh. I also felt the Uni was not as fresh as I have eaten in other places.  As for the cooked items, I did enjoy them more than the sushi, the fried tofu topped with a nice miso sauce.  

The service was mediocre, for a small restaurant I felt they could done a bit better.  I went away a little hungry and ready for dessert....we almost went to Bi-Rite but  somehow ended up at Marco Polo...:)) which is NEVER a disappointment!

Maybe I didn't drink enough sake to enjoy the meal?  I doubt I would return here.  I rather to go to HOSHI's in Santa Clara, which is currently my favorite sushi restaurant in the Bay Area for now.  

Oh the worst part was that I RAVED to my friend about this place and she kept telling me too look around, do you see any Japanese business men or even Japanese people here?....I couldn't say yes because there weren't any...
author: Mel S.

description:
by far my favorite Sushi stop on the west coast! I have enjoyed Sushi all over the world including Japan, Hawaii and several spots in California, Oregon and Washington. KOO is at a level above all. Your first visit to this warm and welcoming restaurant must be experienced while seated at the bar! 
Trust me, you will be thankful. The owner will take great care of you and encourage you to try his unique creations! 
Enjoy Koo!
author: Ramzy H.

description:
I went there with my brother for his birthday and I have to say that it was rather disappointing.

We are native Japanese so we have high standards when it comes to Japanese food.

The overall taste was acceptable but for the portion of food we got, I have to say this place is over priced.

$5 for some mix green salad that you can just buy at Safeway, and $17 for 6 pieces of California rolls and 5 tiny pieces of nigiri pieces.

Other side dishes were also expensive and there are better places to spend same amount of money we spent.

For us, this place is a total rip off and we won't be going back again even if someone else is paying for it cos it's just not worth it.
author: Shumi S.

description:
Oishikata!
Compared to sushi in Japan this comes close.  Kiyoshi-san knows how to prepare sushi the Japanese way.  A must if you are looking for something more authentic
author: David S.

description:
Spoonful of ........mmmmmmmmmmmm!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!  

I got the big DV treatment, so spoiled.
author: Aaron I.

description:
I miss Koo, I love Koo !  This is one of the best Sushi in SF !   Fish is very fresh! 

I'm Japanese I know real Sushi is!
author: Megumi C.

description:
Koo makes the grade for me! The fish is great and they have quite an array of cool japanese fusion dishes. Spoonful of happiness is yummy if you are into uni and quail egg. The bamboo tower salad is a daring pairing of sashimi and an interesting gelatanous dressing. (excellente) 

The ambiance is chill. Not the scene like Go Go or Sushi Groove South, but a relaxing place for dinner - where you can talk (not shout) over the ambient noise to talk to your friends. I like the decor which feels like you are in an old Japanese farm house. Nice touches there.

Been there several times, and will continue to go.
author: Stephanie I.

description:
Typically, I don't like uni, and I never thought I'd like monkfish (it usually smells like ass when you cook it) but I LOVE Spoonful(s) of Happiness. 
The decor is nicely minimalistic and slightly quirky (skiing geishas) and the waitstaff is very sweet, so much that ya might feel inclined to overlook their dinginess in delivering ur order correctly.
Also enjoyed their huge servings of nigori. I almost drank the traces of sake in the tray/cup the shot comes in, I love that stuff so much.
author: Joyhan S.

description:
I've been rather tired of the standard sushi/sashimi/rolls fare lately that I was excited to go to Koo and see what they have to offer

Their "Catch of the Day" menu was varied and impressive. I wanted to try almost everything but ended up with Hotaru Ika (tiny whole squids, yay, squid guts in the head! They taste better than it sounds), the Toro Trio (Blue fin tuna, Albacore, and Yellowtail bellies, oh melty melty goodness), and the Gindara nigiri (Black Cod sushi... okay, could have picked another fish). My friend and I split a Miso Marinated Black Cod, which just melted in my mouth and the marinade was super yum. You can never go wrong with miso marinated softy buttery fish! I was just swishing the fish between my tongue and the roof of my mouth instead of chewing it, and it was heavenly!

At last, I realized my wallet couldn't take it anymore, but I was still itching to eat something. Usually I end my sushi outings with an iku-tama/ikura with uzura (salmon roe with raw quail egg) orgasm in my mouth, but my friend suggested trying the Spoonful of Happiness, since it had the raw quail egg, and I agreed, just to see what it was all about. 

So you actually get TWO spoons of happiness, yay! The first one was monkfish wrapped in white fish, this one had a bit of a kick, and the second one had the quail egg... and uni.

I don't particularly like uni, and I had neglected to notice that uni was served in the spoons of happiness, but thankfully, it was only on one spoon! And I got to wash it all down with the sake. But the aftertaste of uni was still there, wah! So if you like uni, the second spoon of happiness will most definitely be for you. 

Anyway, Koo is rather pricey, but it's worth it and it seems like there would be something new the next time. I'm coming back to try the Best Roll, and whatever is on "Catch of the Day!"
author: Cat D.

description:
QUALITY!

I've been meaning to stop by Koo for the past year.  I have walked by it many times and it always looked so cute and inviting.  Last Friday was a gorgeous evening and my husband and I decided to take an evening walk down Irving.  While walking we decided to stop somewhere for dinner and Koo happened to be right there.  We were both quite impressed.  The prices are not "cheap," but they are incredibly reasonable fr the quality of the sushi.  The quality of the fish and sushi really couldn't have been better.  We got quite a variety and ordered several kinds of fish that we had never heard of before.  All of it was excellent.  One of my favorite kinds of sushi is Spanish Mackerel.  All I have to say is that they had some of the best.  I will definitely return to this great neighborhood spot.
author: Kate B.

description:
Great. Spoonful of Happiness was really fantastic. I would go back just for this. Five stars for that. 

3 stars for the roll selection. I didnt like the salmon, lemon, asparagus roll. Wish they had more options. Stick to the nigiri. 

We did order some of the fresh scallop and uni, and both were 5 stars. 

I'll be back.
author: Lady L.

description:
a. may. zing. 

Sashimi platter: a little pricey ($24 for 12 pieces, but very very tasty): maguro: A+, white fish: A, hamachi: A+, salmon: A+

Spicy Tuna roll: different than any other I've had and delicious

Rock N Roll: UNAGI. YUM. so good

Special Sushi Hamachi Toro: if butter were present in fish form... this is it. Melt in your mouth hamachi heaven.

availability of Asahi beer on draft: A+

Service: excellent. as soon as my husband finished his beer, he was asked if he wanted another. He gave a little nod, returned to our conversation, turned around and the new beer was there. Ninja beer refill.

Will most definitely go back.

p.s. get the REAL WASABI. totally worth it, totally delicious.
author: A P.

description:
i tried this place w/my friend (who's in the yelp elite oooooh!) after hearing about it on yelp & was rather concerned it didn't have 5 stars (after all, so many places to try, so little time). but boy am i glad i did! it's so important to order the right dishes, & reading other rvws (here & chronicle) helped us do just that. UPDATE: this has become one of my favorite restaurants in the city. so cozy, so comfortable, & guaranteed to love the food. i've added more dishes i've tried on valentine's day.

ORDER: ~u absolutely must try the spoonful of happiness at least once in ur lifetime. one of my all-time FAVORITES in the world. i told the chef & he was so humble & thanked me. he's so cute!

~tuna/salmon tartare on shrimp chips is always great!!!

~all of the sushi rolls & dishes we tried offered something unique & very pleasing. tokyo crunch is alright, too much crunchy stuff.

~best roll rocks!

~flying kamikaze is good b/c the albacore, but the asparagus overpowers it a little too much with a garden taste.

~2-way tsukidashi was a v-day special, but get it if u can! the marinated scallop on lemon mash was of the highest quality, michael mina-caliber.

~mint spare rib butter lettuce cup was good, but not my favorite.

~crystal bamboo tower salad was yummy, big, but not amazing.

~seared tataki is not that good. i've never found it to be good at any restaurant, so maybe i just don't like the dish itself.

~miso black cod is homey, o SO delicious, & earthy. black cod = butterfish = my favorite fish ever. common in hawaii, but hard to obtain here...but i know where!

~mt. fuji is to die for, like the softest fudgey texture & only $3 amaaazing. UPDATE: now it's $4! still cheap tho.

SERVICE: the hostess was so sweet, but our waiter was kind of spaced out, perhaps he was on the young & inexperienced side. i would let him know our needs, & he had to be reminded to fulfill them. UPDATE: the same waiter is much better now, he's great.

DECOR: is that of a neighborhood joint. good lighting tho.

CROWD: other clientele seemed food savvy. 

BATHROOM: japanese bathrooms always smell good. they could tidy up some junk laying around, but otherwise clean & private. the automatic towel machine always scares me! UPDATE: they lowered the paper towels so it doesn't have a mind of its own anymore.

OVERALL: one of my FAVORITE sushi places in s.f., the kind of place you show people. during our meal, i kept raving about the culinary journey we were embarking upon. i have dreams about the spoonful of happiness--aptly named, eye-opening, epicurean epiphany!
author: miss b.

description:
Everything is fresh, and unlike many other sushi restaurants, their rolls all actually taste different.

JONASAPPROVED!
author: Jonas T.

description: The fish was fresh and delicious. I wish there were more choices in the raw fish rolls. The sashimi was delicious and so was the best roll!
author: Wildeflower M.

description:
Ohhhh... kooooo.  I feel as happy as a pigeon having sex on our windowsill there... OK, that's gross.  Never mind.

Until Koo, I did not like uni.  Until Koo, I did not realize the joy of quail eggs.  Until Koo, I did not realize that happiness can come in a spoon.

Koo goes to the top of my lists of restaurants that I *crave* returning to.  I've been back 4 times in the last month... and I can't wait to go again!
author: Serena Y.

description: LOVED it here! Can't even remember what we ordered, but every single thing was delicious and fresh. The service was fantastic and I like that it's not in a super trendy location that is painfully overplayed and overrated. I didn't want to leave!
author: Abby W.

description:
First of - the authenticity test - Is the restaurant run by Japanese people and the food prepared by Japanese people?  Yes!  That's 3 stars right there.  The next star goes to freshness of the sashimi.  The last star goes to the great service.   

For starter, the spoon full of happiness is yummmmy (if you like uni)!You can't really share this dish though.  You need to have it all for yourself.  The house mixed green salad is good and pretty big, so you can share this.  The Hamachi Kama is good for sharing too if you like grilled fish.

They have daily specials of sashimi from different parts of the world, which is not always on the menu.  Those are guaranteed to be fresh.   Any sashimi is fresh, we've been there many times and have never been disappointed.  The spicy tuna roll is good because it's not like most places where you feel like you're just eating hot sauce.  You can actually taste the fish and a bit of spiciness to it.  We love the Azteca roll and I'm generally not a big roll fan.  I generally like to stick with the sashimi.  

For dessert, try the Mt. Fuji and get a scoop of green tea gelato with that.  The portion isn't huge and won't put you over the top.  

Oh and if you like beer try the black Asahi.  This was the first time we had it and we love it.  It's a dark beer but very smooth and not too heavy or bitter.  I'm not a beer drinker and I like it alot.  It's rare to find this at Japanese restaurants and only a few supermarkets sell it.
author: Irene C.

description: Food was very good, nice ambience. but when we got our bill it was really high.  We found they had overcharged us by almost $35.  When we asked about it, we were told that they had changed cash register systems recently and thus the mistake...  hmmmmmmm.  No apology, no manager, nothing.  Always check your receipt.
author: Kris H.

description:
The Japanese-husband-wife-duo (I think they're married) put in some work in this menu, its as if they spent a lot of tender lovin care on each dish, making sure the flavors we're right. For example one roll we tried had the perfect amount of wasabi in it. It wasn't overpowering yet it made you wonder what the hell it was and it was friggin wasabi. And then I thought, "so that's how you use wasabi..."

All I can say is for a dinner for two...

3 appetizers:
-1 basket of fried calamari 
-2 orders of Spoonful of Happiness, 1 for each person (two spoons per serving, one featuring a fresh, raw, quail egg and the other fresh urchin.)

Entries:
And then get anything with as much raw-anything as you can because the fish melts in your mouth; its so damn fresh and high quality. The fried calamari is made from smaller squid, not the big ones, they're crisp, tasty, and lasts the whole dinner.

We had two rolls and two other dishes (3-4 piece nigiri and sashimi stuff) and it cost us $68 total. Pretty good for a great quality sushi spot for two. Feel free to experiment, this place doesn't seem to have a hit-or-miss menu.

Cons: Small, very intimate so great for 2 or 4. Weekend parking can suck. More expensive than usual, but worth a first try. It gets busy, so attention from waitresses isn't that great, but when served they are very friendly.
author: Albert B.

description:
I don't understand how Koo gets such great reviews!  I've been here only once & did not not even want to finish my meal here.

We started off with the godzilla tofu which was awful!  The sushi was of mediocre quality!  We left sadly disappointed.
author: Minna T.

description:
It was one of those commutes home on the N-Judah. Everyone got kicked off the train at the UCSF stop cuz of some problem with the power lines, and our train was being turned around.  And it was raining. And then only a single car shuttle came to pick up all the passengers that had been packed on the 2-car train. 
I decided to just get dinner instead and the first restaurant I saw was Koo.  I walked in wet from the rain, and totally pissed. It's a testament to this place that after my meal, I left in an awesome mood.
The menu offering was perfect - a la carte everything - so I could mix sushi, entree, and sides without having ordered enough food for 4 people. I got the Negi Toro special, a Chicken Teriyaki plate, and a bowl of rice.  The teriyaki was a bit too tough but the sushi was awesome.  I'll have to come back with companions next time so we can try more.

Update 4/13/06 - finally got together w/friends to try Koo in earnest, and was very VERY happy (especially cuz I had to make up for making them suffer w/me at Hamo-ko). Spoonful of Happiness, indeedy!  Also thoroughly enjoyed their Dynamite Handroll (bbq scallops w/tobiko)
author: CINDY K.

description:
Spoon Full of Happiness - I want a bowl of it!!!!

Amazing sushi specials. I was in heaven.....until the bill came. Well, the prices are actually reasonable, but I am just a glutton for great sushi.
author: Karen C.

description:
Wanna go to Koo?  Who?  Koo.  Who?  Yeah I've passed by this place hundreds of time since it's right off the N-Judah.  I didn't even know what it was and I can't even read the sign outside the restaurant.  

I went to eat here and discovered how fresh the sushi selection is.  The tuna and salmon with the shrimp chips was unbelievably tasty.  Best appetizer I've had.  Anything you try here will delight your palette.  Sake is good too.  

It's hard to find a good sushi place with good service.  I thought their service was just  as good as their food.  The only thing about this place I didn't like were the prices and the food portion sizes.  But this place is more about quality.
author: Stacey C.

description:
You would never believe that this place is in Inner Sunset.  It's got great ambience and the sushi chefs are very nice.  We sat at the bar because the place was packed on a Weds night at 8pm.  Recently in the past year I gravitate towards the bar because I like the interaction with the chefs.  

Dinner started with a salmon and onion small bite.  The negi-toro maki was excellent followed by the bonita tuna sashimi, very good too.  We had the Rock and Roll and also the tempura hamichi and avocado roll.  Both were delish. 

I have to come back and try more of the sashimi.  :)
author: Julia H.

description:
Best seat/chef in the house: all the way to the far wall at the sushi bar, in front of the youngest sushi chef. He is AWESOME. It's also humorous to sit in front of him and listen to him yell to the chefs in the back - in Japanese accented Spanish.

Our usual order is nigiri - uni (bf LOVES it, very fresh and melty), hamachi (fresh, cool, delicate), tobiko, wasabi tobiko with quail egg on top (sinus clearing!), hamamoto oyster (the perfect item to end your meal) and whatever sounds good on the catch of the day menu. Most recently, I had the Hokkaido scallop which was surprisingly tasty - not too chewy, but not fish-like either. 

Koo's roll selection isn't large, but all the rolls are QUALITY. My new favorite is the U2 roll - not usually a big fan of fried rolls or anything with tempura inside, but the shrimp tempura is LARGE and the balance between warm shrimp tempura and cold spicy tuna & tobiko on top is like an orgasm in my mouth.

I keep meaning to go try other sushi restaurants, but with Koo around, why bother? They never disappoint! Better get a reservation though, they tend to be busy all nights of the week.
author: Wendy T.

description:
Not really sure why this has three dollar signs for the price. It was pretty standard. 

I came here today with my sister. We ordered the tuna tartar on guacamole appetizer which came with shrimp chips, the azteca roll and the kamikaze roll (both of which were 2 of the priciest on the menu), and the sashimi combo which was 20 slices of fish and our bill came to about $65, pre-tip. It was a pretty damn filling meal.

Originally, I had actually shied away from it because I thought it was going to be super expensive due to the yelp rating, but it was actually moderately priced, surprisingly. Had I not decided to indulge in an extra roll last minute or had the appetizer, I could have easily had a satisfying dinner for 25.
author: Hendson L.

description:
I'm almost tempted to give Koo a terrible review in hopes of throwing everybody off the scent of this amazing place!  The perfect site for sushi when friends or family are visiting.  All their offerings are tasty and unique, with beautiful presentation.  We routinely fight over the last piece of Godzilla tofu and pepper-crusted seared tuna.  Their Best Roll really is the best!  

Amazing service and intimate atmosphere.  Although too expensive for an everyday dinner joint, every time we see our bill we think "oh, that's all?"  It's just that damn good.  

Reservations are helpful.
author: t k.

description:
The salmon tartar is from heaven!  Even though I'm not Japanese, the sushi chef talks to me in Japanese and treats me like a Japanese.

It's a must try!
author: Anastasia Beaver Housand J.

description: You get what you pay for. You can tell the chef actually spends a lot of time on your food and everything looks delicious. I am a big sushi fan and I think this place is worth to try. Parking kind of sucks but other than that, highly recommended. :]
author: Sandy L.

description: Koo has some of the highest quality fish in the Bay Area.  The katsuo (seared Hawaiian bonito tuna with ginger / garlic ponzu sauce) was a catch of the day the last time I ate here and just amazing.  Off the regular menu, the marinated salmon is like butter and the albacore is perfect.  We've also tried the Tokagen sake, which turned out to be deliciously peach-flavored and smooth.  You will have your best meal sticking to the raw stuff.  (However,  the baked scallop handroll is very tasty.)  My only real complaint is the teri sauce flavor seems to be on the burnt side.
author: Sherri C.

description:
Koo is hands down the best sushi restaurant in San Francisco, followed closely by the much smaller Hama-Ko in Cole Valley. 

Service is insanely friendly, fast enough, and the fish selections are fresh and creative (the special here REALLY ARE special). Their non-sushi appetizers are very tasty. And to top it all off, it's not ridiculously overpriced, finding itself nestled between the Cole Valley and Inner Sunset "strips." 

Take the N-Judah to avoid parking, and you've got yourself an excellent dinner experience.
author: A B.

description:
Mmm, MMM! Was going to wait to write this until I could confirm the consistency of this place with a second visit, but I just couldn't resist being the 100th reviewer. :-) So four stars for now, but I'm thinkin this place is on the road to five.

SUCH good sushi here. The Best Roll (asparagus tempura and avocado wrapped in thinly sliced salmon and lemon) really lives up to it's name--it's amazing. Tart and fresh and delish. I'm not usually a fan of sake sushi, but the lemon makes it totally doable for me. I was also pleasantly surprised by the shrimp tempura roll...it has asparagus in it, which (incredibly) mimics the texture of macadamia nuts--which are FANTASTIC in sushi (not sure why more places don't use them). The spciy tuna roll was also among the best that I've had--could've been a tad spicier IMHO, but the tuna was incredibly fresh and flavorful. Also had a cal roll, which was perfect in that it was made with real crab and minimal mayo.

I don't eat a lot of raw fish, and I don't like eel or eel sauce (which is why I didn't fall in love with Red Box--it seems to focus a lot on eel), so I'm hard pressed to find a place with a really great selection and variety, yet I'm still picky about  quality, flavor, and especially texture. In other words, I'm hard to please in the sushi restaurant area. But Koo managed to please me immensely, while still offering plenty of the stuff I don't go for. Not only that, but they also provide a decent and relaxed atmosphere, friendly service, and very reasonable prices.

The breakdown for two: (generous) wakame salad, cal roll, best roll, tempura shrimp roll, spicy tuna roll, and 5 or so glasses of plum wine + tip & tax = $60
author: Jasmine F.

description:
I really liked this place.  The space is laid back and not stuff at all, and the servers are really Japanese (I'm half Japanese and have a thing for real Japanese people - ok so I guess I'm food racist!)

Anyhow, the pieces of sushi are nicely sized and the specialty rolls were delish too!   Just need to go back a few more times and it could be one of my faves in the city.  Definintel a nice date spot too
author: Gene X.

description:
Oh where oh where to begin...

Their mouth full of happiness is LITERALLY a-mouth-full-of-happiness!! It was truly a mouth full of love. A complex textural wonder. 

That said the sashimi we ordered was of the best quality. So fresh and cut perfectly.

The green tea was excellent, with a hint of "toasted-nuttiness"

Prices were more than fair and the decor was relaxed yet sophisticated!

Loved it!!
author: rachel c.

description:
This place is totally awesome.

My husband and I met up last Saturday with my sister in SF for fleet week. What a disappointment. Got down to FW and found out the show was cancelled due to poor visibility. Bummer. Then we walked, what seems to be, 5 miles to pier 30 to see the only fleet offering a walking tour and it was shut down for special events. WTF!!!!! On a Saturday! Any how, Sis took us to Koo instead.

This has got to be the high light of our day. The place was small, but I dig the decor and it is clean. Walked in w/o reservation at 5:30, and was asked if we can't finish by 7:45PM then they can't accommodate us (understandable given we were a walk-in.)

The menu was limited, but has good amount of selection. We were starving so I ordered a couple of starters fried tofu and stuffed jalapeno. The tofu was tasty, but it was nothing special. The jalapeno was stuffed with hamachi with a touch of unagi sauce over it. It had a little bite to it, but it was very good.

I was immediately drawn to the Catch of the Day nigiris. I ordered (2) (blue fin) maguro (1) Toro and the soft shell crab. My sister order the Spoonful of Happiness. My husband ordered CA roll, spicy tuna roll. Then we ordered some of their special rolls that I can't remember the name right now, but they were all excellent. I can't stop raving about the "Catch of the Day" nigirs. Oh my lord it was fresh. The fish just melt in your mouth. My sister said it's all about her "Happiness" dish.

All in all, this was an excellent ending to a dismal day. Whooray to my sister. I highly recommend this place to all you sushi lovers.
author: G K.

description:
Koo not only has great, tasty rolls, but the service is great and the decor is really interesting (great hanging lamps!).  My boyfriend thought the geishas on skis painting was pretty funny.  

In terms of rolls, I really enjoyed the Azteca roll and the U2 roll.  They also have really fresh sashimi and the ankimo was one of the best I've had.  The hamachi kama and the seaweed salad came in generous portion.  I will definitely be dining here again.  Yum!
author: Mitzi C.

description:
I was excited about going to Koo after reading such fabulous reviews...but I came out pretty disappointed. I'll have to admit that the sushi was good, but it was nothing extraordinary. 

What I really didn't like was the service. The maitre'd seated and gave us menus when we walked in. Ok, so far, so good. We quickly decided what we wanted to eat, and then waited for our waitress.....and waited and waited. She never bothered to come and greet us or ask what we'd like to drink until we waved her down. And the restaurant wasn't even busy at this time!! 

We asked our waitress if Koo offers geoduck clam sashimi. I know it's called something different in Japanese, but we didn't know the term. Instead of trying to help us figure it out, our waitress said (in a curt tone): "What do you want?? I do not know what you're talking about." She was a pretentious you-know-what. 

The fun didn't stop there. After we placed our order, we waited about 25 minutes before our first dish came. It was 12 slices of sashimi - how long does it take to cut pieces of fish?! Our second and third dish arrived 5-10 minutes after that, which isn't bad, but we were already irritated.

Overall: Good sushi, bad service. For these prices, I'd rather go to Taraval Okazu Ya, a great sushi place in the Sunset that is cheaper and has better service.
author: Cee J.

description:
Ahh...

I recently made a trip to Koo with some friends.  When having sushi I usually set my expectations a little lower when I see that there's a heavy emphasis on decor* ("like not another Asian Fusion white washed place").  However, I was very surprised Koo delivered.

Uni is usually my litmus test for a sushi joint and Koo hit it on the mark.  The ankimo was also solid.  All the fish I tried was very fresh and balanced.  The Sake was great with fair amount of choices.

Service could have been better though my friends said it usually wasn't as bad.  I'd definitely go back...

(*not that the decor is super 'luxe' it's tastefully done.)
author: Rafael s.

description:
This is not a run of the mill sushi shop so for some unique combinations, this is highly recommended. Go for the Shichimi Crusted Tuna and Marinated Wild Mushroom because it come with a raspberry sauce or 
the Tokyo Crunch roll for the crunchy texture.
author: Jan Michael K.

description:
Amazing!

Went here with a group, and was so overwhelmed by the sights and smells, my foodie friend and I split off from the group and ordered a criminal amount of food. We ended up paying a good sum, but it was totally worth it. If you want to have some amazing Japanese food (not necessarily just sushi), this would be the place to go. Koo is probably on my list of top 5 japanese restaurants I have tried in SF.

Recommendations: 
I started with the Spoonfuls of happiness. Definitely recommended. Savory earthy flavors of the ponzu and truffle oil were balanced by the freshness of the uni. Topping off the spoon was a quail egg, adding a rich velvety texture. 

The grilled octopus is absolutely amazing. Perfectly seasoned and cooked, the octopus manages to retain a firm texture, without a hint of rubberiness that sometimes happens with such a robust cooking method. We went through the first plate of it so quickly, we had to order a second. 

In addition to the spoonfuls, we also ordered the miso glazed cod, which was good, though not spectacular.

We ordered most of our sushi based on what was on their fresh catch menu. Their very fatty tuna and butterfish nigiri were awesome, but you really can't go wrong with anything. Its all tasty and extremely fresh.
author: Rondeep C.

description:
I love Koo!!! The fish is always fresh & the service is always good. Also, they have a variety of small plates to share so that you are not limited to sushi and sashimi alone. Try the Japanese eggplant - soooo good!
There are a couple smaller tables that are perfect for a date (ask for the corner table to the right, back at the window).
author: Doro P.

description:
Probably the freshest fish we've had in a sushi restaraunt.  The nigiri was unbelievable.  The rolls were very good too, but if you wan't to get the best quality, go for the nigiri or sashimi.  Yum!!

The atmosphere is clean and upscale with small tables and tasteful decorations.

Finally, this place is within walking distance from 9th and Irving so plenty of post-dinner activities are available.  Parking can be tough so get there a bit early if possible.

Great fish and excellent overall experience.
author: Kash-money K.

description:
My two friends and I really, really enjoyed our experience here. We ordered so many items that I can't recall everything we've had. But the most memorable dishes are the Spoonful of Happiness, the black cod, and the dynamite. We also had their special sake.

Terrific food, but one point deducted for the ambiance. It was pretty cramped and noisy.

Price: $60/person after tax and tip
author: Jack W.

description:
There aren't enough words in the dictionary to describe how much we love this place.  We have been coming here since day one and have loved and tastefully enjoyed every trip. At this point we have tried everything on the menu and then some. The best page to look at is the first one with all the specials on it. Try at least one thing on there because it may not be there the next time.

If you ever get around to going PUH-LEEEZE don't order the california roll and make a review saying it was only alright....ITS A FREAKING CALIFORNIA ROLL. how good can it really get. If you go you must eat the raw fish. They have one of the biggest selections of raw fish. My favorite is the kanpachi(amber jack). Only order this though if your almost full. Otherwise you may order some more and then there will be none left for me.

Toothpicks - 5/5 because they have that awesome toothpick dispenser. You push down on the birds head and it grabs you a toothpick.
author: KY L.

description:
Holy amazing sushi, batman!

I won't go into too much detail, except to say that the only way my friend could top this meal was to tell me a story about getting fresh sushi in Tokyo that involved getting up at 3AM and waiting in line for two hours.

It was that good.

We had an amazing hamachi, wonderful soft shelled crab, and the tuna belly. I'd warn against the belly if you're on a budget, because though it was good, at $6.50 a piece, it's a bit pricey.

Overall, though, the meal was very reasonable. I hope they don't decide to increase their prices as a result of all the positive publicity!
author: Jesse E.

description:
Went here on Saturday evening based on my iPhone Yelp application.  We were coming from spending an afternoon at the de Young museum and had a hankering for some sushi.

This place has excellent fish!  Also had some that I have never tried before.  We mostly had nigiri style sushi which is my favorite.  Melt in your mouth Toro, 3 kinds of salmon, hamachi belly, japanese snapper, grouper, and a few others.  They make their ankimo in house which is monk fish liver, it was delicious.  Also the uni was very good that night.

We sat at the sushi bar where there were three sushi chefs one of whom was the owner.  Very nice staff.  Also we were given a couple of complimentary items that were very tasty.

I am going to make an effort to get back here.  I was very happy with the sushi here.
author: Lonnie R.

description: Great sushi, great service.  Always awesome and a great experience.  I also LOVE that it's in my neighborhood.  Please stay in the Sunset forever!
author: Carolyn J.

description: Again, had dinner here the other night at the sushi bar. Spoonful of happiness, was perfect. Tuna, salmon, eel, all extremely fresh.  Sushi chefs very nice. Calamari salad, spicy and fresh. Rice was perfect.  Very low key.  Perfect!
author: Pug P.

description: I can't really believe anyone would give this place less than 5 stars.  I would give it more if I could!  The only explanation for these less than perfect reviews is that the reviewers have no idea what is good sushi.  If that is the case and you think it is overpriced and not good enough, please go wait in line at Ebisu, because I'll then have a spot at the Koo counter to eat the freshest pieces of sashimi and nigiri in town, not to mention the great orgasm competitor, Spoonful of Happiness.  Thank you very much!
author: Cami B.

description: No wait on a weeknight (+), clean (+), friendly service (+), fast drink refills (+). However, the sushi was not super fresh, creative, or delicious.  It didn't taste bad but not ultra fresh.  1-2 rolls tasted fishy (sign of fish past its prime).  The roll with the salmon and thin lemon slices on the outside was easily the best.  Probably won't be back because there are sooo many sushi places to try instead.
author: Desmo K.

description:
After having my mind set on going to Sebo. I decided to check what my fellow yelpers were thinking first. After seeing the horrible reviews on them I decided I probably didn't want to spend my money there.
One place I have wanted to try was Koo. I love Ariake but lately it seems like I've been there so much lately I just felt like I wanted to try a new place. 

The parking isn't very abundant but we were able to find some within about 10 minutes of circling the block. We walk in and have a seat at the sushi bar and get to looking at the menus and specials.

--First things first was the alcohol. Nice sake selection and the koshikari echigo has always been one of my favorite beers. I ordered some daiginjyo and waited for the party to start!  The coolest thing I thought was the fact that they serve your sake In a tall shot glass situated in a little box. For some reason I find this too cool. The only other place I can remember  being served sake like this was In New York.   
--The first thing I had was the dynamite King crab hand  roll which was baked and served warm, I'm so glad I got the last 2 orders because it was very good.  
--We then had the  Tempura hamachi which was served crispy and warm as should be expected.
--Another dish was the sweet shrimp, which was good but the real treat was the fried head. I gotta admit I felt bad about eating the head and eyeballs but it  was sooo good. Probably the best part of the dish.
--The albacore tataki was very good as well but seemed to have a bit  too much cilantro which overpowered the fish.
--We tried the toro which was a bit steep but not bad. One roll was actually a bit bigger than the other.  I think I'd rather have spent the $16 on another menu item but that's my own problem so I  cant complain. 
--Then came the hamachi Kama which was excellent. I even asked the chef if there was anything else they had that was similar  and he told me they did but it wasn't on the menu. I believe he said it was tai or in other words seabream. It too was very tasty and seemed a little more lean than the hamachi Kama. Still one of the better fishes I've  had the pleasure of tasting. 
 --For dessert we had  the mt Fuji which was good but seemed like the chocolate part should have been served warm which it wasn't.

All in all I was very impressed with the service and food here. It was about 2x what I would typically spend on sushi but no complaints on my end. It doesn't hurt that the chefs answered all my questions about the daily specials  and made some excellent recommendations. The dynamite king crab roll and hamachi Kama alone are enough for me to go back.
author: Cesar H.

description:
Went to Koo for the first time the other night and had an incredible time. 

The fish was incredibly fresh. There were lots of fishes on the menu that were unusual and you don't see on most other Japanese restaurant menus in the Bay Area.

The staff were all Japanese and very attentive and gave us great service. 

We asked for something special from the chef and they brought us two spoons. One had Ankimo with a piece of Hirame on the top. The other had Uni with a Quail Egg. Delicious and creative!

We will definitely be going back again! And again!

We walked in but next time we want to sit at the sushi bar. We will definitely have to call ahead, as there are only six seats.
author: C. S.

description: Nice Japanese food, different from the restaurants you'll find in the Peninsula or the South Bay.  The Sushi quality here is great, but this is not just a Sushi restaurant, nor it is a plain old Izakaya or some fusion restaurant.  The food here is really authentic though creative, and I now understand why it's so popular among Japanese in the SF area.  Parking in this neighborhood is a huge pain though.
author: Durif M.

description: Went there couple times for different occasions.  It is not the type of Japanese restraunt that cook by Chinese or Mexican Cooks.   Food are fresh but wish they have a little wider varity of fish chices.  They have a good number of average to good Sake selections which is good.  I wouldn't mind spend a good chunk of money on good quality fishs.  FYI, there is a wine bar which is only couple blocks away from the restaurant, a good start-up before the dinner.
author: Jade P.

description:
Good spot for sushi.  We were out cruising around the 9th and Irivng area looking for something new on a Friday night, and went into this place. I feared that going in at 7 on a Friday would mean standing around outside (it was raining at the time) for an hour and getting bitter.  It turned out that we got in in under 15 minutes.  I can usually handle 15 minutes, hours if there is booze involved.  Lucky for everyone involved it was the former.
The atmosphere is very nice, the sushi is good.  Not OH MY GOD good, but definitely good.
author: Nelson W.

description:
catch of the day we ordered: $6-7/pair
they were out of kohada :(
Toro sushi - Japan, Blue fin tuna fat belly $14
Wild Salmon sushi - Washington, steelhead trout
Tombo sushi - Hawaii, Albacore Tuna
Hotategai sushi - Miyagi Japan, Scallops
Moi sushi - Hawaiian royal sea bass
Kamasu sushi - Japan, Barracuda
Wild Aji sushi - Japan, Spanish Mackerel
Hiramasa sushi - Australia, Young yellowtail
Kinme-dai sushi - Japan, Deep sea red snapper
and came specially for the signature dish -- spoonful of happiness
a spoonful of uni, quail egg, tobiko ponzu & a spoonful of ankimo wrapped with whitefish, white truffle-oil ponzu & a shot of chilled sake
definitely it was the highlight and lived up to its name...if pressed, only one slight criticism was slightly salty aftertaste, thus the shot was needed, not an enhancement
all the fish were fresh tasting; i think the rice was a little dry and i still like okina rice more
i would like to try omakase, maybe more cooked dishes
service here was excellent
problem with reviews at a place like this is that some are rating the rolls, some are rating the cooked dishes, some the nigiri sushi, and some the omakase...
author: Rob C.

description:
This has become my favorite little japanese place in the city at this point.  (oo)Toro is $12.  Not a bad deal.  The sushi here is good, but it's their other prepared foods that really shine.
Be sure to get the miso-marinated black cod and their beef tataki.  exquisite.  Their grilled eggplant (nasu) is really good too.
author: Fong L.

description:
I wasn't too impressed after my first visit here.  After hearing what I have to say about this place, my friend who's a regular here insists on taking me back to change my mind.  He totally redeemed his restaurant!  It might have something to do with the fact that he told the sushi chef I wasn't too thrilled after my first visit.  I was so embarrassed!  That's not the kind of thing you say to a sushi chef.  Ever.  Oh no!  Now that I've offended the chef, my food is going to be totally crap.  But the sushi chef was very gracious.  He only gave me the best things Koo has to offer.  He did remind me all night that bay area uni is just as good as uni that's freshly flown in from the pacific northwest.  It's debatable.

Go there for their fish.  They have a wide selection that goes beyond your everyday tuna and salmon.  Their cooked food is still not that great to me.  Maybe my friend can talk to the chef in the kitchen?!
author: jenn c.

description:
what i liked about this place was the seat we got and that we didnt have to wait cause my date call ahead

what is the not so great about this place, the lighting its so dark in side and it was even 8pm outside, i could barely read my menue so i was glad my date could, the food was alright but the teriyaki sauce on the unagi wasnt right at all, and any place that use cuccumber should just take one star off, over priced an yes i have had better
but i like my date regardless i just felt bad when i said i have been to cheaper place and had better
author: Seaera T.

description:
Good sushi joints in San Francisco are still a diamond in the rough. I like Koo because everyone is actually Japanese. (Somehow non-Japanese sushi chefs feels like a lie to me....)

Anyway, if you like Uni, Koo makes  a special dish that pairs two spoonfuls of uni with sake.  

The sake bottles are also reasonably priced (we had a great bottle for $45) called Genjoki. 

Again as always, try sitting at the bar.  There's something to be said to watch the chefs in action.  I always like to share the sake with them as well because they are the one prepping your food and they can select the best pieces of fish for your order.  It's just nice to socialize with the amazing power of the sushi gods....
author: Alice H.

description:
I gotta admit, I always thought this place was a lot more expensive than it actually is. It just looked that way to me for some reason.

I was actually really surprised at how reasonable it was. The fish we had was all amazing and very fresh. (Disclaimer: we only ordered sushi from the chef's specials that day). 

I'd come back here for a quick bite, although it probably won't work out to just drop in since it seems to get pretty full during peak hours and you'll need to make a reservation.
author: Jon N.

description:
Koo can count me as a fan.  

There are some strange rules here as we learned.  If you are a first-timer, apparently you are not allowed to sit at the bar.  In addition, they encourage you to follow their version of the "omakase" which includes a choice of sashimi plate or "spoonful of happiness" followed by a mix of nigiri and cooked dishes.  

A spoonful of happiness it was indeed.  

The spoonful of happiness is two spoons served side by side, one of ankimo and the other of uni with quail egg.  They are heaven.  We had the sashimi plate as well and while a lot of the fish was relatively ordinary, the yellowtail belly stood out.  Very fat, very tasty.  

The most unique dish we had was the two jack fish that the chef had taken all the meat off of and served to us sashimi-style over a bed of ice.  Then the bones themselves were deep fried.  This was my favorite dish of the night and I would gladly return just to have this.  Maybe I'm just a sucker for deep-fried fish bones.  

The next dish was a small plate of baby shrimp also deep fried such that you could eat the shell.  This was part of the "catch of the day."  We joked that these were the shrimps that Chinese people would probably throw away or not eat since they are so small but boy were they tasted.  The chef definitely knows what he is doing.  

The last thing we tried was a couple of hot dishes served together - eggplant, tofu and a hot pepper stuffed with yellowtail.  None of these items really stood out and if I had a choice, I would probably not order them again.  However, I'm sure they would have served a meaningful break from our final nigiri course.  

Sadly, we didn't make it to the end due to extenuating circumstances.  

I will be back to finish this meal.  You can bet on that.
author: Simon L.

description:
Spur of the moment C and I went up to SF just to eat at Koo. I don't think I've had better sushi in a long time. Call me a bumpkin, but this was the first time I had REAL wasabi from the root (not the green tea ice cream stuff). To me, that's for you to really taste the freshness of the fish and not to mask it.

We ordered the sashimi special, a couple of rolls, the blue fin toro, and the sake (salmon). All of it was supah fresh and supah good! I still dream of it on occasion.

For two, it was a bit on the steep side of $40/person for the amount of food we got, but I'm definitely going back.

Oh, and did I mention I found the review from Yelp? Kudos!

I have pics, but my camera sucked in the dimly lit room. Ro-man-ti-cah lighting!
author: Tsou D.

description:
We got in, and it was pretty empty. Then again, it was barely 6pm. We sat in the corner, listening to the lounge type of music they were playing, looked at the menu, and decided on the U2 roll, California roll, Best roll and a shrimp/scallop dumpling. The dumpling was decorated quite nicely, although I have to say I could barely taste the scallop. It was like a piece of shrimp wrapped in a wonton wrapper. The rolls were ok. California roll (with real crab) was too salty for my taste; I much preferred the one from yum yum. Out of the three roll options, U2 roll was the tastiest. Other tables had ordered the Best roll (not the best IMO), which was tempura asparagus, avocado, topped with a slice of lemon and salmon. Weird combination, but it goes. The U2 roll was a piece of tempura shrimp, avocado, topped with baked tuna on the top. Not too salty, perfect with wasabi. 

The restaurant was slightly upscale, although not so much like a Geisha house or Koi, so the prices were obviously jacked up. Wasn't too happy about that but hey, you can only appreciate the best places after checking out the "competition" right?
author: Yosie G.

description:
Okay, hands down my favorite Japanese restaurant in San Francisco. Hot dang this place is good. My usual menu consists of Spoonfuls of Happiness (you gotta have this folks, esp if you're a risk taker..or a seasoned sashimi eater), the Miso Black Cod, Hamachi Kama, the Flying Kamikaze rolls or seriously, any of their rolls. Dessert is delectable as well. You can't go wrong with this place. I have taken everyone and their mom here and I will keep on coming back! 

Also, I always like to make reservations and then shift them sometimes - props to the hostesses for putting up with me and being very patient and helpful always with my time changes!
author: Nebula H.

description:
4 stars for cooked food, 3 stars for raw food

If you're going to go to Koo and want to make sure there's no disappointment, get the miso marinated black cod.  After reading the reviews on Yelp, I knew I had to get this dish and I wasn't disappointed.  We added the option to get salad + rice with the share plate to make it a full entree.  The seaweed salad was your standard wakame salad and the rice was just a cup of sushi rice.  

In addition we ordered two sushi rolls, Flying Kamikaze and Dragon roll.  Though the price is a little high, you do get a sizable roll.  The rolls themselves aren't bad, but they pale in comparison to the miso marinated black cod.  

I'll be back, but I'm definitely sticking to the cooked food.
author: Joann C.

description:
Great sushi - nice atmosphere and kind waitstaff!
All in all a great experience - I always take my out of town friends here!
author: sHoo o.

description:
(Note to self: Yelp doesn't support posts in Japanese. Grrr.)

Good, decent sushi in the Sunset. Ebisu has nothing on this place. I'd hit this place again.

Neta was fresh, but it seemed a bit dry. Shari was flavored well, but a bit on the dry side as well.

I liked the fact that their list of daily special neta had many choices, some not usually encountered in my sushi outings in SF.

Lighting was a bit too dark for me for the table seating, especially since I was eating sushi. I usually want to eat my sushi in a clean, well-lighted place. That way you can really appreciate the sushi from a visual perspective. Not to mention making sure that your neta isn't past its prime.

Service was okay, by the numbers. Could have been better. It was a bit difficult to get the attention of our waitress/waiter.

Didn't bother with the fusion stuff on the menu this time. I stuck with the nigiri and hosomaki this time. To borrow from Noboo K.'s lexicon, no Jive Ass Rolls for me.

Maybe I'll try if I can conjure up enough courage. I've been burned one too many times with crappy Japanese restaurants in SF, so excuse my cynicism.
author: Bono B.

description:
Koo is as close as any restaurant can come to my family's go-to spot for sushi.  It's conveniently located, never too packed, the ambience is both comfortable and trendy, and of course, the food is reliably satisfying.  

Start off with the mouthful (or spoonful?) of happiness, which comes with (if memory serves correct) uni, quail egg, something else, something else other than the other thing, and a shot of sake.  Drop them one at a time down your hatch, and you've got the one thing I look forward to when I come here.

As for the rest of Koo's culinary cast, I'd say it's all above average.  The rolls are all right, and the sushi too, so if you're looking for good stuff, get the items you rarely see on a typical sushi menu.  They're typically located on the piece of paper that comes attached to the menu, with daily catches and whatnot.  After a few years of patronage, I typically go straight to the interesting stuff (and the decent sake list) and skip the rolls and the rest.  

So, at Koo, you get a good value for what you pay, without the crowds, without the pretense, and without the hype.  Koo is a place to go when you're looking for a neighborhood restaurant to meet up with friends, catch up with family, and have a decent sushi meal.
author: Stephen H.

description:
Our Koo experience is kinda mixed. We both had the "spoonful of happiness" the ingredients were fresh. But the ponzu was so heavy handed and over powering we both had trouble tasting the flavor of the uni. Also the sake that came with the 2 spoons wes just the cheap stuff that you can buy for 12 dollars/1.5 liter @ 99 Ranch 
Next up we had the Bamboo Tower Salad. The fish and the greens were fresh and didn't feel like a bunch of side cuts. But the bamboo was really just a center show piece, they could have used a PVC pipe and done exactly the same thing. I was hoping that they should have some bamboo shoots in there to add some texture to the dish and really lived up to the bamboo tower name.
Most of the sushi lived up to it's name, the hotategai (scallop) was fresh, never frozen and actually had a bit of a snap to it (awesomeness), it was so good we ordered seconds. But the hamachi wasn't so good. Don't get me wrong, the fish was fresh. But it was just not a good cut. We were sitting right in front of the sushi chef, I was hoping that they would have served us a belly cut and saved the cuts we got for some sushi combo order.
We also ordered some hot food, i thought the miso eggplant was nice. But my wife didn't like it as much as i did. We also had the jalapeno popper stuffed with hamachi. It was baked in mayo and kinda tasted like the tiny lobster you'd get when you go to a Chinese buffet
Overall the food @ Koo is better than your regular sushi place, i'd try Koo a couple more times when i'm in the Sunset
author: Yummy P.

description:
I lived down the street for years and walked by all the time thinking it was just your average sushi place, until some friends were in the neighborhood and wanted something raw and fish-like.  

3 words:  Spoonful of Happiness! 

I can't even name for you the ingredients in it, but one spoon chased by a sip of sake you'll finally realize what it's like to truly understand your place in the world and how small and insignificant you truly are...for a brief moment I think I actually surmised the true meanings of our very existence, but it escaped me along with the aftertaste.

I can't give it 5 stars however, as the sushi itself is in my "excellent but nothing original" category...I'm sort of a sushi traitor in the sense that I prefer original japanese-american creations more than straight up traditional methods.
author: D L.

description:
#1 the food was good, I cant lie about that!  please get a "spoon full of happiness"!  best thing on the menu! just do it, you will thank me later!

#2 DO NOT ORDER Nigiri!! the portions are unbelievably small!!!  The rice will be the size of your first finger knuckle!!! its sooooo small!!!  You will see!  I do not lie!  Nigiri rice should be the size of your palm rounded into 3 sides!!! 

#3 the Toro was $15, I admit it was a savory cut, almost oil like! very good!!!!  but it was the size 1"x2",, WTF was that!!!

Ok to sum it up, good food, small portions,,,, do not in your life, if you have ever eaten nigiri, order nigiri!!! 

thats all, enjoy :)
author: William G.

description:
One of the more authentic sushi places in the city. You will see lots of Japanese nationals which is always a good sign for a sushi place. Very creative and unique sushi which you'll discover when you do the omakase style meal and quality is also top notch.  

I only gave it 4 stars instead of 5 (tho tempted) because Sebo is truly 5 stars in my book and no one else has achieved Sebo standards.
author: Lola Z.

description:
Seriously, it's delicious. Surprisingly it may be one of my favorite restaurants in SF. The Spoonful of Happiness is indeed a delight and their sake selection is quite nice.

Sushi portions are small (bite sized) and a little on the pricey side, but one bite and it's all forgotten.
author: anon m.

description:
spoonful of happiness holds a special place in my heart! 

this is definitely one of those sushi spots where you would be selling yourself short to not sit at the bar and let one of the sushi chefs just hit you with their best fish. last night was japanese deep sea red snapper and it was AMAZING. Also, we split the black cod on a recommendation, usually i prefer to stick with the nigiri and sashimi items, but I am so glad I tried this. So delicate and buttery and with a delicious broth and bok choy. 

great service, awesome sushi chefs, not as high personality as roger from zushi puzzle, but hey, who is?
author: LeeAnne T.

description: My wife and I wanted to try a new Japanese restaurant and saw the reviews here and it looked good so we went. $110 later we were unsatisfied, still hungry, and ended up going to our money japanese place "Kabuto" on Geary. The appetizer of spoonful of happiness was pretty good, but nothing stood out that would be worth going back for. We went right afterwards to Kabuto and ordered the foi gras sushi and green tea creme brule to get satisfaction. I did not want to order dessert at Koo cuz they have a $2 service charge just for dessert on top of what you pay for a dessert.. The staff did their job, but the menu just did not boast anything worth coming back for. Lastly, it was NOT worth $110... check out Kabuto or Sebo for some really good sushi and fresh A+++ fish!
author: brenton m.

description:
Went here for my 21st birthday dinner with my father because my father was gonna start working there on the next day. I haven't been here since the restaurant first opened and my father used to work with the owner, Kiyoshi-san, many years back at Tokyo GoGo.

Everyone is so very nice and sincere. Well, we are friends with the owner, but when the chefs were talking to the other customers, they were very kind and friendly.

We had the Spoonful of Happiness since I've heard so many good things about it on here. I actually don't like uni or ikura, but wow, I might love it now just for the Spoonful of Happiness! It's THAT good. The Maguro Carpaccio is also delicious! The sushi is very fresh and of high quality and I know for a fact that the chefs there know what they're doing. The yuzu cheesecake is also really awesome.

Since I'm a working college student, I don't think I can really afford to eat here for a while, but the next time I do go, I'll be sure to buy a round of beers for the chefs! My dad is probably working right now as I speak and I believe he's enjoying the Koo atmosphere!

Oh, just to let you know, they say they do to-go, but if it's too busy, they cannot do it. It's better to sit down and eat there anyway.
author: Momo C.

description:
The food is great. Been here 3 times in the last few months and have yet to be disappointed by the food and service.  Spoonful of happiness is one of their most unique dishes, and it has become my favorite. I order it every time.  I typically only order rolls to fill up after I've gone through my sashimi and nigiri orders, but their rolls are quite delicious.  

It would be a pretty crappy review if I didn't find something to complain about.  The bathroom really sucks.  They only got one, and it's dual use. And the sink is separate from the toilet.  As somebody who drinks a lot, this really sucks when the place is packed. I hate waiting, even more so when it's to use the bathroom.  Thankfully, I haven't encountered any issues yet.

Overall I love this place.  It's the best Japanese restaurant near where I live.  It's a great place for a date or if you just want some good sushi by yourself at the bar.  The booze is pretty reasonably priced too.  As far as street parking goes, there's much tougher places to find parking in the city.
author: Wes C.

description:
I've never realized until now how much food is on just Irving alone. One of my good friends took us here for sushi after hopping around from restaurant from restaurant. You know what they say, 3rd time's a charm. This was the place that we grubbed at for the night. Let me say, this sushi joint is great and has become one of my top favorite sushi places of all tie. It's just the right size, all the fish is fresh and the staff is super friendly. This aint your run of the mill Korean owned sushi house (no offense to my Korean friends), it is definitely Japanese. 

The night we went, all of us chose 2 specialty rolls each. We ended up with 8 different rolls which were all fantastic. The ones that stood out the most to me were Tokyo Crunch, Azteca, Flying Kamikaze and of course The Best roll. You can choose from the wide array of fresh sushi and sashimi. I have yet to try the other items on the menu, but i'm sure they wont disappoint. There is a sushi bar which is on the small side, but it is cozy placed right in the left corner of the restaurant. This is a great place to take friends, but beware, street parking can get tricky in the daytime and evening. Carpooling is a must, or you can take the Muni N-Judah line and be dropped off just steps away from the restaurant.

If there is one word to describe this place all-in-one...it's Koo! :)
author: Ryan B.

description:
The vegetable tempura rolls here are delicious--the soy, tofu-like wrap they use (instead of nori) literally melts in your mouth. Goes well with the warm, delicate crunch of the tempura.

Service here was impeccable. Though the space was a bit cramped, nothing to really complain about. :)
author: Richie K.

description:
Koo is the best sushi i have had in the city.  clean, easy interior and a wide selection.

do not miss the 'best roll"
author: Brooke M.

description:
This is an excellent place for Sushi.

High quality fish.
Lots of variety and unique dishes (try the Spoonful of Happiness!)
Great atmosphere.
Great selection of saki.
author: Didi R.

description:
An unexpectedly nice sushi place on the outskirts of the Inner Sunset business hub. I think it used to be a humbler, shabbier Japanese restaurant, and it's now a slightly hip place that seems to offer good sushi at reasonable prices in a comfortable setting. The place could stand some curtains or a rug to muffle the sound a bit.

Service was quite attentive; our drinks were always refilled, pronto. Our food came out at a brisk pace. Everything we had was good, and it was cool that they offered wild salmon nigiri in addition to the usual farmed kind. I enjoyed the goma ae (a la the version served at Tokyo Go-Go, which is apparently where one of the chefs used to work) and the broiled eggplant. And as always, I loved the miso-marinated black cod -- I usually enjoy that dish anywhere. Pieces of fish were slightly smaller than what I'm used to, but tasty.

Seems like a reliable option.
author: Tara M.

description:
Decent enough sushi, but not worth the premium price which we assumed was for the atmosphere since it was not for the service.

We decided we would rather walk a few more blocks down to Sushi Kazu for better food at a better price.
author: Christian M.

description:
The Spoonful of Happiness is awesome and I will go again just for this. I love it. I was not overly impressed with the place. It has a kinda traditional feel. Not really that...hey this is a hip cali sushi joint.. feel. 

I liked it. I think it is a good place to pick-up some apps and drinks then go off to another restaurant to get the big heavy hitter meal of the night.
author: howard h.

description:
UPDATED 04/01/08:

I came back here this past Saturday (visit #3 or #4) and I am even more in love with this place.  If Yelp would let me, I would add another 5 stars to this review.

I had the Tuna/Salmon Tartare and Dynamite hand rolls again, and three days later, I am still dreaming about the amazing flavor combinations in each of those dishes.  Since I didn't go into much detail last time, I will elaborate now.  The tartare has the perfect balance of fresh tuna and salmon, avocado/guacamole, sesame oil, seaweed salad, and is paired with crispy light shrimp chips.  The Dynamite hand roll is simple with warm and juicy baked scallops accompanied by a dollop of wasabi tobiko.  You will need two or more of these.  One just won't cut it!

If you haven't been to Koo yet, you have to check this place out!  But please don't take my seat ;)

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
I've only had one dining experience here, but hey, first impressions are everything.  So 5 stars it is.

This is well-executed, simple, yet elegant Japanese fare.  We started off with the Tuna and Salmon Tartare, maxed out on lots of delicious rolls and nigiri, then finished the meal with Yuzu Cheesecake and the Mt. Fuji Chocolate Mousse Cake.  The prices are really reasonable for sushi (try the $5 baked scallops hand roll) and the desserts are only $4 - I highly recommend the Yuzu Cheesecake; it's the perfect balance between sweet and tart.  Top it off with attentive service and a relaxed, understated decor and you really can't ask for more.
author: Kalista W.

description:
Thank you Tom P. for your review!  Otherwise I wouldn't have known about this awesome find in the sunset.

Top 10 Reasons I would go back:

1. A Spoonful (actually two spoonfuls) of Happiness made me so happy I just had to order 2! 
2. The fresh uni, hamachi,  kona kanpachi, heck - ALL nigiri sushi
3. The Ankimo - monkfish liver in ponzu - delectable!
4. Service and atmosphere
5. The fact that it's authentically Japanese
6. The cleanliness and decor - the place seemed too cool for me.  
7. There's actually parking on Irving & 5th!  
8. Getting seated within 15 minutes on a Saturday night w/o a reservation
9. It beats the hell out of Ebisu on 9th & Irving!  
10. Did I mention a Spoonful of Happiness that comes with a cold shot of Suigei sake? Absolutely divine!

4.5 stars for now.  I'll give it 5 if they deliver the same experience when I make the return visit.
author: Yvonne C.

description:
Koo Koo for Koo?  Usually, YES.  Last night, not as much!  I was there at 6:30 and it wasn't too busy, but for some reason they felt compelled to bring 99% of our order out at the same time, which took well into 15+ minutes (mind you, we were all sharing the same order).  
The Maguro was very stringy, and the Spider Role was a bit chilly (usually the soft shell crab comes out warm).  A bit of a disappointment from other nights of eating at Koo, but everyone has an off evening.  I was more disappointed because Mom was in town and this is her favorite Raw Fish spot
author: Jason I.

description: Sit at the sushi bar, order Omakase and you will not be disappointed. Spoonful of happiness is always a delight. My husband order it as a starter and then as dessert.
author: Andrea K.

description:
This place is some of the best sushi I've ever had!

Started first with the spoonful of happiness.  For those experienced and more adventurous sushi eaters I recommend it highly.  For those with less of a taste for raw fish, you may find the textures more challenging and tastes overwhelming.  I enjoyed it quite a bit.  We also had the tuna salmon tartar which was delicious.  The wafer chips combined with the tartar and avocado was nearly perfect.  Then came the sushi.  The dragon roll was put together well such that it didn't come apart when picking up with my chopsticks but quickly fell apart and flavors melted as soon as it hit my tongue.    The flavors were very present as there was a good balance of sushi ingredients and rice.  In addition I also had the softshell crawfish handroll.  Also super good.  I highly recommend this place to anyone visiting the Golden Gate Park area.  There's plenty of dessert and coffee places to enjoy afterward!  Also, make sure you show up a little early.  Parking can be challenging.
author: Julian M.

description: The more I look up on Yelp, the more restaurant that I found familiar with.  I've been to many Japanese restaurant on the Yelp list.  Koo is one of them that is not too far from ebisu and it is a very neat place. Food is A-, drink is A+.  I like the selection of sake that they have.  And this place reminds me of the trendy restaurants in Tokyo.  Good for Friday and Saturday night. Not good if you are super hungry and just want to chow down.
author: William F.

description:
I know some people are sad Hana is gone, but KOO is wonderfulness in a restaurant. The sushi here is outstanding. My favorite roll is the U2 roll. Also, there is a really darling Japanese waiter.. He is very thin and boisterous. The fish is always very fresh... don't forget to try the monkfish liver (ankimo), it's absolutely delicious!!!!!!

WOWNESS so I have been back several times.. we even went here when the police were diffusing what they thought were 4 bombs on my block (true story). Anyway, get the BAKED SCALLOP hand roll with citrus tobiko.. (mouth crazy sensation love you to!!! beatles)
author: O K.

description:
VERY fresh, very good...albeit a bit pricey.  The salmon sashimi was delicious...

service was a bit slow and we got forgotten about a few times (refill water, bring check after asking for it, etc.).
author: David H.

description: haven't been back in so long, but i still love everything on the menu. I did try something new which is the cod. to die for. the end!
author: Karen H.

description:
Koo, you're expensive, but damn you're good !

It's the first time I tasted baby butterfish sushi, and I heard angels singing :) So I guess I have to say that it's a must if you have the chance to get there when they have it (it's on the special menu only).

Cool atmosphere, modern yet cozy and asian flair.

A lot of different choices for sushi or sashimi, including some specials depending on the market. That's cool. At least you always have something new to keep you coming back.

Great sake menu too, and I like that they describe what to expect - although I never taste it, but it sounds great - 

Too bad it is so difficult to find parking in this part of town. Oh well, it's worth it !
author: Catherine L.

description:
Best sushi I've had in SF. 

Order: Spoonful of happiness, veggie combo, plum sake. 

I'm not much of a sea food person, but I had to try that happiness stuff everyone was talking about on here. It's interesting to eat and tastes pretty great. It's TWO spoons that consist of the following: 

Spoonful of Uni, Quail Egg, Tobiko, Ponzu & Ankimo wrapped with whitefish, Truffle-Oil &  a shot of chilled Sake.

The others at the table liked the Ankimo better than the Uni and Quail Egg spoon, but I thought they were both great.. I'm not one to talk about fresh ingredients because I do not have a touchstone to compare them to, but the texture and taste agreed with my primarily vegetarian taste buds. 

The veggie combo is enough for one - a veggie tempura roll, a veggie roll and veggie nigiri - asparagus, eggplant and inari. The quantity is just right, two pieces of each roll and the additional nigiri makes for a good meal.

The texture of the wrap was incredible, not chewy and hard to bite into like other rolls, where your mouth is so full you're covering it with your hand to not look like a fat ass. The vegetables were cooked and seasoned to perfection. The quantity of wasabi is slightly less than a dragon-mouth like me would ideally desire, but my friend obliged and gave me hers. 

The plum sake was great too! They have a lot of different types of sake, must try all if/when possible. 

The server was a little odd, but they were totally cool about splitting the check in four cards. Most places give you crap about that, but not this one! Atmosphere was casual. We made reservations, but didn't need to, they had a few tables open (3 I think). They close early (maybe just on Thursdays), but 10:30 isn't that early for a sushi place. I'd recommend you go expecting to pay a good amount but get a great meal and experience in return.
author: Meg P.

description:
This is one of my favorite Sushi places in the city.  I love it for the easy parking access, and it quaintness.  I always sit at the Sushi bar and just ask Kiyoshi or his partner what is good that day.  They are very friendly and are Japanese which isn't always true of places in SF.  The owner and his wife run the place and do a great job.  I usually always get the Bamboo salad as well as a few Nigiri pieces.  The seaweed salad is also nice.

-- Update 9/07
This place never seems to disappoint.  As long as you go with what they recommend, you can't go wrong.  Some of the freshest fish in town.
author: Mitch A.

description:
Num.  Super num.  I'd been wanting to try Koo for months since it's in my 'hood, but had not gotten over there til last night. Being a vegetarian sushi eater (i know, it sort of defeats the point, right?) I'm not all too discriminating about how I like my avocado rolls, but Koo really got their veggie dishes right.  I had the veggie combo and the tempura roll was very good.  I was very impressed with their daily choices of fresh fish as well.  And my dinner companion (a red blooded meat eating kinda guy) can attest for the freshness and quality of the fish.  To my delight, I decided I wanted desert but honestly was not expecting too much from a sushi restaurant on this front.  WOW was I WRONG!  If you go, please try the MT. FUJI cake.  Please.  I cannot even attempt to recapture it's chocoaltey *melt* in your mouth goodness, but just please get it and see for yourself.  

Other perks:
Nice decor and comfortable atmosphere
Great music (jazz)
Friendly waitstaff
author: Laura H.

description:
4.5 stars - probably my favorite Jap restaurant in the city along with Eiji (see previous review). I've passed by this place a few times and thought it looked like a cute and cozy place and finally had a chance to try it. A lot of Yelp reviews raved about Spoonful of Happiness and it also seemed like their signature dish, and in fact I've never seen anything like that at other Japanese restaurants in the city so we ordered that. It's came with two spoons and a shot of chilled sake - one has whitefish wrapped around monk fish liver and the other one has uni with a quail egg. It's $10 for two spoons of seafood that you can eat in two bites so at first I thought they were a bit pricey, but it wasn't until I tried them that I realized they were quite heavenly! I was instructed to take half shot, then eat the lighter spoon first and then finish the rest of the shot before eating the second and heavier tasting spoon. The ingredients were super fresh and tender. The sake helped clear any aftertaste you have in your mouth between spoons and even the sake was quality - it was smooth and didn't burn unlike some cheaper sake I had. Was never a HUGE fan of fish livers and uni but because the ingredients complemented each other very well along with the right sauces and sake, my tummy was happy afterwards (hence the name!)

Other things we ordered:

Azteca roll - really one of the best rolls I've ever had! It has crab,avocado, gobo and cucumber wrapped in white fish, topped w/ a thin slice of jalepeno , spicy mayo, tobiko & ponzu then lightly baked. I must give the chef mad props for understanding how to complement the ingredients. The aroma of the lighter ingredients (avocado, cucumber) brought out the flavor in the fish while the jalepeno and spicy mayo added a kick to the overall taste. Loved it!

Miso Black Cod - Another dish strongly recommend by the house.  The huge piece of cod was basked in a fish-based miso soup with bak-choy and tofu. The fish was cooked so well that it fell right off the fish bones (so you wouldn't have to worry about choking on the fish bones) and the meat itself melted in your mouth. It was DELICIOUS and I felt healthy eating it at the same time. 

Didn't get a chance to try other raw fish they have although the three items I tried already made me a fan! As for why I didn't give this place a perfect 5? I am saving the last 1/2 star to try other great items they have to offer next time I come back! :)
author: Melody L.

description:
Time for the Jar Jar speak: 
"Me thinks the Koo is KOO-KOO good.
Me no like rolls so much. Me thinks
Itami-san not try so hard in right areas,
try so hard in wrong,
make rolls funny.
But me thinks Nigiri is
freshy nice nice,
and ambiance is so nicety,
Jar Jar me thinks."

Ok...maybe a bit on the Smegle side, but this place rocks. It's quiet, nice local, good food, nice Strawberry Tiramisu. Chase with a Muscato from Paso Robles (best wine growing region in Cally thanks to the natural Lime Stone deposits)...and you're feeling better than Oprah after exposing the "Million Little Pieces" dude crackho writer guy who lies a lot.......But this is supposed to be non-fiction. 
Koo rocks. Buy some of Aiko's art while you're at it. 

"Smegle like it!!"
author: Johnny C.

description:
Delightful...the service, ambience, presentation, and food.  I now know where my happy place is.

My highlight dishes...the miso marinated black cod will melt in your mouth, the best roll is self-explanatory, and the tuna and salmon tartar is fresh and original.

I've come here on a date, but also with my grandpa and little cousins.  Koo pleases everyone all around.
author: Yasmine G.

description:
MODIFIED REVIEW: Only go here if you can sit at the sushi counter. The quality of food from the tables is not very consistent with what you get if you are at the bar.

This is one of my favorite sushi places in San Francisco. Do yourself a favor and sit at the sushi bar. The best way to eat sushi is ordering directly from the chef as you decide what you want to eat next. Ask them what's fresh. Talk to them. You'll learn a lot.
