Start with the Spoonful of Happiness, a perfect appetizer to the night. It comes with two spoons full of flavor and a shot of clean, smooth sake. 

Next, order some nigiri (try the white toro if they have it) and then order a cooked dish, go back to the sushi (try Aji this time), get another cooked dish, more sushi, and then dessert. Be prepared to drop $60 for a good meal.

My only gripe with Koo is that they aren't always consistent with quality. But it's rare that I've felt any dissatisfaction with a single item on their menu.
author: Timothy P.

description:
Koo and Chika are probably two of the best sushi restaurants in that area.  The first time we were there, my friends and I sat at the bar. We had the  spoonful of happiness, the tartare, Maguro/Sake sashimi, and the owner/chef had recommended the Best Roll on their menu.  After the meal, I told him the Best Roll was OK, and asked him what the second best was.  He didn't have an answer.  

Good stuff.  recommended.
author: Chris T.

description:
Best Japanese restaurant in town.
Been there several times, tried everything on the menu.

My favorites are:

Spoonful of Happiness (everyone's favorite)
Wakasagi (fried smelt w/ curry flavor)
Steamed scallop & shrimp dumpling
Azteca roll (w/ jalapenos)

plus the sashimi, best selection at a very reasonable price

Desserts are also great & I think only like $3, chocolate cake is wonderful.

Service is excellent as well.

Nothing bad about it, I recommend going on a weekday since on the weekends might be hard to get a table....
author: Mr P.

description:
Didn't know happiness came in the spoonful.

This place is has fresh sushi and a good variety of non-raw items.  The spoonful of happiness won't find you a hot boyfriend or help you lose that extra ten pounds but it'll make your mouth tingle.  

Their sake list has a variety of by-the-glass options that allow you to have some fun tasting the different types of fermented rice.

The atmosphere is fun but not cragee.
author: L Y.

description: I don't understand what all the fuss is about.  We got terrible service and the sushi was "meh."  I've had much better for a lot less money.
author: Maureen K.

description: What's not to love?! The ambiance is great, intimate and usually pretty quiet. The sushi is the absolute best. Do yourself a favor and get the Best Roll! You'll be very glad you did!
author: Christy C.

description:
If I were to have sushi in S.F., this is THE place to go. Although I hate driving across town to get to Sunset and looking for a non-existing parking space, Koo is one of the few Japanese places that I am willing to go. If I lived nearby, I would go there every week! 

Two of my non-sushi favorites are Spoonful of Happiness and Tempura Wakasagi with Curry-Salt . For sashimi and sushi, I order all the special white board stuff. Not a bad sake selection and they do have Asahi kuro nama.
author: Yuko K.

description:
3.5 as I am torn. Went last night for a healthy dinner after Baker St. stairs. Back to the matter at hand. Our food was great, we had the tuna tartar. Awesome very fresh and Iove that is is served along w/ guac! Lovely. Jalapeno Hamanchi poppers were awesome! Not really spicy, but with just enough kick! Then came the rolls!! Best Roll, Azteca and something else, all were awesome!! The best was my favorite. 

Now comes the kicker, although the food was great, service not so much. It seems like there was only one or two waiters so service was slow. Not enough to deter me from going back, as the food again was awesome, it would just be nice to have quick help!! 

I shall be back for more yummy sushi!!
author: Nicole F.

description:
I came here with my boyfriend after reading some of the reviews on Yelp and Citysearch.  We had reservations for 7:30 and quickly found parking across the street.  The waitress seated us in a little corner by the window, away from the loud crowd and the lights were dim with candles lit on every table, which gave it a nice romantic feel; too bad that vibe was drowned out by how totally loud this place was. They almost lost a star for that. Boo.

But different story when the food came, we ordered:

Godzilla Tofu: They're so good! I wish I had more, but they're starters so the portions are small.  The garlic mayo dipping sauce was great!

Stuffed Jalapeno: This, I also wished I had more of, but once again, it's another starter that I ordered.  All I can say is, BIGGER PORTIONS PLEASE. They're yummy!

Azteca Roll: I popped one of these in my mouth and it instantly made my taste buds happy.  It's a cooked roll with crab, avocado, some kind of fish on top, a piece of jalapeno and some sauce that had a light spice to it. Yum. My boyfriend's fave.

Best Roll: This one was my fave; it was prepared nicely, the fish was cold and tasted fresh.  This roll has a refreshing clean taste to it and i LOVED it.

Dragon Roll: I am a lover of the Dragon Roll, so we had to get it.  The tempura had a crunchy batter the shrimp was delicious, but my two favorites of the night had to be the Best roll and Azteca roll.

Mt. Fuji: We ended out night with this chocolate cake dessert with a sccop of green tea ice cream. The presentation of this dish was so pretty, it really looked like Mt. Fuji! There was white sugar powdered sprinkled on top with the green tea ice cream on the side.

The bill was about $78, kind of pricey, but totally worth it! I would definitely come here again.
author: Helen Z.

description:
My new favorite Japanese joint in town offering fresh flavors and small bites. 

Favorites under Nigiri:
Hamachi and Tuna - it just melts in your mouth like butter!

Also on the same page, we tried a fish Pate, forgot the name, but it was so delish! I kid you not, but they were the size of quarters. Savor every bite!

If you're looking for something hot, try the Miso Marinated Black Cod under the Shared Plates side.

Can't wait to go back for more. Save your money cuz you'll want to order more!
author: izzie c.

description: went here for a monthly anniversary...calamari was awesome...all the rolls were amazing. i recommend this place for dates because it gives you a romantic setting with awesome customer service
author: Kurt N.

description: Very friendly service.  We had the U2 roll, the aztecs roll, mint short ribs, and tuna spicy tacos.  Amazing food, fun environment (its loud so be prepared),  they have booths.  Love this place.  My new favorite sushi in SF!
author: Cindy B.

description: Service was very personable and attentive. Food was excellent! Definitely a "quality over quantity" place :)
author: Rod N.

description: I love sushi!  I'm always on a lookout for a good sushi restaurant ever since coming back from Japan and looking for the freshest.  Stumbled upon Koo here on yelp and persuaded my fiance to take me here.  It's a dimly lit small restaurant in the Inner Sunset on the not so busy side of Irving.  Upon being seated, I realized that this is a Japanese-owned restaurant.  We tried the starters: tempura-fried crawfish hand roll.  Delicious!  We also ordered 4 different sushi and it was so fresh.  To top it off, we ordered dessert: Mount Fuji chocolate cake, gelato, and cookie...They do pay attention to presentation of their foods.  I would definitely come back  here.
author: Lisa W.

description:
Had to try Koo after reading the review on SF Gate. Heeded their advice on what to order and was NOT disappointed. Such innovative options...from the mixed tartare to the Spoonful of Happiness to the Best Roll to the White Sake salmon. Truly memorable and truly excellent. We will definitely add it to our sushi rotation. Give it a go and be daring as you order!

Wrote this review a couple of years ago and just wanted to note that once we discovered Zushi Puzzle we never went back - just that once.
author: Sarah R.

description: I went to Koo the other night (thanks for the recommendation yelpers!) and ever since I've been eager to go back. It is definitely a very cool sushi place with both inventive and traditional dishes. I was a little skeptical of the spoonful of happiness (partly due to the name, partly because it has sea urchin), but it was delicious! We also ordered a whole bunch of the fresh sashimi listed, the best was the amber jack. We also ordered a bottle of cold sake which was delicious. I don't usually get hand rolls, but my friend had the crab one, and that was also really good. We got a couple of other things.. but all the sake is making it blur together. I also thought the service was great. We were there on a Thursday so there were not many people there, and the waitress was very attentive and helpful. I will definitely go back!
author: Ashley H.

description:
Yes, but...

Great quality sushi. For Uni lovers, don't miss the Spoonful of Happiness.

But, they are not kid friendly. When we showed up with our 1-month old baby quietly sleeping, the waitress was very unpleasant the whole way through. (And we had been customers for a while). Thankfully a more business-minded lady ended up making it work. I almost walked out that night. I probably won't go back for some time.
author: Elsa T.

description:
Everything we had was fresh and delicious. Between the 3 of us, we ordered a bunch of sushi. I highly recommend the Flying Kamikazee. The specialty roll is basically spicy tuna roll topped with hamachi. It was really good. The maguro sashimi was also excellent. The nigiri fatty tuna is also highly recommended.

We also ordered the grilled halibut from the entree list and it was only OK. I'll probably go back next time just for the sushi rolls and sashimi.
author: Denise L.

description:
I didn't feel like sushi last night, but Angela wanted to eat at Koo. I will always dine at whatever fine establishment my lovely friend desires, so I told her of my sudden sushi craving.

But I'm happy we ended up at this Inner Sunset joint.  It surprised me. I thought it was going to be run-of-the-mill sushi.  The dishes and service were terrific.

Some of our dishes, in descending order of affection: (1) Mint Spare Rib Butter Lettuce Cup, (2) Japanese Eggplant Dengaku; (3) Tuna and Salmon Tartare on Shrimp Chips, (4) Beef Tataki, (5) Wakame. Angela's rainbow roll was nice too.

A word to those unfamiliar with the Japanese language.  The name of the restaurant is not a Japanese word, spelled as it is. See the explanation here: http://www.sushikoo.com/pages/about.html
author: Keith K.

description:
So I recently had a deeply philosophical debate with a co-worker about which was better, Sushi Groove or Koo. And by philosophical, I mean the words Nuh-UH and Yuh-HUH were definitely used multiple times by both parties. I was rooting for Sushi Groove. She for Koo.

I love Sushi Groove, but I lost. I've been to Koo several times since, and let's face it, the place is AWESOME! The service is great, the parking is easy and the rolls are huge. And try the Best Roll. I hate salmon, yet somehow it still manages to be my favorite.
author: Ben R.

description: Can you have an orgasm while eating sushi? The answer is yes if you eat here. I'm quite particular with sushi, and I must say they have an eclectic array of fresh sushi. My eyes rolled back as I tried their trio dish of tuna belies and while slurping up the spoonful of happiness (uni with quail egg on a spoon served with a saki shot). Also, if you don't like the raw stuff, the grilled hamachi kama and miso cod were wonderful. If you can't get a table at kiss seafood, then koo is a great alternative.
author: Elaine L.

description:
The fish is really fresh here. I came in with some friends on Halloween for dinner. We ordered a bunch of different rolls and nigiri. Everything was presented beautifully and each piece was hand crafted with care. In addition to the sushi we ordered the special calamari. It was fried perfectly so that the squid was tender and not chewy. 

I have a feeling that the real way to eat here is to sit at the sushi bar, because the people sitting there seemed to be having a really fun time with the sushi chefs. My only regret was not trying the tasty sounding satsuma mouse. I guess I will just have to come back!
author: Dana H.

description:
I just enjoyed the best sushi dinner I've had in a long time.  There are so many sushi places to choose from in the City, that when you've found one that you like, it's hard to venture out because there's nothing worse in my book than mediocre, uninspired sushi.  

Well, tonight, we venture out to Koo.  I hadn't even heard of it, but in combing through the reviews on Yelp, Koo was discovered.

Tonight we enjoyed the following dishes, and ALL were excellent:
     - Negi-Toro Roll (gotta love the fatty tuna)
     - Tuna and Salmon Tartare appetizer
     - Tataki something with garlic ponzu sauce
     - Spicy Green Beans
     - Azteca Roll (this was friggin' AWEsome.  Highly recommend)
     - Mt. Fuji chocolate cake with white cream filling and green tea gelato for dessert

And, it has to be said, one entire star goes to the size zero Asian chick who I watched go into the bathroom who had the most amazingly gargantuan tits I've ever seen on an Asian chick.  I couldn't help but stare because I just couldn't figure it out.  I even asked my boyfriend to look because well, come on, any man who's ever watched enough porn to have a favorite should be able to tell the difference.  Alas, he didn't get a good look, but it was worth a good ten minute conversation filled with laughter to go with our nicely prepared Tataki.
author: Tamar D.

description:
So far, I think this is the best sushi in the city.
Love their innovative yet simple sushi & dishes without sacrificing authenticity & freshness. The service is always great. 
There's gazillion sushi restaurant in downtown SF, but I always feel that Koo sushi is worth the driving to Richmond district.
author: Levy O.

description:
Nigiri here's the bomb (rice is perfect and the fish flown in from Japan). 
All of the cooked fish is above average, but not above the Nigiri or Spoonfuls. 

And do yourself a favor and try the omakase at the bar like the 4 sushi master's Noboo, Dan, Ken, and Toro have recommended.
author: David G.

description:
It's been 3 weeks since I ate here, so I cannot speak in specifics. I'll try to remember what I had. This is a disclaimer though: the food was really good, but it was a little more costly than I thought it was going to be. 

Spoonful of happiness was awesome. Close your eyes and remember to chew. It looks intimidating, but it's really good
Tamago nigiri: very good.

...that's all I remember. Sorry! I basically got rolls and nigiri. Everything was good. Unfiltered sake goes well with sushi. Have a try. When you leave the restaurant you can gaze up at that ivory tower that is UCSF and sigh just once, then move on.
author: Albert D.

description:
I went to Koo last Friday and was very impressed with the overall experience.  The food tasted decent, but the variety of adventurous offerings was amazing.  Apart from the typical sushi offerings (i.e. Dragon and rainbow rolls, California rolls, salmon sashimi, etc.), Koo also serves up exotic fresh catch sashimi.  

My first impression was good; the place seemed trendy and upscale.  The decorations were classy and the waiters were friendly.  We went pretty early and since there were many tables available, we were surprised they asked if we had a reservation.  But it wasn't without warrant, as by the time we were finished with dinner the entire restaurant was full.

For our appetizers, we decided to be experimental and started with Mexican black sea bass nigiri and deep sea red snapper.  It was definitely obvious that this fish was fresh, and not all fishy like some places (I won't name any names).

We also had some shrimp dumplings which were alright.  The best thing about that dish was the presentation, with colorful garnish and sauce artfully sprawled on the plate.

For our main entre we ordered a couple different rolls: Dragon, Flying Kamikaze, and U2.  They were all great.  The ingredients tasted of utmost quality and the presentation was fantastic.  The waiters were also very attentive and helpful.  Sometimes when I order various rolls, I don't know which is which?  But when the waiters at Koo served our plate of sushi they walked us through each roll and told us the names of each one. 

We had a great time Koo; it was a wonderful place to have a date.  They only downside is that the prices are a little steep.  The rolls will run you nearly $15 each, our dinner was $75.  But then again, it's an upscale restaurant and you're paying not only for the quality of food, but also for the atmosphere and good service.  I'd definitely recommend this place to impress a date or to have a romantic dinner with someone special.
author: Timothy C.

description:
My friends and I came here on sunday and we loved it.  We started the meal off with the tuna tartar, the tuna was fresh and it comes with shrimp chips, which I thought was a cool twist.  Then we got the spoonful of happiness and WHAT A SPOONFUL OF HAPPINESS they were!!  the uni was fresh, no taste of "under the bay".  the monkfish liver was smooth and tasty.   And the chilled sake that it comes with... well come on now.  we moved on to some sushi and some rolls.  All fresh and the rolls were definetly new and interesting.  

We ended the meal with the mt. fuji, which is not especially special, but the name is cool.
author: Janet S.

description:
One of the best and most authentic Japanese sushi restaurants in the city.  Host is Japanese, sushi chefs are Japanese, servers are Japanese with Japanese accents and polite Japanese mannerisms.

A little more on the expensive side, but it's worth it.

Love that:
1. The genmai tea is hot and flavorful, not weak and watered down
2. They keep the tea coming
3. They have toro
4. There are creative rolls and non-sushi dishes
5. They have toro

Recommendations (from someone who almost exclusively eats sashimi at sushi restaurants):
1. Spoons of Happiness (or Ecstasy)
2. Hamachi
3. Aji
author: L Y.

description:
This is a very comprehensive review because I think my friend and I ordered everything off the menu! My favorites: 

Japanese Eggplant (from the grill)
Bamboo Tower (to be shared with at least 3 people)
Dynamite hand roll
Azteca sushi roll

The best part of this place is the friendly service. I would definitely recommend this to my friends and would come back for more.
author: Elaine T.

description:
This is my Go-to sushi place. Based on proximity and mostly because I love the menu.

Interesting enough, my favorite things on the menu aren't the sushi or the sashimi. Its everything BUT actually.....

My typical order: 
1. Spoonful of Happiness
2.  Mint Spare Rib Butter Lettuce Cup 
3. Miso Marinated Black Cod
4. Mt. Fuji with Ginger Gelato 
5. And a Large Sapporo if I really want to get craa-zay.
author: Cin H.

description:
I don't get the hype of this place, unless the sushi chef has recently changed, or their fish supplier has changed since 2009 or something.... anyways I went and as I always do when testing a new japanese restaurant, I take the sashimi because it gives u a good idea of the quality of the raw fish, no tempura or fat or spices added. Well the fish was completely blend, no taste, it was very disappointing.
I took a roll and it was ok. The maki I took was way too salty..... and they didnt serve any water with the sake......so I will definitely not go back to Koo's !
author: Linguini c.

description:
A sushi place with actual Japanese sushi chefs behind the counter.  Who would think it would be so rare in SF?

Sitting at the sushi bar gives you a great view of the chefs at work, while the rest of the restaurant is quiet and cozy with paper lanterns.

The fare here leans toward traditional Japanese sushi with an American twist, as opposed to wholly American-style sushi places in the area.  The preparation is perfect, the fish is always fresh and great, and the rolls are some of the best renditions on classics you'll find anywhere in the city.

I have forgotten the name, but one of the best rolls had salmon wrapped around the outside and thinly sliced lemon outside of that.  Amazing!

Service is good, not great.  Prices are only okay or else it would get a hugher rating.
author: Lauren J.

description: This is one of my favorite sushi places!! Even though I don't eat much seafood they have vegetarian alternatives. They are always friendly and ready to help you choose your favorite dish. I would recommend reservations as it gets busy, duh it super good!!
author: Kris M.

description:
Koo... where do I start...

First off I must say sorry to Koo for not remembering to write a review!  It has been 2 years overdue!!!!

Koo is by far my #1 Japanese restaurant in San Francisco!

My Meal almost everytime here:
-Tuna Tartar!
-Albacore Tataki!
-Beef Tataki!
-Flying Kamikaze!
-DYNAMITE HANDROLL!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
-Their fresh catches that constantly changes!
-And finally the reason I come here the most: Mount Fuji Dessert with Green Tea Ice Cream!

The workers here are awesome and nice!  The atmosphere is semi-romantic and feels really good.  The artwork on the walls, especially the japenese woman skiing, brings this place alive for me!

I love KOO! and I hope you love KOO as much as I do!

PS: You may want to make reservations... Walk-ins are a bit tough nowadays due to the populartity of this place!  Parking is rough but 6pm is the sweet spot!  Right when the meters are off and not quite everyone is home!
author: Benny S.

description: I've been to Koo a few times because it's one of the decent sushi places in my partner's neighborhood.  Decent, meaning the freshness of the fish is inconsistent and the prices are too high for the quality.  But, in past visits I felt it was an enjoyable-enough experience to come back.  We went there last Thursday for dinner, and there was an obviously newish host working.  He took a bit too long to greet us and then seemed confused about where to seat us (we had a reservation).  Before ordering, I asked the waitress for recommendations on rolls, since I usually order nigiri or sashimi.  She pointed out to me the most popular, meaning most ordered, rolls on the menu, which are the rolls including fried things/tempura, or the more Americanized rolls.  Being raised with Japanese culture, I was disappointed by her recommendations.  We enjoyed our decent meal though, and were paying our check and finishing off our second bottle of sake.  Then, the host came up to us and said something to the effect of, "I have another reservation waiting for this table.  I'm not asking you to leave, but just consider that."  Mind you, we had not taken our sweet time with this meal, in fact, we were on our way to an event so were aware of being timely and our total time in the restaurant was still under one hour.  What bothered me more though, was that we were seated next to an older, more Caucasian couple who had been there long before we had arrived by the looks of where they were in their courses when we sat down, and nothing was said to them by the host.  I felt discriminated against, which is really unacceptable especially at a place with such high-end prices (we spent over $100) and attitude.  I won't be going back.
author: Stephanie S.

description: Went for happy hour and the prices were very reasonable with very delicious food. Customer service was great. My water glass never went empty.
author: Edwin F.

description:
I was visiting SF from Colorado - not the best fish market in my home state beyond trout, etc - but for my money and experience the sushi here was fantastic.  Definitely more of a hip scene/rolls type place . . . but I was pleasantly surprised at the quality and precision of the fish presented.  

My dining party loved the rolls, especially the kamikaze . . . and the "caterpillar" roll they made to order for them.  I'm more of a sushi/nigiri fiend and I was ecstatic with the feel and especially the taste of the toro, saba, sake, hamachi, suzuki.  Just heaven.

We stumbled in here to meet some friends on a Friday night.  Though it wasn't too late - 8 - it felt like they had already turned their tables a few times.  You know that look of relief of a hostess, followed by a relaxed couple of servers . . . we were seated right away.  Nothing to complain about regarding service; it was prompt.

Strange sake "tasting notes" . . . but good sake nonetheless, at fair prices after the restaurant markup.  

Again, there isn't much in Colorado that prepared me for such good fish, but over-nighted sushi in Fort Collins shouldn't be far off from days-old fish in San Fran.  This obviously wasn't days-old fish, but I can't comment on its quality relative to the market in SF.

The notorious "spoonful" seemed like more of a novelty than the purported cornerstone of their menu.  I'm not sure why it gets so much play in these reviews.  This is supposed to be a sushi bar; if you're going somewhere just for a "spoonful," just take it to its logical conclusion and eat at raw bars for the rest of your life.
author: Brian S.

description:
I have walked by this place many many times and for a long time I have no idea what is the name of this Japanese Restaurant. (If you see their sign you will know what I am talking about. ) So, when I first mentioned it to my friend, I called it, ICDD.... 

Anyway, the first time when I was eating there at the Sushi bar, the girl next to me recommend me this delicious share plate: Albacore Tuna Tetekki, with lovely cilantro leaves on the top. Highly recommend. 

The chefs work at the sushi bar are all Japanese, at least they all speak Japanese to each other. If you sit at the sushi bar, they will serve you a small plate of salmon slices and onion for free. 

While you are sitting there, don't forget to look around. There is a paint  of two Geishas skiing on the Fuji mountain, pretty cute.
author: Lei B.

description:
One of my favorite places to dine in the city.  The "Spoon Full of Happiness" is exactly that.  I can eat that all night!  Sushi is fresh and satisfying.  Other good things to order:  hamachi kama and miso glazed black cod.  I can't even remember all the good stuff I ate because I was with a friend who eats so much, we ordered food for 6 (there was 2 of us) and he ordered in Japanese.

This place is definitely worth it!
author: vanessa c.

description:
It was as if a yellow tail fish came up to my wasabi dish and jumped in! Yes. Enormously exaggerated, but point made! 

My friends and i had an absolutely fabulous meal here.

Goods:
- SPOON FULL OF HAPPINESS: I swoon, die, arise, and swoon again.
- Sashimi - YUM!
- Small/intimate setting- I hate Costco-sized sushi places
- decent prices - pricey? a little, but are YOU going to pay 99cents for raw fish?
- sushi 
- dark Asahi beer

Okays:
- black cod and other hot plates: ehhh

Bads:
- Sunset location: at least it's right off the N 

Quick! Someone give me a reason to go back the same week!
author: Angelinaaah h.

description:
Wow. 

From the Spoonful of Happiness, brimming with mega-fresh sweet uni, ankimo, quail egg, and drizzled w/truffle oil accompanied by palate-cleansing dry sake; to the marinated grilled artichoke with addictive aioli; to the fresh-from-the ocean selections such as aji, kanpachi, and did i say mega-fresh SWEET uni??... Koo never misses a beat. 

DEFINITELY sit at the sushi bar -- there's something so much more special when chefs really show that they have pride in what they are serving up. 

Service: Friendly, attentive, accomodating. 
Decor: Nice japanese. Comfortable. 
Will I go back?: ALL.THE.TIME.
author: Sharon C.

description:
My master plan to steer away my dad's hopeless narrow-mindedness on only wanting to eat Chinese is close to success.  I suspect next time he happens to go to a Japanese restaurant (and I hope it'll be a freewill choice, not by anyone's force), he will look at the menu and say to himself, this time, I will not order Teriyaki Chicken!  

Koo, indeed, was perfect to introduce him to a few of my favorite dishes to show him Japanese food can have great flavor and texture too.  All the dishes we ordered were great with flavors, never too strong, always complex and well balanced.  The ankimo, Bamboo Tower, and the dumplings were all excellent.  The black cod was delicious and the grilled hamachi was very tender and flavorful despite looking kinda dry.  I literally zoned out and took a moment to savor the taste in my mouth after each bite.  I was seeing fireworks in my head like Remy in "Ratatouille" with his bite of cheese and strawberry.  The sushi we ordered, Hotate Nigiri, Fresh Albacore nigiri, and Rock n' Roll, were all good as well. 

The service was efficient and well paced.  Never felt rushed, but always had something ready to eat and cleared off as soon as we were done.  

Definitely come early, because tables fill up quickly.
author: Candice B.

description:
I'm firmly of the belief that the only way to judge a sushi is at the sushi bar, face to face with the chef making your dinner. Suzuki (an Ebisu deserter if I'm not mistaken) did an amazing job. The fish was fresh and excellent, and the chef put together a great dinner with a beginning, middle and end. I was especially impressed by the plate of three toro varieties, and the delicious, firm hamachi.

The feel of the place was lively without being overwhelming; the food was alternatingly simple and creative, but always delicious; and the staff was attentive.
author: Adam L.

description:
Great sushi, great dishes, great homemade desserts.

Favs: Azteca Roll, Toro, and creme brulee

Reservations recommended.
author: Lisa C.

description:
Last night was my second visit to Koo.  The food here is amazing.  Their sashimi is fresh, their rolls are unique, and according to my other half, nothing in this world compares to their A Spoonful of Happiness.  So, if are a Uni lover, you have to come to Koo to try their A Spoonful of Happiness.  

So, not only did we have amazing food last night, we also had great service.  They were attentive and the wonderful lady that took our order said "sorry"  when my 5 year old son goes "yuck! why is there lemon in my water!!!"  SHE said sorry...for me having a much too vocal son!  She then proceeded right after taking our order to bring him a lemon free water.  How cool is that?  

And to top off the evening, mochi ice cream for the little one and Mt. Fuji with ginger gelato for the adults.  

This was an easy 5 star for me.
author: Stella C.

description:
Thanks again to Nobu K for mentioning this great new place.

I've been twice now and very, very happy both times and here is why:

Beautiful serene decor
Very pleasant and attentive staff
Delightful, some modern, some traditional sushi
Very fresh fish

Favorites:
fresh sardine nigiri
fresh salmon nigiri
kani nigiri

I love the cute rabbit noren on the wall!
author: G Z.

description:
The perfect sushi place for a quiet evening with your significant other or a small group of friends. Koo serves a range of dishes, from hot appetizers to sashimi and sushi rolls. 

Quality has been consistent, and I've been there many times! Favorites include Tokyo Crunch, Sashimi platter, Stuffed Jalapeno, and Tuna and Salmon tartare. Leave room for dessert - their Mt. Fuji is super yum!
author: buggy b.

description:
gemma to us to the "let's treat ourselves" sushi joint.

apparently you didn't need reservations at koo not too long ago. but good places catch on, and after almost 300 reviews koo has a pretty strong following, with good reason.

the tartar is awesome, avocado and raw fish never tasted so good on a light crispy rice cracker.  the stuffed jalapenos were good, but not spicy enough. the tofu appetizer we got was delish as were the rolls.

there's definitely an imagination at koo, with ingredients and presentations that i had not seen before. or maybe i just don't get out enough.
author: Ameer N.

description:
I am really on a mission to find THE ONE - the sushi place in the City that deserves all 5 BIG stars.   I had hoped that this was it.  Sadly, it was not.

Don't get me wrong.  Koo definitely has potential.. but it's just not quite there for me...yet.   

The sashimi was very fresh, but meager and thin.  The artichoke appetizer was a little charred - not sure if it was intentional but it did add a little smokey kick.  The nigri were not extraordinary... just typical.   The highlight of our meal was the Kamakaze roll (a roll of spicy tuna, asparagus, and white tuna, serve with ponzu sauce) - this one, I'd highly recommend it.

Maybe Sunday night just wasn't the best night for sushi.  I should've known that.  Or, as with other things in life, maybe I should give it a few more shots before I jump to the conclusion that this was not THE ONE.  But heck, it's only one of the thousand sushi joints in town - there are plenty of sushi out there to be had...
author: Shirley F.

description:
This just made my books as my favorite Japanese restaurant in the city and am willing to drive all the way from SOMA to get my fix.  And besides Santa Ramen, there aren't many places I would drive for.

I agree with the other Yelpers, the Spoonfuls of Happiness kicks ass!  Plus they serve it with a sake to clean the palate or bring out the taste.  I don't know.  Anyhow, I was told that the owner's wife is a pastry chef so we tried her Strawberry Tiramisu.  OH MY GOODNESS.  I almost had to come home to change my pants ; )  The staff is extremely friendly, provided responsive service, very knowledgeable of sakes, and did a great job recommending the most popular.  Folks, this is not the place you come to order California Rolls and Dragon Rolls so be daring and ask the chefs to make you something special.  I assure you that you will be pleased.       

After our delicious meal, we scheduled a reservation a week in advance to sit at the bar.  And from what I hear, it's A TREAT!  The chef basically makes whatever he wants and I have been told it is an adventure for taste buds.      

Koo has set a new standard for me.
author: Caesar C.

description: Been going here since it opened. Best sushi place in SF by far. Family is very nice. Husband = sushi chef, wife = hostess + dessert maker. Nice non-sushi dishes. Really great place!
author: Robert P.

description:
Ok, these guys were even better before... I guess they became too popular. 

Things to die for: 
- spoonful of happiness 
- Try belly sashimi 

Things to try: 
- hamachi tataki 
- dynamite hand roll 

The rest of the menu is just good. 

Sushi rice was less than perfect last time I was there - one star off
author: Terry A.

description: Solid middle of the week date night....sat at the sushi bar.  The fish was first class.  On par w/ SF's best (minus Ino, of course).  The sashimi wasn't the world's most attractive fish, but it tasted fantastic nonetheless.  Don't forget to order the spoonful of awesomeness...or goodness...or something like that.
author: Albert B.

description:
We decided to go up a notch and go somewhere we hadn't been to for my birthday. It began to fill up pretty quickly and it was a Tuesday night, well, i think this place only seats 50 people or something. 

We started with the Bamboo Tower salad- sounded substantial and more just seaweed or greens with a Japanese dressing- wow- was really fresh- strips of fish, salad, some kind of fish jam (i cant describe it any other way, but it melted quickly and left a light fish taste- YUM) with a light ponzu dressing...ahhhh am salivating- everything but the greens are stuffed into a bamboo (hence the tower) then the server removes the bamboo and lets the filling fall onto the greens..... definitely a treat and very flavourful.. wanted more... 

We ordered the black cod and barracuda nigiri- mild and the slices of fish were pressed very firmly onto the rice, so you could dip the fish into the soy sauce without it all falling apart. Wow- skill. 

Azteca Roll was my fave out of the sushi we ordered. With thin slices of jalapeno gave it the perfect crunch and was not over powering. Ever so lightly baked, it was like the fish was kissed by a touch of heat, the mayo was perfect- kept everything moist, didnt need dip for the rolls as there was so much flavour..... ahhh! Over heard a few other people order the Best roll, so thought we would join the club- asparagus tempura which was not greasy and kept crunchy throughout, with salmon and paper thin lemon slices draped on the top. Again- no dip needed- it was moist enough to carry its own but next to the Azteca, it was a strong second place 

Although it was full by the time we had settled in, the atmosphere was quiet intimate with the candles on every table and we could talk easily without having to raise our voices. The servers were friendly and made sure our tea cups were full. Surprised that they didn't offer desert, especially reading here on Yelp that there was black sesame mousse. I would have stayed for that! 

I wouldn't come here every other week cos its a little out of the way and it is a little pricey, but definitely would return with people from out of town, as this place is pretty exceptional. I am curious about the 'spoonful of happiness' now after reading the other reviews.. maybe next time
author: Sushi Y.

description:
Price: If you're looking for an inexpensive meal, this is not the place.

Food: A creative menu:
Spoon full of happiness is off the hook extraordinary. This was served with a refreshing sake, between the smooth, cool and sweet portions of white fish, uni, quail egg and tasty sauces.
Kumamato oysters were fresh and meaty, with the peppery daikon on ponzu.
Miso soup: pretty uneventful.
Tempura: Good, but nothing extraordinary.
Bamboo Tower: fresh and light white fish, shrimp and scallops with tasty greens and light onions.
Hamachi Kama: the best I have had. The yellow tail jaw is roasted and served with daikon and a dipping sauce. This part of the fish must be ultra fresh as it will turn quickly and if stored incorrectly or prepared, can be dry and very fishy. This had crispy skin and fresh moist meat around the bones.
Ambience: Pretty tight quarters. Kind of surprised to see kids there.
Service: Above average, although the order was incorrect, the food was so good, we did not send back.

We will try the sushi next time, which clearly means, "We're going back."
author: A I.

description:
love my fish raw.  we've been coming for years now, and we come for their "catch of the day" sushi specials (wish they updated this online more often!) and we try just about all the sushi specials.  we don't come here for their rolls, but they look good if you're into that.  we always start with their "spoonful of happiness" -- yums!  definitely my favorite place in the city for raw fish!!

bill came to over $200 (w/tip, for 2), but we ordered A LOT of sushi (including an order of the spoons for each, live scallop, toro, uni w/quail eggs, 2 sake specials, just about all the sushi specials -- basically, all the pricier items).  not cheap, but when it comes to raw fish in the city, you're not going to find this quality of fish for cheap.

and we always reserve for bar seating -- service is good.  sushi chef takes care of the food at a pace, waitress takes care of the drinks.  nice  sake selection.

street parking is not super easy, but i usually find something within a few blocks.
author: S R.

description: Spoonful of happiness was amazing, good amaebi, prompt service, but it was more of a yuppie spot than anything else.  They serve sake and beer but did not serve sake bombs because they said other tables would complain.  Definitely get the spoonful of happiness.
author: Kim N.

description: Koo has INCREDIBLE sushi, however they have terrible management. I've been going to Koo every week for months, I called to make a reservation for 6 at 6:30 on a tuesday. I was called back and told there is a $20 minimum per person for parties of 6 or more.... on tuesday? during happy hour none-the-less? Terrible. Never going in again.
author: Brandon E.

description: We love this place for sushi.  The best sushi in town and great service.  Can't get any better for the money.
author: Y K.

description:
Came back again, and it is still supremely amazing. Yes they do have sushi, but the real prize is the upscale izakaya like menu. 

Despite it's slightly tacky name, Spoonful of Happiness is wacky good: top grade ankimo wrapped in a whitefish coupled with uni and roe... wow! Oh and this also comes served with its ow dry sake!
author: Muck P.

description:
Went with the fam for Mother's Day....glad we made reservations a couple of days ahead of time, because they ended up being completely booked and turned away any walk-ins.  

Sooooo good!  Tried lots of things, all of the sashimi was delicious, but my favorite by far was the amaebi nigiri....the shrimp was super sweet, and the heads came deep fried in their own little dish. I love fried shrimp heads!  Oh, and I don't know why I never knew about this, but you can request fresh wasabi. My bro-in-law asked the waitress for it, and it really makes a difference. Just a fresher, sharper, taste. Also, they carry Asahi Kuronama, one of my fav beers.

Service and ambiance were both better than expected - my tea cup was never less than half-full, and even though the restaurant was packed, servers were always checking up. 

Will definitely go back, I can't stop thinking about little fried shrimpy heads, mmmmmm.
author: marissa a.

description:
First time here and I have to say I'm impressed with the quality and freshness of their sushi/sashimi.  There were some interesting small plates that I want to try next time I'm here b/c this time around we were in the mood for sushi/sashimi so we didn't get to explore their other menu.  Will definitely have to do a follow-up review but for this one, two thumbs up for their sashimi and sushi rolls!

p.s. We had good parking karma that night but be aware that this area of Irving can be pretty tough to find parking!
author: Rick P.

description:
WOW

what a great restaurant.  Happiness in a spoon was amazing.  Bonito nigiri was melt-in-your-mouth.  Our waitress was very helpful and nice.  All the rolls were very good, and i generally hate rolls.  

Prices were completely reasonable-- I've paid more at many "Brand X" sushi joints without this level of tastiness and good service.  Until someone steers me to an even better spot, I will never be caught eating sushi anywhere else in SF.
author: Anthony L.

description:
Spoonful of Happiness, enough said.

I love KOO and would go there more often if I weren't so lazy to venture out to the Sunset.  The chef/owner is super friendly, adding to a great dining experience.
author: Helen T.

description: Koo is a bit pricey, but the Spoonful of Happiness is one of the most amazing things EVER!  This is definitely the must have here.  Everything else was good.  Good not great.  The sashimi was fresh.  Their other cooked items were ok, but nothing spectacular.
author: Tim W.

description:
I've only been here once, but that one time left me excitingly checking my calender for the next time I could come back. 

I am currently attempting to checkout as many of the top-rated sushi restaurants in the city and I firmly believe Koo definitely lives up to its reputation. The interior of Koo is very clean and the decor is absolutely perfect. Koo has managed to pull off that fantastic blend of a modern and Japanese environment.  The service was very polite and attentive.

While being important to the overall rating, the above is just the icing on top of the delicious cake that makes Koo worth visiting. The food was divine and there wasn't a single thing that I regretted ordering. The Azteca and Frying Kamikaze rolls were both delicious and I found myself struggling to eat each piece slowly while enjoying the explosion of flavors. (instead of gobbling all of them up quickly). 

I'm not a sushi expert by any means, but I felt the sashimi was quite fresh and full of flavor. I would recommend simply choosing from the daily specials, but you probably can't go wrong with any of the choice.So far, the only sushi places that I have tried in the bay area that are better than Koo are Sushi Ran (Sausalito) and Hana Sushi( Rohnert Park).
author: Amar S.

description: Amazing fresh daily sushi selection.  We also had the soft shell (crawfish?) roll and the shrimp tempura roll (can't remember the name).  Sushi super fresh and amazingly delicious.  Only down side was that the service was really slow.  Not sure if they were just out one waitress or what but it took forever to get our check...
author: K O.

description: Realllly good sushi here. Was not disappointed at all. Fish was fresh, and the appetizers were great. Server was nice. I would come back again.
author: Darren J W.

description:
When I think of Koo, I think of the:

"A Spoonful of Happiness" -- good combination of texture and taste of the ingredients. Way to kick off a meal.

the other speciality rolls are good in general. The ingredients of each roll compliment each other well.
author: Benedict C.

description: My family and I had dinner last night @ Koo. It was a bit pricey, but it was very good. I had the 'spoonful of happiness', which was actually 2 spoonfuls of happiness with a shot of cold Sake. I also had the King Crab hand roll. They were both fantastic. My  daughter had the dragon roll...unbelievable. My wife the Rock and Roll with same reaction. The blue fine tuna was melt in your mouth. Service and dining room were great! Best parking is a few blocks up the street at the UCSF public parking structure.
author: John F.

description: We only got sushi and saki, so can't speak to the rest of the menu, but everything was excellent - fresh, delicious, good service.
author: Syd S.

description: The best roll is amazing! You have ot try it.. The spicy green beans hot plate is excellent. We shared a bunch of nigiri and sashimi and the fish was good and fresh. The restaurant was packed and yet we were seated promptly w/o a reservation on a Friday night. It's a little pricy, but well worth the price.
author: Ana F.

description:
warning! this place is expensive! but we had omakase so i guess it could have been less expensive if we did a la carte. 

we started out with several small sunomono as we were drinking shochu. then we had a wide variety of sashimi, including blue fin tuna, hamachi, toro, mackerel, smoked monk fish liver, blue shrimp, tofu, grilled salmon skin, bamboo shoots, and a variety of other things i cannot remember. 

the food was definitely very very good. and the sushi chef were so creative, nice and thoughtful with the presentation. they observed how fast we're eating and how much we're drinking to pace their service. 

we ended up spending $70 each. that's by far the most expensive meal i've had in sf, or in a long time. but it was definitely well worth it. although, next time i rather go w/g.
author: Diana L.

description:
K says: One of my favorite sushi places in the City. A while since we've been, but this place is still good. It is owned and operated by a husband and wife team, and you can tell they both really care. I'm a big fan of the Spoonful of Happiness, and the sui-gei sake. This jewel of a restaurant is never over-crowded, and hopefully it'll stay that way. 

J says: Yum, I quite like this place.  Great food, friendly service, and they take reservations.  It's been almost a year since we last came here and the food seems to be even better.  We had very fresh chu-toro, hamachi and kampachi.  The rolls are pretty cool too, especially the Azteca roll.  Also a fan of the godzilla tofu appetizer, lightly fried tofu topped with miso paste, mmmm.
author: Jen Ken H.

description:
The daily fish specials were great. Katsuo was great (a favorite of mine) and I also tried a new type Koni Kanpachi which was fabulous. I'm surprised to learn Kanpachi is actually a type of yellowtail, as typically I don't like yellowtail. 
Kani was also very good.
author: vickie j.

description:
I'm SO happy that finally, FINALLY, Chika found its match.  Chika used to be a tiny Japanese restaurant on Irving and 10th Ave., only a few blocks away from Koo, but they were able to grow their business and thus moved away to the South Bay.  Great for them but I have to admit that it was a very sad day for me.  Anyway, so after eating a few times at Ebisu, family took me to Koo for the first time.

I was amazed by the ambience there - warm, friendly, cozy, and truly authentic.  We ordered a whole array of sushi and sashimi plus rolls and weren't disappointed. The fish was fresh, succulent and absolutely delicious.  The presentation was fantastic and the service impeccable.

The Bay Area has innumerous great Japanese restaurants, but Koo is most definitely one of the best ones.  Sure, parking is a pain, but it's so worth the trouble.
author: Hadley K.

description:
Fresh sushi which is very important!
Good options for rolls and Nigiri. Considering the quality and clean, modern decor the price is reasonable.

Only reason why it's not a 5 star is because they seem to be short on wait staff and you may wait longer than someone who arrived after you.
author: Bee N.

description:
Ankimo Onegaishimasu!

I never could comprehend the allure of uni until I visited Koo a couple of years ago. I've craved the spoonful of happiness ever since. Something about the uni+ponzu+quail egg = super melt in your mouth scrumptiousness. Not to mention the ankimo -mmmmmmm. 
It has now been quite a while since I've been there only b/c of the wait/fact that 
it's always packed.  I'd resisted writing a review b/c I didn't want my little secret to get out. Too late. 
I always enjoying eating at the sushi bar and getting chef's recommendations though I have yet to do an omakase. Everything has always been fresh and oishii!

Update: 1/31/08

On a recent cold night, I was finally reunited with my happiness and even convinced my reluctant friend to try it. she was delighted. 
all the nigiri was more petite than i recalled, but absolutely fresh and buttery. exceptional quality. 
wasabi tobiko was utterly blissful as was the dynamite scallop handroll. 
For dessert, we shared the pyramid shaped mt. fuji chocolate and white chocolate filled cake a la mode (green tea gelato). 
Was quite satisfying and could have been doubly so if it had been served warm.  

 i could eat it all morning, noon, and night.
author: Sandrita R.

description:
Are you depressed?  Are you blue?  Then is this what you need.  Get a friend or loved one, and order a SPOON FULL OF HAPPINESS from Koo.  (actually it should be SPOONS FULL OF HAPPINESS 'cause ther are two, but the singular does sound better somehow...)  How can you not love sushi that comes on little spoons and is served with a big shot of sake? If that doesn't make you happy, then maybe perscription drugs are in order.

The fish here is always impeccable so I order lots of sashimi, especially the specials.  I only wish they would change up the rolls a little more, or add more rolls with lots of their excellent fish!  They also have a great sake menu.  So, come on, come on get happy!
author: Farah G.

description:
Umm, I am not impressed. Came here for a friend's birthday. She saw that Koo has all these good reviews so we thought we'd try it. Bad.

Cute decor, nice staff, good service. However, the food was simply....lacking. We ordered the black cod, the ribs with the butter lettuce cup, the chicken teriyaki, the dragon roll, and the best roll. 

Normally I wouldn't even get something like chicken teriyaki but I was having stomach problems so I had to order some stomach-friendly items. Otherwise, I'd be all over the sashimi I tell ya.

Overall, I thought the cod was pretty good but slightly salty (maybe it was the sauce it was served with), the ribs were dry and somewhat salty (there was no sauce for it), the chicken teriyaki was like any normal chicken teriyaki, but it was served over potato salad, which I thought was kinda weird. 

Now, onto the sushi. It was pretty good. It tasted like any sushi that you can get at any decent Japanese restaurant. Nothing knock-your-socks-off spectacular. 

Overall, I give Koo three stars because the food was indeed three stars. I tried to like it, I did.
author: C. T.

description:
This has to be the best place for sushi in SF.  We've been coming here every Friday night for the past few years since we found it.  I am sure that you can find sushi as good or better elsewhere in the city if you search for it but what makes Koos so outstanding is their service.  The staff is friendly and super attentive.  The other nice thing is that they accept reservations so you don't have to do the "put your name on the list and wait" when you get there.   

If you have friends who are not into raw fish they have a great menu of cooked dishes as well.
author: ZenRunner -.

description: Koo is amazingly tasty. So after reading tons of reviews about their Spoonful of Happiness, I had to try it. The combo sounded a little weird, and the dish definitely looked odd but pretty when I received it. So not weird...heavenly. Both of those spoonfuls were little mouthfuls of pure happiness. Not to mention, the chilled sake balanced it out perfectly. However, I would not recommend ordering this if on a date, it can be kind of hard to consume...i'll just leave it at that. I was a little disappointed with my King Crab Dynamite roll b/c I was super hungry and I didn't realize it was a small hand roll, but it still tasted really good! The japanese eggplant was super delish as well. My friend ordered the Best Roll and the Rock n Roll- both really good too. This place deserves all 5 stars for their Spoonful of Happiness, because I've eaten super bomb sushi several times before, but this blissful 5 min of my life was rare.
author: Sonya D.

description: Had reservations here for a Saturday night and we were seated promptly.  The complementary tea was a nice touch and they kept my water filled.  The vegetarian sushi was ok, nothing really outstanding. The restaurant's ambiance was a little cold and the tables are situated pretty closely together and I felt a little uncomfortable being watched by the neighboring couple while we ate. All in all it was an average sushi experience for me. Apparently the reason why this place is so highly rated is because of the spoonful of happiness which I did not partake in so maybe that's why I wasn't wowed.
author: H T.

description:
I like this place more for the small plates (Japanese "tapas" if you will) because they distinguish it much more than the sushi/rolls. However, the fish is outstanding and the rolls balanced. My girlfriend and I hit this place all the time. 
Favorites include:
Tuna and Salmon Tartare
Goma Ae
Grilled Asparagus    
Stuffed Jalapeno
Albacore Tataki
Hamachi Kama
The other very notable thing about this place is the monthly sake specials. Most amazing sakes I've ever tasted! I've been converted, baptized, and confirmed to sake-love. Mon Amour!
Finally, the service is superb! Very gracious but on top of it.
author: Felix A.

description:
Deliciousness... This may, just may have taken over my favorite Japanese spot in town.  

I should put the caveat in here perhaps it wasn't fair that I'm rating this place so high since I was with a Japanese girl who essentially ordered everything for us and suggested some new things I haven't had elsewhere.  I went to dinner here last Sat. in a group of four and it was surprisingly not too crowded.  No reservations and we waited like 10 min. max.  

Spoonful of Happiness: Yes, for first timers (aka me) the ingredients sound adventurous, but realize this what they are known for!  Read other reviews for a full description, I had the quail egg/uni spoon and all I can say is that it was truffle oil heaven.

Black Cod Miso: I liked the light sauce they served it in, and the fish tasted actually very smooth and quite buttery.  While good, I felt like might have had it better at places like Yuzu.  

Azteca/Dragon/California rolls: The rolls, IMHO are pretty outstanding here.  The Dragon/California I would say is high quality but nothing spectacular.  I highly recommend trying the Azteca.  They top this roll with a thin slice of jalapeno and while I'm not usually a fan of jalapeno, this provided a nice kick for the roll without it being too overbearing on the taste. 

Price is about the same if not a little cheaper than other sushi places in town.  We paid ~$25/person for all the above, some additional appetizers, and beers
author: Ken S.

description:
Since I have been pregnant I only get sushi once or twice a month these days, and I have spent most of my sushi quota in the last seven months at Koo.  Their Tokyo Crunch roll and Best roll are to die for.  Spoonful of Happiness makes my husband drool.  Plus, they have always managed to seat us without a wait, even without reservations, even on a Friday night.

Added 4/08: the parents' perspective.  We made our reservation about 20 minutes before we showed up, and we were led to a table with a little "reserved" sign on it and a high chair all ready to go.  The woman who served us (who recognized us even though we go maybe once every month or two) went above and beyond, digging up a plastic kiddie cup and spoon for Mini-Me to bang on the table while we ate.  On the down side, there is NOWHERE to change a baby in the restroom - my husband reported changing the baby in the air while she was screaming.

Still our favorite sushi place.
author: Hypercycloid ..

description:
I've been pregnant for 9 months now, and as soon as I spit out my pup, I am going to Koo and eating LOTS AND LOTS OF Koo's fishy delights!!!  Had I known how difficult it would be to forgo the delights of Koo, I don't know if I would have signed up for this child rearing business!  I know I will enjoy it even more now that I have deprived myself.

first...A SPOONFUL OF HAPPINESS
then...Bring it!!
Mt. Fuji in closing
author: Erinn B.

description:
my favorite sushi spot in the city. very good quality fish. not overpriced. really good omakase. nice husband and wife team.

the only reason i give it 4 stars instead of 5 is because on one visit the cuts and the quality of the fish were not as good as on all of the other ones (still great though, just not as AMAZING as always)
author: Yevi A.

description:
Had a great meal here last night. Had the Unagi, Hamachi, Red Snapper 4pc Sashimi, Hotate Gai, Asparagus, Shiitake, and I think one other thing that I can't remember. Washed it all down with a bottle of Kikusui sake. Very nice.

Had to wait about 15 mins for a table. Mostly Asian clientele, which is a good sign. Had three chefs making the stuff. It was pretty fascinating watching them work their craft while we waited for our table.

Koo is away from the main restaurant section of the Inner Sunset. A bit quieter, but no less filled with appreciative guests. That said, we could hear each other easily.

Yummy. Must go again.
author: Steve R.

description: We went here a few times shortly after they opened.  It was very good and we appreciated the creativity in the menu.  However we haven't been back for a few years, so I guess it's not worth the drive.
author: David H.

description:
there are japanese people eating in here all the time, so it's gotta be good right?  

seriously, it's very tasty, very clean sushi.  my man is obsessed with the spoonful of happiness.  too rich and too adventurous for my tastes!

the nigiri specials are the way to go.  while they serve rolls, it's not a roll type of place.
author: Melissa Y.

description: im from the east coast and wanted to really try west coast sushi and at Koo i was not disapointed! there aztec roll was amazing and we had another roll i forget what it was called but it had lemon on top of it, it was out of this world. If you like tuna sushimi i recommend trying theirs. i was reading reviews about everyone loving the spoonfull of hapiness but i was unimpressed, maybe it was a little to japanese for my scottish ass.
author: Thomas T.

description:
Happy Valentine's Day!

As a pre-Valentine's Day dinner, we called in for reservations for Friday at 8pm for 2 people at the bar for omakase.

Decor:
* Intimate, charming and minimal.
* Beautifully decorated both inside and out.
* Koo stood out from the rest of the neighborhood.

Atmosphere:
* Dim lighting and soft music definitely made it an intimate affair but there were also a few groups as well.
* Main dining room was lively and energetic, while the sushi bar was much more relaxing.
* Sushi bar only sat 6.

Service:
* Extremely prompt, efficient, not overbearing and nice. With every new dish that was presented, a server came and quickly clear the last plates.
* Very accommodating as a group came in and left their luggage by the door where we put our jackets and bag. 
* Our hot tea was always refilled immediately.
* We sat right in the middle, in front of Kiyoshi (owner).
* He was polite, soft spoken and funny:) I liked him! Very sweet man who knows how to run a business and does it extremely well.
* As we finished our meal, a server dropped our plates and broke some next to us and apologized profusely. It was no biggie since accidents do happen:)

Food:
* Exotic, fresh and delicious!!
* Sashimi melted in my mouth, spiced with a bit of fresh wasabi.
* Think of all the nigiri you see at a restaurant -- yea, we didn't have that. We ate everything he had that night except your regular nigiri (maguro, sake, hamachi, tobiko, etc) and it was all exceptional and beyond.
  - oh toro: fatty and succulent
  - kamasu (barracuda): A slight smokey taste from the skin but it was very tasty and fresh
  - blue shrimp (raw): An interesting texture; I had a hard time getting my piece off the tail :) A slight shrimp flavor - good! Bf had another order.
  - baigai (sea snails) in a broth: 3 pieces of baigai, which were all very chewy but not overpowering. Subtle flavors with a rich, tasty broth.
  - tobiuo (flying fish - Not the eggs): If you think the eggs taste good, you should try the flying fish. I had 2 :)
  - tombo (albacore tuna from Kona - seared): delicious and fun to watch him sear it right in front of us!
  - sayori (needlefish): Slight texture but still melted in my mouth.
  - Sawara (spanish mackerel): I am not a fan of mackerel, though I still eat it from time to time. This one tasted like nothing I have ever tried. Slight flavor but delicious!
  - Plate of grilled Japanese eggplant, hamachi stuffed jalapeno and tuna tartare "taco": SO GOOD. PERIOD.
  - Spoonful of Happiness: DIVINE!! 2 spoons of HeavenInYourFreakinMouth accompanied by a shot of cold sake. We each had another (although we could have asked for 10 more!!).
* Bf finished a hot sake. The cold sake shots were smoooth!

Our bill was close to $200 (without tip) but worth every penny of it.

Tips:
- Another couple ordered omakase next to us and got a totally different menu but they had a much more precise taste. They will cater to whatever your preferences are.
- Parking is so hard to find so come a bit early.
- They close at 10:30 on Fridays but last call is at 10.
- He has other restaurants in SF (Ace Wasabi/Tokyo A GoGo) but Koo is more for nigiri/sashimi (since they have the best selection).
- They have a dessert menu and one of them changes every month!! This month was creme brulee:)
- I can't comment on the taste of the rolls but they all looked delicious!!

We had the best time at Koo! It's definitely now our favorite sushi place:) When we were talking to Kiyoshi, he said he enjoys making people happy with his food and does so without judging you, because he knows that each person has their own specific tastes. Koo is such a delightful, delicious, authentic Japanese restaurant. We walked away full and totally satisfied with the overall experience.

I fell in love with Koo. We will be back!! : )
author: T L.

description: Finally a great Japanese restaurant in SF that doesn't cost a fortune for little portion! Everything we ordered was excellent.  We got there a little before 7 and they had their happy hour menu.  Handrolls for $4 and appetizers and sake for $5.  We also ordered their spoonful of happiness which was an excellent creation.  It's a must try.  We also had their grilled eggplant, taro roll, black cod, and a Hawaiian wrapped crab and mango which I thinks is their best.  We also ordered their chocolate cake "Mt. Fiji" which I thought was too sweet but pairing with ginger gelato was great.  The gelato has a nice flavor.  The mochi is also great.  Will definitely return!
author: Crystal L.

description: Spoonful of Happiness. Toro sushi. Butterfish. Uni. Need I say more. Everything was excellent. Aside from being sort of too dim, I give this place my stamp of approval. Will return....soon.
author: Alex C.

description: I was not impressed with this place.  It took 45 minutes for 4 handrolls to be brought out.  The fish was very fresh and delicious, but pretty pricey.  I ordered the tempura handroll, U2 roll, and Azteca.  They were just meh.  Nothing special, just pricey.  Sadly, they were out the spoonful of happiness.  (That's what they told us)BUT, lo and behold we saw a few tables that came in after us getting spoons and shots of sake, so maybe they got more somehow?  I don't know.  I don't think I'll be going back to Koo.  Back to my quest of finding the perfect sushi joint!
author: Cheryl L.

description: Absolutely the best sushi I've ever had at a delightful restaurant full of talented sushi chefs. We went last night after - by chance - and snagged two seats at the sushi bar. We ordered omakase (chef's selection) and were treated to a sinfully yummy selection of fish, crustaceans and other yummy goodness. Can't wait to go back.
author: Stacey W.

description: I visited Koo to last night to have a quick bite before working for the evening. I arrived at 5:23 PM. The restaurant was empty except for a table-full of staff who were drinking and laughing together. I asked "when do you open?" and was told "we open in 7 minutes." I asked if I could sit at a table along the wall in the back corner and do a little work until they were ready to open and she said "absolutely not" and insisted that I leave the restaurant immediately. How totally pathetic, rude, and unnecessary.
author: Eater S.

description:
I read an article in the LA Times a couple of months back that said less than 10% of the Japanese restaurants in California are owned and operated by Japanese. In SF, it's gotta be less than 5%. So, imagine my surprise when I walked in and was greeted by Japanese sushi chefs and waitresses. I knew I was in for a treat. 

I enjoyed Koo quite a bit. We ate there on a Saturday night and expected a long wait (or to be shown the door), but that simply wasn't the case. We were told 30 minutes and waited about 10.  The staff was very friendly and accommodating. I ordered the sushi combination and asked the waitress to recommend a few rolls. I also asked her to have the chef make a few extra orders of nigiri of his choosing.  I was very impressed.  This will probably be my new spot for sushi in SF. I  docked one star for the price as I thought it was a bit expensive vs. comparable restaurants in other areas of California. But if I need a sushi fix in SF, this is where I'll be.
author: Phil S.

description: 4.5 stars. The fish was impressive! Very fresh and good flavor, especially in comparison to my last experience at Ebisu. Uni, sake, himachi, amberjack, red snapper!! Excellent. Rolls aren't usually how I judge a sushi place, but their rolls were quite good also (for my timid sushi-novice parents). They didn't do the spoon full of happiness as take-out, so that will be on my list for next time! Koo booted Ebisu out my list of favorites :).
author: Cammy H.

description: probably the best traditional sushi/nigiri place in SF.  better than ino sushi; better than sebo.
author: woojin k.

description: i was disappointed with our dinner tonite because the sushi was sub par. the fiance liked the spoonful of happiness (but really just the spoonful of uni). i thought the kumomoto oysters were on the fishy side. the aji nigiri and the hirame with ponzu sauce were just ok. even the rice on the sushi was too hard. it's probably safe to say that we won't be coming back anytime soon. we will stick with ino for our sushi and kappa for our japanese dishes. too bad.
author: Helen Y.

description: Fresh fish, specials based on what's good, the best app ever (spoon of happiness).  Sashimi, nigiri, rolls are all good, as well as non-sushi Japanese fare.  Consistently ranked in the tops in SF.
author: Chad M.

description:
small plates: eggplant, stuffed jalapenos ... YUM
entrees:  miso glazed black cod ... DELICIOUS
sushi: hamachi .. EXCELLENT
dessert: ginger ice-cream, a little different, but I enjoyed it.

Great food, great service.
author: My N.

description: This is one of my favorite restaurant! I have been here numerous times and they have never failed to satisfy me. My favorite out of all is the crab hand roll! It is sooo good! This is definitely one of the best Japanese restaurant in the bay area! a MUST try!
author: Linda Y.

description:
If only there was a no star review......I have washed my hands 4 times and they still smell of bad fish.
My wife and I have been trying to get over to Koo since we moved to the area in July. Encouraged by the great reviews on Yelp, we finally made it in tonight.
I can only assume that we made it in on an off night...This place was HORRIBLE. For those that know me, I am an overwhelmingly positive person, prone to rate everything as "the best....ever" that said, there was NOTHING positive about the sushi at Koo. It was easily the worst, oldest and least cared about fish I have encountered since my last visit to Long John Silver's in '84. The service was very friendly, but that actually made it worse. They had to know how bad their product was. It was like someone smiling in your face while they peed into your cola.
I cannot imagine that anyone who appreciates sushi could give this place a decent review. Unless,again, we just caught them on a REALLY bad night. Which is possible as our chef  looked embarrassed as he put each course in front of us....And he should have been.
The key to any sushi place is the fish, and the bottom line is that Koo's fish was old and clearly had been frozen for way too long. If they cared about their customers at all, they would have done the honorable thing and thrown their last shipment out.
They should be ashamed of what they are selling. The chefs clearly know better and yet still sold it to us any way.
author: Jason T.

description: I went to Koo a blind date. It was a spot I pick after I saw all the good Yelp reviews. This place is really intimate and cozy. The roll are delicious, we also had the Saki which was quite good. I had a dragon roll. For desert we had the Mt. Fuji which is Chocolate cake stuffed with white chocolate mousse and a side of green tea gelato. Yummy!
author: Leslie A.

description:
What is the matter with some of these Yelpers?!    How about "Mona n"  ??  I HAVE to write just to respond to her outragiously tired and long winded "review" for a meal!  Geez!  Did someone not get the recognition she craved in english class?  She must be friends with "vivi n" --who is equally full of herself and shares the similar tired and long winded style of not saying much.

By the way- great food in a great neighborhood.
author: Katy W.

description:
A friend recommended this place as the best sushi place in SF so we went and tried it out.  The tempura was just right - light, crispy, and you could savor the favor of the vegetables.  Many times you'll just be tasting deep fried bread.  It was a very good sign.  The cuts selected for the sashimi had a good soft texture and the soy sauce wasn't overbearing.  Nothing particularly unique about the various sushi rolls that we ordered.  But then I tried my sushi yardstick and the Unagi was excellent.  Delicate, melts in your mouth.  Yum.

Decor was simple, modern Japanese American styling.  Good talkable atmosphere.  A bit crowded for space (you're right by your neighbors and don't try to move your seat back too far unless you want to bump heads with the guy behind you).

So while I'm not ready to brand this place as the best sushi place in SF, it's certainly up there.
author: Dave L.

description: koo-wabunga dudes!  Good sushi splinter.  lets be honest, not the best sushi in sf, but still really good stuff.  I really like those thingies they put in that spoon, it's expensive, but it's really worth it, so interesting.
author: christopher h.

description: This restaurant was great (3 stars is not a diss!), but there were a number of things that made it less than perfect. One, parking was horrific. I'm not from San Francisco, so I'm not used to driving around blocks and blocks looking for street parking, which we finally found 3 blocks down from the restaurant. We ordered toro, hamachi, ikura sushi, scallop hand roll, shrimp and scallop dumplings, and a roll (can't remember the name, but it had shrimp tempura in it). I also had a glass of plum sake. Everything tasted good, but I must admit I have had better. Our waitress also forgot about our dumplings and hooked me up with another glass of sake, though I wish she wouldve just given us complementary dumplings. (the dumplings weren't even that great). Aside from that though, the staff was very nice and courteous. Seems like a good place to come for a date or with friends and family.
author: Yuree N.

description:
gastronomically blissful....will write more when i'm done "spooning".  please be patient as it may last for a few days....    

don't. laugh.    if you ate here, you'd be spooning too!
___________________________________________

What's HOT & what's not at Koo? 

Spoonful of happiness
       This was everyone's favorite for the night  Spoonful of happiness is actually 2 spoonfuls of happiness.  In one spoon: uni, quail egg, tobiko with ponzu sauce.  In another: ankimo wrapped with whitefish and truffle oil.  This delightful appetizer comes with a shot of sake - you are suppose to have one spoonful, take in some of the sake, and do the same for the second spoonful.  The sake helps to clean your palate after each spoonful so you could fully enjoy each of the flavors.  Oh so heavenly!  
      Spoonful of happiness is like foreplay.  I understand why the chefs thought it would be perfect as an appetizer, but I feel it could very well be something you could end the night with too. It's not just wam bam, thank you ma'm.  Hence, my 5 days of spooning  :)  
 
Uni Nigiri 
We originally had 2 orders, but we added an extra order so that we each could have an order of uni to ourselves.  If you've never had uni before or had one bad tasting of uni and want to give it a second chance....come here, this is what uni should taste like.  After Live Sushi, I really needed this to re-affirm my love for uni.  Uni love rekindled.  

Hottegai scallops from Japan
Unlike some of the previous scallops I've had, this one does not smell, at all.  It's big, thick, delicious and most importantly fresh!

Hamachi sashimi 
Hamachi is my favorite fish.  I order it 90% of the time.  Sashimi style/over rice.  It never fails to satisfy my tummy.  Our hamachi is clearly sashimi grade, there is no fishy scent whatsoever, and when you push on it, it's got a firm bounce.  Just like men, I hate mushy - I always send it back.    

Mirugai (local geoduck)
It's quite easy to prepare mirugai in the comforts of your own home, sashimi or lightly stir fried.  I haven't had it in a while, but my love for mirugai is still going strong! 

Azteca roll
This (baked) roll is wrapped a little loose, but the flavors....oh my god....the inside is filled with crab, avocado, gobo and cucumber wrapped in white fish....the outside is topped with a thinly slice of jalapeno with spicy mayo and tobiko.  It's the first time a roll just melts in my mouth.  YUMmmm....    

Miso marinated black cod
Light and buttery, over a bed of bok choy and fried tofu.  Miso love this dish!  

Mt. Fuji
You have to make sure you leave room for dessert!  If you are absolutely full and just thinking of sharing ONE dessert, this would be IT.  This chocolate cake stuffed with white chocolate mouse might be a little rich for some but I absolutely loved it.  An order of ginger gelato was the perfect complement to this dessert, it came with homebaked cookies.    

(The 8 items above are my favorites of the night, the ones listed below weren't too bad, but I would rather save the room to try something new next time.)

Ankimo
Ever since I've had ankimo at Kabuto, I've compared every ankimo dish to that.  The one here is not seared - it is chopped up into little mini squares and spread on top of rice, wrapped with seaweed.  Not bad, but not what I was hoping for.  

Flyfish from japan
I remember seeing a whole school of this on my Mexican Riviera cruise, and have always wondered what flyfish tasted like.  It reminds me of red snapper except the meat is a little finer.

Godzilla tofu
I'm 50/50 about this dish.  The menu said it is crispy tofu with spicy garlic mayo.  It looks crispy, but once you bite into it, it's a little chewy on the outside and silky soft on the inside.  I like the inside more than the outside.  Personality is more important than looks.

Stuffed grilled jalapeno
I like my grilled stuff, but this one was a little bit too charred for my taste.  It gave me an instant pimple in my throat but it did not deter me from stuffing my face for the remainder of the night.  This is just grounded hamachi stuffed into a jalapeno, grilled, and you dip it with lime aioli.  Of all the dishes we had, I would say that this was my least favorite, and given the chance, I would probably not order it again.  

Ginger gelato
I'm not a fan of ginger, but the gelato was good.  I wouldn't order this alone, but it was the perfect complement for our Mt. Fuji.    

Cheesecake
Mousse topped with some fruity jelly-like thing on top.  It was missing something, perhaps some lavendar/roasted sesame.  I only had two spoonfuls of it - it's quite forgettable.  

Who needs a fork when you can spoon?  Def comin' back and sitting at the bar!  :D
author: Paulina C.

description:
my oh my - this is the real deal here. 

first off; the spoonfull of happiness was actually 2 spoonfulls; 1 filled with a uni and quail egg (this was ma-ma...) but the other spoonful a truly delicious  spoonful of ankimo wrapped with whitefish, white truffle-oil ponzu.  you slurp this down in between sips of chilled sake.  what an taste sensory experience!

the oh-toro and mackerel sushi from japan were like butter in my mouth. divine.
 
the rolls were good; california roll and the best roll were awesome.  I would skip the soft shelled crab roll - after such exquisite food taste, the overpowering deep fried taste was kinda of slumming it.

the bill came up to about $100 for 2 of us - not your everyday kinda place but certainly a place to impress that special someone.
author: Teresa T.

description: Found it by word of mouth--return by taste of same. Nice room, super service, no crowd, great food cheap enough to stuff yourself silly. I usually stick to my standbys to keep some change in my pocket, but these prices invite exploration. Everything was exquisite, especially the Aji and Hotate.
