The "Tokyo Crunch" roll was a sensory experience to be relished. I usually skip dessert but the little pyramid of white chocolate mousse-filled chocolate cake for $3 was irresistable. Add a scoop of white ginger gelato ($1.50) for an awesome ying-yang flavor to savor on the much needed walk afterward.
author: Andy R.

description: Quiet little place.  I really loved the sushi here.  It's also off the beaten path, which I like.  The prices are really good, compared to what I usually pay for this kind of food.  $5.00 for a shrimp tempura roll...right on!  And the portions are pretty decent, too.  Try the Mt. Fuji chocolate cake with the white chocolate mousse filling and ginger gelato...see what you're missing?
author: Kristina R.

description:
Wow, wow, wow!  I think I've discovered a new regular neighborhood gem when I have sashimi and sushi cravings.  I've heard great things about this place but we usually don't feel like venturing to this side of the park.  Now I think I will be coming to the sunset side much more often.  

We came here late Friday night on a whim.  I had already eaten a little bit for dinner but was still hungry and had been craving some awesome nigiri for awhile.  When we walked, we were serendipitously seated in front of the owner at the sushi bar.  I had no idea until near the end of the meal that he was the owner.  He's a very unassuming and nice man and offered great advice on fish picks.  

I ordered my usual favs of amaebi and hotate (a special one that was shipped fresh from hokkaido,) a blue shrimp nigiri I have never tried, the scrumptious uni from mendocino, a spider roll that had a huge crab in it, anago,  and Kiyoshi gave us a complimentary salmon sushi dish mixed w/ miso sauce and onions.  All were spectacular and a great value considering the price.  An order of amaebi or uni nigiri was $6.50.  I usually pay more for much lesser quality.  My girlfriend, who never will eat uni, tried it here and loved it.  If you're feeling like a roll, you must try the spider.  The crab IS HUGE, fried lightly so it's not too crispy, and the best I've ever had.  

From speaking with Kiyoshi (http://www.sushikoo.com/pages/about.html), he's told me his career has progressed like my sushi eating habits.  I started off with rolls and then learned to appreciate the fresh fish and nigiri from my hawaiian friend who has great taste.  He also started his restaurant career as a partner as ace wasabi designing rolls for the menu, then moved on to start Tokyo Go-Go in the mission, and now he told me the focus of his latest restaurant here is on the fresh fish.  He has a daily menu that changes based on what good stuff his suppliers have and what he requests from Japan so you'll never get bored of the same old stuff here.  I wanted to try some other nigiri I had never seen anywhere else like the flying fish and matsuwasa (sp??) but we had to leave unfortunately.  He also recommended the "spoonful of happiness" if you're a a fresh fish fan.  I'm looking forward to a whole meal of happiness next time I'm here.
  
A couple of side notes:
1) There were a good amount of Japanese dining here.  That's always a great indicator for me of any type of restaurant.
2) I discovered he's friends and golf buddies with owners of some of my other fav japanese restaurants in the city - Oyaji and Tekka.  I guess the "birds of a feather flock together" saying applies with awesome sushi proprietors like it does with hot women.    ;P

DSKO favs: EVERYTHING!!
author: Dik Shun K.

description:
One of the few Japanese restaurants that I've been to where the tables don't smell like soy sauce or wet rags.  I would describe this place as a tapas & sushi restaurant (you won't find chicken teri here).  

My husband and I  had the fried smelt, artichoke, grilled sardines, hamachi sashimi, hamachi kama , large echigo beer & two bowls of rice for $66 (including tip).  The menu was limited, but everything was delish.  The service was attentive and courteous.
author: MELLY D.

description: Great little gem of a restaurant hiding out in the Sunset.  I am always trying to find a great sushi place, and this is one of them.  If you are a man, or a woman for that matter, this is a nice date place.  The atmosphere is quaint and romantic, with dim lighting and sparse, authentic decor.  They have a long sake list.  Try the spoonful of happiness, which has a quail egg in spoon.
author: apple r.

description:
been wanting to try this place for awhile and was finally able to check it out this past weekend. cute, little place, a block away from ten. breakdown of our order:

-spoonful of happiness: i LOVED the uni/quail egg one (you get 2 spoons w/ the one i mentioned and the other, monk fish pate wrapped w/ white fish - looked and tasted like liver, not so good)
-dynamite hand roll: i thought it was supposed to be spicy? eh, had much much better
-tokyo crunch: yelpers recommended this but i didn't think it was all that great. again...thought it was suppose to have some spicyness to it?
-spicy tuna: definitely not spicy enough
-japanese eggplant: decent
-hamachi sashimi: fresh!

overall it wasn't the best sushi i've had but when you've had good, fresh sushi...you become a sushi snob (much like any other food). their sushi seems pretty fresh but the rolls weren't flavorful enough for me BUT the 4 stars do go to the spoonful of happiness (didn't think i liked uni before but i guess fresh uni makes a BIG difference) and their mt. fuji (chocolate cake w/ white chocolate mousse and green tea gelato)....YUM YUM YUM!!! ok this alone deserves 5 stars! if i lived around here, i would go there everyday to get this! it looks like chocolate cake but tastes like heavenly truffles!!! iinhaled mine and started eyeing my friends hoping she wouldn't finish...i could have ordered another! A+ service!
author: Jane Y.

description:
Before I head to SoCal, I decided to have a nice dinner with my kid sister who lives in SF.  I've heard good things about Koo, so chose this place not just for me to try a restaurant that is new to me, but also to chat with her in person.

The interior is the mix of traditional Japanese architecture and modern look, with black-painted wooden joists and purple ceiling.  The color purple was considered expensive because of dye technique until recently, so the use of that color in the architecture is modern.

I'm glad that I reserved for two persons beforehand, because when the head waitress found my name on their reservation list, there were several groups at the 6 p.m. block.  Good that those without reservation still were able to sit down relatively quickly though.

We first ordered Bamboo Tower, Shichimi Crusted Tuna and Marinated Wild Mushroom, and Japanese Eggplant Dengaku.  Bamboo Tower is a salad with mizuna (similar to watercress?) and chopped seafood.  The taste was mild without the dressing overwhelming the fresh taste of mizuna.  Seafood adds nice contrast on texture and flavor.  Crusted tuna had a bit too much of shichimi (mixed spice), but raspberry sauce made the dish interesting.  Maybe I should've eaten with marinated mushroom to balance things out.  The eggplant was nice as expected.

Then we started ordering sushi.  I ordered veggie combo because using only veggie to sushi appealed to me.  The tempura roll was ok, as I usually don't care too much about eating tempura and sushi rice together.  Asparagus, cucumber, and sweet potato were mild in taste.  My sister ate avocado nigiri, and commented it was nice as expected.  I told her that (correct me if I'm wrong) avocado was first used by a Japanese sushi chef in the US to substitute fatty tuna.  Asparagus nigiri was not bad at all, but eggplant one pleasantly surprised me with its smooth, viscous texture and grilled flavor.  Too bad that the eggplant had lots of oil to make that texture, because when I ordered the eggplant nigiri separately, the second one had me enough with oil.  More conventional nigiri's (kanpachi, ikura, tobiuo - flying fish, mackeral, and scallop) were all good, although not outstanding.  I was glad to eat tobiuo because of its subtle taste and bouncy texture.

My kid sister liked the dinner, but wanted to save some room for dessert.  So she ordered mochi ice while I ordered ice cream crape with fuji apple.  She commented and I agreed that the ice pretty much was from Trader Joe's or its equivalent.  The crape was nice, not too sweet.  For $4, they were in a very good value.

Because we ordered quite a bit of sushi, the bill was a little higher than I expected.  I kinda wished they had some rice dishes with fish on top so I could've satisfied my appetite that way and ordered fewer nigiri's.  Oh well, what mattered the most was that my sister and I chatted a lot to keep in touch while enjoying these dishes.  The relaxing and adequately lively (not too much so that we had to scream to each other) atmosphere even as the restaurant was filling up helped us converse comfortably.

One more thing to comment.  I cannot praise this restaurant enough to have that veggie sushi combo for curious minds like me to try something new, and vegetarians who cannot otherwise try good sushi except conventional and often boring cucumber and pickle rolls.  More traditional sushi places would discourage vegetarians, and given the diversity within SF, it's definitely nice to have at least one sushi place that serves veggie nigiri's and encourages vegetarians to come to Japanese restaurants.
author: Tak K.

description: Probably the best and freshest sushi in San Francisco, maybe that I've ever had.  A liiiiiiittle pricey, but there is a price for quality food.  They have a rediculous list of sashimi to order from, and the chefs specials are always amazing.  If you order the "Spoon full of happiness"  you might not ever eat sushi at another place again.  ITS ONLY 10$ WHAAAAAAAT?!?!?!  Anyone who gives this place a bad review knows NOTHING about sushi!  Ive been eating sushi all over California since 8 years old, this is as good as it gets.
author: Brandon H.

description:
I am koo koo for Koo. Oh yes, after my first visit to Koo last weekend, I am a fan. Living in the 9th and Irving area previously, I've walked by this japanese restaurant many times and have intended to check it out. The Inner Sunset certainly hasn't let me down in terms of japanese food - with Kazu on Irving as one of my favorite sushi joints in the city. But, I'm often skeptical about "trendy" looking japanese restaurants - convinced that the sushi will only come in roll form (and drizzled with tons of fancy dressings) and that it'll be far from "authentic" (so says this 4th generation Japanese girl :) ). That was my fear walking into Koo last Friday. But, let me break down why Koo is now one of my favorite japanese dining experiences in San Francisco.

- Service was excellent and waitstaff are all nihonjin which seems to offer up added credibility.
- Decor is simple, comfortable and elegant all at the same time. Perfect for a dinner date or a meal with the in-laws.
- Food, oh the food, where do I start. If you aren't too picky, love variety and have $50 to splurge on your dinner, I'd highly recommend the omakase (chef's choice). We actually asked for the omakase but the waitress said that we needed to note that request when making reservations (which we actually made only an hour before). BUT, since we were 1st time customers, they could offer us a variety of dishes to try for $50. DONE. Here's my quick take on the 7 course meal:

*Salmon sashimi with onions - delicate, delicious and makes me ready for more
*Spoonful of Happiness - HOLY SH*T. The best spoon(s) full of happiness EVER - accompanied by a shot of sake. The TWO spoons include: 1) uni, raw quail egg and some yummy sauce 2) ankimo (monkfish liver) wrapped in sashimi of some sort with white truffle sauce. HEAVEN. I'd definitely order this off the menu.
*Assorted sashimi (about 8 pieces) - Up with the best of SF. Fresh, nice slices. Hamachi was out of this world and the FRESH wasabi is ...wow...
*Grilled foods - Grilled eggplant, jalapeno stuffed with hamachi, fried tofu ....eh, give me more spoonfuls of happiness!
*Fish collar(s) - This is super delicate and tasty part of the fish. We had TWO collars one of which was black cod. DELICIOUS. Highly recommended if you can maneuver your way through fish bones with chop sticks.
*And to finish: nigiri and rolls - Delicious, fresh and unique. But, by this time, I was stuffed!

I am not sure if it was the assortment of yummy dishes, the awesome bottle of sake or if the spoonful of happiness had a secret ingredient...but Koo has it going on. Thank you for a wonderful experience, Koo, I will be back.
author: Deann M.

description:
authentic, elegant, mouth-watering delicious.

i was born and raised in japan and hawaii and am no stranger to sushi.  this is the one sushi restaurant in the city (other than oyaji for a more boysterous night of drinking and eating) where i would happily and un-embarrasingly bring my relatives from japan.  in fact, i've taken my tokyo-bred mother here a few times and she has raved.  which is not an easy feat.

the spoonful of happiness is a must.  as are the oysters on a half shell if available - small, firm and briny touched with momijioroshi (a grated daikon and red pepper condiment) and ponzu.  i'm also a fan of the usuzukuri (paper-thin sliced hirame) and ankimo (monkfish liver).

the sushi here has class.  if you go, you'll see what i mean.  nigiri is made with small portions of rice, drapped with fresh cuts of fish.  simple rolls that aren't overstuffed or oversauced.  eating here really has a peaceful effect on you.  almost zen-like.  

you will leave here with a happy stomach and a smile playing on your lips.
author: Reina M.

description: Good sushi, good value in casual yet elegant setting.  They serve true Japanese style sushi here, including a few selections flown in from the Japan area.  I would say this is one of the three best sushi restaurants (from a purists' standpoint) in San Francisco.
author: J L.

description: My original post was deleted!  WTF?  Not only did I get rejected for Elite 2009 but they also erased my review for Koo.  Bastards.  I am gonna quit soon.  But for now Koo is one of my favorite Japanese restaurants in SF.  Everything is tasty and fresh.  It was good enough for me to bring my fat dad.  He really enjoyed the spoonful of happiness cuz it came with sake.  Fat ass.  I love the tuna and salmon tartar with shrimp chips.  The hamachi Kama and godzilla tofu are also raelly good.  Pretty much everything I've eaten here is good.  This a great place to take your manatee.
author: Fatty A.

description:
THE PLACE:
Cozy little date place.

THE SERVICE:
Decent, they didn't bring out the soup (I guess he forgot) until I reminded him. 

If you're in the sunset and need a nice place to take a special lady/guy friend, I would recommend this place. 

THE BATHROOM:
Wow. I ended up using the bathroom twice. The first time I went I was struck by the volcano above the urinal and then I noticed the Zeitgeist review right next to the urinal. I don't think the owner thought about associating reading of a review of the restaurant with going to the bathroom (I think they should rethink this one). There was no sink in the bathroom so I was confused and went back to my table without washing my hands (gimme a break here). The next time I used the bathroom I found the sink which was outside the toilet to the right (maybe the alcohol effected my ability to find the sink the first time). Anyways, they had an automated hand towel dispenser which I thought was going to eat my hand. It took me a while to figure out there was no lever so I put my hand on it trying to find a lever and all of a sudden it started to move. Scared the shit out me. Anyways, all in all an OK bathroom experience.
author: Michael S.

description: Koo was pretty coo. Fresh fish, interesting combinations. A bit pricey, especially for the student-centered Inner Sunset, but the taste is worth the extra Jackson.
author: Kel S.

description: My friends and I went to Koo the other night, and we were really excited to eat there after hearing so many good things... Well, we get there and the host tells us 20 minutes. So we put our names in and wait 20 minutes, and he says, "Oh, I'm sorry, I gave your table away. Misunderstanding. Then he says, "10 minutes." So we wait 30 minutes, and he says, "Oh, sorry. Only 10 more minutes." Are you kidding me? At that point we said "screw Koo" and went to Ten down the street. The atmosphere was better, and their service was amazing. It can't get much worse than the service at Koo.
author: Kevin O.

description:
for the most part, koo is good but nothing to write home about. the sushi is decent though a bit small, the service and ambiance aren't memorable, but its one redeeming factor is the spoonful of happiness.

before koo, i hated uni. it tasted like the armpit of the ocean to me. i had tried it in several different places, always hoping to understand why people liked the foamy orange thing so much. yet over and over again, i was disappointed. even eating uni at its freshest at the fish market in tokyo at dawn still made me want to vomit in the back of my mouth.

i dream about the spoonful of happiness in my sleep. i would go back just for those 2 spoonfuls, that against all odds, make me a fan of uni.

(according to the menu, the spoonful of happiness contains a spoonful of uni, quail egg, tobiko, ponzu & ankimo wrapped with whitefish, truffle-oil &  a shot of chilled sake)

however, the shichimi crusted tuna and marinated wild mushroom with rasberry sauce was soooo disappointing. the description sounded divine, and i wanted more than anything to like it. but, as many things in life, it sounded better than it was in reality.

i would go back to koo just for the spoonful of happiness, but nothing else.
author: Jenni B.

description: Love the people here.  They are extremely friendly and do their best to accommodate you, despite being so busy.  When my wife and I went there on a busy night without reservations, they took our cell phone number and gave us a buzz when a table opened up.  That freed us up to go up the street for a pre-dinner cocktail vs. languishing in the waiting area like other busy restaurants make you do.  The fish is top notch.  Very fresh.  They also have some interesting sakes and last time I was there they had beer that was actually from Japan (most is brewed in Canada under license from the Japanese brewers).
author: Jason S.

description: Pretty good sushi but I'm only giving this place 2 stars for complete lack of originality. I understand the chef came from Tokyo a go-go but it's a little ridiculous that he stole the WHOLE menu from them and the prices were the same.  I'd rather go to Tokyo or Ace's for the exact same rolls (same in quality as well) but funkier ambiance. Servers were really nice but slow.
author: Tanger T.

description: Soooooo good!  Ill totally be back!  Super fresh fish.  Great flavor combinations and a great non traditional menu.  If you are wanting some gourmet sushi at a decent price, come here.  Great service, amazing food, my new addiction...
author: Lindsay C.

description: Wow, this place truly is a gem! Nice people and great sushi! I really enjoy their "Best Roll" which has a tangy slice of lemon on top.
author: Ericka A.

description: The sashimi here is among the best I've had, ever.  My favorites from the menu include the abalone sashimi and the monkfish liver, which unfortunately isn't always available.  This place is truly amazingly delicious, and not just another gimmicky date-night sushi joint like those that have saturated this town.  A down side is that the portions are quite minimal and the price is quite high, but that is the case when it comes to quality sushi.
author: Renee K.

description:
Alot of people seem to have a misconception of koo and koo sort of has a misconception of itself also.   I'll get straight to the point.  Similar to other sushi places in the city like Murasaki, Koo is known for their NIGIRI yes NIGIRI.  NOT ROLLS for you sushi amateurs.   Although they do have a select number of rolls (some of them being very delicious like the best roll) I highly recommend to order just nigiri sushi here.  It's also kind of obvious especially when they concenrate so hard to have a wide assortment of imported special nigiri selections every night.   Whenever I eat at koo I don't even look at their regular menu, I carefully browse through the paper print out which if you're lucky you'll have a selection at both rare and exotic deliciousnesses from the ocean.   For example have you ever had New Caledonia shrimp?  Compared to the lifeless rubbery white and pink striped crap you usually get at the average sushi bar these days Caledonia shrimp will either 1) make you a shrimp lover or 2) send you straight to an orgasm without foreplay.   But what about amaebi you ask?  Well Koo's New Caledonia shrimp has the subtle sweetness and umami flavors thats known with amaebi but with the impact thats probably 20 times stronger.   But enough about this one elusive taste that can only be found at koo for all i know of.   They usually have chu-toro on that print out too.  Chu-toro is like the A - grade piece of toro, (A is o-toro, and A+ comes from a miraculous piece of o-toro).   I have never seen O-toro at koo but their chu-toro can be hit or miss, sometimes its like an A, other times its like a B+ almost.   But those of you that have been eating at the average sushi bar in SF are most likely eating toro thats not even close to the freshness of koo's.   

But if you must get a roll.  I highly recommend the best roll.  A roll that has asparagus tempura and on top is salmon and on top of that is lemon.  Now let me describe how masterful this combination is.  The taste of asparagus actually goes quite well with the taste of oil, so the fact that its fried enhances its taste, but wait a second doesnt salmon have a pretty high fatty content why yes it does which bring harmony to the tempura asparagus and salmon.  But wait the taste of oil lingering in my mouth is gross, thats where the simplicity of a sliver of lemon comes in to bring a complex series of tastes that makes the best roll best.  

Koo if you're reading this just continue to concentrate on your nigiri sushi and sashimi and let places like sushi house in oakland take care of the sushi roll whores.
author: Tomo S.

description: I read the review in SF Gate, and went in full anticipation of amazing rolls. I think my expectations were too high, because I was totally disappointed. I went the day the article came out, on my first date with my guy, and neither one of us were impressed with anything we ordered. Don't think I will go back.
author: Marina K.

description: I only came here cause of the high yelp reviews. All the sashimi we ordered were mouth watering!   I crave, crave, and crave for more. We each got a order of the spoonful of Happiness.  I loved it!  My bf commented, "wow, the sake is so smooth!"  I had no idea that it came with sake. For the Catch of the day, we ordered the scallop, blue shrimp, and sea snail.  The sea snail was alright.  I had to order my favorite amaebi, it was delicious. We also got the sashimi combo...the salmon was amazingly fresh.  We had the black cod as a warm dish. The bf loved it.  For dessert, I had the mochis with the cookies.  The cookies were really crispy!  I would definitely come back again.  This place took a big dent out of my bf's wallet.
author: con c.

description: From the previous chef/business partner of Ace Wasabi and Tokyo GoGo, Koo would be one of my first picks for sushi in the Sunset (ie I like it better then Ebisu and Kiki). We had the tuna sashimi, spicy tuna roll and spider roll which were all pretty good. The mixed green salad with ginger soy vinaigrette was also good. The hamachi stuffed jalapeno appetizer sounded like a good idea but I was surprised when it came out with the hamachi cooked. I think the dish would've tasted better with raw hamachi inside. The decor is simple and understated. The ambiance is low key and quiet in contrast to Ace Wasabi.
author: Trinh T.

description: We came here on wednesday night around 7pm and we got a nice parking right in front of the restaurant so that was very convient. The place wasn't packed and wasn't empty. It was half and half. We got seated right away for 2 people. The waitress that was at the front was very nice and kind. They offered a wide variety of different foods available. Me and my friend ordered the spider roll, dragon roll, inari, and the tempura shrimp, and I got a sprite while she got water. The drinks came by fast. When we got our food, they placed it all in one plate. I thought that was odd. The waiter told us that our tempura was in the rolls and cut up. The unagi on the dragon roll was really fresh and delicious. The sushi was yummy and tasty. We thought that was interesting how they made the tempura that way. The bill turned out to be $40, it wasnt too bad.
author: Claudia M.

description: I don't usually get to eat the sushi I love because of a moderate case of gout but I splurged this night at Koo. The sushi was delicious! We had the fresh toro(tuna) which really melts in your mouth and the fresh hotate(scallops) which were also good. The amaebi(raw sweet shrimp), another one of my favorites, was also very fresh and delicious. They best dish we had though was the spoon-full of happiness. I would go back just for that appy. I didn't care for the calamari much at all. It's really an out of place dish on an exquisite menu. The fried tofu was just ok to me but others might like it. It's kinda expensive though. But it's worth it.
author: Johnny J.

description: Disappointing.  I was expecting great things with the Tokyo Go Go pedigree, and from the reviews.  While having many of the same rolls that make the Mission restaurant a stand-out, that's where the similarities end.  Everything was just mediocre.  You know you're in trouble when the best thing is the California roll.  As my dining partner and I had just been to T-G-G for his birthday on Tuesday, we thought, we'd follow it up with more fish fantastic-ness on Friday.  Ugh.  When you're spending over 100 bones, expect better.  Much better.
author: darla s.

description: Legit Japanese restaurant with authentic sushi and dishes.  Coming from a sushi lover who used to live in Tokyo this is a great restaurant, friendly wait staff.  Make reservations beforehand as they can often be booked on weekends and Thursday nights.
author: Dave L.

description:
Absolutely the BEST Sushi I have ever had. 

And they have a great sake menu- try the Kikusui sake to start, light refreshing. 

And their appetizers rule:
-Tuna and Salmon Tartare- -very clever little chips + guac dish, delicious!
-Marinated Artichoke- -to die for, lemony, grilled yummyness.
-Steamed Scallop & Shrimp Dumpling--with mustard and some red sauce dotted along the plate, tangy, sweet, tender, downright heavenly.
-Miso Marinated Black Cod--ok, this was rockin, light, fluffy with an incredible sauce. 

Then I just usually order the sake or nigiri sashimi--like butter. 

Almost forgot desert, Mt .Fuji-Warm--chocolate cake stuffed with white mousse, or was that vanilla ice cream? dunno, don't care. so good. 

* Make sure to get reservations
author: Boheme P.

description:
Koo is a gem. We sat at the sushi bar and initially ordered from the menu and specials, but then started getting so tempted from watching the chefs preparations in front of us, and ended up ordering additional items. 

What we had: 
-Spicy scallop roll -- Not on the menu but they made one for us. Sooo good. 
-Hamachi sashimi -- Extremely high quality fish and served with *real* wasabi, not the stuff from powder. A mark of a good sushi place. 
-Spoonfuls of happiness: Spoonful of Uni, Quail Egg, Tobiko, Ponzu & Ankimo wrapped with whitefish, Truffle-Oil & a shot of chilled Sake. This was one we saw someone else get and it looked so impressive we had to try it. It's too spoons, each with a little bite. The main ingredient in one is monkfish liver, in the other it's sea urchin. I loved that one, especially since it was topped with tobiko also. The liver one, eh, just ok. Everyone in the know seemed to be ordering this though. It's fun, since it feels so special and comes with the sake. 
-Salmon and lemon over tempura asparagus roll 
-Azteca roll: Crab, Avocado, Gobo and Cucumber Wrapped in White Fish, topped w/ a thin slice of Jalepeno, Spicy Mayo, Tobiko & Ponzu then lightly baked 
-Special roll with tuna and green onion: Simple but one of my favorites since the quality of the tuna was so high. It showcased why you should go with their specials. 

All came to around $100. For such a feast (think Sushi Ran transported to the Inner Sunset), well worth it.
author: Shoshana D.

description: From what i hear, the rolls here are quite delicious.  I wouldn't know because I was too tempted by the prospect of Omikase from a sushi restaurant that offers as impressive a selection of sashimi as Koo does.  The O-Toro was some of the fattiest and most delicious I have ever had and as I mentioned earlier, the variety of fresh fish offered here really ensures a well rounded and unique sushi dining experience.  And I can't forget to mention the spoon full of happiness.  A delicious plate of two spoons and a shot of sake.  One spoon has a piece of hamachi and the other has a healthy dose of uni topped with a quail egg.  A must try experience.
author: Mike G.

description: So far my favorite sushi in San Francisco. I went here with the boyfriend for my birthday and the fresh picks were amazing.  You get what you pay for and in this case it's true, you'll pay a bit more than some of the lesser sushi places but it's well worth it.
author: Rodney P.

description: Moderately priced sushi, which in terms of quality was slightly above average.  The atmosphere is quaint and there's a sushi bar if you want to go solo.  I had the sushi plate and my friend had the veggie plate...enough to fill us up, but not enough to stop us from tackling the Mt Fuji dessert (a must have for chocolate fiends).
author: Mark D.

description:
We didn't want to cook Saturday evening and decided to venture out to Irving and DH have wanted to come to Koo for a long time.  Verdict: wasn't a dissapointment.  We didn't wait too long considering we didn't have reservation and it was a weekend.  We ended up sitting in the sushi bar.  A little close to other diners if  you ask me. This annoying girl on her date talked so loud the entire restaurant could hear her and I felt like she was yelling in my ear... but I digress.

The spider roll is a staple for me and the fried crab legs were the longest I've seen.  Usually I can eat a spider roll sushi end in one bite, I had to do it several.  It did come warm though, which I never had it warm.

The sushi chef was very nice and attentive. Even gave us a sample of a pickled salmon salad with jicama and celery, I never did figure out what it was called.

I wish the servers was as attentive, I never did get a refill on my ice tea.

Minus one star since i was craving udon soup that evening and they don't serve soup.
author: Mona B.

description: It's good sushi in a cute space, but it's not worth the trek out of my hood when the menu is pretty much identical to Tokoyo Go Go, and the service was about half as attentive.  It needs a bit of work in my eyes.
author: Sarah D.

description: This is one of my favorite Sushi restaurants in SF. Sitting at the counter is the best way to enjoy sushi, IMHO. Mirugai (geoduck?) is really good here, and they even have the TORIKAI shochu! mmm.. gotta go back there sometime soon.
author: Naonao T.

description:
i treated the boyfriend a dinner here and he was pretty much blown away. since he loves sashimi and all i figured i'd indulge him with the omakase.  

we also had the salmon/tuna tartar (good)
the beef tataki (good)
the miso marinated black cod (really good)
and a roll....forget the name but it was tempura with spicy tuna on top

must say, the sashimi was really really good. superbly fresh and the pairing was phenomenal. i suspect adding sake to the mix woulda been even better but i had to drive.  good thing we made a reservation because that is a must on friday nights, or you'll end up waiting for a while in the cold outside bc the restaurant isnt that big.

aside from the sashimi, the dishes were pretty good but not mind blowingly good. i still prefer the cod at the house over in north beach.  but this one was really good too.

i think the prices are reasonable for two, for the amount and quality of food we got.

grate date spot. and i like its location.
author: Peggy W.

description:
MMmmm, some of the best sushi I have had in the city. Also, had the Spoonfuls of Happiness but everything else ordered was full of happiness, too. The sashimi & nigiri are the way to go as the fresh sushi really shines here.  And who knew, that fresh wasabi was so good yet so spicy when eaten by the spoonful. 
Will definitely return.
author: Cbr A.

description:
pretty sure this is my favorite sushi in the city. so fresh. so delicious. the 'best roll' really is the best roll ever: tempura asparagus and avocado topped with salmon and a thin lemon slice - simple and amazing. that and the goma ae salad with some nigori sake is the perfect light meal. oh and the stuffed jalapeno! 

good for every kind of sushi lover - the vegetarian kind, the authentic kind, and the stylized kind. walk a couple blocks away from ebisu (ick) and treat yourself.
author: Elle C.

description: Terrific.  Very fresh and very tasty.  We were seated right away (8pm on a Friday), so that set the tone nicely.  The sashimi (ultr-thin slices of halibut served with a ponzu sauce) was yummy and flavorful.  Our favorite of the night was probably the flying kamikazi roll--we ordered seconds!  Will definitely go back.
author: Jason L.

description: I haven't been here in awhile, so hopefully it hasn't changed because i would like to venture back soon.  This is another great sushi place that ML introduced me to.  The staff were really friendly and the sushi was fresh and tasty.  Spoonful of Happiness  was a item that I remember ML loving and the monkfish.  I'm usually not a fan of monkfish, but this was the only place where I tried it and loved it.  I remember there was a great ambience about the place.  It was definitley unique in a great way.  Make reservations ahead of time because they seem to keep pretty busy.
author: Cino B.

description:
this is just been the best month for me, first i discover Pebacco, now it's Koo. thanks to all the yelpers... 

so i've been on a hunt for a good sushi restaurant, like a real fresh fish place. Koo is now definitely on the top of my sushi list. i read lots of review about the "spoonfull of happiness", DAMN! that is the spoonful of happiness, the uni was fresh, and tasty, and the combination of that plus the sake made it even better. i didn't go all crazy with the raw food that night, just kind of try out all the different stuff on the menu.. 

my bf order a duck salad and the chicken teriyaki with grill vegetable which were both  amazing. i have to say their food has a tint of fusion flavor overall. its not all that traditional. And i also had the salmon sashimi, which was very fresh!!  and the oyster, of course was super super fresh and tasty.. yumm

the only thing i wasn't very impress with was the tuna/salmon tartar.. not as flavor as i expect to be.. 

i have to give KOO a 5 star for the "spoonful of happiness". and the fresh sashimi.. for all you raw food lover out there.. gotta check it out this place!! plus the price is reasonable
author: Cindy C.

description:
When it comes to a myriad of positive reviews of Koo, I will unfortunately have to be a dissenting voice.

Neither the service or the food was great. I felt that the service was relatively inattentive; I had to signal to our server several times for a refill of our drinks and also take some of our plates away (started crowding up). 

The spoonful of happiness had very delicate flavors that were complimentary but very short-lived. They went together relatively well with the chilled sake, but the texture was more of a highlight for me (than the flavor). 

- Kumamoto oysters were delicious, but were not cleaned thoroughly. Having sand in them was a definite turnoff

- Bonito nigiri; I decided to try this first, and if I felt that the quality was up to par, I would have ordered the Toro. This was not the case. The chef tried, but unfortunately failed in integrating the flavors he intended. The quality of the fish was average based on the flavor and texture (based off the area that was not overwhelmed by the ginger/scallion). The ginger/scallion placed on top almost completely masked the flavor of the fish to the point of overwhelming the fish. I do not understand why the rice portion was drowning in ponzu; although the integrity of the rice was still left intact, I felt that it was going to fall apart in my fingers.

I also ordered the fresh wasabi; it appeared fresh, but I wonder if it was freshly grated, or was this old "fresh wasabi". The reason being is that it seems to have lost a lot of the natural sweetness that fresh wasabi normally contains.

- Next up, contrary to not really liking rolls, we ordered the dragon roll. I enjoyed the unagi, but otherwise found the tempura to be average (maybe excessively fried/starchy).

- Entrees (2) : Beef Tataki and Miso Marinated Black Cod

Beef Tataki: The beef was more tough than I would have wanted. The sauce on top was very salty, countered by the watercress. I thought the the watercress countered the saltiness, but the beef was not up to par (tough and the flavor was not great)

Miso Marinated Black Cod: The fish was very tender, but the skin underneath was burnt. The flavors was just.... overwhelming and terrible. Although a good concept, that much salt totally ruined the dish. The broth it was bathed in felt like a solution of concentrated salt, and the fish just happened to swim in it. I enjoyed the part of the fish that was not submerged in the broth, but the rest was almost inedible. By the end of these two entrees, I had to drink so much water and tea just to remove the taste of salt from my mouth.

By then, I had just about enough. I paid the bill and left with a dessicated tongue from the salt. Very glad I did not get omakase. I do not feel that the fish was that fresh, the execution of the shared plates was terrible and I will not be coming here again.
author: John T.

description:
Koo Sushi makes some of the best sushi I've ever had!  A few must trys:

1) Tuna and Salmon Tartare:  I have loved shrimp chips since I was young (what little Asian kid didn't?), but this was definitely the most delicious and innovative use of shrimp chips I've ever experienced!  The avocado sauce with the delicately cubed pieces of ahi was amazing--I highly recommend this as an appetizer.

2) Dragon Roll and Tokyo Crunch Roll:  Very, very fresh and high-quality ingredients!  The rolls practically melted in my mouth

I would definitely recommend this place over many sushi bars in J-town and look forward to returning soon!
author: B H.

description:
KOO SUSHI  for me is one of the best japenese restaurants in the city for sure.Everything about it from the art on the wall, to the all-inclusive menu and the service is perfect as well. Now on the food: Godzilla tofu was a perfect little starter before moving on to the sushi. Get some of the day's catch, as they are super fresh and you can try something new and ask the waitress to point out favorites. We had the albacore tuna, spanish mackerel and halibut after her recommendations and they were all superfresh and yummy. And tried their eggplant and shittake sushi which were really good too, as a fish alternative. Finally, we had a couple of their rolls, the rock'n'roll and tokyo crunch which stole the show: Hamachi and unagi in one with bits of tempura flakes that makes it crunchy! 
We washed the lovely flavors down with a sapporo and a delicious aromatic flowery sake. Easy on the sake though, it gets you drunk without realising...
Their desserts are suprisingly good for a Japanese restaurant. The Mount Fuji is a pyramid shaped chocolate mousse served with Green tea mochi ice-cream... Delicious!
Make sure to go to Koo and not its overrated neighbour, Ebisu, when you're in the neighborhood. You will thank me for this...
author: Chris D.

description:
This is one of those places where you are just so lucky to stumble upon. While I was a visiting student at UCSF, I was looking for a sushi place to eat nearby and in the process I stumbled upon sushi Koo. After my first visit which did not go so well because one of the waitresses was quite mean to us when we just showed up without any reservation, we were turned away with a cold shoulder. I don't know if it was because English was not her native language or what, but we were not so impressed being treated poorly like that. 

Even though the first experience did not go so well, I have dicided to give this place another try simply because the restaurant is always crowded (compared to the other sushi restaurant "Ten" just down the street).. And obviously I have not been disappointed since. My recommendation is to order catch of the day. I LOVE their hotategai. It's the sweetest scallop I have ever tasted anywhere.. and I have lived in Japan for a year.. so I would say I know what good sushi is when I taste one. Another fish that really stands out is their kinmedai (red snapper). It's really one of the best.. sweet and the chef sears the skin.. OOHHH.. just typing these words make my mouth watering. 
In general, if you order catch of the day, you can't really go wrong. Although the one and only time I tried their blue shrimp, I was not super impressed. But it could be an off day for them. 

And yess I have tried the spoonful of happiness that everybody on yelp rave about.. It's really not my cup of tea. I love uni and I kinda like the ankimo (monk fish liver?).. but I don't think the combination with the ponzu sauce was all that great. But it's just my 2 cents.

The restaurant has a really nice decor and ambience. When I go there alone, I usually try to sit at the sushi bar and ask for a recommendation from the chef regarding which items on the catch of the day list that he would recommend. I think I have been to Koo for more than 10 times.. and obviously I am impressed. The price is quite right for the quality of sushi that you get. I would go there again in my next trip to San Francisco.
author: Mary P.

description: I came here for a date! The presentation was fun and the sushi chef/owner was very friendly. We sat at the bar and he told us funny stories. His wife makes the dessert menu. Dessert was decent.  =) Hmm, I wasn't a big fan of the spoonful of happiness.
author: Tiff W.

description: My favorite sushi and I don't live anywhere near the neighborhood.  You can taste the freshness in the sushi.  Eat whatever nigiri is on the special list.  Inventive take on traditional Japanese cuisine.
author: Scott W.

description: This place had amazingly fresh sushi. Ask the waitress what the chef recommends that day. The tuna tartare was delish and the rolls were fantastic, although some a little too big for their own good.  This place is a great date place. Cozy with very good lighting. Not too expensive. It was 70 including tip for two people. We got alcohol as well and stuffed ourselves.
author: liz L.

description: Great location in the Sunset district. Love the presentations on certain menu items. Good quality fish, Fresh, fresh, and very fresh. Service was excellent. I didn't get to sit at the sushi bar because it was full, but was guaranteed a spot next time when I go back...Can't wait!!!
author: L K.

description: The best sushi in San Francisco!  We have been coming here since they opened, the service is wonderful, they remember you and are always friendly!  The blue fin tuna is a must!  The grilled artichoke is also Delicious!  They have a great variety of great rolls, and if you are feeling adventurous sit at the sushi bar and ask the chefs to just make whatever they want for you, it is never a disappointment!  There are some things that are so good that they need to sell them to go such as the dip for the marinated artichoke, the miso salad dressing, and especially the homemade cookies that come with the mochi ice cream!  Consistently great, a must try!
author: Rebecca W.

description: Great food, well executed, great friendly service . The Sushi and Sashimi is very fresh and the creativeness of the the different rolls and the Spoonful of Happiness is excellent!
author: Garden Lover S.

description: best happy hour deals ever!!!  i love the handrolls and the grilled artichoke.  ginger gelato w/ the mt fuji cake is awesome as well!
author: Helen T.

description: You can read the other 400+ reviews.  I took the Mrs. here for din-din and it rocked!  Piece of advice: if you get the tuna/salmon tartare, ask for some srirachi (sp?) on the side.  Otherwise, everything was perfect!!  Service, food, ambiance - brilliant!
author: Curtis H.

description:
The first time I came here, I wasn't impress with the food. This was about 2 1/2 years ago. We sat down and ordered some typical rolls and a few nigiris. It was good but nothing great. I haven't been back until a few nights ago. This time we got seated at the sushi bar after convincing the waitress that we'd rather wait for the sushi bar. It was full of people ordering rolls. The lady insisted that the we sit down at the regular tables, but after a few minutes two people left and another waitress told us we can sit at the sushi table... this is when we got the attention of the head sushi chef and the damage$ started. We stuck to the catch of the day for the most part and it was AMAZING! 
We ate with our hands and only used the chopsticks when it was necessary. The waitresses soon figured out that we were there to drop a few bills. The service soon became very attentive and the sushi chef started comping us a few items. We had a very pleasant and informative conversation with the head sushi chef. He thoroughly understood our demanding tastes and he delivered nicely. At least for this night, the experience was A+. Aside from the "misunderstanding" about where we wanted to sit, I highly recommend this place. And judging from other reviews, if you are a theme roll person and like fancy appetizers, they do a pretty good job.
author: Demanding T.

description: I am new to this site, but not this wonderful Japanese restaurant. This is one of the few authentically Japanese restaurants in the city. It is Asian fusion, but  done on Asian and not Western terms. I don\t actually bother with the sushi, since I don't care for the Americanized stuff like California or rock n roll or whatever rolls with the rice on the outside. Rather, I look for the flavors and styles of Japan. Stick with the share plates and sashimi, which they serve with real, fresh waabi (They don\t so this with the sushi). The sake list is also impressive. Go here and skip Ebisu or Blowfish or Ozumo. This is the real thing with an authentically Japanese modern twist.
author: 和子

description: My favorite sushi in San Francisco, hands down.  Forget that overpriced, snooty Sebo that I rightfully ripped a new one in a prior review - THIS is where you need to come for amazingly fresh fish prepared ridiculously well.  Skip the main menu (except for ordering some of your traditional faves and the excellent tempura hamachi roll) and order off the specials menu, which lists all of the special fish brought in that day from Japan and elsewhere.  Follow the sushi chef's intent and do not add soy sauce or wasabi if your sushi comes already dressed with accompaniments (you'll be able to easily tell which ones you should just savor without addition)... you're really in for a treat!  If they have the fresh red snapper on the specials menu, GET IT... they lightly torch the bit of skin left on the slice giving the fish a nice smoky flavor that is to die for.  Everyone I bring here falls in love with this place.  It's kinda small, so reservations are highly recommended.  The service is perfectly Japanese - prompt and kind, but not overly studious.  I haven't gone wrong with anything here which is why almost all of my sushi $$$ get spent here now :).
author: Chris P.

description: I've been here a half a dozen times and I have yet to be disappointed. I'll have to agree with the other reviewers that "A Spoonful of Happiness" was fantastic -- and I normally do not like eating uni. The service is friendly, but on occasion can be a bit inattentive. Also, food here is a bit pricey, but worth it. Overall, if you can appreciate good sushi, this is the place.
author: Cynthia H.

description: One of the best Japanese restaurants in San Francisco. Great appetizer and Sushi. Service and atmosphere is also great. I highly recommend this place. Trust me, I'm from Japan. I know my Japanese food ;)
author: fumiko t.

description:
Nice lamps! Koo is a solid mid-range sushi option. It's not cheap if you like to gorge yourself on sashimi specials like I do, but it's cheaper than super high end places or a night at Kabuto. I liked their variety of small plates and that they offered some interesting specials, different types of fish that you don't get at every neighborhood sushi place. The fish was fresh too, no signs of mealiness, and some of the portions were pretty generous. 
Gripes: Koo is squarely anchored on the mayo/cream cheese/hot/tempura-ed roll bandwagon. Totally necessary to have a few inventive rolls that are free of the mentioned afflictions. Don't get me wrong, I like an occasional foofy roll, just like you'll sometimes catch me drinking beverages with umbrellas in them, but I like roll options with fresh, raw ingredients. Also, there are only 2 choices for white wine. And some of the tables are small and close together.
Service was very accommodating and didn't give us the evil eye for showing up at 1030pm. They get huge points for including an ice bucket with the bottles of white wine. I like my wine icy crisp! And I'm fond of the name, who doesn't enjoy walking around saying "koooo" to themselves?
author: Candice L.

description: Yum. Delicious white tuna, eggplant, halibut. Very nice.
author: Ellie P.

description:
So many sushi places in SF, so little time (and money). After just one visit, this has definitely become one of my favorites. Not at all loud, flashy, or trendy like many of the other places around town, Koo is tucked away on the quieter end of Irving St in the Inner Sunset -- a pleasant, relaxing setting for a great dining experience.

My friend and I came by relatively early on a chilly, wet Tuesday, so it was pretty empty when we arrived. It did get busier later, and even though it's in a quaint space, it never seemed congested. Service was also friendly and attentive. Most importantly, the food was awesome. Unfortunately neither of us came with huge appetites, but we did split the Bamboo Tower (very refreshing salad with lumps of mixed seafood with a nice kick from the sesame-ponzu gelee bits sprinkled about), Marinated Artichoke (very tender with a great shichimi soy may dip), Hamachi Kama (my favorite part of the fish! grilled! amazing!), and then finished up with a Tokyo Crunch roll (spicy fried crunchies, hamachi, unagi, cucumber and tobiko) and sweet shrimp nigiri (raw, of course). Hmm, now that I wrote it all out, I guess it does sort of seem like a bit, but portions aren't huge which lend to more ordering and sharing, so that's always a plus.

Definitely going to go back several times to try the rest of their extensive menu.... Highly recommended!
author: Alex C.

description: I love Koo. I've loved it since my first meal there. The rolls are interesting and very tasty. My favorite roll is the U2. The spicy tuna is fresh and not overly spicy. The first couple of times that I went there I stuck with the rolls and other typical Japanese type foods you'd find in a sushi restaurant, until one day I noticed that they had a grilled artichoke in the starters section of the menu. I love artichokes, but you never know how good it's going to be in a restaurant. The artichoke at Koo is probably the best artichoke I've had in a restaurant. It's grilled with very tasty marinade and paired with a shichimi soy mayo. It's so good I couldn't eat it fast enough. They only give you half of an artichoke so if you're sharing you might want to get more than one.
author: Kiersten B.

description: I've been to this place many times and I love it.  This is my most favorite Japanese restaurant in the Bay.  I love the spoonful of happiness since I'm a uni fan.  I love raw fishes and the sashimi there are so fresh.  Too bad they do not have Chawa Mushi or I'd give them 6 stars.
author: Jen C.

description: The food was wonderful and VERY reasonably priced.  We were seated immediately ( we did call a few hours earlier to make a reservation ).  The  service was prompt and very efficient.  Everything came out quickly and tasted amazing.  The fish was fresh and delicate.  The desserts were cheap and just right.  Great meal, great ambiance.  Parking in the neighborhood is a pain however...beware or take a cab.
author: Nilu r.

description: Seriously disappointed.  The spoonful of happiness was SWIMMING in soy sauce.  I like soy sauce fine but drinking it is over the top.   Lots of things on the menu sound innovative and yummy but sadly are not.  On the plus side, the sake was good.
author: James Y.

description: Personally, I wasn't very impressed with the sushi rolls we had especially the spider roll. Th service was good, but the food wasn't impressive and it was very expensive. I've had better sushi...
author: Ghiz S.

description: Good rolls and fresh seafood.  I tried the spoonful of happiness, which is kind of a misnomer because it is TWO spoons of "happiness": I found the raw quail egg in that dish very rich but my boyfriend really loves this so I think its just my sensitivity to unusual raw foods.  A bit pricey (~$110/3 people + 1 beer) but good for a special occasion.
author: Grace M.

description: I had to edit my review after about ten visits because my previous review made me sound like a chode (which I am not). Anyway, out of the 5 or more Japanese restaurants in the Inner Sunset this is the best, if not the best in the city. They have a solid sake selection and very helpful staff. Sitting at the bar can be a very nice experience, especially if you're adventurous. I love the inventiveness of this place and the desserts - especially Mt. Fuji.
author: michael c.

description: I had dinner here at 6pm on a weekday.  Place was pretty empty.  Our food came out super fast.  Ordered only the nigiri here.  The fish was fresh and tasty.  Ordered one of everything off of their specials.  The only complaint that I had was the rice was a little on the dry side.
author: J I.

description: Oh man, this place is really good. We had the most fresh tasting fish. Along with the seaweed salad and saki... you can't go wrong! Well, yes you can... if you don't go. There is not one bad item on the menu. Seating is limited and they have a small bar area. Make reservations. And as a side note: they're cclosed on mondays.
author: andre h.

description: Koo, why can't you be in my neighborhood? Great sushi. They don't have a ton of rolls to choose from, but there are enough great ones to make up for it. Plus, the rolls are a perfect size as not to choke you. The salmon tartare is also one of the best I've tasted. Meanwhile, the sake selection is nice, although not as extensive as Tsunami. As for service, it's great early on, but as the place quickly fills up it goes downhill. I never got my last glass of sake.
author: a p.

description: Great sushi place. Definitely a must try. Fresh fish and nice service.
author: Sam B.

description: Koo is coo!! But seriously folks. The fish is super fresh and the tuna/salmon tartar with spicy guacamole is delish. Unless you are an oyster fanatic I would not go there. Oh yeah? Fine, have a 3 dollar mouthful of salt water. And another, and another....keep going..... satisfied? I didn't think so. I think that is actually a complaint about oysters. Not Koo. You should go to Koo.
author: Carly S.

description: Definitely some of the best and most reasonably-priced sushi I've had since I moved up to SF from San Diego. The Tokyo Crunch, Best Roll (aptly named!), and Tempura Shrimp are some of my faves. All the rolls were very flavorful, service was great ("Irashaimasu"), and since it's sushi the Sapporo was at my side.
author: Bryan Z.

description:
this place has the best sushi in the inner sunset and maybe even the...city???

the rolls are really innovative but not too kooky and the flavors meld extremely well. i really like the best roll - tempura asparagus, salmon and super thin lemon slice? you bet! 

the nigiri is always fresh with perfect sized portions to fit delicately in your mouth, no stuffing necessary. 

the sake selection is great, they have lots of good choices. if you do decide to get sake, try the cold version - not hot - the sake is heated up to mask the real flavor. 
a good cold sake is the perfect pairing to sushi AND it tastes good to boot. 

i love koo.
author: Erika A.

description:
Super Oishi~!
You've got to try the Spider roll.  It's the best!
author: apple p.

description: loved the dynamite handroll. scallops all the way to the end...
author: Ethan L.

description: For those vegetarians who don't eat fish, this is the best sushi place in SF!  Tofu Godzilla is amazing.  The veggie combo plate is delicious.  I like the warm house sake too.
author: Elle D.

description: okay.  I found my sushi joint.  Too bad it's 3000 miles away.  two nights in a row.  wow. unagi unagi unagi.
author: Bernice r.

description:
i had 2 experience at Koo... 

first one: 
half a year ago, i came here on a weekday night and wanted a table of 3.  the hostess was not very nice and said if you do not have reservations it'd be 1.5 hours.  i asked if i can stick around to see if i can get a table if the reservations don't show up. she refused to work with me so i left. 

second one:
i came here last month with some girl friends since i've heard good things about this place. we tried a little of everything but my main thing at a japanese restaurant is sashimi/nigiri.  their sushi is very traditional and fresh.  but i m used to Sushi Sam's exciting sushi that i feel these traditional sushi are very bland... but still, their fish are fresh.  

i tried the other dishes (ie. salad, miso sea bass, etc) and they're alright... nothing special... not sure if i'd come back again... i had to go have a second dinner after this because i was not close to full at all!
author: Kapo T.

description: Tastes good, but after the pricey meal, my friends and I definitely were no where near full. By comparison, Zen Sushi is a much better value for quantity and freshness.
author: Edmond Y.

description: A little out of the way for me but it was almost nice driving and getting out of the neighborhoods I tend to find myself in all week. The sushi was fresh and the rolls we had were simple but good. The place got pretty busy so I would keep that in mind if you're planning on stopping in. We were havi ng dinner at the senior citizen hour so it didn't really matter :) Didn't try any sake so no comments on the alcohol. The service was good. The waiter was attentive and our food came out pretty quickly.
author: shadi m.

description: Yeah, they know how to do sushi.  I'd say that this place ranks as having some of the best sushi in San Francisco (yes, it's at least as good as Ebisu).  This place is equally good for a casual date (one of the few restaurants in the Sunset with any sort of atmosphere) or for a nice dinner with a friend.  The last time I came here, I think we ordered just about everything on the menu; yeah, my date was very hungry.  We tried so many random types of fish, I really have no idea what half of them were, but they tasted pretty damn good.
author: Danielle B.

description: Everything here was pretty balance, the service, the food and the ambiance.  I thought it was kinda strange that the sink was outside of the bathroom, but hey, we came for the food and service, and that's exactly what we got.  If there is a short wait  you can leave your name and phone number, and they will call you.
author: Will T.

description: The fresh meter is high here.  I love Koo for its deliciousness and great service.  I love the traditional dishes done very well.  I've been a few times and am constantly impressed.  I'm planning my next visit soon.
author: Chard M.

description: Way better than Ebisu.  Also very telling that I spotted the sushi chef of one of 2 of my favorite SF sushi joints eating here.
author: Pelle Y.

description: Fresh sushi.  Too many cooked stuff.  Price is on the higher end. Cute decor.  The raw stuff were good.  Miso soup was not good.
author: Carrie-C N.

description:
it's koo sushi - do i need to say more? seriously... we KOO's know what sushi should be :)

my boyfriend took me here on one of our date nights. we sat at the sushi bar and ordered the sashimi combo - it was fresh and so good. my uni was yummy and the godzilla tofu is a must for next time too. 

i am not a big fan of rolls - but the best roll was pretty good. i don't particularly favor baked rolls, so the aztec roll was just a-ok for me.  

the sushi chefs were delightful and so friendly - we will have to make this place one of our regular sushi joint for sure.

next time - we already know we are just going to get sashimi after sashimi :) can't wait!
author: Dot K.

description: I have gone to Koo many times and really have enjoyed their sushi.  The other day I had a HORRIBLE experience.  We asked for a table for six and they made up a random rule that in order to seat us we needed to commit to spending a specific amount $ per person.  I believe this is because we had two sushi eating children in our party and they simply wanted to save their tables for customers without children in order to make more money.  They could have also simply told us all the tables were reserved and we would have had no problem with that.  When I tried to reason with them they dug in their heals in a completely unreasonable way.  I found the experience offensive and will never return.  I recommend avoiding Koo particularly if you have kids.
author: Tom S.

description:
sushi. koo. 

i am in love with this place.  Simple, traditional sushi.  Awesome all around, from freshness, service, ambiance, and lovely, absolutely divine sake.

More words will just ruin it.  It is just simply really damn good.
author: Today Y.

description:
a spoonful of happiness.  they seemed to have taken it off the menu but you can still order it.  for the un-initiated, it's a spoon of uni in ponzu sauce topped with a raw quail egg.  simply the best!

the special apps and non-standard sushi selection (abalone sashimi)  is the main draw.  rolls and such are pretty standard.  prices are pretty good for the quality & selection.  also like the sake collection which is more diverse than what you'd get at a neighborhood sushi joint.  not on the levels of a sake bar but let's not be too picky.
author: Bonnie C.

description: Decent mid-upper end sushi.  A very large sake selection [lost on me alas] but less options in the beer/wine category.   Only about 10-12 roll options [and several are in the $10-15 range] but a large range of fish options several of which were quite good.  All in all the sushi was good, but it didn't seem any better than say Blowfish or Tokyo Go Go for a bit pricier.  Service was fine and we were able to get a table right away.  Perhaps it is just my lack of taste when it comes to sushi, but I don't find it all that much better than some of the cheaper sushi places in the neighborhood where I could get 4-5 rolls for about $25-30.    Given the number of cheaper alternatives [often with a wider range of rolls] within 5 blocks, I really can't see myself going back here.
author: Alured P.

description: They have this stuff called "sushi" (I believe), which I surmised to be just raw fish.  But maaaaan is it tasty here.
author: mcmalaprop ..

description: For those looking for high quality traditional edomaezushi in SF, go here.  Do not order the "spoonful of happiness" or be distracted by the lengthy list of big rolls.  Stick to the special fish, most of which is flown in from Japan.  I've been looking for a place like this in SF for a long time.
author: Peter M.

description: Despite only living in San Francisco for 3 months, this is probably the best Japanese place that I've been to yet. "A Spoonfull Happiness" was just amazing. Can't really describe it, you just have to try it. The "Miso Marinated Black Cod" was probably the best fish I've had in my life. Dinner for 2 with drinks came out to be around $80. Not bad at all.
author: Chris C.

description: Oh so good.  Fish! Lots of yummy fish!  Very slow to get the food.  Good suggestions on what to try off the fresh catch list.  Some of the rolls were just amazing.  Very quick service with the drinks, though it was hard to catch the waitress's eye.
author: Heidi P.

description: Mmm so delicious.  Already dreaming about going back and I just got home 5 minutes ago!  The sashimi melts in your mouth, the rolls are creative and of great quality, and like many other reviewers, we were able to enjoy our meal in the peaceful atmosphere.  Will definitely be returning!  The Best Roll and sashimi plate were our favorites.
author: Julia P.

description: Koo has only been around for four months, but it's already my favorite.  They have unique (but not over the top) rolls, and wonderful specials.  The fish quality is top shelf, and the sushi bar is small enough to interact with the chefs (including the owner).  They also have a small but very fine sake selection.
author: Ken B.

description: To be honest,  I was starting to be disappointed in the sushi restaurants in the Inner Sunset.  Ebisu is too crowded and not as good as it was a couple years ago and the rest aren't worth writing about.  However, since Koo opened, I have a new place to roll over to.  It has everything I look for in a sushi place - good specials, a selection of non-sushi dishes, some off-the wall items, decent alcohol selection, friendly chefs who recommend things, cute waitresses, and of course, fresh, buttery, tasty sushi.  Is it always great?  Nope, but every time I have been there, at least a couple of the fish have been spectacular and that outweighs any less exciting one.  The ambiance is nice too.  Koo.
author: matt d.

description: It's a four-wheel drive, it's useful for everything, for a date, for friends, for a date, for a business meal, etc.
author: Alex A.

description: I ordered take out from koo last night and I was very impressed. The tuna sashimi was heavenly and so fresh. Spider roll was huge and tasty and the standard wakame salad was great as well. I can't wait to dine in sometime soon.
author: Meg L.

description: My favorite sushi in the City.  Super friendly service.  Good combination of seating sushi bar/dining room.  Perfectly constructed nigiri.  Awesome people!
author: R M.

description: If you're an uni lover like I am, then you must go here to try the "Spoonful of happiness" because it really is.
author: Gina W.

description: Good but not great. It has a been there done that feel. The Spoonful of Happiness is good, but expensive for two spoonful of food. I think it was around $10. Another thing was the salmon we had was not that fresh.
author: Erica B.

description: My favorite thing about this place is the  Nigori sake which is unfiltered.   If your not a sake fan, you should try this kind at least once.  Way more flavorful thatn filtered, and so much better than hot sake.  As far as rolls go, I'd say the Flying Kamikaze and the U2 roll are my favorite.  Also have had the Hamachi and that's excellent.   The list of rolls is a bit limited, but the fish is always fresh and I've never had a bad experience here.  Although, i highly recommend reservations on a Friday / Saturday night as it can get packed.  Once waited an hour for a table...if that happens, try waiting at Fireside down the street.
author: kimberly k.

description: As a total sushi snob, Im down with this place. True, it is expensive, but well worth it. The artichoke is out of this world and all their sushi is fresh and delicious.
author: Jonathan W.

description: Great service.  We were slow to order but didn't feel rushed at all.  The organic tuna was soo fresh, melt-in-your-mouth and we really enjoyed the U2 roll.  Went with my girl-friends, had a blast and bottle of vino (sauvignon blanc) went very well with a very satisfying meal.  For SF, parking wasn't too crazy.
author: Deirdre M.

description: YUM.  I love sushi. I love all things raw. Koo (and yes, it does rhyme with poo-I checked) is great.  The combos are definitely not traditional.  We loved the Toyko Crunch! The Azteca was spicy goodness, but there was some saltiness I couldn't put my finger on...judging from previous reviews, maybe it was the sauce? Whatevs, Koo was still fab.
author: Rachel D.

description: I live in the neighborhood and have been to Koo twice.  Both times I've enjoyed the food and found it to be very fresh and tasty.  The sushi chefs are Japanese which is a requirement for me.  I feel this way about every restaurant, ex: french food = french chef, chinese food = chinese chef, etc.... The staff is friendly, the beer was cold and the fish was excellent (try the halibut nigiri and the flying kamakazi roll).  The one downfall for me is that the tables are small and close together, but I'm pretty tall so I felt a bit cramped. Next time I'll sit at the sushi bar, it looks very spacious.
author: Sabrina L.

description: Best rolls in San Francisco. 'nuff said.
author: Juls M.

description:
Came here early on a Wednesday night and first thing I noticed even before eating is that the parking around it is Horrible (note the capital h). Yeah it's pretty bad, but if you bitch hard enough you might end up with a cool baller parking spot like me, right in front of the restaurant. 
The place has nice decor and once you step in, that amazing smell of raw fish and sushi rice just smacks you in the face. And it's a good smell. They have a daily special menu and an ordinary menu which is pretty simple to read and order from and the service is good.
I highly recommend the blue fin 'otoro' which at $15 for 2 pcs sounds outrageous, but it's worth it. I tried a bunch of random fish that I've never tried before including barracuda and deep sea snapper. Both amazing. Some of the other standard higher grade fish like the amber and yellow jack were good but not special. Spanish mackarel I've had better elsewhere.
For cooked food, the miso cod was whatever and pretty regrettable/forgettable. Definitely should have ordered another blue fin sushi. 
I heard this place has good omakase from some friends who recommended it, and I'm sure that would be amazing. The price for 2 ppl no alcohol was about $100. Not bad not great, but the food and overall experience was good. 
Oh and must order the tokyo crunch roll. Wow. Not so much the spicy tuna, which is pretty standard.
author: Art L.

description: The chef here came from Tokyo Go Go and brought with him many of my favorite rolls (azteca) and other plates (stuffed jalapenos).  But, the scene is much different - less trendy/hip, but still a fun spot... and much easier for parking.  And save room for the chocolate cake!
author: Ken H.

description:
random sushi cravings, not from me but from my hunny we ran into this place in san francisco

spoon full of happyness was happy
fish was fresh
price was what is expected from going to a sushi place
parking wasnt too fun, then again when is parking fun in SF

not much more is needed to be mentioned
author: Edin T.

description:
very good salmon sashimi, tempura, and house roll.
save a wee bit of room for dessert - their strawberry tiramisu is deelish. (i think it should be called strawberry shortcake, but at any rate, it was good).

the service was not the best on a crowded night. and the noise was quite apparent...but the food was good.
author: Sheren H.

description:
too overpriced for mediocre japanese food

personal recommendation: seaweed salad
author: Mei N.

description:
I went there with my parents on a beautiful, sunny Sunday evening (same night as the Blue Angles).  So, needless to say, parking was a little tough.  It's a small place--didn't need a reservation, but it was pretty early.  The staff was friendly and attentive.  Service may have been slow, but if it was, it wasn't in a bad way and we certainly didn't notice.  The food was amazing, including the tofu.  I wish we had been more famished, we could have used an excuse to order more dishes.
The atmosphere was clean as well as laid back.  We ended up making conversation with the table next to us about the Red Sox, which I enjoyed since I went to college in New England, and because I appreciate opportunities to shoot the shit with random folks.  I would definitely come back again, though it might be out of my price range to make it a regular thing (it's nice to have parents around, isn't it)
author: J B.

description: Koo has excellent sushi.  I am always impressed when I eat here at the specials, the quality and the attention to detail.  If you go, make sure you sit at the bar.  They serve this yuzu salmon dish only to bar diners on the house and it's AWESOME.  Service can be a bit cold.  We often get that, "Do you have a reservation?" size up that I hate so much but the food is worth the minor irritation.  Glad it's in my 'hood.
author: M M.

description: I almost hate to review Koo since this will no doubt make it harder to get into, but this incredible little neighborhood find is a must for anyone that loves extraordinary sushi in a hip environment.  As other reviewers have noted, the Spoonful of Happiness delivers on its promise.  Even though I'm not a huge Uni fan, the silky Uni in the SoH is like a spoonful of Japanese Foie Gras.  Wow.  Also not to miss are the lightly spicy and perfect stuffed peppers...all in all a wide range of novel and well-executed dishes.  Check it out.
author: Josh M.

description:
no, yeah, its pretty in here. id love to bring a date here and impress her with my ability to chose a restaurant that does not involve unwrapping your food. but its pricey too - well, i guess thats a plus as far as date restaurants go...

the food was pretty good, although there was a distinct lack of specialty rolls. their warm house sake is very tasty. nicely sized nigiri, but the rolls could be larger and a bit more balanced on taste (sometimes overwhelming). fair to cute wait staff, and the decor is wonderful.

so, yeah, itll take a pretty good chunk out of your wallet, but the atmosphere is pretty, so bring a date - you getting laid will make up for the expensive meal...
author: Darrell L.

description: Simply put, Koo is a great place for sushi, easily a member of the top 5 in SF.  You will very likely not be disappointed by the creativity, freshness and flavorful character of their offerings.  We sat at the bar, so can't comment on the efficiency of the staff.    It is relatively small and there is really no waiting area whatsoever, so reservations are a good idea.
author: Aaron F.

description: Had dinner at the sushi bar here a few weeks ago. I found the fish quality and selection just average. I decided not to get omakase because the selection didn't look particularly great. A mistake on my part? If there is a next time, I'll probably sample more of the cooked food and less of the sushi (there are plenty of other restaurants that offer better sushi).
author: Sunny Y.

description: Nice environment, good sushi (ten times better than Ten, down the street), and priced accordingly.
author: Patrick L.

description: SO GOOD. all i need sometimes is fresh fish... unlike the kind you'd get at say... sushi rock, where you need all those extra ingredients to down your sushi. the sashimi was just absolutely spendid.
author: Cathy C.

description: BEST SUSHI ANYWHERE!  Hands down!  I have lived in many places, often by the sea; have loved sushi since I was a kid and this is the best.  Amazingly it's not uber-expensive either.  I come here all the time and their awards are well-deserved.  Great staff too; definitely try the spoonful of happiness if you're slightly adventurous!
author: Chase N.

description:
Came here on New Year's Eve, for a couple reasons. First off my jam Domo in Hayes Valley was closed still, and secondly, thought it was time to expand the sushi horizons a bit more here in San Francisco. Did some research and while I've definitely done it up at Ebisu in the Sunset before, a little placed called Koo began to really catch my eye. Especially after reading that owner/chef Kiyoshi Hayakawa was the one who opened the pretty awesome Tokyo Go Go in the Mission, which obviously is on the right track now and can very likely be attributed to Hayakawa's early insight & culinary perspective.

Koo, which is take on the word "ku" meaning "to eat" in japanese, is decidedly more low-key, which is nice. It doesn't need to be all ultra refined & semi flashy like Tokyo Go Go cause there's less to compete with around here, and the area just isn't as busy. Once you enter, there's two sides to the restaurant. As many people have pointed out, the main dining area on the right hand side is nothing to write home about. But the 6-seater sushi bar itself is totally separate on the left hand side, and because of that, you really feel like you have a special seat.

My gf and I did omakase here, along with a big ole bottle of Nigori sake (only one kind of Nigori, the basic kind, and only in large bottle) and a large Sapporo. Being that it was our Koo debut, I think a lot of the chef's selections tonight were also on the menu, but we still had some things noticeably off menu but beyond that, there's some great stuff on the damn menu itself.

Stand Outs:
- A Spoonful of Happiness -  People, there's a reason why there's about 50 fucking pictures of this dish on Yelp. It will BLOW YOUR GODDAMN MIND. It's a double crudo spoon, one with Uni (Sea Urchin) + Quail Egg & topped with ponzu & tobiko, and the other one with Ankimo (Monk Fish Liver) wrapped in whitefish and topped with WHITE TRUFFLE OIL. Even more amazing?  You get a shot of chilled sake to sip before and in between the two crudo spoons. An absolute masterpiece.
- Japanese Eggplant Dengaku - It's rare that a vegetarian dish ever tops my list at a new sushi place, but I really don't think I've ever had eggplant that tasted this good, ever. We had three cuts, and the eggplant itself is braised with sweet miso. The taste is delectable, but the texture is really where this dish impressed me. The meat of the eggplant was soft yet thick as usual, but the skin was crisped perfectly, making it particularly easy to eat, and ultimately giving it another dimension.
