- Hawaiian Blue Prawn - Delicious freshwater prawn that literally has a vibrant blue tail and was *so* beautiful on my plate. I've never seen anything like it, and apparently SF is one of the few west coast cities who have a chance to experience it. The taste was great as well.
- 2 kinds of Sea Bream - One was from Japan and I *think* the other was from Hawaii... delicious, light fish related to snapper. They bother were great.
- Not to sound like a broken record, but I had to top it all off with another piece of Uni sushi. Their sea urchin really had a body that was noticeably and significantly more rich than it is at most places. The chef told us they get them from some special northern california farmer, or something to that effect. Mmmmm.

All in all, thumbs way up to Koo, I look forward to returning. Now that I'm acquainted with their menu, I'm excited to hit the omakase there again so they can go even deeper with what they serve. It really is an excellent alternative to Ebisu. I've waited at Ebisu for a lonnnnng time in the past, but now, Koo will make me reconsider which place to go to first. Definitely check this joint out if you're looking for a new SF sushi adventure.
author: George C.

description: The service was great. The food in my opinion was just average. The beef tataki was too salty, the flavor would have been great if the sauce did not overpower the beef. The sushi rolls were good but I've had better. My favorite roll of the night was the flying kamikaze but for people that don't eat spicy it would be way too spicy.  The dragon roll was pretty disappointing actually. The dragon roll was good don't get me wrong if I didn't know much about sushi rolls,  but dragon roll is one of my favorite rolls and the dragon roll i had at koo was mediocre compared to all the other sushi places that I've ever been to. I would come back again to give this place another try. The price was not too bad for the amount that I ordered. Maybe it was just one of their bad nights.
author: A L.

description: I am koo-koo for Koo. Spoon full of happiness is really hapiness but everything was great. Agreed with the other reviews, this place ain't cheap! But it makes you forget about how light your wallet will be.
author: Jason P.

description: Came here on a Friday night and didn't have a reservation but they were very nice and fit us in between reservations. The sushi was wonderful. We had the spider roll, the u2 roll and the king crab dynamite hand roll. All three were very good I would definitely recommend the king crab dynamite!!! A little pricey but it was worth it.
author: Kelly M.

description: Other than finding parking (which is always a struggle in that area) the sushi is super fresh and the ambiance is great.  They lose a star, though, for the bathroom ... it's very clean but has one serious downfall..
author: amanda g.

description: To start, the service here is the best. Everyone is always genuine, friendly, and accommodating. They have the freshest sashimi I have ever tasted. In fact, I don't think I ever knew good sashimi until I had it at Koo. I always order the Chef's Choice plate.Their sushi rolls are creative and delicious. For a while, all I did was obssess over when I would visit their place again because their food was so good. They serve a chocolate lava cake that is scrumptious, in the shape of a paramid, tastes like quality, and cost $3!
author: Faye S.

description: Great place.  Super friendly staff and wonderful service.  I'm not one for fish, but I will eat veggie sushi.  This place has a great selection for picky eaters like myself.  The stuff I ordered was creative and tasty.  I'll definitely go back again.
author: Courtney B.

description: Good quality sushi.  Come here for more simple, authentic sushi and sashimi.  Don't come here for a huge variety of rolls.  Their hamachi was excellent!!  This is a place to come for a lighter palatte, something simple but flavorful.
author: Tadd L.

description: Excellent, excellent, excellent sushi! The only reason it doesn't get a "5" is because I've had equivalent quality for a lot less $$$$. I took my gf here for here birthday and the bill came out to $140ish and I didn't even think we ordered that much. The sushi was the freshest I've had and I highly recommend coming here for a date as the atmosphere is elegant koolness. Just try not to think about the price!
author: Nick H.

description: Sat at the sushi bar (with no reservations on a Saturday night) and ordered off the specials menu, augmented with some free extras that the chefs threw in. Mmm...  The wild salmon sushi was the winner of the bunch, but I also liked the monkfish pate quite a bit. Service was absolutely charming.  Not the cheapest at about $2.50 per piece of sushi, but the fish was very fresh.
author: Jan C.

description: I'm always suspicious of places that look too trendy as my fear is that they worried more about the decor than the food when opening a restaurant. The food is good though. It's on the pricier side but you're also kind of paying for the ambience, I guess. The service was a bit gruff when I went but it was also pretty busy. Plates that I would be happy to recommend are Hamachi Kama, Miso Cod, Azteca Roll, and the Best Roll. I like that the rolls are creative but not questionable; you can tell that the chef thought about it and made sure that the combinations of items would work well together instead of creating a crazy roll just because it's new and unusual. That kind of stuff pisses me off.
author: Queenie C.

description: Excellent sushi, perfect saikyoyaki, and a great selection of sake! I'd been waiting to try Koo for quite a while and wasn't the least bit disappointed. Prices seemed pretty reasonable to me, although the sashimi special was fairly expensive. However every single item was incredibly fresh so I won't complain. If it wasn't for the 4 glasses of sake the bill would have been only a little bit higher than my typical 2-person sushi meal. I wouldn't hesitate to go back, especially with a larger party that wouldn't fit in one of the smaller places like Eiji.
author: Will A.

description: Great ambiance if you shop at IKEA, & have an infinity for 70's porn then you will appreciate both the decor and the lame soundtrack that is played. Small claustrophobic Sushi bar with a couple of the few chairs taken by screaming babies in high chairs, made me opt for a table.Sampled a few items same old same old, nothing of note interesting out of the ordinary. I could get something better at Safeway take it home & would not have to deal with the kids.
author: Bill K.

description: Good food.  Its in the top 5 in the city though.  Its not a cheap joint, but have fun and enjoy when you can.
author: david l.

description: It's about time we get a sushi establishment that is devoted to sharing "real" sushi as opposed to crazy fancy makis that don't really showcase the freshness of the fish! Every bite was melt in the mouth and every piece was as fresh as it could be. And they have very unusual selections too!
author: The L.

description: The quest for a good affordable sushi bar in san francisco is never ending. Finally, here is a place that has great quality fish, no wait, and affordable prices. I can't wait to go back!
author: Kai H.

description: What I liked most was the Tuna and Salmon Tartar -- cute with the white circular shrimp chips.  :) and the Azteca roll.
author: Lise T.

description: I love this place - found it through Yelp - and took a friend there.  The interiors are calming and modern - so nice enough for a date, but not pretentious.  The prices are very reasonable - the rolls are delicious and creative.  The dessert (only $3!!!) was awesome - get Mr. Fuji - delicious!  I would definitely come back and plan on taking other friends there later this week.  I love this place!!!  My new favorite sushi place.  Even if parking in this neighborhood is a nightmare.
author: Christina S.

description:
yummy - yummy - yummy!!
that chocolate cake was delicious! i was so full but determined to finish each bite full!  

the sushi is okay.... not bad... 
but for those of you that know me well, you'll know that sushi is not so good here in the city. there is only one place that can make me smile and crave for more! 

i think we tried this thing called spoons full of happiness - the uni was good! yummy yummy! worth having again or atleast trying! 
... the other items - dynamite hand roll, spicy tuna ... and a few others were okay...
author: kiko v.

description: Average.  And the tuna was fishy.  And I didn't like the California rolls.  So actually, below average.  The service was good.
author: Ann E.

description:
mmmm....
great starters, rolls, and sake!
i loved the monk fish liver pate and the spoons of happiness. 
so good. 
i had the shrimp tempura roll and king crab hand roll.
both were impressive.
great service; my tea & water were filled up the whole time!
author: Tiger Lily ..

description: Traditional sushi is strong here. The rolls are also well made and interesting but there are other sushi places for that. The "ootoro" extra fatty tuna was on special and a new highlight to add to my SF sushi scarfing memories. It had better have been at $14 for 2 pieces! Also the staff and chefs are very sincere in their hospitality. No wonder we were the only gaijin in the place.
author: Brandon R.

description: I ended up here accidentally and what a nice surprise. Best sushi I've had in ages... make a reservation in advance...the place is small but so worth itl!
author: Laurie H.

description: Pricey but very good.  All the fish we ordered was super fresh.  I've never been a fan of hotate until going here.  Super fresh and OH so good.  Besides all the nigiri we had, we also tried the tuna tar tare.  The tar tare was good.. but I've had better.   The decor was imitate and the service was good.  I highly recommend reservations as this place will be packed.
author: Sam C.

description: A cute little sushi spot in the inner Sunset. Being that there are sooo many great sushi spots in the sunset it doesn't really stand out, but I did really enjoy my meal. I got the yummy veggie combo and a beer, and my friend got an assortment of veggie rolls and a salad and we each paid $25. Decent. This is really probably a 3.5.
author: Hella M.

description: Yes it is pricey, but I think it is worth it. I love the sushi here and so does the rest of my family. I like to sit at the bar when we can so we can mingle with the sushi chefs. We are terrible at making decisions so we always do chef's choice and they have never let us down. The one thing I always do get though is the "spoon full of happiness". I always start and end my dinning experience with one of these little treasures. Get one yourself; you won't be sorry.
author: Mike Y.

description: Koo has a couple of great things going for it. 1) Atmosphere - though the dining room can feel a little cramped, it's still decked out with style and flair & the lighting suggests trendy with a hint of romance, without seeming too pretentious. 2) The menu is quite varied - creative assortments of sushi, succulent tempura, and burikama that makes your tongue tingle.  and finally - 3) the selection of 'adult bevvies' is quite nice, including the newest fad - shochu. If only they'd sprout some imo-shochu from Kagoshima or Miyazaki, then maybe, just maybe, they'd pull that 5th star out of me.
author: Andrew H.

description:
(07.20.07) Once again, very happy with my meal! We had the U2 Roll (fantastic!), the Flying Kamikazi Roll (yum!), and the Rock n Roll (cheap alternative for unagi lovers, like myself). The teriyaki chicken and potato salad was good too! And we finished it off with Mt Fuji's for dessert - very rich! It's a Friday night so good thing we made reservations.

(02.17.07) Ooo very nice ambiance. Great quality food. Definitely worth the try! Love it. Will go back again!
author: Q C.

description: Good fish, good atmosphere, good service... Not a huge selection, but the food is excellent. Make sure to save room for dessert; the Mt. Fuji cake and the strawberry mousse were both delectable.
author: Matt Y.

description: I have come to Koo many times; and it's always pretty good.  The asparagus and spinach salad is fresh and delicious.  I also like the shrimp and scallop steamed pot stickers.  The roll I ordered, however, was a bit too salty.  Service is good here, I must add.  My friend adores this place, and always orders the "Spoonful of Happiness."  There are two spoons, filled with various items; and it is served with sake.  He is in love with this appetizer. For dessert, you HAVE to order the fresh baked cookies.  They are paper thin, sweet, and they are addicting.  Make reservations, as this spot is always packed!
author: Sarah F.

description: What's better than sushi at Koo? Their awesome modern minimalist Japanese style, that's what. This is a great place to come with a date, or a group of friends. The sushi is very good, but the best part of their menu is the appetizers. Their Godzilla Tofu has a fantastic sweet and spicy sauce, and their artichoke, though on occasion too oily, is usually splendid.
author: Kath R.

description: The best of the best , this is a true Japanese spot, little bit on the expensive side but it just brought me back to the real Japanese cuisine. Sake, fresh sashimi and great service ......yes! i am a big fan.....
author: Daniel W.

description: Small but quaint Japanese restaurant.  Good selection of Sake.  Loved the rolls and the fresh sashimi.  You HAVE TO try the Spoonful of Happiness appetizer.
author: M S.

description:
My co-workers decided that needed to indoctrinate me into the Koo Culture as people in my lab call it.

My girlfriend came up for the night and we went.  One of my co-workers knows and golfs with everyone who works there and is a "regular".  We got the service you might expect.  Attentive and helpful.  I thought that it was a great deal in price since there were 7 of us and we had everything that we wanted, including a good amount of sake and beer for $33/person total.

Great experience!  Looking forward to going back soon.
author: Alex B.

description: First off I am allergic to fish, so the four stars are based on my girlfriends opinion.  She ordered two rolls (Best Roll and Spider Roll) and said they were really good.  I ordered the steak and Godzilla tofu, which we shared and was really good, but the portions are definately not for two.  Call and make reservations, because this place gets really busy.
author: Mike S.

description: Spoonful of Happiness.  Nuff said.  I thought uni was gross before I tried the spoonful of happiness.  Uni can be bad, but not at Koo.  The usuzukuri is lovely.  Their salads are unique and beautifully presented.  Other restaurants copy Koo's stuff, but don't come close.  Best sushi in SF (and I eat a lot of sushi).
author: Janet S.

description: Koo is totally under-rated one of the best sushi joints in town.   Its reasonably priced and the service is excellent.  We dine their often.
author: Chris D.

description:
A solid sushi choice with good service and atmosphere.

One tataki dish was rather uninspired, but the sushi and sashimi were fine.

After a day at GG Park, this is a good choice, but I'm not sure I would make a trip across town just to eat here.
author: Richard P.

description:
Koo is fantastic. Great service, great food, great atmosphere. It was around $60 for two and here's what we ordered:

Mint spare rib butter lettuce cup
Shrimp Tempura with soy ginger sauce
Albacore Tataki
California Roll
Sake 
Spicy Greenbeans
Rice, Miso soup and salad for two.

The Tempura and Albacore were to die for. The rest were delicious. We couldn't finish all of the food and left extremely satisfied with our restaurant pick.
author: C. G.

description:
Must try salmon/tuna tartar with guacamole and shrimp chips. I absolutely crave this dish when I'm not in SF...

Everyone also raves about the spoonful of happiness.

Delicious food, my only complaint is the high prices...
author: Mic L.

description:
very good sushi.  service was good also.  they kept pouring green tea just like my mom would...
not too many reviews from japanese customers here, but i grew up in japan eating good/bad sushi and i have to say, koo's fish was very nice and tender, draping over rice balls.  i will be going back there soon!  all 5 of us were happy with their food/service.
author: fat n.

description:
The spoonfuls of happiness are a must!  The reviews below are accurate, and one thing is for sure, the appetizer is sure to make you smile after your first bite.

I'd also recommend the "best roll" - an inside-out salmon roll with thinly sliced lemon on top.  Very tasty.

I was not impressed with either the cooked black cod or the yellowtail cheek/collar.  Both were a little overcooked and underseasoned.
author: Brian K.

description: NIce quiet place to dine out...very cozy enough to linger and enjoy...great service and very efficient...water and tea were filled constantly no questions asked. Delicious sushi and they have some of the freshes fish. Small dishes are decent to share ...go for the eggplant and hamachi kama!! Desserts were affordable..homemade cookies with green tea gelato....YUM. Parking can be very difficult, but there is a parking lot where u can park just one block up btw irving and judah. My experience at Koo would only tell me to go back again ...WONDERFUL authentic japanese food!!!
author: stephanie n.

description: So happy I live close to this gem of a sushi restaurant. The chefs can be a bit austere but the fish is sooo delicious. If it weren't off the beaten path, this place would be ridiculously packed. It can still get crowded but usually isn't too bad - especially during the week.
author: Rob G.

description: fresh sashimi, but too pricy. spent $90 for 2 people on food only, excluding beverage, not even close to full. sure there are other Japanese restaurants in town just as good if not better for a more reasonable price. if you go for a date, i highly recommend this place (irony). be aware of their service, not that friendly.
author: Bei K.

description:
The restaurant has a nice,cozy, relaxing feeling to it.  Went with two other people and had:

Tuna and salmon tartare:  It came with shrimp chips!  yum.

Japanese Eggplant Dengaku:  The miso sauce is really good on this.  You could probably take this sauce and put it on anything else.  :)

A special plate of halibut sashimi ( I can't remember the name of it for the life of me, but I just remember I had fun pronouncing it): The fish was soooo fresh.  I didn't really care for the muscle part that was piled next to the ginger, but according to the waitress it's supposed to be the best part.  You must get this if it is available. 

Azteca roll and the Dragon roll: both good, but not that stars of the show.

Miso Black Cod:  It was really good!  The fish has a nice flavor to go with the texture. 

Mt. Fuji Cake with ice cream:  How can you pass up rich chocolate cake filled with white chocolate, especially when it's only three bucks?  Add a scoop of ice cream for $1.50.

Go to Koo for  super fresh fish.  The rolls aren't as creative(still good), however the quality of the sashimi is excellent.
author: Ellie K.

description:
Three words: 
Spoonfulls Of Happiness.

Oh yes, they are heavenly.  I can't get enough of this place!
author: Tisha J.

description: Overall, the sushi was just ok and nothing special.  However, the spoonful of happiness is to die for.  That is absoutely one of the best things I have tasted.  I'd still go back to my all-time favorite sushi place -- Shimo's.
author: Mary L.

description: If - again- you can't get a table at Ebisu, try this place! The atmosphere is really nice and the sushi is great. My favorite is the Tokyo Crunch Roll. The prices are reasonable and the service is good. I also love their tuna sashimi, very yummy!
author: Iphigenie S.

description: This place was wonderful!  After reading reviews on Yelp, I decided to order the "Best Roll," and like others have said, it really is the best!  The tartness of the lemon pairs so well with the salmon and the crispy asparagus tempura inside.  I liked how the tempura inside wasn't soggy, like it is in some other restaurants' rolls.  Thus, each piece of the roll was such an interesting experience of textures, and of course, taste!
author: sarisha h.

description:
Best Japanese food in the city! The fish is fresh and the cooked items are equally amazing. Must try: Azteca roll, beef tataki, Spoonful of Happiness, miso braised eggplant, crab handroll, dragon roll.
Awesome sake selection, great desserts. And of course, the waiters are very friendly and helpful. A bit pricy, but worth it!
author: Bekka S.

description:
I have been to the "koo" second time since came to here.
there are a lot of scrumptious foods and alcohols, fresh sushi i love it
I ordered 2wine and many kind of sushi. it was very good. 
They were take care us and nice service. the prices are a little expencive but the taste and the place is good, so it balances
I'll be back soon
author: umex s.

description: As good as advertised.  Excellent sushi, nice atmosphere and service oriented staff.  It's also pretty reasonable.  It's a keeper!
author: T D.

description: Really authentic! I had been reluctant to eat Sushi in the US because, as a Japanese person, I always felt difference between American Sushi and Japanese Sushi. But, Koo's Sushi is as fantastic as in prestigious Sushi  restaurants in Japan. In particular, I recommend to try spoonful of happiness, which can tell you "core of Japanese cuisine".
author: shintaro u.

description: Koo is a nice stop in San Francisco for lunch or dinner. I stopped in for dinner and really enjoyed my time there. The staff is the best I've had so far at a sushi restaurant, very friendly and welcoming. The place had a good amount of people and it's nice that the place is spacious, lots of seating. The Spoonful of Happiness has the best presentation. It comes with two spoons with whitefish, quail egg, and some other stuff that's hard to remember along with a shot of sake. Probably their signature appetizer here. I had the calamari for an appetizer and it was really crispy and tender on the outside. It came with a salsa Verde dipping sauce which I thought was very bland, I preferred a tangier sauce. Only got to try two rolls there, the Azteca and the U2 roll which were both yummy. The Azteca had spicy tuna and a slice of jalapeno but it lacked the spicy kick I was expecting. The Himachi on the U2 roll was extremely fresh. There isn't a whole lot of special rolls, but they do have a full menu with other rolls and dinner entrees for you to choose from.
author: Karen L.

description: dizam. some of the best sushi i have eaten. super fresh fish, the perfect temperature of rice, scrumptious rolls, melt-in-your-mouth nigiri. great service and atmosphere tops it all off. coming back here FOR SURE.
author: Luvlife R.

description:
maguro nigiri and spicy tuna are two foods that make me wet my pants from too much excitement.

....and Koo does them both well, with an array of spicy tuna roll options and really fun specialty rolls. my roomie and i devoured the kamakaze roll like true sushi hunters.
author: bloopie s.

description: Impressive.  After hearing others rave about the 'spoonful of happiness' I had to come and see for myself.  We were greeted with a warm welcome and seated quickly without any reservation.  The decor was nice and moody...the good type.  For the most part, prices were on-par with other sushi restaurants, so not too surprised...however, $9/each for the 'spoonful of happiness' and tuna/salmon tartar seemed a little much.  While the 'spoonful' was indeed delicious, I'd rather have just ordered my uni as a nigiri (which I also had).  Uni and quail egg was good, but not orgasmic...same with the monkfish liver wrapped in white fish.  The tuna/salmon tartar really stood out in my mind.  Maybe it was the pairing with shrimp chips...that really made the dish.  Salmon sashimi and amaebi were exceptionally fresh and tasty.  No complaints here.  The presentation was equally done well.  Is it the best...no...but it's in my top 5 now.
author: JeFF T.

description: I have passed this restaurant several times and have found it to be intriguing. However, when it originally opened I thought that it was a bit pricey. It has now since gone down, and so I have decided to try it. My friend and I oredered the Dragon Roll, some kind of Sake Roll with asparagus that I cannot recall, and the Black Cod appetizer. I ordered green tea and she ordered Iced Tea. The rolls were quite generous and the sauces on the rolls were so tasty that you didn't even need to use soy sauce and wasabi. The seafood seemed quite fresh as well. On the other hand, the Black Cod appetizer was not what I had expected. When I order this appetizer, also offered at other Japanese restaurants, it is usually dry and comes with a sauce. The Black Cod at Koo is served in broth. It was still good, but I prefer the Cod to be grilled and dry with the sauce and not grilled and wet. The vegetables accompanying the Cod in the broth was bland as well. The service could be better, but the restaurant itself is quaint and not too noisy. You can feel like you are in your own world in the restaurant.
author: Lorna D.

description: Great sashimi.  Melts in your mouth and it's the perfect size.  Their rolls and hand rolls aren't half bad either but I'd recommend sticking with the sashimi (either a combination plate or a la carte).  Price is very reasonable too.
author: Jason E.

description: Ate at this place on Tuesday night. It's awesome. I had to restrain myself and keep the bill to $30 per person, so I did not order favorites like hamachi kama or gindara misozuke (miso black cod). I had the ankimo, heirloom tomato salad, toro (boston tuna that night), tai (from New Zealand), the live baby abalone sashimi (awabi), and the spoonfuls of happiness (so very good!). BTW, Koo is not short for Shoku, the on-yomi (borrowed Chinese reading) for the character "to eat", but is another kun-yomi (native Japanese reading), kuu, in addition to the common one, taberu. Any 3rd year Japanese student knows this. Kuu is an informal and therefore vulgar verb used to mean "to eat". The Japanese would never shorten "shoku" to "ku". They always take the 1st sound. For example, Buraddo Pitto becomes BuraPi. And to quote from the SF Chronicle: "Koo, says chef-owner Kiyoshi Hayakawa, could also be spelled 'ku[u]' in Japanese, and is the masculine form of 'to eat.'" It even says so on the business card; the character has the mouth radical, and is pronounced either "kuu" or "kurau"; see here: http://www.unicode.org/cgi-bin/GetUnihanData.pl?codepoint=55b0 . And the two spoonfuls of happiness are not swimming in soy sauce. One is snapper and ankimo (monkfish liver, the foie gras of the sea) with a splash of ponzu. The other is raw quali egg (uzura [no tamago]) and creamy uni. People who eat california rolls need not apply.
author: Hao L.

description: This place is so delicious -- the freshest tastiest sushi I've eaten in San Francisco.  My favorite is the Best Roll.  This is an original roll with salmon and lemon slices on top that is amazingly delicious.
author: Mike R.

description: I've probably eaten at every well known sushi joint in the city, and this was the  best sushi I can remember. We ordered the tombo, blue shrimp and unagi to start, and let the chef suprise us with the rest. He proceded to make us: salmon salad with miso dressing, amberjack, king salmon, fried shrimp heads, halibut and I can't remember the type of dried fish he gave us, but it was excellent as well. There was a 20 minute wait, but it was Friday at 8pm and let's face it, the wait is usually longer at Ebisu down the street. Also, the service was attentive and there were never any real delays in ordering drinks or getting the check. Totally going back next week.
author: Pete J.

description: i dunno, 3.5 stars. people rave about this place but i thought it was pretty standard, nothing special. my wakame was the typical that you can get in the safeway sushi section, and for some reason, i always judge a sushi joint by the seaweed salad. we also had various nigiri, which were very good and fresh. also, tokyo crunch, dragon roll, best roll, california roll and a few other things. good, yes, but not great. service was good; ambiance was enh. i guess my expectations were too high but i was not wowed. i still think tsunami is tops for sushi, if you removed all the self-important assholes who eat there.
author: Mary V.

description: Fancy schmancy sushi restaurant even the hosts and hostess dressed so proper. I didn't know we had to make reservation so I was told the wait time was 45min. But, It took us literately less than 20min to be seated. They were extremely polite. Not to comment on the waiters and waitress, they were friendly and very amiable. To the point that I felt like throwing stone at them, "get me som O-cha now!" hehe..just kidding. I had to nibble my food just to show politeness(grin).I like koo restaurant (very cool) and will definately go back there again. Sushi is delicious, fresh, and fish quality is top notch. The restaurant is a bit small but very well-used of space. The latern lamps? make the place looks very modern and contemporary. Sushi prices are very affordable about $40 per person + sake.  There aren't many good japanese restaurants in SF. This is one of my new favorites. On other note, nothing related to food, i saw a sushi chef at the bar looks like Tony Blair. An asian Blair-esque. Freaky huh? or maybe it's my sake!
author: Michael K.

description: hate to give away another great secret spot...  but this place fires on all cylinders.  great food, great service at the bar (acceptable service in the dining room, too), still possible to get in with short notice...  very happy with yet another dinner there last week (probably my 10th time)...  as many have pointed out, do not miss the 'spoonfuls of happiness' appetizer...
author: Matt L.

description: I have been going to Koo since it first opened and it just gets better and better. My only complaint is that it's now difficult to get in! Fresh sushi, imaginative appetizers, great service and cozy surroundings. Can't recommend it enough. Just get there early!
author: Blake H.

description: This is a really good sushi restaurant; not too big a place, great service and very fresh sushi. Parking's a bit hard but not as difficult as say 9th & Irving which is a few blocks down.
author: Steve K.

description: great atmosphere, good food, the catch of the day menu was most memorable for me!
author: Angie C.

description: Everything we had was good.    The fried calamari was, in fact, excellent.   We wished there had been more similar non-sushi items on the menu, for those in our  group not crazy about sushi.   It would also have been helpful if the menu had given us some indication of the quantity of each dish, as some tended to include ten to twelve pieces and some were two to four.  We had to reorder additional items a couple of times because we had not ordered enough the first time.  Our waitress seemed slightly annoyed at this and so when we ordered more dishes we had to do it from memory because she had taken away our menu.   We hated to bother her but she was the only person on the waitstaff who seemed to speak English.    This seemed to me a little too "authentic" in it's difficulty.   In short, the food was terrific and the staff was obviously working hard, but I wished they could have slowed down a little to educate us on their menu, and maybe give us a clue as to the size of the various dishes and the order in which we might expect them to appear at the table .
author: David H.

description: okay, to me when you walk into a sushi bar, (granted it was around 6pm on a thursday night), sit at the bar and get your own personal sushi chef who is attentive, friendly, and anticipates your every desire, it gets 5 stars.  but, to then taste the amazing fish, with unusual selections, while throwing down unique sake, no denying the 5 stars.  plus, the owner who worked at sushi ran (i run there whenever in sausalito) for years, and opened  a couple other sushi bars in the city, is super cool, and keeps a keen eye on all dishes coming out.  they made me feel like a rock star.  free delicious tid-bits were offered almost after every dish i ordered.   i like that.  that keeps people coming back, uh, people like me!
author: Betsy K.

description: One of the better sushi restaurants in the city.  Great service, great fish.  A little pricey but you pay for what you get.  And whoever mentioned earlier the tartare, listen to them!  They have these puffy cracker things that you scoop this great fish with, and it crackles, like a rice-crispy's!  so tasty, mmmmm.
author: Robin R.

description: What a pleasant surprise!  I used to go to Sushi Sho in Albany for the best sushi but for those of you who had been there, you know how difficult it is to get a seat.  So I yelped and found Koo and have never returned back to Albany for sushi.  Koo rocks!
author: j w.

description: Busy on a Friday night, we walked in without a reservation. The hostess's inviting smile evolved into a worried look. She wanted to accommodate us with a table and poor thing, she was staring at her table chart for about a minute, stressing over where to seat us....Well, can't emphasize enough the quality, fresh ingredients - possibly fish flown in from Japan and other parts of the world to get amazing sushi. I loved the artichoke appetizer accompanied with a dallop of savory, creamy sauce- FYI, the way to eat it is to teeth off the meat - do not chew and swallow! The last part of the artichoke is the best - it's the meatiest! I had the barricuda, black cod, Azteca, Kamikaze, Ikura. The first two are similar in taste to yellowtail - fresh and melt in your mouth like butter! The Azteca and Kamikaze were very good special rolls - note that Kamikaze is spicier than most spicy tunas I've had. Lastly, Ikura was very, very fresh - the best I've ever had at any restaurant. Also our waiter was very sweet and helpful in making suggestions based on what we usually like!
author: Audrey L.

description: koo is interesting. they don't have omakase (where you tell the chef how much you want to spend and he makes the sushiaccordingly), but instead they keep making sushi for you until you tell them to stop. koo is reasonably priced enough that it works out to be about the same, and the sushi is fresh. a little low on the variety (they didn't have toro or marugai), but what they had was quite fresh, and they presented it all very well. worth a try.
author: monkey l.

description: A solid restaurant! The salmon tartar with gucamole is delicious! My favorite is the stuffed peppers. The tuna crunch roll is the best in the City. Better than Sushi-Ran, UMami and similar Japanese fusion restaurants. Yummers!!!!
author: Mama L.

description: The quality of the fish here is quite good. The overall dining experience is so-so, but I have a preference for smaller joints. Oh, and make sure you order the Spoonful of Happiness appetizer; it's $9, but the shot of sake makes the price somewhat palatable and helps you get over the slight weirdness.
author: A. T.

description: Dinner for 2 just over $100. Food is amazing, spec. the blue fine toro sashimi is one of the best in the city. Roll Recommendation: tokyo crunch and best salmon. Sake Recommendation: junmai small bottle. One of the few sushi places that is not only great but you feel full after you eat. Great date place.
author: blahblah h.

description: The food was good but hardly filling.  But you should have the Spoonful of Happiness because it is a culinary experience that lives up to its name.  The sake list needs expansion.
author: Michael G.

description: Ebisu is closer to my apartment, but I always choose to walk the extra few blocks to Koo.  I love the non-traditional take on sushi.  It's like sushi meets contemporary cuisine.  They have dishes that you can't find anywhere else (at least not that I have encountered).  They have a nice atmosphere and very friendly staff.  The rolls are very good (The Best roll really is the best), The fresh fish of the day is always great.  They have a nice selection of sake and they have tasty appetizers.  I have never been disappointed.
author: Katie B.

description: Awesome sushi!  The spicy king crab handroll is to die for.  Good atmosphere.  OK service.  Very busy most times, so I'd recommend a rezzie.
author: Melinda G.

description: the food was fresh and delicious. i enjoy clever re-interpretations of food, and one appetizer in particular still rests with me. growing up, i always relished the crunchy shrimp chips that come with duck at chinese restaurants. at koo, they've taken said shrimp chips (kinda like funyuns... but ruffles style) and paired them with guac and raw tuna... and it's creamy, crunchy, and soft!
author: Patricia S.

description: I went there last night for the second time. My favorite still goes to "A spoonful happiness" , one spoonful of uni with quail egg + another spoonful of sashimi  (what type of fish i forget), come with a shot of sake. Definitely my type of spoonful happiness!! We also ordered beef tataki, tune and salmon tartare and butter luttuce cup with roast short rib, all very good. Maki are huge in size, each about  8 pieces, so don't order too much, pace yourself! I also had the miso marinated cod last time, it was really really good, thanks to a friend's recommendation! Other places with such good marinated cod or mackeral are Kiss Seafood restaurant and Tanpopo, all authentic Japanese restaurant. (see my other reviews), Sushi Ran in Sausalito also have good sea bass and i defiinitely recommend their Tuna Poke (okay, speaking of that, i'd better write up a review for it)  Dessert priced at $3 each, didn't have much of selection but hey, most japanese places don't even offer dessert. It is very well priced and yummy. Weekend nights reservation is recommend, sometimes wait can be up to 1 hour (my friend's experience), week nights generally more relaxed and 80% full. Japanese hostess, chef and waitresses.
author: Angela H.

description: Koo is our favorite sushi place in the city.  Good service and a nice selection of rolls.  The fish is reliably fresh and prices are reasonable.
author: Clay B.

description: This place was so delicious!! I've been to a lot of different sushi restaurants in the Bay Area, and this one is by far my favorite. The fish was so fresh and the rolls were amazing. The price was totally reasonable for the outstanding quality and taste! If you love sushi, you owe it to yourself to check it out! Try the best roll...so yummy!
author: Blair D.

description: Good sushi always makes me SOOOO happy. And this place is no exception.  My favorites were the Spoonful of Happiness, the hand rolls (I think only 2 kinds are served...one with lobster, and one with scallops, but both are excellent), Tokyo Crunch, and Best Roll.  Makes me miss San Francisco and Sunset... Highly recommend the place, but make sure you have reservations b/c it's a small seating area!
author: Elana N.

description: I've been here twice and always left hungry. The food actually is fantastic but alittle on the pricey side (the miso marinated cod being my favorite) I recommend it but it's not a place I would go frequently.
author: Mei F.

description:
delish! i was a little skeptical at first...i looked at what ppl ordered and based on the menu, it seemed like a lot of "trendy" japanese/sushi--the itty bitty rolls on a big ass plate thing, i hate that!  to my surprise, it wasnt the case--the rolls were all decently sized, the fish was FRESH, and the service was good. prices are expensive (thank god for my friend's xmas gift cert for this place) 

only cons--prices & parking
author: Yolanda L.

description: the "spoonful of happiness" dish alone is worth the trip to koo. it is a cozy, warm neighborhood restaurant, the service is straight-forward and down to earth, nothing formal. it is a bit more upscale from other neighborhood sushi spots, without being overpriced. it's a fun menu. they also have really good unagi.
author: Jessica C.

description: We live two blocks away and LOVE it!!  Fresh fish, creative dishes.  I recommend: tuna and salmon tartare, ankimo appetizer, spoonful of happiness, hamachi sashimi with fresh grated wasabi (my fave), real crab california roll, albacore tataki.  avoid the miso black cod (it's much better at nobu, its origin), they make it funny here.  the fresh grated wasabi is key.
author: IA K.

description: delicious! the dessert is good too!
author: Wwy m.

description: gosh...finding parking is just not the easiest in that location but once you get in...you know it is all worth it...the people there are all so nice and the owners are such hospitable people...i highly recommend the dynamite handroll...it is good..for those who love raw fish, their sashimi are very fresh..for those who don't eat raw fish, you should try the cajun....and the azteca...if u don't like sushi's then i think you should try the duck salad...good lemony flavor.
author: Mee-stique K.

description: I love this place! This is by far my favorite sushi restaurant in San Francisco.  If you take a trip out to Koo, make sure you order the duck salad and the Toro.  For the duck salad, they actually give you a generous portion of duck.  What's surprising is that the duck isn't heavy and doesn't have a gamey taste.  As for the Toro, it's just heavenly.  Once it reaches the tip of your tongue, it practically melts in your mouth.  YUM.
author: Diana T.

description: A Fav for the wifey and I.  Every time we've been, we've always had great food, and we always make sure we sit at the sushi bar.  The sushi is good, and they always have a few specials it seems which we love to try.  The interesting thing (at least to me) is that the owner/head chef, isn't actually a sushi chef.  Some of their other dishes are great, but you can't go wrong with the sushi/sashimi here.  You have to sit at the sushi bar because they give you a bunch of extras which they'll make on the fly or have prepped before (like one of the chef's home made pickled veggies).  The owner and his wife (who looks amazing for her age), are extremely nice people and great to talk to.  They'll help with picking food, and can recommend a bit of sake or something new.  The place isn't cheap by any means, but not unreasonable I would definitely say.  You get what you pay for and come out happy is what we think.  Overall, one of our favorites places in the city for not only the food, but also the service.  Only complaint is the location, because finding parking in that area sometimes can be the turnoff of going (but could say that for lots of places in SF!).
author: RJ T.

description: Okay if I could give this place two ratings I would 5 stars for the quality and freshness of fish.  It was like butter.  But 2 stars for price, it was every expensive, and we didn't eat lite.  But we had to go to Tart after for dessert to fill up lol.  But back to the fish, I ordered the Hamachi it was delicious, we also did the sashimi plate, and the maguro and salmon was amazing.  I loved that they pair lemon slices with the salmon sashimi.  The rolls were tasty, very refreshing and light.  I would go back, but only when I want to pay twice with I pay at my regular place.  But you gotta figure, you pay for what you get and here you get amazingly the most fresh fish I have ever had in my life!  SO if I could afford it I would go every day!
author: Devon F.

description: I had some of the best Alaskan salmon I've ever eaten here.  The prices are a bit high, and the portions a bit small, but everything is incredibly fresh and tasty.
author: Matthew H.

description: My favorite Japanese restaurant. I would eat here all the time if I could afford it. Contemporary + traditional Japanese food.
author: VVVV H.

description: I took my friend here for her birthday dinner, and we both enjoyed a delicious dinner.  The grilled artichoke was delicious,  as was the salmon sashimi and the multitude of rolls that we ordered.  I would definitely recommend this.  My absolute favorite place is Moki, but this is a very close second!
author: jen c.

description: Koo is really, really good. So rare is the japanese restaurant that does sushi and warm dishes equally well, but I think Koo accomplishes that. The special fish are always fresh and interestingly prepared, and the warm items are extremely inventive and delicious. I like the vibe too. As Ebisu continues to fade  (in my opinion), this is a welcome addition to the neighborhood.
author: Jonathan B.

description: Excellent food.  By far the best sashimi in San Francisco. Plus, the service is friendly and efficient and the SF health dep't score is 100 (which is amazing for a sushi restaurant, as many sushi restaurants have lower scores because they leave the rice out to cool).  My only complaint is that they do not accept AmEx.
author: Michele L.

description: After being depressed over not having a local sushi joint I can eat at in Cole Valley (Grandeho's Kamekyo made me sick and Hama-Ko isn't worth the sushi nazi treatment) my friend recommended Koo. So it's not exactly in Cole Valley, but it's close enough and I love it.  The only sushi place I like better is Sushi Ran, and that's all the way in Sausalito.  The fish is fresh, the service is great, and the place is comfortable.  Happiness is a warm sake.
author: C L.

description: The only reason this place doesn't get 5 stars is b/c it''s a bit of a hike to get to it.  Great fish - I loved the scallop handroll and the best roll.  The spoonful of happiness is a favorite of my boyfriend.  I've been there a few times and never had a problem getting a table.  Also, there always seems to be a fun crowd there.
author: Megan K.

description: everytime we go they ask if we have reservations. um NO. then they bring us to a table that has a reserved sign that they remove upon seating us.  i think they pretend theyre busy by having these fake reservation signs everywhere.  our waiter was never paying attention us. i just wanted to go into the kitchen and help him bring my food out.  so we ended up ordering a bunch of stufff:  the best roll-was perfect. crab dynamite- the way to spend $7 on one roll, godzilla tofu- too salty and not to mention the size an ice cube, spicy tuna-great, salmon and tuna tartar- yuck, the shrimp chip it comes with is always stale and and its just not that good, beef tantaki- um could they leave it on the grill a bit longer? the mount fuji dessert was a lil piece of heaven for me.
author: ruby l.

description: We found this sushi spot on Yelp as we were looking for a new place to find our raw fish fix.  We walked in on a Saturday night with no reservation and were sat down immediately at the bar.  The entire staff was extremely friendly and even though the entire dining room was packed the sushi chef's at the bar made us feel like we were the only people there.  On top of the great service the fish was amazing.  Be sure to get the Spoonful of Happiness starter if you like uni.  This place is a must if you're a sushi lover in San Francisco.
author: Marc G.

description:
care for brunch ? check my next review

***

mediocre ...

3.5 (ok, i'll be nice) ... the service was truly incredible ... can't say any more ... a modernized sushi place ... 

it's quite fascinating to me how sf can be so segregated depending on where you stand on the grid ... 

so you're thinking, "irving..." 

given that i AM asian who doesn't stick with my asian roots at all times,  crossing 19th ave on the other side is predominately white ... and if you cross the other side going towards the ocean, they're all asian ... so soo weird. why can't we all be happy and mingle together? *no pun intended*

koo is located centrally in the white section of irving ...

koo ... 

we sat at the sushi bar w/ressies, and had a great time talking to the owner and the other 2 sushi chefs ... upon walking in, the younger looking guy who was onto the far left pretty much made sushi for the rest of the patrons on the general dining area, while the middle guy and the one on the right made sushi for the ones sitting at the bar ... the owner, however is a long time sushi chef, or so he implies ... he initially opened Koo 4 yrs ago, and prior to koo, he was also the owner of ace wasabi and helped out with sushi ran (which isn't exactly my favorite as well: http://www.yelp.com/user_details_review_search?userid=EKdyI4jpUF29YtPkKiCtcg&q=sushi+ran) which is located in the marina ... he mentioned how he didn't really like the marina crowd since it was more of a hang out place with "good looking people" looking for "other good looking people..."while koo was a place for folks who really wanted to eat authentic japanese food...

as a marina resident ... my initial thought ... "i suppose... i guess the marina is the marina for a reason" lol

i must say, the extra star DOES in fact go out to the fact that this IS japanese owned, and not korean or chinese owned ... 

we spent almost $200 on mediocre sushi ... there were some catchy specials and i must say, their nigiri ?? ive had cheaper ones elsewhere and it was byfar MORE fresh ... their specialty rolls were a hit or miss. the flying kamikazi was super yummy, but their tokyo crunch and their azteca wasn't that great ... 

the head chef (owner) highly suggested us getting a spoonful of happiness (what a cute name) which entails a spoonful of Uni, Quall Egg, Tobiko, Ponzu & Ankimo wrapped with whitefish, Truffle-Oil &  a shot of chilled Sake for $10... any choice of the sake... this sake we had was called suigei tokubetsu junmai, which is $7 normally... very flowery for the nose...  they also have a wide range of other sakes, wine and champagnes ...  the spoonful was definitely a delight!

i'd say if we spent almost $200 on sushi, i personally would've hooked my people up with free dessert or something.. maybe i'm just asking too much.. but i can tell you, that this seems to be a local favorite because the very few folks who did trickle were on a name basis with the owners, and i in fact, witnessed the owner hooking one couple up with free drinks and discussing their trip at hawaii ...

they UNFORTUNATELY don't take online ressies ... good luck!
author: Jennifer S.

description: super yum. great sashimi, creative grilled items, lots of sake choices. among the best sushi i've had in the city. right up there with zushi puzzle. helps they have good service and their lamps are not eye-bothering.
author: reech u.

description: This place is solid , albeit off the beaten path. We walked in and the hostess couldn't have been more gracious. It's the perfect spot to catch up with friends or have a date, especially with the low lighting and generally cool atmosphere. Prices are reasonable and there's good-sized portions. For a group of 3, we started off with the Scallop / Shrimp dumplings and Butter Lettuce Short Ribs (on the "share" menu) which were really tasty. You get solid mouthfuls and I was already feeling somewhat full. Next came a sashimi plate with 4 different types of fresh fish. Lastly, we had two rolls, the Azteca and Flying Kamikaze, both very tasty and at a good fish-to-rice ratio. We didn't pass up on dessert and got the Mt. Fuji with ginger gelato, which was refreshing. If you're a chocolate lover, I'd say get your own Mt. Fuji (all deserts were around $4, plus $2 for the ice cream). Solid dinner at about $31/person with tip included.
author: Reeny L.

description: one of the best sushi restaurants in SF! +1 star from being walking distance from my house and being open til 10 or 11pm :D really helps when my random sushi cravings kick in! the food is delicious- so fresh, tasty and generous! it is a little pricey, but the quality of the raw fish and other [cooked] tasty items on the menu, it's worth every single penny and then some! i'm a stickler about service in asian restaurants, and this place has attentive, thoughful and courteous servers, the owner's wife herself walks around checking on customers and even chatted my friend and i up. the tuna and salmon tartare is awesome, though the one at tokyo a go go is better. spoonful of happiness is great, except i don't drink sake, and they have best ankimo ever!!!! i also never like uni until i had it here, damn that spoonful of happiness!!!!!! but now apparently i eat uni, lol. for dessert, the mt. fuji is a MUST HAVE! CHOCOLATE CAKE STUFFED WITH WHITE CHOCOLATE MOUSSE? HEL-LO! the only thing possible that would make the restaurant even more perfect is if they serve mirugai and ankimo on the same night. MMMMMMM. i would be here everyday if that happened.
author: Gaile C.
